SIMMONS--Paula Johnston Born in 1921 in Boston, MA., passed away peacefully on October 9, 2010. She was a resident of Hobe Sound, FL, and previously of East Hampton, NY, Chicago, IL and Franklin Lakes, NJ. She was predeceased by her husband John W. Simmons, former Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Morton Norwich Products, Inc., her parents Frederick J. and Alice G. Johnston, and her sister Alice J. Carroll. She is survived by her children, Lorraine S. Tuohy, Carol S. Conklin, Paula S. Butler, and John W. Simmons Jr., eleven grandchildren: Judson, Alexander, and Jake Tuohy, Cam and Alexis Rathborne, Margaux Lisiak, Nina Paun, Mark Butler, and William, Sam, and Eleanor Simmons, and two greatgrandchildren: Grace Tuohy and Reed Lisiak. Mrs. Simmons graduated from the Newton Country Day School of the Sacred Heart, Newton, MA and Manhattanville College, Purchase, NY. She was a member of the Women's Board of Northwestern University, a trustee of the Lyric Opera of Chicago and the Boys Club of Chicago. Mrs. Simmons was a member of the Jupiter Island Club, the Maidstone Club, Devon Yacht Club, Glen View Golf Club and the Arcola Country Club. A funeral Mass will be held on October 16, 2010 at 10am, Most Holy Trinity Church in East Hampton. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Most Holy Trinity Church Outreach Program, 79 Buell Lane, East Hampton, NY 11937 or Kenwood Convent of the Sacred Heart Center for Retirement, 799 South Pearl Street, Albany, NY 12202.

Have you ever wished you could replay a phone call after it's over? Google's free call-handing service, Google Voice, will record calls as MP3 audio files for free, with a few caveats. First, Google can only record calls you receive via Google Voice, not those you dial out yourself. Second, Google announces to all parties that the call is being recorded, so you can't use it to trap callers. (Recording a call without the consent of all parties is illegal in some states. Recording a call without anyone on the call knowing it is a federal crime.)

SIEGEL--Leonard O.,passed away at home on Sunday October 10, 2010. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Marilyn, his daughter Debbie Siegel Sherman, his sons Gary and Richard and his grandchildren Jeremy Sherman and Geena Sherman. He loved music and playing tennis. Slowed by Parkinson's disease, Leonard still enjoyed playing Bridge, and talking politics and sports with peers. A World War II veteran, Leonard will be buried at Arlington National Cemetery on Thursday, October 14, 2010 at 9am. Shiva will be at the home of Debbie Siegel Sherman.

Republicans are asking voters in central and western Missouri to oust Representative Ike Skelton, the Democrat seeking an 18th term. But that would mean giving up local claim to a prestigious post: Mr. Skelton is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, which is no small thing in a district with two big military bases, Fort Leonard Wood and Whiteman Air Force Base. So the House Republican leader, John A. Boehner of Ohio, the likely speaker if the party wins a majority, sought to reassure district voters on Wednesday by promising to help Mr. Skelton's opponent, Vicky Hartzler, get a seat on the Armed Services panel if she wins.

A judge set bail at $500,000 on Wednesday for a film student accused of slashing a Muslim taxi driver over the summer. The student, Michael Enright, has been in custody since his arrest on charges of repeatedly cutting a cabby with a knife in Midtown on Aug. 24 after the driver said he was Muslim. The driver, Ahmed H. Sharif, 44, required more than two dozen stitches.

When the Giants' Tim Lincecum and the Phillies' Roy Halladay take the mound in the opener of the National League Championship Series on Saturday night, the matchup of aces will take its place among the best in postseason history. Assuming Halladay wins the Cy Young Award, this will be the first time since 1991, when the Braves' Tom Glavine faced the Pirates' Doug Drabek, that a Game 1 in a League Championship Series has featured the reigning Cy Young winner against the soon-to-be Cy Young winner.

Vimeo aims to make Hollywood - and its pesky rules and constrictions - irrelevant, and judging by the winners of the online video-sharing site's first awards contest, it's doing a credible job. Nine short films were selected for the first Vimeo Awards Saturday at the SVA Visual Arts Theater in Chelsea. The overall Best Video Award, which includes a $25,000 grant to create a new project, went to Eliot Rausch of Phos Pictures for the documentary ''Last Minutes with ODEN.''

TISHMAN--Robert. The Board and staff of Grand Street Settlement mourn the passing of our friend and long-time Board member, Robert Tishman. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family and in particular, his daughter Lynne Handler and her husband Harold.

LOWENSTEIN--Richard L.,died peacefully Wednesday afternoon at his home in Mamaroneck surrounded by the love of his life, Rita, wife of 52 years, the pride of his life, son Michael, and Carol, and cherished prize of his life, daughter Wendy Sandler, and Neil. Dick was born in New York City, July 3, 1920. He was a true New Yorker from his Upper West Side childhood to the Village. Although his childhood was marked by the polio epidemic, a historic custody battle, and the Great Depression, Dick was not. He saw things clearly and called it like it was. His passions were simple and deep, first and foremost his family, his Jets, excellent food, and comfortable clothing. Dick graduated from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania in 1941 and then joined the army stationed in Japan during WWII. He created and built what was, at the time, the largest wholesale cruise business in the United States. Dick's grandchildren, Jeff, Matthew, Brad, Scott and Melanie are the fortunate beneficiaries of his non-judgmental, pure love and pride. We will remember him with laughter and love. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Holocaust and Human Rights Education Center of Westchester, or a charity of your choice. Funeral services will be held at Larchmont Temple on Friday, October 15, at 1pm.

CHRISTIE--George Nicholas, economist of Great Neck, NY on October 12, 2010. Born November 2, 1924, Wilmington, NC. Beloved husband of Mary. Loving father of Sultana (Clifford) Malmgren, Stephanie (Mark) Antonucci, Susan (Marc) Solomon, Gregory (Melanie) Christie, and the late Sandra. Adoring grandfather of Pamela (Patrick), Michelle, Jonathan, Rachel, Sarah, Andrew, Gray, Boden, and great-grandson Harrison. BBA -- University of Miami, 1948; MBA -- New York University, 1956, Ph.D, 1963. Positions at Dun and Bradstreet, National Association of Credit Management, American Bankers Association and Credit Research Foundation where he retired as Executive Vice President. An Associate Professor at LIU, he also lectured at Dartmouth College, Stanford, and Rutgers Universities. Principal author of Credit Executives Handbook as well as many professional articles. A veteran of the US Army during World War II, he continued to serve until honorably discharged in 1966 with the rank of Major. Freemason (Past Master) and Shriner (Past Potentate and Recorder Emeritus). Friends may visit Friday 2-4:30 and 7-9pm, at Beney Funeral Home, Inc., 79 Berry Hill Road, Syosset, NY. Funeral 9am Saturday at Archangel Michael Greek Orthodox Church, 100 Fairway Drive, Port Washington, NY. Interment Roslyn Cemetery, Roslyn, NY. Donations to Kismet Shriners Hospital Patient Transportation Fund. Mail to, Kismet Temple, P.O. Box 834, Hicksville, NY 11801.

On the 50th anniversary of President John F. Kennedy's inauguration on Jan. 20, the Kennedy Center in Washington will honor him with a star-studded concert, kicking off three weeks of related performances and events. Diane Sawyer and Mike Nichols will co-host the concert, which will include appearances by Julie Andrews, Harolyn Blackwell, Herbie Hancock, Yo-Yo Ma, the Manzari Brothers, Terrence McNally, Lorne Michaels and Brian Stokes Mitchell. American Ballet Theater will perform ''The Dying Swan,'' and Christoph Eschenbach will conduct the National Symphony Orchestra in the world premiere of a composition by Peter Lieberson that features narration, drawn from Kennedy's speeches and writings, to be spoken by Morgan Freeman. The subsequent three weeks will include more concerts by the National Symphony Orchestra, performances by American Ballet Theater featuring the favorite ballets of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, and tributes to historic musical performances at the White House, including recreations of the ''Concerts for Young People by Young People'' that the Kennedys began holding in 1961. Although the original legislation creating a national performing arts center was signed by President Dwight D. Eisenhower, Kennedy strongly supported it, and the center, which opened in 1971, is named for him.

OTTAWA -- The government of Canada formally declared bisphenol A, a chemical widely used to create clear, hard plastics, as well as food can liners, to be a toxic substance on Wednesday. The compound, commonly known as BPA, has been shown to disrupt the hormone systems of animals and is under review in the United States and Europe.

MILES--Dick. June 12, 1925- October 12th, 2010. Athlete, writer, business man. Beloved husband of Mary Detsch. Beethoven Quartet Op. 135, slow movement.

LEVERING--Susan Dworkin, of Huntington, NY, December 25, 1946 - October 13, 2010. She is survived by her mother, Ruth Dworkin; husband, Les Baltimore; daughter, Beth Baltimore; son, Sam Baltimore; sister, Nancy Miller; brother, Greg Dworkin; numerous in-laws, nieces, and nephews, and thousands of friends of all ages. As an attorney, Sue practiced primarily in Nassau County Family Court defending the rights of children. In lieu of flowers please consider donating to Amnesty International, www.amnesty.org/en/donate, or Project Main St., www.projectmainst.org.

With the long-awaited opening this week of a Barneys Co-op branch in Brooklyn, the borough's Atlantic Avenue -- long a shoppers' mecca of independent designer boutiques and well-trod antiques stores (with the occasional bail-bond agent thrown into the mix) -- gets a powerful magnet store that's sure to draw even more of the city's shopaholics to the burgeoning neighborhoods of Cobble Hill and Boerum Hill. (The closest subway stops: Borough Hall, on the 2, 3, 4 and 5 lines, or Hoyt Street-Schermerhorn Street, A, C and G.)

In a live episode of ''30 Rock,'' at 8:30, Liz (Tina Fey) becomes agitated when no one seems to remember that it's her 40th birthday, and Tracy (Tracy Morgan) annoys Jenna (Jane Krakowski) by trying to get her to break character during the show. Meanwhile Jack (Alec Baldwin) struggles with his promise to give up drinking while Avery (Elizabeth Banks) is pregnant. In ''The Office,'' at 9, Michael (Steve Carell) thinks he has herpes and contacts all his former girlfriends, played by Amy Ryan, Melora Hardin, Amy Pietz, Linda Purl and Nancy Carell, Mr. Carell's real-life wife. And in ''Outsourced,'' at 9:30, Rajiv (Rizwan Manji) fakes an Indian holiday to get Todd (Ben Rappaport) out of the office before his future father-in-law visits.

Four Republican-friendly groups are intensifying their political advertising in the final weeks of the campaign and jumping into House races in a big way as they seek to cut the financial advantage Democrats hold. The organizations -- American Crossroads and its related advocacy group, Crossroads GPS; the American Action Network; and the Commission on Hope, Growth and Opportunity -- began what they called a ''House surge strategy,'' pouring $50 million into several dozen races.

McMahon in their race for United States Senate in Connecticut referred imprecisely to a newspaper headline used in the ad. While the headline, ''McMahon: Congress should consider lowering minimum wage,'' was published by The Day newspaper in New London, it was used only on The Day's Web site the day of a McMahon press conference, not in the newspaper's print edition the next day.

For a second week in a row, country rules the Billboard album chart. Toby Keith's new ''Bullets in the Gun'' (Show Dog/Universal) is No. 1 with 71,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and last week's best-seller, Kenny Chesney's ''Hemingway's Whiskey'' (BNA), fell to No. 2 with sales of 65,000.

The Shopping With column on Sept. 30 misstated the role played by Anne McClain, a perfumer, in designing the scent used in a ''perfume fountain'' in a Brooklyn park. Although she had a small part in its creation, the basic work was done by Robertet Fragrances of Oakland, N.J.

''There's not a lot of free-spirited stuff going on in Midtown,'' Todd Patrick, the music promoter better known as Todd P, said the other day in the Showpaper 42nd Street Gallery, his new gallery near Grand Central Terminal. Eager young volunteers were hanging puppets in the window while two installation artists who were playing a fencing-themed video game exchanged insults. ''So it's nice to provide a place like this for people to come and hang out.'' For years, Mr. Patrick has been providing places for people to hang out -- mainly twentysomethings with discerning tastes in independent music. But until recently, he has focused on booking all-ages shows in lofts and small, sweaty clubs in northern Brooklyn and its environs, all of which are listed in his free broadsheet, Showpaper, which comes out every two weeks.

SCHWARZ--Richard, passed away at home very peacefully on October 11, 2010, sixteen days short of his 85th birthday. Beloved husband of Ronnie, unbelievably wonderful stepfather to Cory and Scott, father-in-law to Leslie and Debbie, dearest GaGa to Bailey and wonderful grandfather to Samantha, Kiley and Dayne, father of Debbie, Pam and Jeff, grandfather to their eight children and brother to Earl (Marilyn). Graduate of Stuyvesant High School and CCNY, ran his engineering company (Steinharter -Schwarz) for many years and had a wonderful reputation throughout the industry; and worked with the Corp of Engineers, MTA and VA Hospital. Always ready for a martini! Pass the cashews and pretzels! Service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, Thursday, October 14th at 11:15am. Please make donations to Visiting Nurse Hospice, New York Hospital and Sloan Kettering.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. - In the first-base clubhouse at Tropicana Field, Tampa Bay Rays owner Stuart Sternberg found Carl Crawford, his star left fielder, about to face the news media moments after the end of the division series late Tuesday night. ''Thank you for everything this season,'' Sternberg said, and Crawford then faced the cameras, answering questions about an uncertain future. He is a free agent after the season, and Sternberg has pledged to cut the Rays' $72 million payroll.

DEERFIELD BEACH, Fla. -- Robert F. Kennedy Jr. told a bagel-noshing crowd of Florida voters here today that Marco Rubio, the Republican candidate for Senate, was a Tea Party ''crackpot,'' ''a radical,'' and a ''sock puppet'' who speaks for a ''corporate plutocracy threatening to crush our democracy.'' It was a compelling, if incendiary description, given not on behalf of Representative Kendrick B. Meek, the Democrat in the race, but rather Gov. Charlie Crist, the newly minted independent.

Joe Scarborough and Mika Brzezinski of the cable news channel MSNBC's ''Morning Joe'' are helping to develop a prime time show, ''Young Turks,'' for the flagship NBC network. Mr. Scarborough and Ms. Brzezinski are consulting producers on the potential show, Variety reported Wednesday. An MSNBC spokesman confirmed their involvement. ''Young Turks'' is said to be an hourlong drama about twenty-somethings in New York who have careers in politics, the media and finance. John Romano, an executive producer of USA's ''In Plain Sight,'' will be the executive producer. The potential show is in the script stage, and it could be considered for NBC's Fall 2011 schedule.
The Gimlet Eye column on Sept. 23, about the resurgence of vinyl records, misstated the address of Other Music, a Manhattan record store. It is at 15 East Fourth Street, not Bond Street.

Defying grim predictions about how they would fare after two months trapped underground, many of the Chilean miners came bounding out of their rescue capsule on Wednesday as pictures of energy and health, able not only to walk, but, in one case, to leap around, hug everyone in sight and lead cheers. The miners' apparent robustness was testimony to the rescue diet threaded down to them through the tiny borehole that reached them on Aug. 22, but also to the way they organized themselves to keep their environment clean, find water and get exercise. Another factor was the excellent medical care they received from Chilean doctors who ministered to them through tubes leading 2,300 feet into the earth.

The flurry of managerial openings in the major leagues has made Bobby Valentine a busy man, with the Milwaukee Brewers the latest team to show interest. Valentine, the former manager of the Mets, the Texas Rangers and the Chiba Lotte Mariners in Japan, broadcast the Tampa Bay Rays-Texas Rangers division series for ESPN Radio. But Valentine has also emerged as a candidate for at least three jobs: with the Brewers, the Seattle Mariners and the Toronto Blue Jays.

PARIS -- The Memorial of the Shoah on Wednesday unveiled a vast exhibition in tribute to the French Jewish writer Irene Nemirovsky, a rare collection including a series of letters she sent months before her arrest and deportation to Auschwitz and an original audio recording of an interview she gave in 1939. The exhibition features about 250 documents - some previously shown at New York's Museum of Jewish Heritage in 2008 - including family pictures, original manuscripts of ''Suite Francaise'' and ''David Golder,'' Ms. Nemirovsky's most famous novels, and dozens of articles she wrote for major newspapers and magazines in the 1930s.

An article on Oct. 6 about the sentencing of Faisal Shahzad, the Times Square car bomber, referred incorrectly to the jetliner that he was on at the time of his arrest. It was still at the gate at Kennedy Airport; it had not been cleared for takeoff.

POLONER--Suzanne Posin, on October 13, 2010. Loving wife of Myron. Dear mother of Justine and Caleb. Best friend and business partner of Josiane Marshall. Devoted grandmother of Isabelle and Benjamin. Successful trail blazing businesswoman, fashionista, world traveler, lover of life. A shooting star burns very bright, but not long enough.

An article on Monday about the Italian roots of the main candidates for governor of New York, Andrew M. Cuomo and Carl P. Paladino, erroneously attributed a distinction to Mr. Cuomo's father, Mario. Charles Poletti -- not Mario Cuomo -- was the state's first Italian-American governor. (Mr. Poletti served as governor for 29 days in 1942, though he was not elected.) The article also transcribed incorrectly a phrase used by Mario Cuomo's wife, Matilda, to refer to claims that her son had been unfaithful. She said ''passaci sopra'' -- not ''passa ci sobre.'' (As the article correctly noted, it means ''pass it over, it's garbage.'')

An article on Tuesday about a proposal to build a transmission line off the mid-Atlantic Seaboard that would harvest energy from future offshore wind farms misstated the size of the investment stake that Marubeni, a Japanese trading firm, has taken in the $5 billion venture. It is 15 percent, not 10 percent.

The Books of The Times review on Wednesday, about Condoleezza Rice's memoir, ''Extraordinary, Ordinary People,'' misspelled the surname of a secretary of state under Ronald Reagan who was one of Ms. Rice's mentors. He is George Shultz, not Schultz. And a picture caption with the review misidentified the university where she received her doctorate. It was the University of Denver -- not Stanford, where she was a professor and the provost and has returned as a professor.

Not every driver likes the suction-cup aesthetic of aftermarket GPS systems. And for those who have space in their dashboard, Sony has two new models that combine audio features with full-service navigational abilities. With a pair of product packages, the new XNV-770BT and XNV-660BT A/V navigation systems, Sony has linked up with TomTom to turn out replacements that will substitute for many factory-installed A/V systems.

An article on Tuesday about the effectiveness of Child Protective Services investigations misidentified the federal law that encouraged better reporting and record-keeping in child abuse cases and misstated the year that it was passed. It is the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, not the Child Protective Services Act, and it was passed in 1974, not 1973. (The Child Protective Services Act, a New York State law, was passed in 1973.)

WEYMOUTH, Mass. The rain beat down last week on a modest South Shore shopping center waiting to receive an underdog candidate for governor. It soaked two men trying to revive a dead car in the parking lot and caused the gray afternoon to sag like a stray plastic bag catching the runoff.

FATH--Joseph, 85, of Princeton, NJ. Born in Frankfurt, Germany, died Sunday October 10, 2010. He was a chemical industry executive, former chairman of DH Litter, and Executive VP of Nuodex/Huls. He was a visionary leader to many Jewish and secular organizations in Princeton. He became both a painter, exhibiting his work in a one-man show, and a writer, recently publishing "In Full View". He is survived by his wife Ruth, four children, Rebecca Singer, Daniel, John, and Deborah, and by seven grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Funeral services were Tuesday at the Jewish Center of Princeton. Shiva observed through Sunday at the Fath residence in Princeton.

It's the duty (and, O.K., the bliss) of an opinion journalist to demonstrate that the Beltway's conventional wisdom has far fewer garments than it supposes. But on one count - that the progressives are at the moment far more marginalized by their Democratic president and Congressional leadership than are the Tea Party enthusiasts by the Republican powers-that-be - it's been hard to show contention. After all, the president who insisted that the day of his inauguration would be "the moment when we ended a war," who confidently said that "we are going to close Guantanamo", who promised to repeal the military's don't-ask-don't-tell policy has shown, through deed if not word, that he's not exactly a hostage to the far left. Nor has the Democratic leadership: Senate majority leader Harry Reid is an apostate on a woman's alleged right to choose -- "abortions should be legal only when the pregnancy resulted from incest or rape, or when the life of the woman is endangered" -- and Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi isn't exactly beloved.
Yet one smile more, departing, distant sun!One mellow smile through the soft vapory air,Ere, o'er the frozen earth, the loud winds run,Or snows are sifted o'er the meadows bare.

Move, Sony's recently released add-on for its PlayStation 3 video game system, is the company's expensive attempt to compete against Nintendo's wildly successful Wii. Like the Wii, Move allows consumers to simply swing a small electronic wand in the air to control game action on a television screen, like a character swinging a sword, throwing a flying disc or hitting a tennis ball. Such technology has made the Wii the most popular of the current game systems because it allows players to avoid having to master the use of more than a dozen buttons, sticks and triggers on a modern console game controller. Meanwhile, the PS3 has languished in third place behind both the Wii and Microsoft's Xbox 360.

Preserved lemons take minutes to make, but they take weeks to cure. There is, however, a compromise, a way to enjoy something pretty close to the authentic preserved lemon experience in much less time. These quick "preserved" lemons are wonderful with fish and amazing with stews.

There is a new No. 1 this week. And no, I'm not talking about our race for the Quad's top prognosticator. Despite a brutal 1-4 performance last weekend, Paul Myerberg still holds a slim, one-game advantage over Pete Thamel. The real new No. 1 is Ohio State, which faces its first true road test tomorrow night at Wisconsin. Camp Randall is always an intimidating atmosphere, but the Buckeyes hope Terrelle Pryor and a tough defense will be enough to overcome the Badgers' stout running game. Auburn is one of the last two undefeated teams in the Southeastern Conference (Louisiana State is the other), but the Tigers looked shaky in beating Kentucky last week. They face a stiff challenge from Arkansas on Saturday. Nebraska knows what it feels like to fall from the heights of the Big 12, so the Cornhuskers could have some empathy for struggling Texas if they choose to. They probably won't though. Michigan is trying to bounce back from a loss to Michigan State, but is running right into an Iowa squad that would like to fight it out with Ohio State for Big Ten supremacy. Meanwhile, in the Pac-10, Oregon State is quietly looking to assert itself as one of the conference's top teams. It beat Arizona last week and will try to knock off a Washington squad that has already defeated Southern California. There is plenty to watch this week and much to predict. As always, if you agree, disagree or merely find our picks laughable, feel free to let us know.

I suppose I always imagined that Jimi Hendrix sprang directly from the head of a particularly freaky hippie Zeus, but Steven Roby and Brad Schreiber set me straight. Their book, "Becoming Jimi Hendrix: From Southern Crossroads to Psychedelic London, the Untold Story of a Musical Genius" - reviewed in this Sunday's issue by David Kirby - mostly ignores Hendrix's days as a superstar to trace his improbable rhythm-and-blues rise, on the road with groups like Hank Ballard's Midnighters, the Bonnevilles, Curtis Knight and the Squires, the Isley Brothers and the Tams. Hendrix got fired a lot. "He couldn't play the music right," a fellow guitarist explained.

Queens is fighting to make sure it gets its share of Superfund attention for Newtown Creek, whose effluent-laden waters lap the shores of both Queens and Brooklyn. Several Queens leaders assert that the federal Environmental Protection Agency has primarily focused on the Brooklyn side of Newtown Creek in studies and sampling of the waterway. "That has to change," the officials wrote. "Time after time, Queens has simply been forgotten - literally omitted from the studies, the documentation and the E.P.A.'s attention." Read about the Battle of Newtown Creek on the Green blog.

Trend-spotters at the Frieze Art Fair this week had an easy time finding the next big thing: the artist as clutter queen. During a V.I.P. preview attended by Keith Richards as well as the mega-collectors Dasha Zhukova, Steven Cohen and Charles Saatchi, I saw so much junk repurposed as found-object sculpture that I actually mistook a pair of fire extinguishers for an artwork. But when I reached the stand of Berlin's Contemporary Fine Art, and a friend blurted a telltale alert - "What the hell is that!" - I knew we were onto something big.

The Hester Street Fair - with its retro bikes, vintage furniture and young designers - will be even more of a food lovers' destination on Saturday when it joins with Grub Street, New York magazine's food blog, for the Grub Street Food Festival. There will be stands set up by restaurants, food trucks and vendors at Hester and Essex Streets between 10 a.m. and 6 p.m., rain or shine. Some of those supposed to be on hand are: Purple Yam, Cheeky Sandwiches, Mile End Delicatessen, Pies 'n' Thighs, Luke's Lobster, Cascabel Taqueria, AnChoi, Kickstand Coffee, Kelvin Natural Slush Company and Mexicue.

Going live added a jolt of excitement to the NBC comedy "30 Rock," and viewers apparently shared the feeling. The show scored its best rating of the season, bouncing up 48 percent from the prior week to a 3.1 rating among viewers between the ages of 18 and 49. (It had been a 2.1 a week ago.) It also increased 38 percent among total viewers.

The college football season is a grind. The clear goal for the top teams is to stay undefeated and that means you have to bring your best game every week. Alabama showed us last week that the top teams can't afford to come out flat. The Tide traveled to face a tough South Carolina team that had a great day and now it no longer controls its own destiny. This week Ohio State, which took over the top spot, goes on the road to Madison for one of the toughest games on its schedule. In the Milan Issue, the Italian capital of fashion, design and business is explored to a T. Dolce & Gabbana talk about bombshells, Giorgio Armani pens a love note to his hometown, Janine di Giovanni writes on divorce in the age of Berlusconi, the next generation of Missonis share their city, and Maurizio Cattelan flips Milan the bird. Up to a point, Peter Baker's excellent Times Magazine piece on the mood in the Obama White House inspires a certain amount of sympathy for this administration. When Baker's sources complain that their boss is being unfairly maligned by foes and friends (or "frenemies," perhaps) alike, they have a point: The most strident criticisms of the Obama presidency have almost all been at least somewhat unfair, whether it's conservatives calling the president a socialist and a radical (when actually he's just a very conventional liberal), left-wingers claiming that he's a sell-out and a crypto-conservative (when actually he's accomplished more for the left than any president since L.B.J.), or D.C. insiders dismissing his political skills and salesmanship (hey, you try being a political salesman when the unemployment rate is 9.5 percent!). I'm no great admirer of Barack Obama's policies, but some of the discontent swirling around the White House at the moment is the usual cult-of-the-presidency nonsense, in which the occupant of the Oval Office is held responsible for forces and events beyond his control, and everyone pretends that the world would be perfect if he weren't so incompetent, so cowardly, or so evil.

Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island were declared federal disaster areas for the purposes of tornado cleanup, the governor's office announced Thursday night. ZHARI, Afghanistan -- I yelled to my men, ordering them to get down and take cover and orient their weapons eastward, halting our joint patrol with the Afghan National Army. A sniper had been terrorizing our small outpost in the middle of the Zhari district in Kandahar for three weeks. This menace had created a phantom persona, like the Ghost of Christmas Past who had followed us to the deserts of Afghanistan.

Today - Friday in Beijing - I had lunch with Angelica Cheung, the editor in chief of Vogue China, at the China Grill on the 66th floor of the Park Hyatt, and since I arrived at the restaurant a few minutes early, I took a moment to press my nose to the windows. Long before gas-guzzling Western capitals did something of a backpedal by implementing safer bike lanes and investing in bike-for-hire schemes, Adam McDermott and Chad Kushner, the South African founders of Linus Bikes, spent years traveling bicycle-centric cities in Europe and Asia. "We loved the simple, utilitarian bikes we'd find in other countries," McDermott says, "and wished there was a similar urban bike-as-transportation culture back home." Inspired by the elegant but basic designs of French city bikes of the '50s and '60s, Linus achieves the aesthetic of a modern vintage cycle: straight, clean lines, monochromatic colors and no excessive logos. Its new bicycle carryalls - crafted from wax canvas, oilskin leather and solid brass hardware that is designed to age nicely - are saddle bags you want.

Margareth Madè has had two roles to date, one in an epic by the director of "Cinema Paradiso" and the other playing Sophia Loren. Not bad for a Sicilian girl who felt like E.T. until she moved to Milan to model. Growing up, she gorged herself on Nonna's pasta as well as on old Hollywood films - "Wilder, Hitchcock, Cukor," Madè says dreamily. When she goes home, her mother still tells her, "Mangia! Mangia! You are too skinny!" Madè says this is what she loves about Italy: "This affection, the presence of your roots. Knowing where we come from allows us to move forward."

One thing that can certainly be said about Thursday's live episode of "30 Rock" is that it occurred. It was a stunt, one that NBC has tried with previous shows like "Will & Grace" and "ER," and while the live "30 Rock" may not have been life-altering television (these days, what is?), it wasn't the 10-car pile-up that some of its creators seemed to be masochistically wishing for, either. Even if it didn't advance the show's meta-narrative, and even if the laughter of the live studio audience was occasionally jarring, it had a certain frantic energy, like, say, the first half-hour of a decent "Saturday Night Live."

On an unassuming side street in Paolo Sarpi, Milan's burgeoning Chinatown, Mirko Pancaldi and Davide Grosso are flying the flag for design's future being in the past. Since 2001, the pair, who collaborate under the G | Lab name, have been drawing attention for their delicately ornate furniture and lighting fixtures made from discarded aged wood and laser-cut iron. ''We are known for breathing new life into traditional materials and forms,'' Pancaldi says in the G | Lab showroom, which occasionally doubles as a workshop for average Giovannis wanting to learn time-held wood-turning and ironwork techniques. ''All of our designs refer back to 18th-century French and Italian furniture traditions, and to patterns and shapes found in nature.'' And so a slab of industrial iron becomes a filigreed room divider that is as intricate as it is commanding, and a hunk of maple found in an abandoned sawmill has a second life as a Baroque cabinet. Is this work, which often has Oriental accents, a function of the showroom's location or the result of travels to Asia? ''I've never been to Asia,'' enthuses the usually taciturn Pancaldi. ''Only the Asia of my imagination.''

Another year, another 1,200 bands looking for a breakthrough at the CMJ Music Marathon, which opens in New York for the 30th time on Tuesday, with showcases, panel discussions and films through Oct. 23. Whether you are a college radio D.J. in town for the first time, or a jaded New Yorker with many marathons under your belt, the sheer scale of CMJ can be bewilder-ing. It's not cheap, either: a badge, which gets you into the official shows (you'll have to wait in line like everybody else for the unofficial parties all over the city), costs $495, or $295 for students. Here are a few suggestions to help you plan your week, whether you want to see as many obscure bands as possible or just want to do some schmoozing. A full schedule of bands is at cmj2010.com, but beware: it's a long, long list.

A column last Friday shared the recollections of Barbara and Emily Hong about their family's relationship with John Lennon and Yoko Ono. As the column noted, their memories were ''viewed through the lens of childhood,'' when they were 8 and 9 years old. Barbara Hong said that when Mr. Lennon played ''Imagine'' for the girls, he told them it was ''a song I'm going to release soon.'' ''Imagine'' was released in 1971, before Mr. Lennon met the Hongs in 1972. The column also related how Emily Hong believed an editor from Rolling Stone magazine introduced Mr. Lennon and Ms. Ono to Yuan Bain Hong, the girls' father and a practitioner of Chinese herbal medicine. The introduction was made by Craig Pyes, now a private investigator, who at the time was editor and publisher of SunDance magazine.

FIRST--Edythe Weiner, died peacefully of natural causes at age 95 on October 12, 2010. Her daughter, Susan First Pollack, was with her at the time of her death. Edythe was born in New York City on July 7, 1915 and raised in Glen Falls, New York. She lived an extraordinary life in civic affairs. In 2005, on the occasion of her 90th birthday, Edythe was honored for her long years of leadership in the community with a proclamation issued by the City Council of New York. The proclamation stated "Among the many vital contributions Ms. First made to her community, her dedication to the Civic Advisory Council of the Deputy Mayor, and was the first Chairperson of the City Commission on the Status of Women." Edythe entered Barnard College on a scholarship at age 15 and was graduated in the class of 1934. Following her marriage to Edward First, a tax lawyer who served in the Navy in World War II, Edythe worked at the Library of Congress in Washington, DC. She moved to New York City with her husband in 1955, where she began her long and distinguished career in civic affairs. In 1976 Mayor Beame appointed Edythe the First Chairperson of the Commission on the Status of Women. She also served several terms as the Chairperson of Women's City Club, an organization devoted to the concerns of all New Yorkers. She was honored by Mayor Giuliani in a ceremony recognizing her many and diverse contributions to the City of New York. Her diary is part of the collection of women's writings in the Schlesinger Library at the Radcliffe Institute. Mrs. First is survived by her daughter, Susan First Pollack, an attorney, her son-in-law, Daniel A. Pollack, an attorney, two grand-children, Samuel J. Pollack of Chicago and Gabriella Pollack Mishev of San Francisco, and two-great-grandchildren, Lillian and Hannah Pollack, both of Chicago, as well as her brother Sidney Weiner of Sarasota, Florida. Burial is private. A memorial service will be held in the future. Any contributions in her honor should be made to the Women's City Club or the Citizens Union of New York.

Bedbugs have made their debut at Lincoln Center. The pests were sighted in the dressing room of the David H. Koch Theater, the New York City Opera confirmed on Wednesday, and at the Metropolitan Opera. City Opera, whose fall season opens Oct. 27, shares the theater with the New York City Ballet, whose season ended on Sunday. The outbreak was reported online on Wednesday by The New York Observer, which quoted from an Oct. 8 e-mail from Mark Heiser, the theater's managing director, who said treatment was under way. ''Please understand that this is an epidemic,'' Mr. Heiser wrote. ''Any signs of bedbug activity should not be considered a sign of an untidy house.'' The pests were also found at the Metropolitan Opera. ''Bedbugs were discovered in some isolated locations but not in any public areas,'' a spokesman for the Met said in a statement, adding that the areas were being treated and monitored. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

O'CONNOR--Patrick Gerard, 57, died peacefully at home in Brooklyn on October 6th, 2010 from Melanoma. Patrick was born at New York Presbyterian Hospital on July 4, 1953 and grew up in Yorkville. One of his earliest childhood memories was watching the dismantling of the Third Avenue El from his bedroom window. Patrick attended St. Ignatius of Loyola Grammar School and Cardinal Spellman High School. He graduated from Lehman College in 1975. Patrick began his career in the art business while still in college, working summers for the Weintraub Gallery on Madison Avenue. He continued there full time after graduation. He was Manager of Hammer Galleries until 1986. For several years he was with Associated American Artists and then became Director of Galerie Tamenaga on Madison Avenue. When Phillips Auction House opened their New York office, Patrick joined the Impressionist and Modern Art department. Most recently he worked at J.N. Bartfield Galleries on 57th Street. Pat had a passion for art, American history, politics and baseball and he read on these subjects prolifically. Anyone entering into a discussion with Pat of these and other subjects was aware of his engaging mind, intellect and warm sense of humor. Friends and colleagues described him as humble, kind and a true gentleman. He loved his family dearly. Patrick was diagnosed in 2006 with Stage 3 Melanoma. He benefited for four years from the expertise of doctors and researchers at New York University Cancer Institute. Patrick is survived by his wife of 24 years, Antoinette Owen, his son, William P. O'Connor, his father, Patrick J. O'Connor and his brother, Martin Kevin O'Connor. He is also survived by numerous in-laws, cousins, aunts, uncles, nieces and nephews in the United States and Ireland. Pat was predeceased by his mother, Margaret. A memorial mass for Patrick will take place at 10am on Saturday, October 16th, at St. Francis Xavier Church, 225 6th Avenue, Brooklyn. A celebration of his life for his many friends, colleagues and family will be held at a later date. Donations in his memory may be given to NYU Melanoma Research Fund, c/o Dr. Anna C. Pavlick, NYU Clinical Cancer Center, 9th floor, 160 East 34th Street, NY, NY 10016; or to VNSNY Hospice Care, 1250 Broadway, 7th Floor, NY, NY 10001.

LOWENSTEIN--Richard L.,died peacefully Wednesday afternoon at his home in Mamaroneck surrounded by the love of his life, Rita, wife of 52 years, the pride of his life, son Michael, and Carol, and cherished prize of his life, daughter Wendy Sandler, and Neil. Dick was born in New York City, July 3, 1920. He was a true New Yorker from his Upper West Side childhood to the Village. Although his childhood was marked by the polio epidemic, a historic custody battle, and the Great Depression, Dick was not. He saw things clearly and called it like it was. His passions were simple and deep, first and foremost his family, his Jets, excellent food, and comfortable clothing. Dick graduated from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania in 1941 and then joined the army stationed in Japan during WWII. He created and built what was, at the time, the largest wholesale cruise business in the United States. Dick's grandchildren, Jeff, Matthew, Brad, Scott and Melanie are the fortunate beneficiaries of his non-judgmental, pure love and pride. We will remember him with laughter and love. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Holocaust and Human Rights Education Center of Westchester, or a charity of your choice. Funeral services will be held at Larchmont Temple on Friday, October 15, at 1pm.

In lieu of flowers, donations to Beth Israel Medical Center/ Head and Neck Center c/o Continuum Health Partners Development Dept., 555 W. 57th St., 18th Floor, NY, NY 10019 or Swim Across America, Inc.

An article on Thursday about language training for L.P.G.A. players, using information from the Language Training Center in Indianapolis, misstated the cost of the center's lessons. Players pay a discounted rate of $50 an hour for an in-person lesson, not $40. (The center offers discounted lessons to players via Skype for $40 an hour.)

An article on Thursday about the rescue of Chilean miners trapped for two months misstated the diameter of the cage used to bring them to the surface. It was 21 inches, not 26. And because of an editing error, the article also misstated the reason that fresh air was pumped into the mine. It was for the comfort of the men; it was not used to prevent their asphyxiation. (The miners were never in danger of suffocating because the air in the mine naturally contained about the same amount of oxygen as outside air.)

House Democrats, who need every advantage they can get in the midterm elections, say they will have about $10 million more than their Republican counterparts to spend on television advertising in the final three weeks before Election Day. In reporting their fund-raising for September, officials at the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee said Thursday that they had $40 million to invest in television spots backing their candidates while officials at the National Republican Congressional Committee said they expected to spend about $30 million.

An article on Saturday about Bank of America's decision to extend its suspension of foreclosures nationwide misstated the date of its merger with Merrill Lynch, a major player in the business of securitizing mortgages. The merger took place in July 2008, not January 2009.

SULANG, INDONESIA -- Made Rai is a frail man with lank white hair and eyes that are glazed with a milky film. He estimates that he is in his 80s: much too old to recount with confidence just how his family started feuding with this Balinese village. He is, however, fully aware of the feud's results. If he leaves his family compound, his neighbors look away and refuse to speak to him. He is banned from the village temples, normally central to Hindu spiritual life in Bali, and when he dies, his body will be rejected from the village cemetery.

The Brooklyn Academy of Music has organized a particularly theater-heavy line-up for its spring 2011 season, including a Donmar Warehouse production of ''King Lear'' starring Derek Jacobi; the Abbey Theater's staging of Ibsen's ''John Gabriel Borkman,'' with Alan Rickman and Fiona Shaw; and an Australian mounting of Gogol's ''Diary of a Madman'' starring Geoffrey Rush. In announcing the shows, Joseph V. Melillo, the academy's executive producer, said that planning the season had been something of an unusual whirlwind. He had expected a centerpiece of the spring to be the third installment of the Bridge Project, the collaboration of American and British actors in classic repertory productions. But one of its leaders, Sam Mendes, informed him in early 2010 that he would need to take 2011 off to direct the next James Bond movie, so Mr. Melillo said he had ''less time than usual - which is ideally a year in advance - to get the shows lined up.''

HENKIN--Louis. Dean David M. Schizer and the entire Columbia Law School community mourn deeply the loss of University Professor Emeritus Louis Henkin. Lou was a towering presence at the Law School since he joined the faculty in 1962, and his intellectual and personal contributions were immense. Known as the "father of human rights law," Lou focused on a nation's obligations to safeguard the equality and dignity of its citizens in seminal books such as How Nations Behave and The Age of Rights. His writings are also cited in hundreds of judicial opinions. Lou developed groundbreaking courses on law and diplomacy, the law of American foreign relations, and international and comparative human rights. He also founded the Columbia Law School Human Rights Institute and supported the Columbia Human Rights Law Review. In 1999, the Law School honored his contributions to the profession and to legal education by establishing the Louis Henkin Professorship in Human and Constitutional Rights. Lou influenced generations of human rights scholars, teachers, lawyers, and advocates around the world. He was an inspiration, an intellectual giant, a generous mentor and teacher, and a cherished friend. Our hearts go out to his wife, Alice; their sons, Joshua, David, and Daniel; and to their grandchildren for this great loss.

The Theaters at 45 Bleecker Street, one of New York's diminishing number of commercial Off Broadway spaces, has closed indefinitely due to litigation between the theater producers and their landlord, the 45 Bleecker theater manager said in an interview on Thursday. Performances have been canceled for Thursday night, including for the two new Off Broadway productions running there, ''The Deep Throat Sex Scandal'' and ''Perfect Harmony.'' The theater manager, Elle Sunman, said that she could not comment in detail because the theater did not want public comments to affect the ongoing litigation or the theater's dealings with the landlord, Fred Rogers of the company Rogers Investment.

J. K. Rowling, the author of the Harry Potter books, still cannot make a years-old plagiarism charge disappear. A lawsuit in a British court accusing Ms. Rowling of partly copying a 1987 book, ''The Adventures of Willy the Wizard,'' by Adrian Jacobs, may go to trial now that a judge has turned down an application by Ms. Rowling's lawyers to dismiss the case, according to Reuters. Mr. Jacobs's estate has said that Ms. Rowling's fourth book in the Potter series, ''Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire,'' published in 2000, took plot lines from the ''Willy the Wizard'' book. Ms. Rowling has vehemently denied the accusation, saying that she had not heard of Mr. Jacobs, who died in 1997, until the copyright claim was made in 2004 and had not read his book. A judge overseeing the case in Britain agreed that the assertions by Mr. Jacobs's estate are ''improbable'' but refused to dismiss the suit. Ms. Rowling's American publisher, Scholastic, said it considers the assertions to be ''completely without merit.''

WALLACE--Steven. The Trustees and staff of the Intrepid Museum mourn the passing of Steven Wallace, past Trustee of Intrepid and Marine veteran, true patriot and lifelong friend to all in uniform. He provided great support for Intrepid and many efforts on behalf of those who have served. Our condolences to family, friends and the Corps. Semper Fi.

No matter how far the Texas Rangers go in these playoffs, they will have already passed two milestones of sorts when they take the field against the Yankees on Friday night. First, this is the deepest postseason run in team history, thanks to its 5-1 victory over the Tampa Bay Rays on Tuesday night. Before this season, the Rangers had made the playoffs only three times, and that includes their incarnation as the Washington Senators from 1961 to 1971. Each time, in 1996, 1998 and 1999, they fell to the Yankees in the division series.

O'CONNOR--Jerry. We at Park Tower Group were saddened at the passing of Jerry O'Connor, a successful and creative businessman with whom we had a long relationship. We feel privileged to have known and worked with him and wish to convey our sincere condolences to his family and colleagues. Park Tower Group, George Klein, Chairman

Talk about having to eat crow. The National Republican Senatorial Committee angrily denied responsibility when allegations surfaced last week that the producers of one of their attack ads in the West Virginia Senate race had sought actors that looked ''hicky.''

An error on some electronic voting machines already in use in Illinois identifies Rich Whitney, the Green Party candidate for governor, as Rich Whitey. Mr. Whitney said he feared that the typo could confuse some voters or make some reconsider voting for him at all.

Enough Tea Party-supported candidates are running strongly in competitive and Republican-leaning Congressional races that the movement stands a good chance of establishing a sizeable caucus to push its agenda in the House and the Senate, according to a New York Times analysis. With a little more than two weeks till Election Day, 33 Tea Party-backed candidates are in tossup races or running in House districts that are solidly or leaning Republican, and 8 stand a good or better chance of winning Senate seats.

MUMBAI, India -- Two years ago, when the crisis on Wall Street reached its pinnacle, the high-flying Indian stock market fell with a thud as foreign investors took nearly $5 billion out of the country. The situation is very different today. In September, foreign investors poured $7.1 billion into Indian stocks and bonds -- a monthly record for foreign investment in India's securities market. The major stock indexes appear poised to breach the highs that they set in early 2008, when many analysts first argued that fast-growth developing countries were ''decoupling'' from the developed world.

An article on Monday about a campaign speech by President Obama in which he criticized political spending by special interest groups misstated the effect of a recent Supreme Court decision on such spending. The decision, in the Citizens United case, lifted restrictions on independent campaign expenditures by corporations and unions. It did not change existing campaign-finance disclosure requirements.

First came ''Couplehood,'' then came ''Babyhood.'' So where does Paul Reiser go next for the third installment of his best-selling ''-hood'' book series? ''Familyhood,'' of course. ''I was trying to avoid the 'Rocky 9'-ness of 'Familyhood,''' Mr. Reiser, the comedian and ''Mad About You'' star said in a telephone interview, ''but people know the other two, and this truly about family.''

An article on Thursday about a decision by the Canadian government to label bisphenol A, a chemical commonly known as BPA and used in many plastics, as a toxic substance misstated part of the name of an industry group that condemned the move. It is the American Chemistry Council, not the American Chemical Council.
London The new Olympic Stadium rising in East London is the object of desire for two soccer clubs that want to uproot and move in when the 2012 Games are over.

The former Tavern on the Green will reopen to the public on Friday, reincarnated as a $2.5-million visitor center, food court and retail shop, temporarily replacing the once-glittering landmark restaurant in Central Park, which shuttered on New Year's Day. Its new name, said Adrian Benepe, the parks commissioner, will be the Central Park Visitor Center at Tavern on the Green.

Trading in her Navy uniform from the acclaimed Broadway revival of ''South Pacific'' for a 1950s telephone headset, Kelli O'Hara will star next month in the New York City Center Encores! concert production of ''Bells Are Ringing,'' the Comden and Green musical with a score by Jule Styne, Encores! announced on Thursday. Ms. O'Hara, a three-time Tony Award nominee, most recently in 2008 as Ensign Nellie Forbush in ''South Pacific,'' will play the role of Ella Peterson, a telephone answering service operator who becomes caught up in her clients' lives. Judy Holliday won the 1957 Tony for best actress in a musical as Ella in the original production, which ran for 924 performances.
LOWENSTEIN--Richard. The Steinhardt and Landesman families mourn the death of our cousin, one of a kind. Our condolences to the family.

For more than 50 years, George Vujnovich was a mild-mannered salesman working away at his small business in Queens and living a quiet life on a quiet block in Jackson Heights. He never spoke, even to his closest friends, about his secret role organizing one of the greatest rescue missions of World War II. ''There was a strict rule in the O.S.S. and not talk about these things - they teach you to compartmentalize them and lock them away,'' Mr. Vujnovich said.

SEOUL, South Korea -- Even in the middle of a loud and bustling outdoor market, her voice drops to a whisper when she agrees to reveal the two secret ingredients that make her kimchi so popular with her customers. ''Fermented-anchovy paste and pickled-prune sauce,'' says Kim Gil-soo, looking warily, both ways, down the alley in front of her store, called Prosperity.

SISENWEIN--Irving. Passed away peacefully at home on October 11th. He was a native New Yorker, who resided in Palm Springs, CA for the past 30 years. Irv was a true renaissance man; world traveler, linguist, golfer, tennis player, boater, music lover (long-time patron of the Metropolitan Opera) and philanthropist. He was able to achieve all of those accomplishments in spite of having to cope with severe sight impairment for more than 50 years. His inner strength and determination allowed him to live a full life with Branna, his beloved wife of 70 years. After retiring from a successful career in business, he devoted his life to helping other sight-impaired people through the Desert Visionaires, a charity that he and Branna founded in California's Coachella Valley. Irv was awarded an Honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree from Yeshiva University in 2007 in recognition of his and his wife's support for the university's Albert Einstein College of Medicine, through their establishment of the Branna and Irving Sisenwein Chair in Ophthalmology and Visual Science. He was loved and respected by all. Irv will be missed and always remembered. Services will be held on Sunday at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City at 1pm. Please make contributions to the Coachella Valley Desert Visionaires c/o Alfred Isaacs, 120 Shoreline Rd., Rancho Mirage, CA 92270.

BERGNER--Andrew Brett, 52 passed away October l3, 2010. He is survived by his children Daniel and Kara, brothers Peter and Jonathan. He is the son of Robert Bergner and the late Lois Grinker. Step-son of Judith Bergner and Charles Grinker. Services to be held at Gutterman's, Sunday, October 17 at 10am in Rockville Centre.

LOWENSTEIN--Richard L. Dick remains forever in our memories deeply caring and generous, warm and inviting. We will miss you always. All our love from Bob, Betty, Susie, Steve, Beth, and Linda, and their families.

ALONG the way to the upcoming Game 1 of the National League Championship Series against the Philadelphia Phillies, the San Francisco Giants have suffered, and benefited, from bad calls by umpires. Bad calls are a disturbingly common phenomenon this season. A blatantly wrong call cost the Giants a game against the Mets in July, while another helped them secure a victory over the Atlanta Braves earlier this month.

COLLINS--Edwin Gorham, adored husband of Penelope M. Collins, beloved brother-in-law of Irene and Lambros Comitas, devoted godfather of Annie, Petra and Phineas Upham. A veteran of the United States Army Air Force in World War II, a graduate of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, he became a distinguished award-winning civil engineer whose acumen, integrity, bright spirit and gentlemanliness were a source of inspiration for all who knew him. Service Monday, October 18, 10am at The Church of Resurrection, 115 East 74 St., New York, NY.

IT took six umpires during Game 1 of the American League Division Series to decide whether Yankees right fielder Greg Golson had caught a line drive by the Twins' Delmon Young -- and they still got it wrong. Anyone with access to a television could see that Golson had caught the ball fairly. But because baseball stubbornly refuses to allow its umpires to consult video on anything but home run calls, the blunder stood. Even though umpires now routinely consult each other in an effort to get calls right, there has been an unusually large number of mistakes on critical plays in this year's postseason, which resumes with the American League Championship Series Friday night.
Democrats have tried many ways to capture the attention of distracted voters before Election Day. Former President Bill Clinton has settled on a personal favorite: football.

GILLESPIE--Helen Macpherson. Damariscotta, Maine, Helen, 93, on October 13th. Survived by husband Stuart, sons Stuart Jr, and Duncan, daughter Margot Iwanchuk. Graveside memorial celebration, May 2010.

KOLB--Anita F.,age 87, on October 14, 2010. School secretary NYC 35 years. Beloved sister, mother, grandmother, aunt, cousin and true friend. Industrious, creative, beautiful inside and out. Her indomitable spirit lives on.

A film review on Wednesday about ''Vision,'' which looks at the life of the 12th-century Benedictine nun Hildegard von Bingen, referred incorrectly to a 16-year-old character who joins the order and becomes Hildegard's protégée. She is a novice, not a novitiate, which is a term applied to the time when a person is a novice or the quarters where novices live or are trained.

BUDAPEST -- As the death toll from the Hungarian sludge disaster reached nine on Wednesday, environmentalists warned of other potentially lethal accidents across a region dotted with poorly maintained industrial facilities. ''There are accidents waiting to happen, and it is not only happening in Hungary but across the region,'' Zoltan Illes, Hungary's state secretary for the environment, said in an interview. ''The lesson of the sludge disaster is what can happen if environmental rules and regulations are ignored in the pursuit of profits.''

BENNETT--Claire Johnson, died peacefully in her home on October 9, 2010 after a prolonged illness. Wife of the late Stephen Bennett, she is survived by her two sons, Andrew and William; her two grandchildren, Alexander and Olivia; and her sister Doris Costello. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th Street, on Friday October 29th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Defenders of Wildlife or the ASPCA.

WARREN--William B. The CINTAS Foundation deeply mourns the loss of its chairman, William B. Warren, who generously provided his wise advise and leadership, helping it carry out its mission of fostering Cuban culture and the humanities by granting fellowships to worthy Cubans in the Diaspora. To honor his work, the Foundation established in 2006, the William B. Warren Lifetime Achievement Award in Music Composition. We will always remember Bill as a truly gracious and learned gentleman, full of life and humor. He will be keenly missed by all of us.
LALLY--Curtis. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Curtis Lally, associated with The New York Times from March 1, 1974 until retiring on April 1, 1994.

When Haile Gebrselassie, the world-record holder from Ethiopia, competes in the New York City Marathon on Nov. 7, he will be both a star and a growing anachronism. Gebrselassie is classically trained as a runner. He competed in cross-country and won two Olympic gold medals on the track at 10,000 meters before turning his full attention to the 26.2 miles of the marathon. He is the only man to have run under 2 hours 4 minutes, setting his world mark of 2:03:59 at the 2008 Berlin Marathon.

SIEGEL--Leonard O.,passed away at home on Sunday October 10, 2010. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Marilyn, his daughter Debbie Siegel Sherman, his sons Gary and Richard and his grandchildren Jeremy Sherman and Geena Sherman. He loved music and playing tennis. Slowed by Parkinson's disease, Leonard still enjoyed playing Bridge, and talking politics and sports with peers. A World War II veteran, Leonard will be buried at Arlington National Cemetery on Thursday, October 14, 2010 at 9am. Shiva will be at the home of Debbie Siegel Sherman.

SCHNEER--Stephen Baruch, age 81, died Monday, October 11th 2010 surrounded by his family. He was a 1953 graduate of Columbia University Law School and a practicing attorney for 57 years, a profession he revered. He was an accomplished bridge player, avid sports fan and keen political observer. He is predeceased by his first wife Sylvia Galin Schneer and his sister Anita Simpson. He is survived by his second wife, Nancy Molesworth Schneer, his children, Matthew and Deborah Schneer, his stepchildren, Ashley Diamond and Jennifer Strother, and his seven grandchildren. Stephen's fierce wit and big heart will be deeply missed. Memorial service will be held Saturday, October 23rd 2pm at his home in Croton, NY. Donations may be made in his name to the ACLU, 125 Broad St., 18th fl., New York, NY 10004, or the charity of your choice.

That would mean bobbing and ducking around rear view mirrors that jutted out from vans like reflective baseball gloves to catch any passing helmeted head. Or I could slow down and go with the flow of traffic.

True to its name, the World Marathon Majors offers the grandest financial prize for the top global marathoners. Since it started in 2006, male and female winners each claim $500,000 in a points series that comprises the top five competitive marathons as well as the world championship and Olympic marathon in two-year cycles. Samuel Wanjiru of Kenya secured the 2009-10 men's series Sunday when he won the Chicago Marathon. Liliya Shobukhova won in Chicago on Sunday and clinched the women's title.

My Sunday column, "Tea in Kabul," offers a few vignettes to explain why I think we're pursuing the wrong strategy in Afghanistan. Granted, any reader knows that I've been critical for some time, warning since 2004 that we were losing ground in southern Afghanistan to the Taliban and strongly against the "surge" that led President Obama last year to triple our troop presence in Afghanistan. So fair warning that my reporting in Afghanistan may not have been entirely neutral. It confirmed my beliefs -- humans always tend to find evidence to back up their preexisting ideas.

Long before Milledgeville, Ga., became the center of the Pittsburgh Steelers' off-season universe, the team had begun the move to a more run-based offense. Within days after the Steelers failed to make the playoffs as the defending Super Bowl champions last season, the team president Art Rooney II talked to Coach Mike Tomlin about reverting to a style that looked more like the Steelers teams of the 1970s and less like the pass-happy version that had emerged in recent years.

One of Rangers Manager Ron Washington's deviations from mathematically optimal baseball strategy - putting batters that are nowhere near his best atop his lineup - wound up working out Friday night, as both the leadoff man Elvis Andrus and the second-place hitter Michael Young reached base twice in Game 1 of their American League Championship Series against the Yankees. Another questionable strategic move, however - his choice of relief pitchers - did not go so well.

Why has stimulus become a dirty word? Many reasons, I guess: an inadequate plan combined with a wildly overoptimistic forecast was more or less guaranteed to create the impression of a failed program. But it's also true that the president himself has had a deeply self-destructive tendency to echo his opponents' arguments. My original invisible bond vigilantes post was inspired, in part, by Obama's decision to go on Fox News and declare that we needed to cut the deficit to avoid a double dip. Then, in July, he repeated almost verbatim John Boehner's justly mocked claim that since the private sector is tightening its belt, the government should do the same.

FLORHAM PARK, N.J. - The Jets stretched and warmed up on Friday morning to Joe Walsh's "Rocky Mountain Way" blaring over the loudspeakers at the team's practice facility. The altitude in Denver is known to play strange tricks with the ball, from Steve O'Neal's 98-yard punt in 1969 to the home runs that fly out of Coors Field. Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon continue their reign as the most in-demand choreographers in the ballet world this spring at American Ballet Theater. Two new works by the choreographers, as well as the premiere of a revival of Antony Tudor's 1967 ''Shadowplay,'' are among the highlights of the company's spring season, which runs May 16 to July 9 at the Metropolitan Opera House. The world premieres by Mr. Ratmansky and Mr. Wheeldon will be part of a special repertory program May 24-26, which will also include the American premiere of a work by Benjamin Millepied in honor of the late cellist Mstislav Rostropovich and ''Shadowplay,'' originally created for the Royal Ballet and based on Rudyard Kipling's ''Jungle Book.'' Other highlights of the season include the company premiere of ''The Bright Stream,'' created by Mr. Ratmansky in 2003 for the Bolshoi, as well as perennial classics like ''Don Quixote,'' ''Giselle,'' ''Coppelia,'' ''Cinderella,'' ''Swan Lake'' and more. In addition to the regular roster of principal dancers, Natalia Osipova, a principal dancer with the Bolshoi Ballet, and Alina Cojocaru, a principal dancer with the Royal Ballet, will return as guest artists.

Angelina Jolie said she hopes audiences will wait to see her coming film about a romance set against the Bosnian war before drawing any conclusions about it, Reuters reported. Little hot dogs were passed around on platters while real dogs were petted on the red carpet. When the actor Josh Lucas, in a Pugs for Obama T-shirt, knelt to ruffle the floppy ears of a motley shelter dog of indeterminate parentage, young women in a 10-foot radius seemed to fight back a collective swoon.

A concert performed by Adam Lambert drew fans as well as protesters in Malaysia, but the singer kept his word that he would follow the restrictions placed on the show, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Lambert, who is openly gay, was criticized by the Pan Malaysian Islamic Party for his plans to perform at the Putra Indoor Stadium in Bukit Jalil, near Kuala Lumpur. Party officials said Mr. Lambert's shows promote ''gay culture,'' and The A.P. said members of the party protested outside the concert with banners that read, ''Muslim students protest gay icon in our country'' and ''Not our culture.''

One thing that can certainly be said about Thursday's live episode of ''30 Rock'' is that it occurred. It was a stunt, one that NBC has tried with previous shows like ''Will & Grace'' and ''ER,'' and while the live ''30 Rock'' may not have been life-altering television (these days, what is?), it wasn't the 10-car pile-up that some of its creators seemed to be masochistically wishing for, either. Even if it didn't advance the show's meta-narrative, and even if the laughter of the live studio audience was occasionally jarring, it had a certain frantic energy, like, say, the first half-hour of a decent ''Saturday Night Live.'' The good folks over at Vulture have compiled this exhaustive list of the differences between the versions of the episode that were presented for the Eastern and Western halves of the country, and, well, it's mostly pretty subtle stuff.

1:43 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES-Apparently, only an ongoing union dispute in New Zealand now stands between ''The Hobbit'' and a start date in February. Warner Brothers' New Line Cinema unit and MGM have worked out their deal to finance the pair of films to be based on J. R. R. Tolkien's novel, and Peter Jackson's deal to direct is now finalized, according to a person who was briefed on the movie's intricacies this week. But continuing uncertainty over attempts to have the filmmakers bargain collectively with their actors in New Zealand still stands between the production and its planned February start date (already delayed from an anticipated January date). New Zealand officials have said the production can't legally enter a collective bargaining arrangement with its actor-contractors, but unions there have insisted that a deal could be struck. If the studios move the film out of New Zealand, the budget, which already runs into the hundreds of millions of dollars, would have to be redrawn, and at least some further delay would be inevitable.

If your laptop happens to be stolen, as mine recently was, it can be a big hassle to protect your data after the fact. That's why it's important to know how to secure your laptop before it's gone. The easiest way to do that, of course, is simply not to keep any sensitive information on your laptop in the first place. ''I recommend you don't store any sensitive documents on your hard drive, particularly if it's a laptop, and instead store those documents in a U.S.B. flash drive and store that in a locked secure place,'' said Paul Stephens, director of policy and advocacy at the Privacy Rights Clearinghouse.

An article on Friday previewing the American League Championship Series, between the Texas Rangers and the New York Yankees, misstated the date that Oscar Gamble was traded from the Rangers to the Yankees in 1979, and in so doing referred incorrectly to the timing of that event with the death of the Yankees' catcher Thurman Munson in a plane crash. Gamble's trade indeed came one day before Munson's death, but it was on Aug. 1, 1979 -- not on Oct. 1.

SISENWEIN--Irving. Passed away peacefully at home on October 11th. He was a native New Yorker, who resided in Palm Springs, CA for the past 30 years. Irv was a true renaissance man; world traveler, linguist, golfer, tennis player, boater, music lover (long-time patron of the Metropolitan Opera) and philanthropist. He was able to achieve all of those accomplishments in spite of having to cope with severe sight impairment for more than 50 years. His inner strength and determination allowed him to live a full life with Branna, his beloved wife of 70 years. After retiring from a successful career in business, he devoted his life to helping other sight-impaired people through the Desert Visionaires, a charity that he and Branna founded in California's Coachella Valley. Irv was awarded an Honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree from Yeshiva University in 2007 in recognition of his and his wife's support for the university's Albert Einstein College of Medicine, through their establishment of the Branna and Irving Sisenwein Chair in Ophthalmology and Visual Science. He was loved and respected by all. Irv will be missed and always remembered. Services will be held on Sunday at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City at 1pm. Please make contributions to the Coachella Valley Desert Visionaires c/o Alfred Isaacs, 120 Shoreline Rd., Rancho Mirage, CA 92270.

Americans will have to wait at least 12 more years to see a World Cup final game at home. The USA Bid Committee said Friday that it had withdrawn from trying to secure the 2018 World Cup and would instead focus on trying to win the 2022 event. The United States was the last remaining non-European country in the running for the 2018 tournament. Belgium/Netherlands, England, Russia and Spain/Portugal remain in contention. England hosted the tournament in 1966, and won the championship. Spain, which is making a joint bid with Portugal, hosted in 1982.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Sunday about Johnny Edgecombe, who was involved in the scandal that led to the resignation of the British government minister John Profumo, misstated, in one reference, the month in which Mr. Edgecombe fired shots at the apartment of his girlfriend, Christine Keeler. As the obituary correctly noted in the first sentence, the incident was in December 1962, not in October.

When an installation by the Chinese conceptual artist Ai Weiwei opened on Tuesday at Turbine Hall, the cavernous entrance space of the Tate Modern in London, visitors were encouraged to touch and even walk on the 100 million hand-crafted porcelain sunflower seeds that gave the piece its name. But on Thursday this kind of intimate interaction stopped. Officials at the museum closed off access to ''Sunflower Seeds,'' and is now only allowing visitors to see it from a walkway above the hall. The movement of the crowds released a ''greater than expected level'' of ceramic dust, according to a statement released by the Tate, which added that it had ''been advised that this dust could be damaging to health following repeated inhalation over a long period of time.'' As a result, the museum, in consultation with the artist, ''decided not to allow visitors to walk across the sculpture.'' Sunflower seeds are a ubiquitous Chinese street snack, and in Mr. Ai's piece they are thought to represent both fellowship and the enforced conformity experienced during the Cultural Revolution, when propaganda posters depicted Chairman Mao as the sun and Chinese people as sunflowers turning toward him. There have been safety problems in Turbine Hall before. In 2007 three visitors fell into the artist Doris Salcedo's ''Shibboleth,'' a jagged crack running the length of the room. The year before, several people suffered bruises from Carsten Holler's twisting slide. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

FIRST--Edythe Weiner, died peacefully of natural causes at age 95 on October 14, 2010. Her daughter, Susan First Pollack, was with her at the time of her death. Edythe was born in New York City on July 7, 1915 and raised in Glen Falls, New York. She lived an extraordinary life in civic affairs. In 2005, on the occasion of her 90th birthday, Edythe was honored for her long years of leadership in the community with a proclamation issued by the City Council of New York. The proclamation stated "Among the many vital contributions Ms. First made to her community, her dedication to civic life is truly exceptional; she has been a Board Member of the Community Council of Greater New York, a member of the Civic Advisory Council of the Deputy Mayor, and was the first Chairperson of the City Commission on the Status of Women". Edythe entered Barnard College on a scholarship at age 15 and was graduated in the class of 1934. Following her marriage to Edward First, a tax lawyer who served in the Navy in World War II, Edythe worked at the Library of Congress in Washington, DC. She moved to New York City with her husband in 1955, where she began her long and distinguished career in civic affairs. In 1976 Mayor Beame appointed Edythe the First Chairperson of the Commission on the Status of Women. She also served several terms as the Chairperson of Women's City Club, an organization devoted to the concerns of all New Yorkers. She was honored by Mayor Giuliani in a ceremony recognizing her many and diverse contributions to the City of New York. Her diary is part of the collection of women's writings in the Schlesinger Library at the Radcliffe Institute. Mrs. First is survived by her daughter, Susan First Pollack, an attorney, her son-in-law, Daniel A. Pollack, an attorney, two grand-children, Samuel J. Pollack of Chicago and Gabriella Pollack Mishev of San Francisco, and two-great-grandchildren, Lillian and Hannah Pollack, both of Chicago, as well as her brother Sidney Weiner of Sarasota, Florida. Burial is private. A memorial service will be held in the future. Any contributions in her honor should be made to the Women's City Club or the Citizens Union of New York.

BERLIN -- As artifacts go, they are mere trinkets -- an old purse, playing cards, a lantern. Even the display that caused the crowds to stop and stare is a simple embroidered tapestry, stitched by village women. But the exhibits that opened Friday at the German Historical Museum are intentionally prosaic: they emphasize the everyday way that ordinary Germans once accepted, and often celebrated, Hitler.

10 P.M. (Cinemax) FANTASTIC MR. FOX (2009) George Clooney, Meryl Streep, Jason Schwartzman and Bill Murray lend their voices to this animated tale from Wes Anderson, adapted with Noah Baumbach from the ''anti-fable'' by Roald Dahl about a fox that rallies his animal friends against three evil farmers. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said the movie is in some ways Mr. Anderson's ''most fully realized and satisfying film,'' adding that, ''once you adjust to its stop-and-start rhythms and its scruffy looks, you can appreciate its wit, its beauty and the sly gravity of its emotional undercurrents.'' Is it a movie for children? Mr. Scott wonders. ''It is precisely the movie that a child smitten with Roald Dahl's fiction and fascinated by the enigmas of the adult world would dream of making: something to amaze and terrify the grown-ups and win the envy and adulation of his peers.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Eliza Griswold, a poet and journalist who reports on Muslim-Christian conflicts, discusses what may be the biggest religious fault line in the world: the 10th parallel, 700 miles north of the equator in Africa and Asia, where faiths, politics and violence collide.
