The staff director and chief counsel of the independent Office of Congressional Ethics in the House, Leo J. Wise, is stepping down in November to join the United States Attorney's Office in Maryland and perhaps sidestep an inevitable political fight over the future of the ethics office. The office was created by Nancy Pelosi, the San Francisco Democrat, in 2008 after she became speaker and promised to ''drain the swamp that is Washington.'' But it has been controversial from the start, and Ms. Pelosi struggled to get enough votes to create the independent watchdog.

“School Pride,” a new NBC reality show, takes a team of four co-hosts to troubled schools to organize volunteers and make needed repairs.
Series like “Hung” and “Weeds” condemn their down-and-out characters, while shows like “No Ordinary Family” praise multitaskers.
New York City Ballet’s first fall season at Lincoln Center, which ended last week, was invigorating and at times unexpectedly intriguing.
Vittorio Grigolo, who is making his Met debut in “La Bohème,” may be the tenor that the opera world has been waiting for.
“Sale el Sol” (“The Sun Comes Out”), the new album from the Colombian singer Shakira, is sung mostly in Spanish, bringing an even more international dimension to her sound.
On his new album, “The Age of Adz,” the guitar-strumming Sufjan Stevens moves toward electronica.
Populations are getting older faster, which leads to more globalization, which means even older countries.
Roxy Paine’s stainless-steel Dendroid sculptures, each making up a gleaming industrial sprawl, mirror arboreal purity.
The fifth anniversary of Stephen Colbert’s introduction of a zeitgeisty word.
The script for Clint Eastwood’s latest film, “Hereafter,” about the afterlife, underwent a near-death experience of its own.
The cookies are delicious fresh but are even better the next day.
Turner Classic Movies has released four films by Douglas Sirk that show another side of this director who has become known for his melodramas.
Adapted from “Lebanese Cuisine,” by Anissa Helou.
Of farro, freekeh and the future of farming.
Gareth Edwards’s science-fiction film “Monsters” was made for about $500,000 and contains 250 effects shots produced on his computer.
The Brothers Quay, animators of unsettling imagery, are shooting a documentary at the Mütter Museum in Philadelphia, home of countless biological oddities.
The term documentary has become a catchall rubric, a label that can be affixed to heterogeneous, even contradictory products.
Dikembe Mutombo, a former N.B.A. all-star center, who is also known for philanthropic efforts in his native Congo, is asking $4.5 million for a three-bedroom condo.
New hotels in Oregon and Northern California bring luxury and environmentally-conscious lodging to a new level.
On bicycle from village to village, travelers visit the intimate family wine gardens and restaurants unique to Austria.
Xinjiang’s trade routes once again teem with caravans, this time carrying crude oil, jade and, increasingly, tourists.
Though Anderson Valley is an easy overnight trip from the Bay Area, it seems far removed — both in geography and in time.
Deep in the Ecuador jungle, a local tribe works to protect its traditions, and a visitor finds answers through visions and revelations.
Residents enjoy cultural institutions, athletic facilities, and stores and restaurants of the highest order.
As a candidate, Barack Obama promised to change Washington. Two years in, he may have to change his approach to his job.
Behind the scenes with President Barack Obama.
Excerpts from Peter Baker’s interview with the president.
Lisa Kron discusses her new play, “In the Wake,” which is both like and unlike her onstage persona.
Racism, class warfare, anti-Semitism, capital punishment — they’re all in the Broadway musical “The Scottsboro Boys.” But the producers don’t want it to be a downer.
Some midcareer globe-trotters hope to show that anyone can hop off the treadmill and go travel.
“I think The Weekly Standard would have been harder on Beck than Leibovich was.”
“Obama’s Wars,” Bob Woodward’s fly-on-the-wall account of Barack Obama’s decision to send 30,000 more troops to Afghanistan, hits the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 1.

The latest computer rankings indicate that this is week one of the Caroline Wozniacki era. But the paradox -- nothing novel to women's tennis -- is that we are clearly not in the Wozniacki era, at least not yet. Wozniacki, the 20-year-old from Denmark, might be a remarkable athlete and fighter with a consistent game, an improved serve and an upbeat disposition. But she has yet to win a Grand Slam title in singles or doubles and has not even reached a Grand Slam final this season.

SCHULMAN--Seymour, passed away peacefully on September 4, 2010 at home surrounded by his loving wife, Nancy (nee Master), and daughters, Gabrielle Schulman and Dara (William) Lanzisero. Loved and missed by everyone.

On an unassuming side street in Paolo Sarpi, Milan's burgeoning Chinatown, Mirko Pancaldi (near right) and Davide Grosso are flying the flag for design's future being in the past. Since 2001, the pair, who collaborate under the G | Lab name, have been drawing attention for their delicately ornate furniture and lighting fixtures made from discarded aged wood and laser-cut iron. ''We are known for breathing new life into traditional materials and forms,'' Pancaldi says in the G | Lab showroom, which occasionally doubles as a workshop for average Giovannis wanting to learn time-held wood-turning and ironwork techniques. ''All of our designs refer back to 18th-century French and Italian furniture traditions, and to patterns and shapes found in nature.'' And so a slab of industrial iron becomes a filigreed room divider that is as intricate as it is commanding, and a hunk of maple found in an abandoned sawmill has a second life as a Baroque cabinet. Is this work, which often has Oriental accents, a function of the showroom's location or the result of travels to Asia? ''I've never been to Asia,'' enthuses the usually taciturn Pancaldi. ''Only the Asia of my imagination.'' HORACIO SILVA
Power suiting softens up. Giorgio Armani blazer, $2,575.

RICE--Roger Douglas, 89, died peacefully following a short illness on October 15, 2010, in Rancho Mirage, CA. Roger was one of the early leaders in the television industry, as General Manager of KTVW in Seattle, WIIC in Pittsburgh, PA, and KTVU in Oakland, CA. While at KTVU he was one of nine members of the national TV Code Review Board. In 1972 Roger was appointed by then Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, to the board of the CULCON Commission, which promoted cultural and educational exchanges between Japan and the U.S. In 1973 he founded INTV to promote cooperation among independent television stations around the country. In 1974 he became President and CEO of the Television Bureau of Advertising (TVB) in New York City, the position from which he retired in 1988. During that time he served on the board of the Advertising Council and was a founder of the Media Coalition for a Drug Free America. Roger was born in Spokane, WA, on February 20, 1921 to Leland Leroy Rice and Bernice Metcalf Rice. He graduated from the University of Washington in Seattle and was called to active duty with the Marine Corps in July, 1943. Roger is survived by Molly Rice, his wife of 64 years, his daughter, Stephanie Ellis, and her husband Michael, of Lihue, Hawaii; his son Douglass Rice and his wife Cynthia Elliott, of New York City; and four grandchildren and their spouses.

LIPPMAN--Edward A.,Professor emeritus of Musicology at Columbia University, died in Teaneck, New Jersey, on June 9, 2010, two weeks after a 3-day family celebration of his 90th birthday. A gifted musician, he composed, played classical piano weekly on WNYC as a child, and later played jazz piano in a hotel band. He was an honor graduate of Clinton High School in New York City and went on to earn a B.S. from CCNY in 1942, an M.A. from NYU in 1945, and a Ph.D. from Columbia in 1952. A polymath, he taught radar to Air Force trainees after graduating from college, and later, while a graduate student, he taught the entire curriculum (which included calculus and English as well as radio and television repair) at the RCA Institutes. At various times he taught at City, Hunter, Brooklyn, and Queens Colleges and at Bryn Mawr. But it was during the 35 years he spent at Columbia (from 1954 to 1989) that he developed his original ideas on the philosophy and aesthetics of music, ideas which he elaborated in five books (one of which was translated into Chinese) and numerous articles (including three for the prestigious German music encyclopedia MGG) and reviews. When teaching, which he loved, he preferred the Socratic method interspersed with quiet humor; bursts of laughter emanated frequently from the rooms in which he held his classes. His warmth, wisdom, and humor are sorely missed by Violet, his beloved wife of 68 years, his sons Robert and Richard and their wives Marlene and Celi, his four grandchildren, Li (and her husband Richard Faustino), Philip, Julia, and Laura (and her husband Jason McCabe), and his two great-grandchildren, Mira Faustino and Conor McCabe.

NELSON--James Hissom, Jr.,MD, (Jim). Died on October 5th, 2010 at age 84, in Charleston, SC after a lengthy illness. Born in Marietta, OH, he entered the Navy at an early age serving in the Pacific during WWII. Remaining in the Navy, he obtained the rank of Lt. Commander, during which time he graduated from NYU Medical School and completed a residency in Ob-Gyn at St. Albans Naval Hospital. He then went on to complete a fellowship in Gynecologic Oncology at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, NY and had advanced training at Sloan Kettering Research Center, New York. Dr. Nelson's long and distinguished career included: Professor and Chairman, Department of Ob-Gyn at State University of New York, Downstate Medical Center, Joe V. Meigs Professor, Harvard University School of Medicine and Director of Gynecology at Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA, Director of Gynecology Oncology at University of Cincinnati, Ohio, Westchester County Medical Center, New York and Director of Ob-Gyn at The Stamford Hospital, Stamford, CT. Dr. Nelson was a founding member of the sub specialty Board of Gynecology Oncology and president of that society, author of more than 100 scientific articles as well as the First and Second editions of the Atlas of Radical Pelvic Surgery. He trained countless residents and fellows to the highest standards of the profession. Dr. Nelson was adored by his patients for his gentle and caring manner, and a dedicated advocate in advancing the care of women. His leadership and pioneering achievements in the treatment of gynecologic cancer earned him international recognition and the respect of his colleagues. Jim will be missed by his wife, Noreen (Nelson, MD), his son Dr. James Nelson and his grandsons James and Matthew Nelson.

MICHAEL FLOYD The Notre Dame receiver, left, caught 3 touchdown passes and had 157 yards receiving as the Fighting Irish beat Western Michigan, 44-20, for their third straight victory. MATT BARKLEY The U.S.C. quarterback tied a team record with 5 touchdown passes and threw for 352 yards in a 48-14 win over California. That stopped the Trojans' first losing streak in nine years.

TEHRAN -- Iran's intelligence minister on Friday insisted that two United States hikers who remain in custody more than a year after their capture near the Iraqi border must be tried in an Iranian court. ''In the opinion of this ministry, the two detained Americans accused of spying must await trial by the judiciary,'' the intelligence minister, Heydar Moslehi, told reporters from IRNA, Iran's state-run news agency, on Friday in Lebanon, where he had gone on a state visit with President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.
'It's just one win -- but it's sweet.'
FIRST--Edythe. Women's City Club of New York mourns the passing of its past president. She was not only an inspirational force for WCC but for New York City as a whole. Ruth Acker, President
MORE ABOUT ZURICH To the Editor:

Incidences of drug-related violence in Mexico and on the border continue to make news. We tend to hear about the crimes that touch American lives -- like the reported killing of a man riding a Jet Ski on the Rio Grande. What we don't hear as much about is how drugs and violence shape the everyday lives of Mexicans. So here are dispatches from four writers on how drug trafficking has changed their parts of the country. They were translated by Kristina Cordero from the Spanish.

OLSHIN--Dr. Sally Ellen (nee Weinberger) on October 3, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Seymour Olshin, devoted and loving mother and grandmother. Survived by children Joshua (Erika), Elizabeth (Harry Mendell), Jennifer, and Rebecca (Eric Stein) and grandchildren Sarah, Caleb, Serena, Julianna, Nadia and Daniel. Born in New York City, she received a BA from Hunter College, a MSW from Columbia University, a DSW from Adelphi University and completed her psychoanalytic training with Robert Langs at the Lenox Hill Hospital Psychotherapy Program. Until recently she practiced as a psychotherapist in Nassau County. She was an inspiring human being who will be remembered with great love and gratitude by her family, friends, patients and all communities that she touched.

It's typical of the murky legend that has accumulated around Walter Albini that no one can even agree if the design college he attended in 1957 in Turin, Italy, at the age of 16 was an all-girls school that he somehow charmed his way into -- or if he simply happened to be one of the few guys at an institution with a lot of women. One version is a lot sexier and more useful for burnishing his eminence. Not that you needed to back in the '70s, when Albini was at the height of his powers and there were only two names that got every tuned-in London design student's motor running: Chloé's Karl Lagerfeld, who still had one foot in the chrysalis, and his fellow Krizia alum Albini. If it's possible to feel nostalgic for something you've never known, then the young plotters at St. Martin's felt it for Albini's storm of polka dots, floor-grazing tea gowns in tiers of floral georgette and plaid velvet dinner suits tipped with swan feathers. His mania for the '20s and '30s, for Chanel and Poiret, for cigarette holders and Champagne buckets, only added to the élan.

When I was a 19-year-old college sophomore, I went to my first grown-up meeting. I was working several hours a week for a political science professor, and any escape from collating scholarly papers about demographic voting trends seemed exotic and terribly adult. Young as I was, I quickly figured out that there was absolutely nothing even remotely useful about this departmental meeting. Here were these esteemed professors sitting around shuffling papers, listening to each other talk endlessly, and then planning their next meeting.

VIESER--Richard William, 82, passed away peacefully on October 14th. Mr. Vieser was an esteemed corporate leader who achieved a national reputation for success in rebuilding, managing and transforming a wide range of businesses in the electronics, defense, oil and gas, automotive and medical fields. A native of New Jersey, he was among the pioneers of the leveraged buyout industry having worked with both Forstmann Little & Co and Hicks Muse before retiring in 1989. After retirement, Mr. Vieser maintained an active presence in business by serving on the boards of some twenty organizations, including prominent firms such as Varian Medical, where he served as Chairman, Fisher Scientific, Dresser Industries, Control Data Corporation, Ceridian and Viasystems. Mr. Vieser was a generous and loving husband, father, grandfather and friend. He is survived by his beloved wife of fifty-nine years, Lois (Johnson) and five adoring children, Richard (and Patricia) of Bernardsville, NJ, Cheryl (Vieser) Kleckner of Alpharetta, GA, Cynthia (Vieser) and Joseph Falco of Madison, NJ, William John David of Madison, NJ and Jaime (and Melinda) of London, UK. He also leaves behind a wide circle of family and friends, including his nine beloved grandchildren, Donald, Francecsa, David, Joseph, Anne, Katherine, Alexandra, Bella and his namesake, Richard William. Born in the Vailsburg section of Newark, New Jersey, on November 14, 1927, Mr. Vieser spent his formative years in South Orange, New Jersey, where he graduated from Columbia High School in Maplewood. He was a member of a state championship baseball team in high school and active in scouting where he attained the distinction of Eagle Scout at the age of 15. After a year at Lafayette College, Mr. Vieser entered the U.S. Army in September 1946. He served sixteen months in Korea as a member of the Army of Occupation and was discharged in April 1948. Being a proud American with unwavering patriotism, he felt these years were some of the most formative of his life. Mr. Vieser re-entered Lafayette, where he was a member of Theta Delta Chi Fraternity, serving as its President in his senior year. His business career began as a trainee at AT&T headquarters in New York City. Mr. Vieser later joined Chatham Electronics Corporation where he oversaw construction of a new factory in Livingston, New Jersey that manufactured highly specialized electron tubes used in the DEW line and other early missile warning systems across Canada and the Arctic. Mr. Vieser went on to hold major executive positions, as Chatham Electronics was part of a series of corporate acquisitions and mergers in the 1950s and 1960s, involving such major and well-known businesses as Tung Sol Electric, Wagner Electric, Studebaker and Worthington Pump Company - ultimately leading to the formation of Studebaker-Worthington. Throughout the series of corporate changes, he continued his rapid rise in leadership positions. Mr. Vieser served as Executive Vice President of StudebakerWorthington and ultimately as Chief Operating Officer. After McGraw-Edison acquired Studebaker-Worthington in 1979, he was appointed Executive Vice President and later President and Chief Operating Officer of McGraw-Edison. When McGraw-Edison was acquired by Cooper Industries, Mr. Vieser was invited to join Forstmann Little & Co. While there, he served as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of three Forstmann Little companies, Lear Siegler Corporation, FL Industries and Midland-Ross Corporation. He also served as Chairman of the National Motor Equipment Manufacturers Association, where he hosted numerous foreign trade missions at the request of the U.S. State Department and received honors from the states of New Jersey, Kentucky, Alabama and Mississippi. Mr. Vieser was an avid historian and voracious reader, with a profound love for music, art and travel. He was greatly involved in historical preservation and philanthropy. Mr. Vieser was a member of the President's Council of Colonial Williamsburg and a Trustee of Winterthur Museum. Mr. Vieser was an avid golfer and a member of several golf clubs, including famed courses such as Baltusrol, Pine Valley, and Morris County in New Jersey and Ocean Forest and Sea Island in Georgia. Mr. Vieser was devoted to his family and his friends. His enormous spirit, sense of humor, kindness and love for life inspired all those who knew him. He believed life was something to be celebrated. His greatest joy was to be with his family and friends around the dinner table. He especially treasured spending time with his family at his farm in New Hampshire in front of a roaring fire or enjoying a beautiful sunset. His infectious laugh, heart-warming smile, generous heart and beautiful spirit will never leave us. Relatives and friends are invited to call Monday, October 18, 2-4 and 7-9pm at the William R. Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Ave., Summit, NJ (908-273-2323). Funeral Services will be on Tuesday, Oct. 19, 10am at Calvary Episcopal Church, Summit. Interment will follow at Restland Memorial Park, East Hanover.

For its first collaboration with the watchmakers TKO Orlogi, Henri Bendel is turning back the clock to the '90s slap band craze. Like those fun bracelets of yore, the watch's interchangeable straps come in a range of neon colors. At only $50 a pop, the watches are a wallet-friendly alternative to Balenciaga's eye-catching timepieces on the runway for spring. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

This year, signs are emerging that Baghdad is ready to do business. The tolls of war are still very evident, however, and several recent suicide bombing attacks show that the city and Iraq as a whole have a long way to go. But in marked contrast to a few years ago, new businesses are opening with regularity, including grocery stores, high-end boutiques, restaurants, car dealerships, movie theaters, ice cream stores and hotels. And despite the city's touch-and-go electrical grid, trading can be brisk at the Iraq Stock Exchange.
HORSE FARM $1,395,000

Like a latter-day John Hughes, Hedi Slimane is smitten with American adolescence. Since moving to Los Angeles after stepping down as the influential designer of Dior Homme, Slimane has exalted an idealized version of youth in his myriad photography and art projects. In ''I Love U.S.A.,'' a new video shot exclusively for the fashion e-commerce site thecorner.com, Slimane turns his lens on two teenagers he discovered at the Coachella rock festival. The premise of the improvised storyline is undeniably abstruse - the star-crossed lovers are a confused cheerleader and her cello-playing paramour, who wears a wolf mask - but as tender as any lingering shot of Molly Ringwald's face. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

COLLINS--Edwin Gorham, on October 13, 2010, adored husband of Penelope M. Collins, beloved brother-in-law of Irene and Lambros Comitas, devoted godfather of Annie, Petra and Phineas Upham. A veteran of the United States Army Air Force in World War II, a graduate of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, he became a distinguished award-winning civil engineer whose acumen, integrity, bright spirit and gentlemanliness were a source of inspiration for all who knew him. Service Monday, October 18, 11am at The Church of Resurrection, 115 East 74 St., New York, NY.
Classical Daniel J. Wakin
Texas Christian Coach Gary Patterson when asked if the fourth-ranked Horned Frogs scored a late touchdown in a 31-3 win over Brigham Young in order to impress voters.

Cesare Rimini is a lucky man. He used to drive a Ferrari but sold it because Italian laws wouldn't let him drive fast enough. These days his hobby is wine. He makes it, but not for sale, just to give lucky friends. ''One bottle of his wine costs more than a bottle of Dom Pérignon,'' says his daughter, Alessandra, with a laugh. Rimini spends his summers in Cinque Terra, Italy, and has so many clients he can't count them. He is fortunate enough to be in a recession-proof business. One, in fact, that is booming in Italy: divorzio.

President Obama signed a bill Friday that he hopes won't be really necessary until at least 2016. The legislation allows the government to start providing transition resources -- office space, computers, telephones and even security clearances for some aides -- to the primary contenders for the presidency before the election takes place.

LOWENSTEIN--Richard. The family of Dick's beloved late brother Lou deeply mourns his passing. We offer our condolences to Dick's immediate family, whose sorrow we profoundly share. Observing Dick, we learned that "a twinkle in his eye" is no mere expression, but a metaphor for a human spirit that indefatigably seized on life's joys, and its sweetness, to the fullest. Observing Dick and Lou together, we learned that life has few greater joys than a loving and loyal kinship and brotherhood. From the Yankee Stadium to the Larchmont Tavern, and over a span of four score and more years, you guys never quit. Dick, you were truly our other half.

''Picasso: Masterpieces From the Musée National Picasso'' consists of roughly 150 paintings, drawings and sculptures from the Paris museum whose collection is drawn from the holdings of the artist himself. That museum is undergoing a three-year renovation and has sent many highlights globe-trotting. One of its stops is the Seattle Art Museum, which through Jan. 17 is displaying works ranging from Picasso's early Blue Period to his late Cubist portraits. To further entice art lovers, sixteen Seattle hotels are offering related packages. One of them, from the Mayflower Park Hotel, offers exhibition tickets allowing visitors to bypass the general admission line, valet parking and a 15 percent discount at Andaluca restaurant ($189 for a classic room and $209 for a deluxe). Another, from Hotel Andra, includes exhibition tickets, a show catalog, a $25 credit at its Lola restaurant and late check-out (2 p.m.) in its See SAM package (from $245 for a superior room, $275 for a suite).

FLYNN--James P.,74, of Manhasset, NY and Jupiter, FL, passed away peacefully at home surrounded by family on October 14th. Survived by his loving wife, Bonnie, children, Carol (Charles Kintzing), Diane, Barbara (James Bruderman), and James Jr. (Stephanie Flynn). Brother to Thomas, predeceased by his sister Jeanne. Grandfather to Kimberly (Szymon Rozga), Brian, James III, Mia, Maggie, Megan and Kate. He was a man of great character, quiet strength and grace, and all who had the opportunity to know and love him, are blessed to have had him in their lives. Visitation will be held Sunday from 7-9pm and Monday 3-5 and 7-9pm at Fairchild Sons, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York. A funeral mass will be held on Tuesday, October 19th at 10am at St. Mary's R.C. Church, 1300 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York. In lieu of flowers the family asks that memorial donations be made to: Jupiter Medical Center Foundation, 1210 South Old Dixie Highway, Jupiter, FL 33458 www.jmcfoundation.org in memory of James P. Flynn.

PAOLO PELLEGRIN Paolo Pellegrin is one of the pre-eminent photojournalists covering global conflicts, often mentioned in the same breath as war-zone daredevils like James Nachtwey or Ron Haviv. He has won eight World Press Photo awards and in 2007 was awarded the Robert Capa Gold Medal Award -- the closest thing photojournalists have to a Nobel Prize -- for his coverage of the war between Israel and Lebanon. (An example of his work is at far right.) Stories like ''Boldface Milan'' (Page 104) replenish Pellegrin's spirits so that he can plunge yet again into a place like the Gaza Strip. (''It's just one of those open wounds,'' he says of the smoldering Palestinian-Israeli conflict.) A Roman by birth -- ''We think of Milan as the enemy,'' he jokes -- Pellegrin splits his time between the Eternal City and New York.

Because of a transcription error, the Boss column on Sept. 26, about David Schlotterbeck of CareFusion, a medical device company, referred incorrectly to the history of Frigidaire, where he previously worked. It was once a unit of General Motors, not General Electric.

WHEN Terry Galmitz went to Avenue D looking for a candy store half-remembered from his youth, he found it was no longer there. In its place stood Sergio Deli Superette, a bodega. Since he was already there, Mr. Galmitz figured he would stay a while and draw. The result is one of the most striking images in ''My East Village,'' his portfolio of neighborhood sketches, on display at SB D Gallery on East Fourth Street through Dec. 4. In the black-inked illustrations, a group of children jump gleefully in the water of an open street hydrant, the bodega behind them, its windows plastered with lunch and lottery ticket advertisements. This quintessential image of urban summer, and its resonant sense of community, lie at the heart of Mr. Galmitz's show, a snapshot of the East Village caught between its ethnic and bohemian roots and an ever-developing future.

A report in the Sports Briefing column last Sunday about Walter Dix's victory over Tyson Gay in the 200 meters at the Prefontaine Classic was published in error. The report, written by Reuters on July 3, was inadvertently repeated by the news service and editors mistook it for breaking news.

2:37 p.m. | Updated Now that the Environmental Protection Agency has approved the limited use of E15 in newer vehicles, consumers who want to sample the higher-alcohol brew may be wondering how to get it into their vehicles.

LEAVITT--Thomas W. The Museum Advisory Council and the staff of the Herbert F. Johnson Museum of Art, Cornell University, deeply mourn the passing of Thomas W. Leavitt, our beloved director for 23 years. After receiving his doctorate from Harvard, Tom served as the first director of the Museum Program of the National Endowment for the Arts and of museums in Pasadena and Santa Barbara. During his long and productive years at Cornell (1968-1991), he helped supervise the construction of the Museum building and organized dozens of distinguished exhibitions, including a pioneering examination of Earth Art. His family and friends have lost a man of great kindness and civility.
Higher Taxes, Less Work To the Editor:

Breast cancer research is an undeniably worthy endeavor, but the container-loads of pink objects that have been sold to help pay for it aren't always what you'd call high design. Which is why the arrival of the Pink Wishbone Project is welcome news. Thanks to Suite New York, a Manhattan furniture showroom, Hans Wegner's famous Wishbone Chair, made in Denmark by Carl Hansen & Son, will be available in pink for the next year, with 20 percent of its sales going to the Breast Cancer Research Foundation. And to draw attention to the program, Barneys New York will exhibit chairs that were customized by 20 leading women designers. (A kickoff cocktail party takes place on Thursday evening at Barneys.) The designers - Sheila Bridges, Allegra Hicks, Kit Kemp, Laura Kirar, Kelly Wearstler and Bunny Williams among them - created cushions for the chairs that are, for the most part, elegant, charming, and deferential to their iconic host. But one, by the creative director Sara Rotman, (whose weekend house was the subject of a recent column in T), is a bit more - ahem - provocative. Her cushion is inspired by a Portuguese man-of-war, with luxurious tentacles (made of suede fringe), and spikes that allude to the creature's domed shape. ''I thought the idea of beautiful, alluring but ultimately powerful and dangerous things was an appropriate source of inspiration for women fighting breast cancer,'' she said. The designers' chairs will be auctioned (you can bid on them on charitybuzz), while the chairs without cushions will be available exclusively at Suite. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about a production of ''Swan Lake'' in London referred incorrectly to the cast. While the dancers who portray the swans are men, the production itself is not all male.

FLEISHER--Doris (Levey), 93, of New York City and Ocean Beach, Fire Island, September 20 in DeKalb, IL. Preceded by her husband Maurice, daughter Carol, and brother Morton (Leland). We mourn her passing and celebrate her long and healthy life. Gifts in her memory may be made to Friends of Fire Island National Seashore (www.ffins.org) or DeKalb County Hospice (dekalbcountyhospice.org).

A chart last Sunday about key races for the United States House of Representatives erroneously included a Democratic congressman from Pennsylvania among a group of freshmen. The congressman, Paul E. Kanjorski, is serving his 13th term.

THE saxophone of a Carnegie Hall veteran and trumpet of a Grammy Award-winner nimbly croon and sway to the drum-brush beat, punctuated by sharp brass notes and bass thumps so close that people in the front row see the musicians' tendons twitch. While those images might sound worthy of $150 seats at Lincoln Center, the performance is best viewed from a pew at the Sixth Street Community Synagogue, an Orthodox congregation between First and Second Avenues, home of the Ayn Sof Arkestra and Bigger Band.

NOT long ago, Eden, one of my 5-year-old twin daughters, bounded into my lap at bedtime and asked me if I would read her a book, ''Bagels From Benny.'' I had never seen this book before, nor had my wife. (I learned later it was a gift from her grandmother.) In the story, written by Aubrey Davis, Benny adores his grandfather's bagels so much he wants to thank God for them. He takes a bag of bagels to the synagogue, places them in the ark, and asks God to taste his bounty. I had not read more than a few pages when Eden looked at me and asked, ''Daddy, if I speak to God, will he listen?''

AUERBACH--Carole. Carole Auerbach passed away peacefully in her home surrounded by her husband, children and grandchildren on October 13, 2010 at the age of 79. A wonderful wife, mother, grandmother and friend, Carole was a fountain of wisdom for all those fortunate enough to be touched by her compassion and understanding. A planner, a thinker, and a doer, Carole had a fantastic sense of humor and could charm the smallest child and the most elderly amongst us with her immense creativity, sharp wit and imagination. Carole stood by "her guy" Larry for 61 years, sharing a life filled with happiness and laughter, centered on the loving family they nurtured. Carole was the perfect partner for Larry and together they built a storied career in the entertainment business and created life long friendships around the world. They were a great team that relished telling stories of a life well lived, often completing each other's sentences. Carole had the innate ability to make people feel comfortable in her presence allowing them to express themselves deeply so that many now feel as though they've lost their best friend. Carole was a great mother to her three sons, David, Bruce and Stephen. She was adored by her six grandchildren: Samantha, Alex, Zach, Katie, Chloe and Lily, and her daughter-in-law, Joy. Daughter of Lottie Rich and Edward Kleinman, Carole was born in Brooklyn, New York were she was raised along with her cousin Michael Kleinman, who she loved like a brother. There was a private service for the family at Hillside Memorial Park on Friday, October 15th. There will also be a celebration of her life at their home on Wednesday, October 27th. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made (in her name) to the American Lung Association.

ELSON--Matthew, 96, died October 11, 2010. Regarded as one of the foremost authorities on camping, Matt was Executive Director of the New Jersey "Y" Camps for 29 years and received numerous awards for outstanding work in Jewish Communal Service. He is survived by Edith, beloved wife of 64 years and children Dr. Jean Elson and Dr. Barry Elson and their spouses, also five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

I moved to Milan in 1949, when my parents left Piacenza to take advantage of the opportunities for work and advancement that Milan offered after the war. In spite of the depth of the attachment that I feel to the city in which I have built my career, I am always aware that Milan does have its shortcomings and that it lies at times in thrall to a prevailing mood of melancholy, which has perhaps altered its character and diminished its sense of optimism, its capacity to think big and retain the confidence to accomplish its ambitions. As the Italian capital of financial activity and the world capital of fashion, design and opera, Milan derives its unique strength, I believe, from its capacity to promote a continuous flow of creative ideas and harness them into successful commercial ventures. I love this city most when its sense of discipline is evident, expressed through its citizens' work ethic and ability to plan on a large scale. I also love its rational approach -- one driven by passion and generosity. (It's no coincidence that Milan is the center of the nation's charitable sector.) I hope that the optimism and the characteristic determination of the Milanese will provide a much-needed stimulus to the public sector, because the greater one's love for a city, the more one expects from it. From this perspective, Expo 2015 could be the turning point, the opportunity to boost Milan's prestige and provide the perfect arena to reassert our claim to greatness.

DRAZIEN--Sydney Martin, of Zurich, Switzerland, died on Saturday (July 31, 2010) in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. He was 75. Beloved husband of Gabriele Elisabeth Drazien (nee Kleiner); loving father of Nadja (Tristan) Pierce and Sacha (Irina) Drazien; proud grandfather of Zoe and Dylan Pierce, Melina and Louka Drazien; cherished son of the late Irving and Augusta (nee Richter) Drazien; devoted brother of Joyce (late Raymond) Parks; uncle to Michele Parks, Ronald Parks (Tom Newman), Tracy (John Paul) Salvesen; son-in-law to Gertrud Kleiner; brother-in-law to Nelly Schiendorfer; uncle to Roland (Franziska) Kunz; cousin, and friend to many. Born April 20, 1935 in Brooklyn, NY; graduated from University of Pennsylvania, Wharton 1956, member of Sigma Alpha Mu; served in the U.S. Army; career executive for Bristol Myers Squibb (Clairol) and Wella in USA, Germany, Australia and Canada. A consummate gentleman, Sydney's charisma, devotion and generosity will be remembered with gratitude and greatly missed by all. Contributions may be sent to "Dana Farber Cancer Institute (DFCI)" noting "Dr. Michael Rabin's Lung Cancer Research Tribute Sydney Drazien". Please send online www.jimmyfund.org/gift, mail: 10 Brookline Place West, 6 Fl, Brookline, MA 02445 or phone (617) 632-2903.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Twice Widowed and Now Smitten With Men in Pinstripes,'' Oct. 10: I was delighted with Jane Heller's article about her aging mother's late-blooming fascination with Yankees fandom. My 90-plus-year-old mother, Virginia Di Fazio, was also a pretty neutral baseball fan while I was following in my father's footsteps as a rabid Yankees rooter. She kept her daily New York Times subscription until her death at 95, for both the Sports pages and the crosswords.

A number of women in Paris were noticeably intent on putting together a practical solution to modern dress, stripping away embellishments for the art of simplicity. This is a necessary step since many designers are intent on the high jinks of clothes for celebrities on the red carpet, paying little attention to the needs of women competing in the modern world. For many women, the starting point was a creative white shirt. Above, the woman's haberdasher style is closely related to the tailoring of men, but there is no mistaking that these clothes were made for the bodies of women.
SEA CLIFF VICTORIAN $1,749,000

Over the years, Andersonville, a neighborhood that sits far north on the Chicago city map, has retained its mom-and-pop charms. Once a village made up primarily of Swedish immigrants, Andersonville now boasts eclectic, independently owned boutiques, cafes, bars, restaurants, bakeries and more. The area, adjacent to the Lakewood-Balmoral historic district with hundreds of preserved historic buildings, caters to families, a substantial gay population and lovers of vintage housewares and diverse and exciting cuisine. The heart of the neighborhood is North Clark Street, a business corridor by day that often bustles at night. ARI BENDERSKY

A review on Sept. 19 about William Ryan's ''Holy Thief,'' a detective thriller set in Stalinist Russia, described its hero's drinking habits incorrectly. He is often depicted drinking throughout the book; it does not take ''283 pages for us to witness the detective having a drink.''

Doris was predeceased by her beloved husband of almost 50 years, Julius Braun, and will be lovingly missed and remembered by Steve and Barbara, Patty and David; grandchildren Mylissa and Sammy, Jessica and Jeffrey, Daniel and Lauren, Robert and Alison; great-grandchildren Julia, Madison, Hayley, Mia and Ethan; and companions Lilia and Vivia. If you would like to make a contribution, please consider Joel Finkelstein Cancer Foundation. Graveside service on Sunday October 17 11am at Old Montefiore Cemetery, Queens, NY.

RAPPEL--Janet Katze, September 23, 1920 - October 7, 2010. A remarkable woman whom possessed a great sense of style, wit and verve for life. Brought up in NYC on Riverside Dr., she attended Washington Irving High School excelling in Fine Arts. Janet then began her life long career in the garment industry. Married for 56 years to Arthur Rappel, raising two fine daughters, Constance Burge and the late Patricia Keller Horgan moved to Westwood, CA in 1961. All the while with her impeccable taste maintaining a loving family, beautiful home and successful career. She leaves behind her daughter, Constance Burge; grandchildren Lauren and Austin Burge, Ted, Brett and Spencer Uniss; great-grandchildren Libby and Katy Uniss. She will be missed.
Art Randy Kennedy

For an international style capital, home to A-list designers who set the trends and dominate the news, Milan gets no respect. The fashion pack descends four times a year and complains about the weather, the traffic. They shop, pillaging the stores on Via Montenapoleone, and then they leave, in a hurry to get to Paris. Even the Italians dislike Milan. Or rather, the Italians in particular dislike it. Any native of Rome or Florence or Bologna will tell you that all people do there is work work work, that it's gray, industrial, unwelcoming, without a soul. I've heard nicer things about Cleveland. Other cities have testimonials that brand them and broadcast their charm. What better promotion for New York as the big stage for self-made success than those catchy anthems sung by Frank Sinatra and Alicia Keys? How many generations of college students have moved to Paris, epicenter of love and seduction, after seeing films by Jean-Luc Godard and Bernardo Bertolucci? But no great talents had penned an ode to Milan that caught on outside Italy, and in the great big global picture, the city seemed to lack for an identity. Until now.

For its first collaboration with the watchmakers TKO Orlogi, Henri Bendel is turning back the clock to the '90s slap band craze. Like those fun bracelets of yore, the watch's interchangeable straps come in a range of neon colors. At only $50 a pop, the watches are a wallet-friendly alternative to Balenciaga's eye-catching timepieces on the runway for spring. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

KLERMAN--Lorraine Vogel, 81, died on August 26, 2010 from complications of cancer. She was a pioneering health services researcher with particular interest in economically deprived women and children. She graduated from Hunter College High School and Cornell University and received her M.P.H and Dr. P.H. from the Harvard School of Public Health. Dr. Klerman was a Professor and Director of the Institute for Children, Youth and Family Policy at the Heller School for Social Policy and Management, Brandeis University, where in 2010 she was the recipient its Mentoring Award. In 1996, she received the American Public Health Association's Martha May Eliot Award for extraordinary health service to mothers and children. In September 2010, she was posthumously selected to receive the Title V Lifetime Achievement Award from the Maternal and Child Health Bureau. Dr. Klerman had four children, Jacob, Elizabeth, Karen and Dan, and eight grandchildren, all of whom survive her. Donations in her honor can be made to: Institute for Child, Youth and Family Policy Fund at The Heller School, Brandeis University, Office of Development, 415 South Street, MS 035, Waltham, MA 02454.

Based on the enticing Travel section article ''Tuscany Without the Crowds'' (March 7, 2010), my husband and I are planning a week in the Val d'Orcia after Christmas. The problem is: we fly into Milan the week before and don't know where to go over Christmas (we will be in Milan for several days at the end of the trip). We've never been to Venice. Any ideas? A.Since you've never visited Venice, this is the perfect opportunity to do just that. It is magical, and December/January is the off-season, when hotels are cheaper and the crowds are sparse; it is also convenient from Milan, by train or car. See my recent Q&A, ''Venice to Naples, on a Budget'' (Sept. 5, 2010), for money-saving tips and for helpful reader comments. In addition to Venice, you can also visit Padua, Vicenza and Verona, all in the Veneto region. Padua (Padova), about 32 miles from Venice, is a cultural center and home to one of the best universities in Italy; it is also known for its Giotto frescoes, and the Basilica di Sant'Antonio attracts droves of pilgrims. Vicenza (25 miles from Padua) is famous for its Renaissance-era buildings, many by the 16th-century architect Andrea Palladio. And picturesque Verona (another 32 miles) has impressive ancient Roman monuments.

To the Sports Editor: ''Favre Reaches Point of No Return'' (Oct. 12) poses some difficult truths for Vikings fans. I can speak for many of us who wanted nothing more than to have Brett Favre return this year. At the basic level, he signed a two-year contract, and we want him to see that through. There is no doubt in this fan's mind this ought to be his last season.

A report in the Big Deal column in some editions this weekend about the sale of a Gramercy Park apartment by Michael S. Rockefeller and Tara Rockefeller describes her ancestry incorrectly. She is a Rockefeller by marriage, to Michael; she is not a descendant of John D. Rockefeller. The report also misstates the relationship between her husband and Michael C. Rockefeller. Michael C. was her husband's uncle, not his father. (Rodman C. Rockefeller was his father.)

COOPER--Helen S. October 14, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Herman E. Cooper, dear mother of Kathy Sulds, Debbie Cooper, and Tom Cooper, loving grandmother of Amy, Benjamin, Michael, and Molly Sulds, Julia and Sam Sternberg, and Sam and Alex Cooper. Steve Fossett, the millionaire businessman and adventurer perhaps best known for circumnavigating the world nonstop in a hot air balloon, was preparing to break the absolute land speed record -- 763 miles per hour -- when he died. He was declared dead after the single-engine plane he was piloting disappeared over the east-central mountains of California in September 2007. (The plane and Mr. Fossett's remains were later discovered near Mammoth Lakes, Calif.) The entire land speed record project, called Target 800 M.P.H., is for sale for $3 million, according to Project 100 Communications, which is handling the sale.

Marilyn is survived by: daughter Jill (Duncan), son-in-law, William, grandchildren, Alice, Theodore, Samantha, Matthew, Joshua, Zachary and Bailey, as well as sisters, Sue (Stu) Getz, Ruth (Harvey) Geller, brother, Donald Bernstein. Services Today at 2:15pm at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, Hewlett, NY. Shiva observed October 18th/ 19th at the home of Sue Getz, 700 Shore Road, Apt. 7M, Long Beach, NY.

An article on Oct. 3 about the town of Carrara, Italy, known for its marble quarries, misstated the provenance of the block of marble that Michelangelo transformed into ''David.'' While the marble he used did indeed come from Carrara, he did not find it there. It was brought to Florence almost four decades earlier by another artist.

An article on Oct. 3 about the Italian designer Gio Ponti noted that a retrospective of his work would open on Nov. 13 at the new Triennale di Milano Museum in Manhattan. After the magazine had gone to press, a representative of the museum said the opening had been moved to early 2011.

The Italian designer Mauro Orietti-Carella believes in combining the old and the new. Several years back, he brought fresh life to Zagliani, a venerable but musty manufacturer of crocodile bags, by applying techniques he perfected in his former life in medical school, where he studied skin reconstruction -- injecting the material with silicone and resin so that its stiffness gave way to a buttery softness. (The company is preparing to open its first stand-alone store, on Madison Avenue.) Orietti-Carella has applied the same philosophy to restoring his grand apartment in Palazzo Durini-Caproni di Taliedo, a spectacular 17th-century building smack in the middle of modern Milan but redolent of 400 years of history. ''I see myself as a person taking care of these beautiful rooms while bringing them forward -- making them the way they were, but with the sensibility of the future,'' he said.

HENKIN--Louis. Human Rights First mourns the loss of Louis Henkin, a giant in the human rights movement and a founder of Human Rights First. Literally and figuratively, Lou wrote the book on human rights. No American was more instrumental in the development of human rights law. The impact he had will reverberate for generations. Our deepest sympathy goes to his wife Alice and their sons, Joshua, David, and Daniel.

An article last Sunday about the film ''Carlos,'' a psychological portrait of the international terrorist known as Carlos the Jackal, misstated the year in which Carlos and his team raided a Vienna meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. It was December 1975, not 1976.

KAYE--Marion, (nee Davis) Beloved wife, mother and sister, was born in New York City and passed away on October 7, 2010, at the age of 85. She is survived by her husband Murray, her son Robert, her daughter Judith, her brother David, and by her cousins, nieces, and nephew. She lived her life enthusiastically, and loved and supported her children unconditionally. She was rewarded and fulfilled by her family, her career, her love of reading and culture, and by her many other interests. She returned to school later in life and received a Master of Arts Degree from John Jay College of Criminal Justice. She worked as a Nassau County Probation Officer for 23 years, until her retirement at the age of 75. She was a long-term member and contributor to several philanthropic and social organizations. She was a woman of exceptional beauty, not only physically, but also in her heart and actions. She was kind and wise. She was vivacious, adventurous, and funny. She was brave and always hopeful. She was special. She was our rock to lean on, our compass in life, our confidant and our best friend. She was deeply loved and cherished, and will be deeply missed, always and forever. Funeral services were held at Gutterman's in Woodbury, NY, and she was laid to rest at Mount Lebanon Cemetery in Glendale, NY. Donations in her memory may be sent to the First Roumanian-American Congregation, 89 Rivington Street, New York, NY 10002, and/or the Hebrew Free Burial Assn, 224 W. 35th St, #

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Mantle Biography Delves Into Traumas and Myths,'' Oct. 13: How can Richard Sandomir possibly characterize Mickey Mantle's baseball career as one of ''unfulfilled promise''? Mantle led the Yankees to 12 American League pennants and 7 World Series titles. He won three Most Valuable Player awards, with a Triple Crown in 1956. When he retired in 1968, only two players had more career home runs than he did: Babe Ruth and Willie Mays.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about foreign buyers investing in New York real estate misstated the name of the firm that designed the Centurion in Midtown Manhattan, where a businessman from Mexico City bought a one-bedroom apartment. It is Pei Partnership Architects, not Pei Partnership Associates with I. M. Pei.

8 P.M. (13, 49) ECHO: AN ELEPHANT TO REMEMBER Echo, above, the matriarch of an extended clan in Amboseli National Park in Kenya, was the most studied elephant in the world. The subject of several books and documentaries, her life was also documented by Cynthia Moss, an expert in elephant behavior, and the filmmaker Martyn Colbeck across four decades. In May 2009 Echo died of natural causes at 65, leaving her family to face the worst drought ever recorded in Amboseli without her -- and leaving researchers to wonder whether Echo had taught her brood all they would need to know to survive. This ''Nature'' episode reflects on Echo's lingering legacy through archival footage of her maternal instincts at work and at play, as well as the recollections of those who watched over her. 10 A.M. In another segment, Maria Shriver discusses ''A Woman's Nation Takes on Alzheimer's,'' part of a network-wide focus on the disease.

SHERMAN--Saul "Sollie", 93, passed away peacefully at his home on October 10, 2010. Saul was born September 25, 1917 on the west side of Chicago. Saul was an All American football player and went on to play with the Bears. Saul was drafted to the Bears in 1939 to help implement the T-Formation which he learned in college under Clark Shaughnessy. Saul played two seasons before going to work for his family and played on the 1940 championship team along with Sid Luckman that beat the Redskins 73-0. Saul went on to achieve many successes in business and life after but always loved to tell stories of his days at QB and how his coach and mentor helped him out after he tore his meniscus in college. Saul would say that luck was his skill and that the greatest gift we can give is human compassion. Saul is survived by two children, four grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Saul was a kind, generous and remarkably skilled man. He will be missed dearly.
WEISS--Doris T. 10/16/30-10/16/2010 In my heart always. Your daughter, Wendy
Black corsets, big hair, luscious lips: Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana have a firm belief in what makes an italian beauty -- even if she's from Utah.

Margareth Madè has had two roles to date, one in an epic by the director of ''Cinema Paradiso'' and the other playing Sophia Loren. Not bad for a Sicilian girl who felt like E.T. until she moved to Milan to model. Growing up, she gorged herself on Nonna's pasta as well as on old Hollywood films -- ''Wilder, Hitchcock, Cukor,'' Madè says dreamily. When she goes home, her mother still tells her, ''Mangia! Mangia! You are too skinny!'' Madè says this is what she loves about Italy: ''This affection, the presence of your roots. Knowing where we come from allows us to move forward.'' CHRISTINE MUHLKE

LAURINBURG, N.C. -- A flood of black voters in North Carolina's Eighth Congressional District two years ago helped Barack Obama become the first Democratic presidential candidate to carry this state since Jimmy Carter and lifted the party's Congressional challenger, Larry Kissell, to victory. Without Mr. Obama atop the ticket this year, Mr. Kissell and a number of other vulnerable Democrats, mostly in the rural South, face the challenge of reviving the spirit of 2008 for black voters without alienating right-leaning white majorities in their districts.

The Federal Reserve has yet to act, but officials in Europe and Russia are already complaining about the prospect of a much weaker dollar. More Fed intervention could ultimately do the global economy good -- especially if it gets China to stop cheapening its currency and squeezing out the rest of the world's exports. A lot of countries are hurting. Very few, except the United States, are speaking out. Some governments are instead choosing to manipulate their own currencies.

''Photography is relevant because it sits at the axis of true, false and fake,'' said Massimo Torrigiani, the Milan-based publisher and editor-at-large behind the year-old magazine Fantom. The English-language quarterly, which is edited by Cay Sophie Rabinowitz and Selva Barni, explores ''the uses and abuses'' of photography -- artistic, commercial, scientific, etc. -- with essays, interviews between photographers and picks from curators and gallery owners. Fantom is riding two trends that Torrigiani finds exciting: the return of intellectual debate in the art world and the emergence of cool independent magazines in Milan like Apartamento and Mousse. And, of course, it makes debate look great. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

An answer in the Q&A column on Sept. 26 suggesting activities for a father traveling with his 15-year-old son from Buenos Aires to Cambridge, Mass., in the first week of November gave one suggestion in error. The Major League Baseball season typically does not last through the first week of November, so attending a Red Sox game in Boston would have been difficult, even if Boston had made the playoffs this season. Had the Red Sox played in the World Series and extended it to the fifth game, they would likely have played at Fenway Park on Nov. 1, pleasing two Argentine visitors but not many Yankees fans.
Film Stephen Holden

SHANGHAI -- A coal mine explosion in central China early Saturday killed 26 workers and trapped 11 others underground, China's state-run news media said. The accident is the latest tragedy to hit this nation's mining industry.

HANDCRAFTED in Europe and so unconsciously self-conscious, Stubbs & Wootton slippers have attained a cultlike following among the nouveau preppy set. Not surprisingly, when Lisa Birnbach was working on ''True Prep: It's a Whole New Old World,'' the recent digital-era update of ''The Official Preppy Handbook,'' she had Stubbs & Wootton create a pair of gray flannel shoes ($425) to be featured inside. If you needed more proof of the company's being synonymous with entitled glamour, the embroidered Scotch terrier that appears on the shoes' vamp also snagged the book's cover. EDWARD BARSAMIAN

A report in the Big Deal column last Sunday about two apartments at 907 Fifth Avenue owned by the heiress Huguette M. Clark misidentified the news organization that first described unusual details of Ms. Clark's life. It was MSNBC.com, not MSNBC. (They are separate companies.)
Dance Jack Anderson

The biggest surprise about Milan's galleries is how few Italian artists show there. Scattered about town or gathered in a few clusters, they wield enough international clout to make up for the time it takes to travel between them. Most ambitious is the Naples-based Lia Rumma's new temple to minimalist cool (1) at Via Stilicone, 19. One of the largest commercial galleries in Europe, it opened last May and has attracted a fashionable clientele. Its triple-height space, designed by CLS Architetti, easily accommodates anything the artists on its blue-chip roster (Marina Abramovic, Andreas Gursky, Anselm Kiefer, Ettore Spalleti, Vanessa Beecroft) can think up. Trust the Giò Marconi gallery (2), Via Alessandro Tadino, 15, for more cutting-edge excitement from artists like Nathalie Djurberg, Annette Kelm and Matthew Brannon, who get the run of two exhibition rooms and an underground lair. For a more historical view (for example, on Arte Povera artists), go upstairs to the Marconi Foundation, founded by the gallery patriarch Giorgio Marconi.

The notion of playing professional soccer until age 38 hardly seemed plausible to Brian McBride. ''Someone asked me how long I was thinking of playing when I was 30 and I said that 35 would be awesome,'' said McBride, who is retiring from Major League Soccer at the end of the season. ''To make it this long has been a good surprise.''

Once a design consultant for Etro and Missoni and the creator of her own high-end knitwear line, Uberta Zambeletti personifies both Milan's scrappy entrepreneurial side and its affinity for bourgeois, slightly bohemian luxe. Now she is channeling her finely edited high-low sensibility at Wait and See, the boutique she just opened in a former convent near the Duomo. ''Milan is so full of brands, but it's either cute little dresses or Balenciaga, with no in-between,'' she says. ''You should be able to get a great, affordable dress without having to go to Zara.'' Wait and See carries jeans, sparkly platform shoes, organic potpourri and evening wear, with prices ranging from about $3 to $1,300. Among Zambeletti's favorites: Sandrina Fasoli's cocktail dresses, Owen Barry's sheepskin coats, Isaac Reina's leather and silicone handbags and the American label Hazel Brown's soft leather pants. ''Everything has a bit of an edge to it,'' she says, ''but nothing is too extreme.'' Via Santa Marta 14; 011-39-02-7208-0195; waitandsee.it. JACKIE COOPERMAN D

To the Sports Editor: Re ''DNA Testing of Prospects Continues Under New Rules,'' Oct. 10: Baseball's continued use of genetic testing to determine the age of future prospects reveals fundamental shortcomings in the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act. Employers are forbidden to request genetic tests, but Major League Baseball's ostensibly testing for paternity and maternity may be safely outside the scope of the law.

DRAZIEN--Sydney Martin, of Zurich, Switzerland, died on Saturday (July 31, 2010) in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. He was 75. Beloved husband of Gabriele Elisabeth Drazien (nee Kleiner); loving father of Nadja (Tristan) Pierce and Sacha (Irina) Drazien; proud grandfather of Zoe and Dylan Pierce, Melina and Louka Drazien; cherished son of the late Irving and Augusta (nee Richter) Drazien; devoted brother of Joyce (late Raymond) Parks; uncle to Michele Parks, Ronald Parks (Tom Newman), Tracy (John Paul) Salvesen; son-in-law to Gertrud Kleiner; brother-in-law to Nelly Schiendorfer; uncle to Roland (Franziska) Kunz; cousin, and friend to many. Born April 20, 1935 in Brooklyn, NY; graduated from University of Pennsylvania, Wharton 1956, member of Sigma Alpha Mu; served in the U.S. Army; career executive for Bristol Myers Squibb (Clairol) and Wella in USA, Germany, Australia and Canada. A consummate gentleman, Sydney's charisma, devotion and generosity will be remembered with gratitude and greatly missed by all. Contributions may be sent to "Dana Farber Cancer Institute (DFCI)" noting "Dr. Michael Rabin's Lung Cancer Research Tribute Sydney Drazien". Please send online www.jimmyfund.org/gift, mail: 10 Brookline Place West, 6 Fl, Brookline, MA 02445 or phone (617) 632-2903.

Long before Milledgeville, Ga., became the center of the Pittsburgh Steelers' off-season universe, the team had begun the move to a more run-based offense. Within days after the Steelers failed to make the playoffs as the defending Super Bowl champions last season, the team president Art Rooney II talked to Coach Mike Tomlin about reverting to a style that looked more like the Steelers teams of the 1970s and less like the pass-happy version that had emerged in recent years. Last season, the Steelers ran the ball 42 percent of the time and quarterback Ben Roethlisberger attempted 506 passes. Roethlisberger, right, returns from his four-game suspension against Cleveland on Sunday to a decidedly different team from the one he last led. Relying on a run-first attack (the Steelers have run 57.7 percent of the time in their first four games) and a suffocating defense, Pittsburgh was far more successful managing without him than almost anyone expected.

Two properties in south Florida -- one new, the other reopening after an extensive renovation - are the latest entrants in the growing field of gay hotels and resorts. And while one is emphasizing large-scale luxury and the other boutique comfort, they both have the same goal: to be a place for gay tourists and locals to feel comfortable and welcome. ''I guess I was in the right place at the right time,'' said Richard Gray, who first opened the Royal Palms Resort and Spa (2901 Terramar Street, Fort Lauderdale; 954-564-6444; royalpalms.com; rates start at $159) in Fort Lauderale in 1991. The resort is reopening in January after an $8 million renovation and expansion. At the beginning, he added, ''there were no upscale accommodations for gay travelers in Fort Lauderdale, period.'' The spot soon became a staple.
Open House The spaces of Judy Chicago and Madhur Jaffrey in a slide show at nytimes.com/magazine. Favorite Spaces

When did Italian design take over the world? Suddenly, it's everywhere: in hotels from Milan (of course) to Tokyo; in shops, restaurants and airport lounges; and even at The New York Times, where cutting-edge Italian furniture can be found throughout the building. At a time in which design has become more international than ever -- provocateurs from the Netherlands, Japan and Brazil are just a few of the players who've shared the field in the last decade -- Italy's reach is global. And when you say ''Italy,'' you really mean ''Milan.'' It's the country's design capital, the place where every aspiring young designer heads in hopes of becoming a powerhouse. Italian design has many legendary, influential figures, like Alessandro Mendini and Michele De Lucchi, not to mention the firmament of departed greats like Joe Colombo, Marco Zanuso, Achille Castiglioni, Vico Magistretti and Ettore Sottsass. But among the most powerful designers in Milan today are three mega-successful people -- Antonio Citterio, Piero Lissoni and Patricia Urquiola, a Spanish protégée of both Castiglioni and Magistretti who set up shop in Milan in 2001.
CHELSEA CO-OP $1,395,000

Milan's annual design week, Salone Internazionale del Mobile, turns 50 next April. As part of the global run-up to the festivities, New York will host ''I Saloni Milano in New York,'' a six-week program starting Nov. 29 that will bring a taste of the design world's reigning extravaganza to Manhattan. It's a mini-Salone, in which 20 Italian furniture showrooms (including B&B Italia, Flos and Poltrona Frau) will host ''Italian Christmas'' exhibitions; the director Peter Greenaway's Milan-centric video installation, ''Leonardo's Last Supper: A Vision'' (right), which was seen at the Salone in 2008, will take over the Park Avenue Armory; and the theater visionary Robert Wilson will create video portraits of Roberto Bolle, who dances at La Scala, interacting with an assortment of iconic design objects (Nov. 30 through Dec. 18 at Center 548, by invitation only). Design has always been close to Wilson's heart. ''When I was 8 years old,'' he says, ''in the middle of the night I took all the plates and glasses out of the kitchen closet and put them back in the shelves in a designed order.'' Perfetto. MARK ROZZO

After taking a second look at its policy, the Mountain West Conference is barring employees or alumni of host teams from serving in the instant replay booth at games. The decision came after Brigham Young's J. J. Di Luigi appeared to fumble against San Diego State last week. Despite video evidence, the initial ruling that there was no fumble was upheld. The Cougars scored five plays later and won, 24-21. The San Diego Union-Tribune reported that one of the three men in the replay booth was a B.Y.U. employee. The league suspended all three for one game. CONNOR ENNIS

Federico Marchetti likes to compare himself to Caronte, the boatman who leads Dante into the underworld. He's joking -- sort of. Since June 2000, when he founded Yoox.com, the online merchant of discounted high-end clothes and accessories, Marchetti has been helping fashion labels navigate the Internet's murky waters. ''The Caronte is like a bridge between two worlds,'' says Marchetti, sitting in the duplex apartment that he shares with his girlfriend across from the Teatro dal Verme in the Magenta area of Milan. ''In my case, it's bringing together fashion and online, two worlds that were so distant from one another 10 years ago and are now closer than ever.''

'Wait,'' Maurizio Cattelan says in his low, conspiratorial, Italian-accented voice. ''I have something for you.'' It's a warm July evening, and I am walking along the Hudson with the art world's most famous prankster, so I feel a double twinge of apprehension and curiosity when he reaches into the cotton bag at his side. Out comes a strange object: a life-size orange hand from which all the fingers except the erect middle one have been broken off. Obscene, goofy and eye-catching, the one-fingered hand looks like a cross between a gag-store novelty and a sex toy. To anyone else, it might well be a joke. To Cattelan, it's something entirely serious: a prototype for his next sculpture, which is to say, his next test of the public's equanimity. Cattelan passes the hand to me, and we continue strolling, talking about his plans. This being New York, pedestrians and joggers studiously avoid glancing at us, two men contemplating a rude, inexplicable object. A couple of months later in Milan, if everything went as planned, there would be no ignoring Cattelan's hand -- or rather a giant marble version of it, standing on a travertine pedestal 20 feet tall, right in front of the Stock Exchange. Cattelan's colossal highway salute has a wry title, ''L.O.V.E.,'' but by midsummer the Milanese, reading about the proposal in the local media, had already begun referring to it simply as ''Dito Medio,'' the middle finger. Inevitably, it would be a gift to the artist's critics, who are apt to dismiss his works as one-liners. The hand's broken fingers, though, hint that things are more complicated. Imagine them back in place, and the gesture becomes a different kind of provocation: a vandalized Fascist salute. Whether spectators see a sly political allusion or simply an icon of good-natured irreverence, the one-fingered hand would be a grand, brazen, unforgettable gesture.

In Milan, the term ''young designer'' is relative -- only one on our list is under 30. The time served on fashion's fringes could be one of the reasons this group is producing such sophisticated fare. These designers share in Italian fashion's sweet spot: microscopic detail, intrepid cutting and a preference for nothing-but-the-best, homegrown fabrics. J. J. MARTIN Cabriele Colangelo

Biffi and Banner In a city known for its mega-brands, Rosy Biffi's stores are a breath of fresh fashion air. Dedicated to new talent and cutting-edge labels, she fills both Biffi and Banner with limited-editions and experimental pieces. ''Research, passion, uniqueness and instinct are the backbone of our business,'' she says. Go to biffi.com. SANDRA BALLENTINE 1. Biffi admires the work of the Milanese designer Gianluca Capannolo.''I like his style -- it's so fresh and young,'' she says. ''This trapeze dress would look chic with a ballerina flat or ironic with a tough-looking ankle boot.'' It's about $920.

LONG before gas-guzzling Western capitals implemented safer bike lanes and invested in bike-for-hire schemes, Adam McDermott and Chad Kushner, the founders of Linus Bikes, spent years traveling the world's bicycle-centric cities. ''We loved the simple, utilitarian bikes we'd find in other countries,'' Mr. McDermott said, ''and wished there was a similar bike-as-transportation culture back home.'' Inspired by the elegant but basic designs of French city bikes of the '50s and '60s, Linus achieves the aesthetic of a modern vintage cycle (above): straight, clean lines, monochromatic colors and no excessive logos. The new bicycle carryalls, crafted from wax canvas, oilskin leather and solid brass hardware designed to age nicely, are saddle bags you want. MARCUS CHANG

My husband and I are professors and hope to take a two-week international trip in mid-December or early January. We're interested in one that will involve archaeological ruins, interesting cultural experiences and intense natural beauty. The places we've discussed so far are Turkey, Peru, Morocco and Vietnam/Cambodia.E. S., Burlington, Vt. A.Any of the countries you mention would be fine choices that would satisfy your particular needs, so let's pick one: Morocco, which offers archaeological ruins, a rich culture and natural beauty. Fly to Marrakesh, an alluring city with a fascinating blend of cultures. Marrakesh's main attractions lie within the salmon-pink walls of its ancient medina. Wander around the maze of alleyways, and explore souks filled with stalls that sell all manner of goods, including spices, kitchenware and textiles. Then make your way to Ben Youssef Medersa (above), a 16th-century Koranic school adorned with dazzling mosaics, intricate cedar panels and religious verses carved in white plaster. After sunset, head to one of North Africa's most famous markets, Djemaa el Fna, a huge, open square that comes alive at night with food stalls and entertainment like musical performances and snake-charming.

OF course I want my husband to have good health and a long life, but it took me seven years to give up food and water in hopes of it. Every autumn, many women -- particularly those from northern India -- observe Karwa Chauth, a daylong Hindu fast on behalf of their husbands' prosperity. It falls on Oct. 25 this year.

PHILADELPHIA - The Mets and closer Francisco Rodriguez have adjourned their grievance hearing scheduled for Monday and are negotiating a settlement to their contract dispute, a team spokesman said. The Mets withheld about $3 million that was remaining on Rodriguez's contract after he sustained a season-ending thumb injury during an altercation with his children's grandfather Aug. 11 at Citi Field. Rodriguez was arrested and charged with assault, harassment and criminal contempt and has a hearing scheduled at Queens Criminal Court on Nov. 10. The Mets, contending that Rodriguez was unavailable to perform his duties because of an off-the-field incident for which he was arrested, placed him on the disqualified list and said they did not owe him the remainder of his salary for 2010. They also said they were unilaterally converting his contract to a non-guaranteed contract, which would essentially mean they could cut him anytime and not pay him the remainder of his salary. Rodriguez and the players association filed a grievance, and it was scheduled to be heard by the arbitrator Shyam Das. The New York Post reported that the sides were close to an agreement in which the Mets would not pay the remaining $3 million for time missed in 2010, but the contract would remain guaranteed, which is the association's primary concern. The tricky part for the Mets will be to find a way to avoid paying Rodriguez the $17.5 million option he has for 2012. The option vests if Rodriguez finishes 55 games in 2011. If Rodriguez is convicted of all charges, he could face up to two years in prison, which could solve the problem. Rodriguez, who is set to make $11.5 million next year, finished 46 games in 2010 before he was shut down after his final appearance Aug. 14. After that game, Rodriguez told the Mets' medical staff he injured his thumb during the altercation. He was found to have a torn ligament in his thumb that required surgery. In addition to the assault and harassment charges, Rodriguez was later charged with criminal harassment after prosecutors produced text messages he sent to the mother of his children after he was ordered by the court not to contact her or her father following the initial charges. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Germano Celant, the writer and curator who coined the term ''Arte Povera'' nevertheless lives in a Milan home rich in artistic and architectural touches. 1. The minimalism of Germano Celant's concrete front steps -- a nod to Carlo Scarpa, sometimes called ''the Frank Lloyd Wright of Italy'' -- sets the stage for the gallerylike spaces within. To soften the building's linearity, voluptuous shrubs frame the doorway. A bamboo jungle by the hot Italian landscape architect Anna Scaravella ''affords great privacy,'' Celant says. It certainly beats putting up an electrified fence.

For the past week I've been in Beijing, my first trip to China. Except for the city's famous traffic jams, the city is nothing like I had expected. And what did I expect of this remarkable, sprawling, fast-changing city? Today - Friday in Beijing - I had lunch with Angelica Cheung, the editor in chief of Vogue China, at the China Grill on the 66th floor of the Park Hyatt, and since I arrived at the restaurant a few minutes early, I took a moment to press my nose to the windows. The sprawl of new buildings - skyscrapers, hotels, apartment blocks - is almost unfathomable and seemingly endless. In front of me was the CCTV building, by Rem Koolhaas, with its twin cantilevered towers. A second building on the site caught fire during the New Year's celebration and burned, leaving a charred hulk, and the area around the complex is still under construction. Still, the dazzling architecture reminds you that you're looking at a new world. My eyes kept coming back to the Koolhaas building.

ESCAPE VELOCITY As the founder of the Tod's luxury group, Diego Della Valle is one of Italy's most visible businessmen, with holdings that also include a newspaper, a bank, a soccer team and the film studio Cinecittà. But Della Valle, whose private jet bears an insignia with the initials D.D.D., which stand for ''dignità, dovere, divertimento'' (dignity, duty, fun), knows from unwinding. ''It's true, I work hard and play hard,'' he says. ''When I started about 35 years ago, it was definitely my motto. Now that I am older, playing hard means having as much free time as possible to do simple things like seeing family, watching a movie, playing tennis and just having time to think.'' Della Valle divides his time between Milan and his hometown of Sant'Elpidio a Mare, and when he's not aboard his Falcon jet (he clocks in more than 400 hours per year), he likes to escape to Capri on his yacht. ''Capri is like my second home,'' he says. ''The flowers, the food, the views -- everything is fantastic. I like to sail to a private place to avoid the madness. For me, it's not easy in Italy to lead a private life.''

According to Paola Bay, who designs Zoraide, a line of handmade shoes coveted by the cobbler cognoscenti, the elegant Milanese woman has a beauty regimen that mixes tried-and-true with up-to-the-minute. SANDRA BALLENTINE 1 Bay works out at Caroli Health Club, one of Milan's most exclusive gyms. ''It's never full, and most of the people who go there are fit without being too pumped-up,'' she says. ''Fabio, my personal Pilates trainer, is wonderful, and knows immediately if I am ready for a heavy session.'' 2 The designer buys handmade combs, brushes and manicure scissors at G. Lorenzi, Via Montenapoleone, 9; lorenzi.it. 3 She calls Dr. Annabella Campiotti ''the most amazing Milanese secret.'' Campiotti's patients include many of Italy's most famous fashion designers (and George Clooney, when he's in town). Known for using vitamin drips, supplements and the latest lasers, she can be reached at hmc.milano@hospitadella.it. 4 When it comes to extreme pampering, Bay says there's no better place than the spa at the Bulgari Hotel, Via Privata Fratelli Gabba, 7/b; bulgarihotels.com. 5 Milanese families have relied on the remedies at Farmacia Comotti for generations. ''I use their calendula cream for dry skin and canfosalicilica [shown here] for muscle pain.'' Piazza Cavour, 5. 6 Another classic: the 106-year-old Antica Barbieria Colla, where Bay had her hair cut as a child. ''It's a typical Milanese place nestled amid aristocratic palaces on a side street near La Scala,'' she says. ''Luchino Visconti and Luigi Pirandello used to go there.'' Via Gerolamo Morone, 3.
