GOLDSMITH--John Frank, on October 14, age 92, beloved husband of the late Caroline Steinholz Lerner and longtime resident of New York City and Chappaqua, NY. Father of Katherine Paradise of Boston, Elizabeth Hilton of Fairfax, CA, and John Goldsmith Jr. of Plainfield, IL, stepfather of David Lerner, grandfather of Alisse Wissman, Chris Goldsmith and Alex Hilton, and brother-in-law of Elizabeth Goldsmith. Survived also by dear friend Margot Tallmer. Graduated from Bronxville high school in 1936, attended Bard College for two years, and graduated from University of Colorado in 1940. In World War II, led an infantry platoon in Italy and France; wounded out of action and awarded a purple heart; subsequently assigned to stevedore battalion and eventually stationed 12 miles from Hiroshima. Long and successful writing and editorial career -- chief editor of Housing magazine (fka House & Home), managing editor of Fleet Owner, and on staff of Factory magazine. Caring and committed family man, steadfast friend, and passionate supporter of liberal and humanitarian values. We will miss your grit, your intense loyalty, your deep convictions, your physical determination, your love of words and ideas, and your commitment to making the world a better place. In lieu of flowers, donations in John's name to Center for Victims of Torture, www.cvt.org or 1-877-265-8775.

FFOLLIOTT--Peter Harvie, of Boca Grande, FL, died peacefully on October 14, 2010, at age 97. He was born on April 15, 1913, in Everett, Washington, a son of the late Frederick Kerr Ffolliott and Ella Lyons Harvie Ffolliott. He was graduated from the St. Paul Academy in 1933 and Dartmouth College in 1937 and served in the US Navy during World War II, attaining the rank of Lieutenant Commander. He was an enthusiastic amateur drummer and the author of two self-published memoirs, What Your Daddy Did in the War and An' Pore Little Peter. He was predeceased by two brothers and two sisters and his wife of 63 years, Gertrude Boeckmann Ffolliott, all of whom lived into their 90s. He is survived by five children: Gertrude Hill (Terry) Ffolliott, Sheila Ffolliott, Mary Boeckmann (Sissy) Ffolliott, Peter Harvie Ffolliott, Jr., and Ann Gavin Ffolliott; four granddaughters, Rachel Anne Ffolliott, Erica Rose Ffolliott, Kerry Krech Morrison, and Teal Krech Paynter, six great-granddaughters, and many nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Dartmouth College, 6066 Development Office, Hanover, NH 03755, or the Boca Grande Health Clinic Foundation, 280 Park Ave., Boca Grande, FL 33921.
Television Neil Genzlinger

Benoît B. Mandelbrot, a maverick mathematician who developed the field of fractal geometry and applied it to physics, biology, finance and many other fields, died on Thursday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 85. The cause was pancreatic cancer, his wife, Aliette, said. He had lived in Cambridge.

1. You have your own knife at Controvapore. 2. You get invited to Rossana Orlandi's design space on a Sunday for her off-hours, friends-only salons. 3. You order a made-to-measure bicycle at Cicli&Co. 4. You use the side entrance at Zucca and drink standing. 5. You borrow a toddler to get access to the Giardini di Villa Reale. 6. Carlo Cracco, Fabio Novembre, Matteo Marzotto and 37 other bigwigs invite you to join, Milan's first urban cheerleading team. 7. You never actually have to order breakfast -- your neighborhood barman just knows. 8. It turns out your tailor works at Versace. 9. You're never turned away for a garden table at the Bulgari Hotel. 10. You spend hot nights at the Anteo Spazio Cinema: dubbed movies and the best A/C in town. 11. Giorgio Armani gets up to greet you at your table at Armani/Nobu. 12. You have a charge -- and delivery -- account at Peck. 13. You learn to park on the sidewalk. 14. You are never in the city on a weekend, a bank holiday or during the month of August. 15. Barring emergencies, you never, ever fly out of Malpensa. 16. The metal detector goes off at Linate and the security guards wave you through anyway. 17. You can tell just by looking if the pizza crust, cappuccino froth or mozzarella ball is off the mark. 18. You don't order fish on Monday. 19. You realize you can negotiate for a discount in any retail store. 20. You know the magic words for the doorman at Plastic: ''Stefano Gabbana.'' J. J. MARTIN

LIBEN--Diana, 92, died at home on August 18, of pancreatic cancer. Her generous heart, fierce intelligence, progressive spirit, and marvelous meals are already deeply missed. A great storyteller and dedicated BMCC professor, she is survived by daughters Laura and Lucy, brother Harry Merliss, daughters-in-law Marie and Sallie, grandson Max, and many nieces and nephews. Predeceased by husband Meyer, son Ned, and sisters Gerry Katz and Raya Glinert. Memorial service on November 21, 3 pm at New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St., NYC.

Ravens (4-1) at Patriots (3-1)Sunday, 1 p.m.Line: Patriots by 3 The Ravens returned to their roots last Sunday, bringing back the retro-chic dive-and-bomb offense that helped them reach the playoffs in 2008 and 2009. The scheme is football comfort food: fullback plunges and mashed potatoes in an N.F.L. world dominated by spread-shotgun fusion cuisine. The Ravens kept it simple last year, rushing for 234 yards in a 33-14 win against the Patriots. Ray Rice missed practice with a sore knee this week, but he's expected to play, so the Ravens' offense should remain nice and starchy.

Football fans who have to travel on Sundays have a reason to rejoice: it's now possible to watch live professional football at 30,000 feet above ground. JetBlue is the first commercial airline to offer DirecTV's NFL Sunday Ticket, which broadcasts up to 14 games played that day. The package, typically available to DirecTV subscribers, is available - free - for passengers flying to more than 50 JetBlue destinations.

ROSENBAUM--Linda, 63, died on September 23 of complications from a stem cell transplant. Linda was a brilliant woman, a compassionate person, and an empathetic, loving and much loved friend. She is missed every day.

THE NEWS The Obama administration lifted its moratorium on deepwater oil and gas drilling, imposed after a blown-out BP well spilled millions of gallons of crude into the Gulf of Mexico in the spring and summer. BEHIND THE NEWS The ban was set to expire Nov. 30, but the administration was under heavy pressure to relax it early because of the economic harm done by idling drill rigs and crews. It will still be weeks before deepwater drilling can resume, though, because rig operators must reapply for drilling permits under newly toughened safety and environmental rules.

An article on Oct. 3 about the decrease in the square footage of residential projects misstated the surname of an architect who said that his clients are going smaller for economic and ecological reasons. He is Stuart Hills, not Hill.

WEINTRAUB--Leonard, prominent attorney, active community leader, veteran of the Normandy invasion, restauranteur, wine and gardening enthusiast, and loving patriarch of his family, died on October 14 at 92. A resident of Port Washington for over 60 years, he was a founder of the Community Synagogue in Sands Point, which was launched through a decision he won in the NYS Appellate Court. He set legal precedent again in 1975 with a landmark decision permitting a group home in a residential community. Survived by his beloved wife of 20 years, Lillian McCormick, his daughters from his cherished, predeceased wife, Leah, Abby Dress and Jane Holly Weintraub, their husbands Frederick Dress and Stephen Bennett, granddaughters Kara Dress, Casey Dress and husband Dana Carey, and Arianne Bennett, great-grandson Dylan, and Lillian's sons Michael, Bradley and Billy and her eight grandchildren. Services will be held Monday at 10am at the Community Synagogue, 160 Middle Neck Road, Sands Point. Contributions can be made to Family and Children's Association, Landmark on Main Street, and Women on the Job.

It may not be as beautiful as Florence or as ancient as Rome, but Milan is Italy's mecca for business, fashion and design. Just as its grandest houses and gardens are concealed from view behind discreet facades, Milan takes some getting to know, so that once you've done the Duomo and marveled at Leonardo's ''Last Supper,'' you can shop, eat and down espresso like the locals. FLYING on my bicycle down the dotted line between lanes on Park Avenue, I had a decision to make. I could follow Dave Jordan as he rode between rows of slow-moving traffic. That would mean bobbing and ducking around rearview mirrors that jutted out from vans like reflective baseball gloves to catch any passing helmeted head. Or I could slow down and go with the flow of traffic. It is the kind of decision confronted less often by the city's riders in today's bike-lane era, where green swaths of cyclist-only pavement knit neighborhoods together for even the most cautious of two-wheeled beginners.

Robert is survived by his life partner, Ron Banyay; sister Mary Walsh (Jim) of West Chester, PA; and brother, Joseph Fontana (Jeff Davis) of Ft. Lauderdale, FL. The family will greet relatives and friends from 24pm on Sunday, October 24 at his residence. On-line condolences may be made at elcollinsfuneralhome.com.

Bernie Williams, a four-time World Series winner with the Yankees, is now a guitarist with another nine-man team, a jazz band. Informally known as Bernie Williams and the All-Star Band, the group will appear on Oct. 23 at the Lafayette Theater in Suffern, N.Y. Williams, 42, is also a spokesman for the Priceless NYC Reserved by MasterCard, a program that offers items like Yankees playoff tickets to cardholders. Q.Are you enjoying retirement? A.Actually, I'm enjoying it a lot. I retired from baseball but not from life. The last two years our band has been playing all over the country. It's a very lively, jazzy, high-energy band that plays mostly original music.

''They never owned up to all the problems leading tohe mortgage crisis.'' Sheila C. Bair, chairwoman othe Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, on the mortgage industry. Last week, all 50 state attorneys general said they would investigate foreclosure practices. The system has been faulted for losing documents and other sloppy work.

An article last Sunday about Pamela Geller, a blogger who attacks Islam, misidentified the location of a beach from which she video-blogged about her visit to Israel during the Israel-Hezbollah war in 2006. She was in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., at the time of her reports, not at a beach in Israel. The article also overstated the number of monthly unique visitors to Ms. Geller's Web site, Atlas Shrugs. The site attracts 194,000 such visitors, according to Quantcast statistics -- not one million. (The Nielsen Company estimated 184,000 in September.) And because of an editing error, the article misspelled the surname of the lead singer of the Who whom Ms. Geller was likened to for being the ''front man'' in the attack on Islam. He is Roger Daltrey, not Daltry.

It is O.K. to take photos while standing in public spaces near federal buildings, after all. In a settlement with the New York Civil Liberties Union reached Monday, the federal government agreed to instruct its employees in writing of the "public's general right to photograph the exterior of federal courthouses from publicly accessible spaces" and to remind them that "there are currently no general security regulations prohibiting exterior photography by individuals from publicly accessible spaces, absent a written local rule, regulation or order."

On Monday, I wrote an article about the competition between the iPhone from Apple and smartphones running the Android operating system from Google. The article discussed some of the advantages and disadvantages of Apple's vertically integrated and closed approach and Android's more open strategy. It concluded by quoting experts and analysts saying that while Android, and perhaps other systems, are likely to do well, Apple has little reason to worry.

The outpouring of passionate, learned and thoughtful comments in response to my column about the demise of French, Italian, Russian, classics and theater at SUNY Albany is a testimony to the hold the idea of the humanities has on so many in our society. The respondents make a number of points, but two are made repeatedly: (1) The humanities not only pay for themselves but help fund the sciences and (2) I dismiss traditional justifications of the humanities - the transmission of the best that has been thought and said, the humanities enhance society, and so on; you could recite them in your sleep - but I myself either have nothing to offer or end by offering a weak version of what I have dismissed.

"Dexter'' has always been a series that gains more and more momentum as the season progresses, and this one is no exception. Sunday's episode set off a psychologically intriguing battle between Dexter and the tortured young woman whom Fowler had been holding captive. It is a wise move on the writers' part because it puts Dexter's warring impulses of ruthlessness and protectionism in direct, high relief. He wants to save and take care of this bloodied young woman, but of course he can't just let her out the door and off to Miami General because she has witnessed him murdering her tormentor. He is forced to treat her like one of his victims, injecting her with sedatives and locking her up.

When Frieze week in London ended yesterday, a collector from New York asked what I liked best about the art fair. There were many reasons to like being there this year, but what stood out in my mind were two exhibitions I saw outside the fair. The Serpentine Gallery hit it out of the park (Hyde Park, that is) with its Klara Liden retrospective, the most affecting show I saw in five days of nonstop art viewing. The other great experience was Christian Marclay's new 24-hour video, "The Clock," at White Cube in Mayfair.

Sandy Alderson was scheduled to return to Citi Field on Thursday to complete the first round of his interview process for the Mets' vacant general manager position, but the team said the meeting was not part of the second round of interviews, in which select candidates will meet with Fred Wilpon, the principal owner, and Saul Katz, the team president.

In the Economix blog, our colleague Catherine Rampell writes that Michelle Obama's public fashion choices can boost the stock price of the companies making her clothes: "That is the conclusion of an analysis by David Yermack, of the Stern School of Business at New York University, published by The Harvard Business Review. Ms. Obama wears an outfit, and in (oftentimes correct) anticipation that her get-up will become the latest New Thing, the company that makes those clothes gets a healthy boost in its stock price."

How can people who have so much feel so empty and so lost? A. O. Scott poses that question with this week's Critics' Pick, "L'Avventura." Directed by Michelangelo Antonioni, the film follows a group of wealthy young Romans on a day trip to a volcanic island. During the trip, one of the women vanishes, but the film's characters seem to pay her disappearance little concern. The film was booed at Cannes when it had its premiere there 50 years ago, yet was also awarded a prize by the jury. It has been debated among cinephiles ever since. Have you seen "L'Avventura?" Please share your thoughts.

The art-world documentarian Chiara Clemente set her sights on seven creative personalities, whom she has profiled in miniature for "Beginnings," a new film series debuting Tuesday at sundancechannel.com. All of the subjects - from Yoko Ono (the profile of her is embedded above) to the Blue Hill chef Dan Barber - hit the big time in New York, and in going back to their beginnings, Clemente reminds us that none of us - O.K., very few of us - fall off of the truck an instant star. Carmen de Lavallade returns to the 92nd Street Y, site of the 79-year-old dancer's first performance in the city. The photographer Mario Sorrenti shows off his mother's art studio, where, as a young vandal, he'd crash after long nights spent spraying graffiti. And the designer Carolina Herrera recalls her first meeting with Diana Vreeland, in which she explained her desire to go into fabric design. "But how boring that is!" Vreeland told her. "Why don't you just do a little collection?"

''All you need to bring is your love for everything,'' went the jingle of one of the Pocono resort's famous commercials. After a heyday in the '60s and '70s, though, the resort had fallen into disrepair by the late '90s, and it finally closed in 2001.

After two years of construction, Ralph Lauren's 22,000-square-foot, four-story women's flagship is finally open, but the brightest sparkle perhaps comes from the 600-square-foot watch and fine jewelry salon on the ground floor. The simultaneous introduction of six fine jewelry collections exclusive to the store represents a new direction for the company, which plans to expand distribution next year in select markets. Standouts include the Equestrian stirrup pendants, the Signature Diamonds and Classic tennis bracelet and necklace, and a jaw-dropping Monogram necklace with akoya pearls and rose gold with diamond monogram (and a hefty $145,900 price tag to boot).

The truth is that Women's Wear Daily, at least in the beginning, was written for men. Not just any men, but "important men in all departments of women's wear" who are "scattered everywhere over the earth's surface and lose track of events and happenings." (Sounds like your typical fashionisto.) These words appeared in the first issue of Women's Wear (the "Daily" came later), from June 1910, in a mission statement titled "Our Excuse for Being." The defensive pose actually makes some sense: it's not easy to prove, as W.W.D. has, that you can write about an essentially frivolous enterprise without indulging in frivolity. This year marks the end of Patrick McCarthy's reign over the newspaper but also its 100th anniversary. In celebration of that second, happier occasion, the paper has just unveiled "W.W.D.: 100 Years | 100 Designers" (Fairchild, $65), about its own history and the designers who have animated its pages for a century. The best part of the book are the reprints of old issues: sketches of Paul Poiret's costumes for a Parisian revue; news of the D-Day landings competing for front-page space next to a report on handbag pricing; and a cover story on the 1999 John F. Kennedy Jr. plane crash that mourned as much for Carolyn Bessette - the former Calvin Klein saleswoman, style icon and fashion publicist - as for John Jr.

I started writing for this blog some 10 months ago -- a time when just about everyone, including me, was trying to sort out what was going on in the economy. In the months since then, I've shared many stories with you about how open-book management has helped propel SRC Holdings through at least three recessions and has set us up to take advantage of the recovery. That's also why I've written several times about our manufacturing facility in Lexington, Ky. -- the plant we purchased not long before I started this blog. I chose to share the stories from Lexington because I thought it would help illustrate what happens when a traditionally run company opens its books.

Fabrizio Ferri is at it again. The renowned fashion photographer, architect, clothing designer and musician has composed an opera, "Anima," which will be performed on Tuesday in Naples at the Teatro di San Carlo (Europe's oldest opera house, dating from 1737). Ferri was initially contacted by Rosanna Purchia, the theater's newly appointed "sovrintendente," to create evocative imagery for the coming season's performances. For the theater's first ever promotional campaign Ferri shot dance students from the Teatro's school in the volcanic surroundings of Mt. Vesuvius, above. Ferri, who had also been working for almost a decade writing, orchestrating and recording the score for a musical film, happened to play a selection of songs for Purchia, who convinced him to turn his film-to-be into an opera for the newly revived theater. "Anima," which means "soul," tells the story of North African immigrants who left their homelands behind for a better life in Europe. "The music envelops the people like the sea," Ferri says, "sometimes soothing, like a mother or father, and sometimes angry and dangerous." An 80-person choir, a 50-person children's choir and an 80-piece orchestra will be joined by some gifted friends of Ferri: the trumpeter Chris Botti, who also contributed recordings for the original score; Andrea Griminelli, a world-famous flautist; and Gil Goldstein, an orchestrator. (A surprise appearance by Sting, a longtime friend, is also anticipated.) Ferri credits the creation of this extraordinary event to Purchia and to "the power of this theater, in a moment of crisis, to have the guts and strength to create the necessary energy so artists come to Naples to play this music, to raise their eyelids, to look ahead."

Thomas Jayne, the New York decorator, has always brought both a scholarly knowledge of design history and a quirky sense of the modern to his work, creating rooms that bridge the old and the new. And even though there is none of Jayne's own work in his new book, "The Finest Rooms in America" (The Monacelli Press), his sensibility is evident in his choice of what the book's subtitle calls "fifty influential interiors from the 18th century to the present." (Full disclosure: I am mentioned in the book's acknowledgments, along with a number of other magazine editors, but was not involved in the book.) Any conversation with Jayne on the subject of decorating invariably touches on his passion for great interiors of the past, and indeed, nearly half the rooms in this book are historic, although Jayne includes 20th-century interiors - like the living room of Frank Lloyd Wright's Hollyhock House and that of Charles and Ray Eames's house - in this category, along with 18th-century spaces like the Tea Room at Monticello or the Large Dining Room at Mount Vernon. But seeing his broad-ranging eye at work is part of the pleasure of reading Jayne's book. His selection of contemporary rooms won't please every decorator - particularly given the book's somewhat loaded title, an homage to the famous 1964 volume "The Finest Rooms by America's Great Decorators," which included interiors by now-departed greats like Rose Cumming, Sister Parish and Billy Baldwin - but it is as catholic as his tastes. So you'll find the more-is-more drawing room of the jewelry designer Kenneth Jay Lane and Robert Couturier's classically inspired dining room sharing the book's pages with an elegantly spare living room by David Kleinberg and an edgy studio by Christopher Coleman. While many of the rooms are fairly grand in scale and furnishings, it is one of the smallest that that makes your heart beat faster: Albert Hadley's Manhattan intimate sitting room, an object lesson in understated chic, which Jayne rightly saves for last.

The performance of the rookie punter Matt Dodge in the Giants’ victory Sunday was a reflection of his young career: at once great and ghastly.
Representative Ike Skelton is a pro-gun, anti-abortion Democrat from Missouri who voted against the health care bill and has a long record of supporting local military institutions.
Saudi intelligence officials informed Paris of possible attacks in Europe and specifically France by Al Qaeda’s branch in Yemen.
The good will that Carol Bartz had when she took over Yahoo two years ago is wearing thin. Her turnaround plan has yet to produce significant results.
Jamie McMurray’s career came full circle at Charlotte Motor Speedway, where he returned to victory lane eight years after grabbing his first win.
Lucy Danziger, the editor in chief of Self, does not have the luxury of moving at a leisurely pace given the field of rival active-woman magazines.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Israel renewed contacts with a German mediator to negotiate the release of a captured Israeli soldier, Staff Sgt. Gilad Shalit.
The book “Decoded” is being marketed along with the search engine Bing. Its creator, Microsoft, is paying for the campaign.
The Fed is having to shift substantially from the approach that has defined it and from which it has long derived its institutional self-esteem.
A listless 2-0 loss to Everton, a city rival, displayed all that is wrong with Liverpool, just sold for $480 million.
A blog paid for a lewd story about Brett Favre, and then mainstream outlets followed.
The government says Abdelghani Meskini, an informer convicted in a plot to blow up an airport, violated his release terms, and one witness is a woman he befriended.
Despite an afternoon of mistakes, the Jets managed to topple the Broncos and to head into their bye week with five consecutive wins.
In Mexico, there is concern about possible spillover effects should California legalize marijuana.
Minnesota fired Coach Tim Brewster after a series of losses, bringing the Golden Gophers to 1-6 in Brewster’s fourth season.
Burhan Qurbani has realized that his audience sees him as an Afghan immigrant who made a movie about Islam, not as a talented German filmmaker.
Fuchs, who set four shot-putting world records, developed a new method that was widely copied in the event.
Despite the strength of insurgent candidates around the country, Andrew M. Cuomo is leading Carl P. Paladino in the race for governor.
Fox News commentators raises questions of ties between a proposed Islamic center and a Saudi prince. But that prince, a Fox News owner, doesn’t take it personally.
If you are among those obsessed with America’s most elusive elected position, Senate Seat No. 51, head to Washington state, where Patty Murray faces Dino Rossi.
New music from Sugarland, Die Antwoord and Benoît Delbecq.
Bradford Cox of Deerhunter kept his serene tone through all the noise when the band played Webster Hall on Friday.
On Monday, the National Geographic Channel will broadcast the first installment of a series that is tracking Virgin Galactic’s efforts to create a commercial spacecraft.
Ben Roethlisberger returned after a four-game suspension and threw for 3 touchdowns in the Steelers’ 28-10 win over the Browns.
The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, which takes the view that musical interpretations can be shaped by the ensemble rather than by a conductor, has expanded on that concept in a commissioning program.
“Jackass 3D,” produced for $20 million by Paramount Pictures, surpassed expectations to sell an estimated $50 million at the weekend box office.
“The Language Archive,” at the Laura Pels Theater, is about a linguist who cannot manage to verbalize elemental emotion in any of the many languages he speaks.
Pat McDevitt, Rich DeMartino, Lynn Deas and Beth Palmer are among the American winners in Philadelphia.
“Claude Lévi-Strauss,” Patrick Wilcken’s intellectual biography of the French anthropologist, offers clear, analytical descriptions of the basic tenets of his thought.
Two of the city’s finest professional church choirs, at Trinity and St. Ignatius Loyola, presented contrasting Handel oratorios last week.
Adonis, the Syrian-born poet and perennial Nobel favorite, has a new volume of selected poems and an upcoming reading at the 92nd Street Y.
Vittorio Grigolo was one of four debuts in Franco Zeffirelli’s production of “La Bohème” at the Met, which has returned to the repertory.
In “Matthew Bourne’s Swan Lake” at City Center, Mr. Bourne’s reinterpretation of a classic raises the ballet’s inherent sexiness and gives Tchaikovsky’s music new force.
Ishmael Butler, a familiar voice from Digable Planets, brings his Shabazz Palaces to the Rose Center for Earth and Space.
The three-day festival at Town Hall was devoted to mostly familiar songs by mostly American songwriters, sung by Broadway performers.
Highlights from the exhibition, at three locations, marking the mega-gallery’s 50th anniversary.
A multigallery extravaganza honoring the Pace Gallery’s half-century in the art business.
The announcement of results from parliamentary elections was postponed as officials indicated that fraud had tainted as many as a million votes.
Ms. Plain, who became a best-selling author at age 59, wrote multigenerational family sagas that won a loyal readership in the millions.
The concept of the rent-a-pitcher — like Roy Oswalt and Cliff Lee — is not new. It has just become more expensive.
With little more than two weeks left before the midterm elections, the White House on Sunday predicted that Democrats would hold onto their majorities in the House and the Senate.
China dismissed the American inquiry into subsidies for clean-energy industries as election-season politics.

Drew Brees, left, completed eight of his first nine passes and led the Saints to scores on their first three possessions in a 31-6 win at Tampa Bay. He finished with 263 passing yards and 3 touchdowns. James Hall, Chris Long and Larry Grant each had two sacks as the Rams stifled the Chargers' offense, which entered the game ranked as the best in the league, in a 20-17 victory.

Mozilla, the maker of the open-source Firefox Web browser, said Thursday that it would appoint Gary Kovacs, a veteran software executive, as its new chief executive. The appointment ends a nearly six-month search that began after John Lilly, who has been Mozilla's chief executive for the last three years, announced that he would leave to join Greylock Partners, a venture capital firm. Mr. Kovacs is currently senior vice president in charge of mobile products at SAP, the German software giant. Before that, he was a senior executive at SAP-owned Sybase. Between 2003 and 2008, he held various senior executive positions at Macromedia, and later, at Adobe, after those two companies merged.
FAGIN--Eileen (nee Flansbaum) on October 17, 2010. Beloved wife of Jay Fagin. She loved, and was loved by the Fagin, Tuttman and Hannigan families.

BLUMKIN--Rubin, 89, of Ithaca, NY, passed away on October 14. He was the most devoted husband of Sabina, loving brother to Martin and his wife Natalie, father of Dan and his partner Ben, daughter Joy and her husband Lewis, daughter-in-law Melanie, grandchildren Josh, Aaron, Zach, Joe and Amy, and great-grandchildren Dylan, Ollie and Gabriella.
BARBASH--Roslyn. 1/5/11-10/18/85. Wise physician, wife, mother, environmental advocate. Remembered with love.

Marzieh, the great diva of Persian traditional song, who was silenced after the Islamic Revolution in 1979 but who re-emerged years later outside Iran as a singer and a highly public supporter of the resistance, died on Wednesday in Paris. She was 86 and had defected to France in 1994. Her death, of cancer, was announced on the Web site of the National Council of Resistance of Iran, the opposition group, founded in 1981 and based in France, of which she was a member. Survivors include a son and a grandchild.

LEVIN--Marilyn S.,79, of Sayville, LI, on October 15, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Robert Levin. Loving mother of Jay (Debi) Demeusy and Bob (Karen) Demeusy and stepmother of Judy (Jeff) Schultz and Dan (Diane) Levin. Proud grandmother of Bryan, Elizabeth, Robby, Eric, Hannah and David. Dear sister of William Schneider. Reposing Monday, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30pm at Raynor & D'Andrea Funeral Home, 245 Montauk Hwy, West Sayville. Funeral Mass, 10am Tuesday at St. Lawrence RC Church, Sayville. Interment will follow in the parish cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Fire Island Pines Care Center or Southside Hospital are appreciated. www.raynordandrea.com

As a competitive triathlete and the editor in chief of Self, a magazine that offers women exclamation-pointed tips on self-fulfillment (''Banish the Blahs and Feel Happier!'' ''Leaner Legs! Tighter Tush!'' ''Be True to You!''), Lucy Danziger is not prone to idling. Just before 7 on a recent weeknight, Ms. Danziger parked her black Vespa scooter with its Lucy D vanity plate at the curb in front of Donny Deutsch's East 78th Street town house. She whipped off her helmet and marched inside, up a flight of stairs and straight to the front of a receiving line where her friend and onetime triathlon partner, Hoda Kotb, the ''Today'' show personality, was greeting guests at her book party.

SEOUL, South Korea -- North and South Korea reopened one of the three severed hot lines between them on Monday in response to a request from the North, its first apparent outreach since the youngest son of the leader, Kim Jong-il, was unveiled as his successor. The reopened hot line connects the principal international airports -- Pyongyang in the North and Incheon in the South -- and a test call was conducted late Monday morning, the Unification Ministry said through a spokesman in Seoul.

Remember Philip Carlo, the tough-guy author from Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, who has fraternized with Mafia hitmen, sexual predators and psychopathic druglords, only to fall prey to a killer within - amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or A.L.S., popularly known as Lou Gehrig's Disease? He was profiled in The New York Times last December. Stricken nearly six years ago by the almost always fatal motor neuron disease that has paralyzed most of his body and keeps him clamped to a breathing tube, he nonetheless manages to keep going to interviews and writing with the help of an assistant.
SAN DIEGO - In Election 2010, there's no time for subtlety anymore. Here in California and in much of the rest of the country, early voting has begun. Election Day itself arrives in 15 days.

An article on Wednesday about the arraignment of an emergency medical technician accused of not helping a pregnant woman who collapsed and later died misstated the surname of an assistant district attorney involved in the case. He is Kevin Richardson, not Richards.

Three weeks into the young season, and three new broadcast series have fallen: ''Outlaw'' (NBC), ''Lone Star'' (Fox) and ''My Generation'' (ABC). No new arrivals are in the top 10 shows. Crime dramas continue to be very popular. These include NCIS (CBS), at No. 3 overall, ''Blue Bloods,'' above starring Tom Selleck, and ''Criminal Minds'' (CBS), at No. 8 in its sixth season.

Barbara Billingsley, who as June Cleaver on the television series ''Leave It to Beaver'' personified a Hollywood postwar family ideal of the ever-sweet, ever-helpful suburban stay-at-home mom, died Saturday. She was 94. A family spokeswoman, Judy Twersky, said that Ms. Billingsley had died of polymyalgia, a rheumatoid disease, at her home in Santa Monica, Calif.

COOPER--Helen S. October 14, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Herman E. Cooper, dear mother of Kathy Sulds, Debbie Cooper, and Tom Cooper, loving grandmother of Amy, Benjamin, Michael, and Molly Sulds, Julia and Sam Sternberg, and Sam and Alex Cooper. Mrs. Cooper was born in Manhattan and led an exciting life filled with family, devoted friends, and a love of the arts; along with a deep commitment to the welfare of children. She was a member of the Board of Directors of Citizens Committee for Children of New York and The Urban League, a member of the Governor's Advisory Council on Youth Affairs - Division of Youth, a Commissioner of the New York State Commission for Juvenile Justice, and Co-founder and Executive Director of Volunteers in Probation. Services will be held at 11:30am on Friday, October 22nd at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in her memory to Citizens Committee for Children of New York (www.cccnewyork.org).

One of the pleasures of being a dedicated ''Mad Men'' fan - and what are you doing here if you aren't? - is connecting with other viewers whose knowledge of the show is as encyclopedic and as obsessive as your own. And no one fills that role better than Matthew Weiner, who created the show, oversees its production and would probably cater it if he had the time, and who is kind of like a walking Wikipedia of ''Mad Men'' (with a much higher rate of accuracy). On a visit to New York to cheer on Jon Hamm in Thursday's live episode of ''30 Rock,'' Mr. Weiner welcomed ArtsBeat to his hotel room to talk about the ''Mad Men'' season. Though he was tight-lipped about Sunday's finale - even on the Friday evening before it was broadcast - Mr. Weiner spoke at length about the ideas that were in play during Season 4, his vision for the show's characters and what the future might hold for the series.

WINTER--Harriet Jane, 83. Died from a fall on vacation in Italy. Best known as Mrs. H. Winter, she was an innovator, pioneering merrill stitching to finish garments, novel fabrics such as upholstery and plastics, and deconstructed clothing design. Inspired by vintage clothing and celebrities who visited her from nearby Chelsea Hotel, Harriet's designs were "wearable art." In retirement, Harriet went back to painting in needlepoint. She is survived by her adoring husband, Lewis Winter; three children, Andrea Shlasko, Joanna Barsh and Alexander Winter; and four grandchildren. We miss your spirit, your remarkable creativity, your unlimited love, and your infectious laugh. Services on October 18 at 11:15am, Riverside Memorial, 180 West 76th Street. We welcome all who loved Harriet as we do.

An Op-Ed article on Oct. 7, about New York City's proposal to ban the use of food stamps for sugary drinks, referred imprecisely to the eligibility of deli sandwiches as a food stamp purchase. While food stamps cannot be used to buy hot deli sandwiches, they can be used for ones that are cold and not consumed on the premises.

Sensor technology has become smaller, lighter and more powerful. At the same time, more attention is being paid to preventive health and personal fitness as an answer to the nation's rising medical bills. A result, for sensor companies like BodyMedia, is an opportunity to marry body sensors to smartphones to create full-body monitors. Last week, BodyMedia announced that its armband sensors would be able to communicate with smartphones, wirelessly, using Bluetooth. Its health sensors will be one of the first devices, other than ear buds, that link to smartphones with Bluetooth short-range communications.

The Jaguars may have a new secret weapon: quarterback David Garrard's wife. Doug Farrar of Yahoo Sports reported last week that Mary Garrard gave the team's offensive coaches advice during a birthday party for Garrard's son. ''She knows I like to move around and run around a little bit more,'' David Garrard said. ''She was just saying we've got to see that some more and see you running around a little bit.'' Mary Garrard should talk to the Titans, who are using play action and motion to hide Vince Young's lack of development as a pocket passer. One thing Young has been able to do in the past three weeks is efficiently attack poor pass defenses with deep throws. The Jaguars' defense has allowed 1,492 passing yards. MIKE TANIER Pick: Titans

Sure, articles about Lindsay Lohan's repeat trips to rehabilitation and Brett Favre's purported sexual peccadilloes generate loads of reader traffic, but do they actually make decent money for the Web sites that publish them? Perfect Market, a company that helps newspapers make their Web sites more profitable, examined the advertising revenue generated from more than 15 million articles from 21 news sites over a three-month period this summer.

LEVIN--Dr. Philip. We mourn the loss of our dearest brother-in law Philip Levin. He was a truly good man--wise, generous and accomplished in many ways. His smile and the twinkle in his eye was matched by the love in his heart. Our deepest sympathy and support are with our sister Gloria, and their children, Scott (Rhea), Mark, Jennifer (Dan), Bonnie (Kenny), Michael (Leslie), David and their 11 grandchildren.

A month ago, a U.C.L.A. graduate student named Emily Elkins spent hours roaming a Tea Party rally on the Washington Mall, photographing every sign she saw. Elkins, a former CATO Institute intern, was examining the liberal conceit that Tea Party marches are rife with racism and conspiracy theorizing. Last week, The Washington Post reported on her findings: just 5 percent of the 250 signs referenced Barack Obama's race or religion, and 1 percent brought up his birth certificate. The majority focused on bailouts, deficits and spending -- exactly the issues the Tea Partiers claim inspired their movement in the first place.

Nuns greeted Pope Benedict XVI in St. Peter's Square on Sunday after he named six new saints at an open-air Mass attended by tens of thousands of people. Among those declared a saint was Mary MacKillop, an Australian 19th-century nun who founded the Congregation of the Sisters of St. Joseph of the Sacred Heart and focused particularly on the education of poor children.

MAYER--Steven M.,65, of Great Neck, NY. Wife Susan and children Jason (Kimberly), Stuart (Stacy), Richard (Aliza) and Deborah (Mark Klinger) and his ten grandchildren mourn the loss of their beloved husband, father, and grandfather. Steven was a loving and kind family man and a respected member of the community.

All along I've been thinking, 'Somebody finally has to take the initiative and say, 'Ready, set, go,' You just pick a spot to begin, and things will fall into place.' RANDAL PERKINS, chief executive of a Florida company that is clearing debris in Haiti. [A1]

BERLIN -- It has been many years since a German film student had a feature-length movie shown at the prestigious Berlinale International Film Festival, a distinction that can launch a career. That is what Burhan Qurbani is enjoying at the moment, with his film ''Shahada.'' But rising fame can be double-edged, as Mr. Qurbani, 29, now understands, as his native country casts a critical eye on his work, and his life. He suddenly realizes that he is a foreigner at home, and that his audience sees him as an Afghan immigrant who made a movie about Islam, not as a talented German filmmaker who chose to explore issues common to all mankind.

FUCHS--James E. of New York City, passed away peacefully, surrounded by his family, on October 8, 2010. He was 82 years old. He was a champion - athletically, in business, philanthropy and as a loving father, husband and grandfather. A man among men with a broad smile and hearty shake, he was treasured by all. Since its inception in 1982, he was President of the Silver Shield Foundation, an organization founded by George M. Steinbrenner, III and Mr. Fuchs, which provides financial support for the education of children and widows of Police Officers, Firefighters and State Troopers in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, who are killed in the line of duty. Mr. Fuchs was President, Chairman and CEO of Fuchs, Cuthrell & Co., Inc., a pioneer in corporate executive out placement and executive consulting, from 1971 to 1994. He was a 1950 Yale Graduate, a medalist in the 1948 and 1952 Olympic Games, and gold medalist in the shot put and discus in the first Pan American Games in 1951. Mr. Fuchs, a world record holder in indoor and outdoor shot put, is listed in the "Guinness Book of Track and Field Facts" for winning 88 consecutive shot put competitions - a record at the time and still second in history for male athletes. Mr. Fuchs was an inductee in the National Track and Field Hall of Fame, The New York Athletic Hall of Fame, a member of the United States Olympic Overview Commission, U.S. Information Agency's International Sports Committee, Yale Athletic Advisory Board, Board of Directors of the Madison Square Boys and Girls Club, President's Council on Physical Fitness, Mayor's Committee for Youth for the City of New York, National Art Museum of Sports, U.S. Olympic Board of Directors, and Sports, Science and Technology Committee. He was on the International Relations Committee of the USOC and Board of the NYC 2012 Olympic Bid Committee. Mr. Fuchs was a member of the NYC Racquet Club and Deepdale Golf Club. He is survived by his brother, Richard G. Fuchs, Jr. of California; his fiancee, Mary St. George; his seven children, Bettina Barrington McCarthy, Barrington "Bingy" Greenough, Holly Armstrong Fuchs, Victoria Holland and Kimberley Corbin "K.C." Fuchs and their mother Barrington King Fuchs; Nicholas and Slater Fuchs and their mother, Anne Sutherland Fuchs and seven grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City, on Friday, October 29, at 4:00pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Silver Shield Foundation, 870 United Nations Plaza, NY, NY 10017 or please visit: www.silvershieldfoundation.org

Big data is like the testosterone of business computing right now. It has put technology's largest players on an aggression bender. The latest tech giant to flex its big-data muscle is EMC. On Wednesday, the storage specialist introduced the EMC Greenplum Data Computing Appliance. EMC acquired Greenplum in July, giving it some of the top data warehousing software in the market. The company has taken that code and wrapped it in a metal bundle, adding servers, storage units and networking to make a so-called appliance, which is data-center speak for a system that's meant to perform a single function well.

SCHLEMMER--Carl. Former GE Transportation leader died on October 14, 2010, after a long illness. Carl Schlemmer was born in Vicksburg, Mississippi, to Jessie and Norman C. Schlemmer, and had two brothers, the late Norman and Robert Schlemmer. After the passing of his father, he lived with his family in Greensburg, Indiana, the Panama Canal Zone and Indianapolis, Indiana. He served in the United States Army Air Corps on Tinian Island in the Pacific Theatre during World War II. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross for exemplary bravery in freeing a live fused bomb from an open bomb bay, allowing the plane to complete its mission. He also received the Air Medal for the longest air mission in World War II. Schlemmer joined General Electric Company in 1951 after graduating from Purdue University, where he received a degree in mechanical engineering. He held a number of positions at General Electric including General Manager of the Transportation Systems Business Operations in Erie, Pennsylvania, and was elected a Vice President of the General Electric Company in 1975. He ran General Electric's locomotive business from 1974 to 1989. During his tenure, Schlemmer oversaw a $500 million modernization program. GE became the industry leader and this led to the development of the Dash 8 locomotive. He received an honorary Doctoral Degree in Mechanical Engineering from Purdue University in Lafayette, Indiana and an additional honorary Doctorate in Law from Gannon University in Erie, Pennsylvania. Schlemmer did extensive community service, including serving as Chairman of the United Way in Erie County and helping to establish the John F. Kennedy Center in Erie. He supported Christian Science churches in several communities in a number of volunteer positions. Schlemmer had a lifelong interest in art and was an avid sailor. He is survived by his wife, Joan Alyea Schlemmer; his daughter, Carla Schlemmer Stillman and her husband, William Stillman; his granddaughter, Lauren Stillman Nofsinger and her husband Robert Nofsinger; his grandson, Mark Everett Stillman. A private family memorial and interment will take place in Greensburg, Indiana. Anyone who would like to honor the memory of Carl Schlemmer may send contributions to the United Way of Erie County, Pennsylvania.

SAN FRANCISCO -- If you want a smartphone powered by Google's Android software, you could get Motorola's Droid 2 or its cousin, the Droid X. Then there is the Droid Incredible from HTC, the Fascinate from Samsung and the Ally from LG. That's just on Verizon Wireless. An additional 20 or so phones running Android are available in the United States, and there are about 90 worldwide.

The latest New York Times poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 10 through Oct. 15 with 1,139 adults throughout New York State, including 943 who said they were registered to vote. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish. The sample of land-line telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of active residential exchanges across the state.

KATZ--Friedrich, 83 years old, of Chicago, on October 16, 2010, in Philadelphia. Professor Katz was a distinguished scholar of Mexican history, whose major work on the Mexican revolution drew acute parallels with trends in global historiography. His wide interest extended from the study of Aztec society to an account of Mexico's diplomatic role in World War I. Katz taught at Humboldt University in Berlin before joining the Department of History at the University of Chicago, where he taught for 40 years. Katz was born in Vienna and raised in Berlin to the age of six, when his family fled Nazi Germany to Paris. In 1938 the family fled to New York. Unable to gain permanent resident status in the U.S., they found refuge in Mexico, sparking Katz's lifelong interest. Katz is survived by his widow Dr. Jana Katz, a pediatrician; his daughter Jacqueline Ross, of Champaign Urbana, his son, Leo, of Philadelphia, and four grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Tuesday October 19 at 2:00pm at Joseph Levine and Sons Memorial Chapel, 4737 Street Road, Trevose, PA. Interment will be held in Vienna, Austrua. (Please Omit Flowers) Further information at 800-992-3339.

E-readers and smartphones have brought big changes to the publishing industry, but Amazon.com is aiming to bring some more with a new format for shorter and cheaper e-books. As it stands now, consumers read texts of a variety of lengths on these devices: long-form books, medium-length magazine articles, short blog posts or tiny Twitter updates.

KAHN--Grete Regina (Schmidt). Passed away on October 16, 2010, at age 96. Born in Bruchsal, Germany, she lived in Manhattan for the past 70 years. Beloved mother of Dorothy and Steven (Carol), grandmother of Michael (Vera) and wife of Hans (deceased). We mourn her passing and celebrate her long and healthy life. Graveside services at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ on October 19, 2010 at 1:30pm.

10 P.M. (VH1) BRET MICHAELS: LIFE AS I KNOW IT In ''Rock of Love'' Mr. Michaels, left, the Poison frontman, searched for a girlfriend while he and Kristi Gibson took a break from their longstanding relationship. But sometimes home actually is where the heart is. In this new series Mr. Michaels -- who received a diagnosis of Type 1 diabetes at age 6 and who this year has had appendicitis, a brain hemorrhage and a ''warning stroke'' -- juggles life on the road with raising his two young daughters while trying to reconcile with their mother, Ms. Gibson. ''Rock of Love Girls: Where Are They Now?,'' which leads in at 9, provides updates on some of the unruly women who competed for, but ultimately didn't win, Mr. Michaels's affections. 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOW Ms. Winfrey interviews a 16-year-old boy who killed the person who molested him.

Harvey Weinstein has hired the Oscar-winning producer Donna Gigliotti as the Weinstein Company's new president of production, a move aimed at recapturing his Miramax glory days. Ms. Gigliotti, who won a best picture Academy Award for ''Shakespeare in Love'' and was nominated last year for ''The Reader,'' will fill a position that has been vacant for a year as Mr. Weinstein and his brother, Bob, have focused on restructuring their struggling studio.

An article in the Square Feet pages on Oct. 6 about the sale of Seamen's Church Institute building in Manhattan omitted the name of one of the building's architects. James Polshek and Richard Olcott designed it, not just Mr. Polshek.

LOWENSTEIN--Richard. The family of Dick's beloved late brother Lou deeply mourns his passing. We offer our condolences to Dick's immediate family, whose sorrow we profoundly share. Observing Dick, we learned that "a twinkle in his eye" is no mere expression, but a metaphor for a human spirit that indefatigably seized on life's joys, and its sweetness, to the fullest. Observing Dick and Lou together, we learned that life has few greater joys than a loving and loyal kinship and brotherhood. From the Yankee Stadium to the Larchmont Tavern, and over a span of four score and more years, you guys never quit. Dick, you were truly our other half.

In a market where many consider $2.99 a lot to pay for an iPhone application, $14.99 may seem downright steep. But Consumer Reports, which more than most magazines has been able to command a premium for its online content, is betting that its loyal readers will pay as much to gain access to its vast library of product reviews from their mobile phones.

An article in the special Cars section on Thursday about trends in automobile electronics misstated the abbreviation for the diagnostic plug under a car's dashboard. It is OBD (for on board diagnostic) II, not ODB II.

The ''This Land'' column on Thursday, about the Massachusetts governor's race, misstated the given name of the former running mate of Timothy Cahill, an independent candidate. He is Paul Loscocco, not John.

An obituary on Oct. 8 about the British filmmaker Roy Ward Baker referred incorrectly to the novelist Eric Ambler's screenplay for ''The October Man,'' the first feature Mr. Baker directed. It was written directly for the screen; it was not adapted from a novel by Mr. Ambler. The obituary also misstated, in some copies, the year that Mr. Baker's movie ''The Singer Not the Song'' was released. It was 1961, not 1962.

VIESER--Richard William, 82, passed away peacefully on October 14th. Mr. Vieser was an esteemed corporate leader who achieved a national reputation for success in rebuilding, managing and transforming a wide range of businesses in the electronics, defense, oil and gas, automotive and medical fields. A native of New Jersey, he was among the pioneers of the leveraged buyout industry having worked with both Forstmann Little & Co and Hicks Muse before retiring in 1989. After retirement, Mr. Vieser maintained an active presence in business by serving on the boards of some twenty organizations, including prominent firms such as Varian Medical, where he served as Chairman, Fisher Scientific, Dresser Industries, Control Data Corporation, Ceridian and Viasystems. Mr. Vieser was a generous and loving husband, father, grandfather and friend. He is survived by his beloved wife of fifty-nine years, Lois (Johnson) and five adoring children, Richard (and Patricia) of Bernardsville, NJ, Cheryl (Vieser) Kleckner of Alpharetta, GA, Cynthia (Vieser) and Joseph Falco of Madison, NJ, William John David of Madison, NJ and Jaime (and Melinda) of London, UK. He also leaves behind a wide circle of family and friends, including his nine beloved grandchildren, Donald, Francecsa, David, Joseph, Anne, Katherine, Alexandra, Bella and his namesake, Richard William. Born in the Vailsburg section of Newark, New Jersey, on November 14, 1927, Mr. Vieser spent his formative years in South Orange, New Jersey, where he graduated from Columbia High School in Maplewood. He was a member of a state championship baseball team in high school and active in scouting where he attained the distinction of Eagle Scout at the age of 15. After a year at Lafayette College, Mr. Vieser entered the U.S. Army in September 1946. He served sixteen months in Korea as a member of the Army of Occupation and was discharged in April 1948. Being a proud American with unwavering patriotism, he felt these years were some of the most formative of his life. Mr. Vieser re-entered Lafayette, where he was a member of Theta Delta Chi Fraternity, serving as its President in his senior year. His business career began as a trainee at AT&T headquarters in New York City. Mr. Vieser later joined Chatham Electronics Corporation where he oversaw construction of a new factory in Livingston, New Jersey that manufactured highly specialized electron tubes used in the DEW line and other early missile warning systems across Canada and the Arctic. Mr. Vieser went on to hold major executive positions, as Chatham Electronics was part of a series of corporate acquisitions and mergers in the 1950s and 1960s, involving such major and well-known businesses as Tung Sol Electric, Wagner Electric, Studebaker and Worthington Pump Company - ultimately leading to the formation of Studebaker-Worthington. Throughout the series of corporate changes, he continued his rapid rise in leadership positions. Mr. Vieser served as Executive Vice President of StudebakerWorthington and ultimately as Chief Operating Officer. After McGraw-Edison acquired Studebaker-Worthington in 1979, he was appointed Executive Vice President and later President and Chief Operating Officer of McGraw-Edison. When McGraw-Edison was acquired by Cooper Industries, Mr. Vieser was invited to join Forstmann Little & Co. While there, he served as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of three Forstmann Little companies, Lear Siegler Corporation, FL Industries and Midland-Ross Corporation. He also served as Chairman of the National Motor Equipment Manufacturers Association, where he hosted numerous foreign trade missions at the request of the U.S. State Department and received honors from the states of New Jersey, Kentucky, Alabama and Mississippi. Mr. Vieser was an avid historian and voracious reader, with a profound love for music, art and travel. He was greatly involved in historical preservation and philanthropy. Mr. Vieser was a member of the President's Council of Colonial Williamsburg and a Trustee of Winterthur Museum. Mr. Vieser was an avid golfer and a member of several golf clubs, including famed courses such as Baltusrol, Pine Valley, and Morris County in New Jersey and Ocean Forest and Sea Island in Georgia. Mr. Vieser was devoted to his family and his friends. His enormous spirit, sense of humor, kindness and love for life inspired all those who knew him. He believed life was something to be celebrated. His greatest joy was to be with his family and friends around the dinner table. He especially treasured spending time with his family at his farm in New Hampshire in front of a roaring fire or enjoying a beautiful sunset. His infectious laugh, heart-warming smile, generous heart and beautiful spirit will never leave us. Relatives and friends are invited to call Monday, October 18, 2-4 and 7-9pm at the William R. Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Ave., Summit, NJ (908-273-2323). Funeral Services will be on Tuesday, Oct. 19, 10am at Calvary Episcopal Church, Summit. Interment will follow at Restland Memorial Park, East Hanover.

A museum exhibition in which there's virtually nothing to see, hear or touch? What's left? The Museum of Arts and Design in Columbus Circle is to announce on Monday that it is planning a show to open next November in which only one sense - a fairly underserved one in the museum world - will count: smell. ''The Art of Scent: 1889-2011'' will present examples of more than a dozen perfumes that have helped to define the lucrative aroma industry. The scents will be wafted around the museum's second-floor galleries by atomizers in an exhibition space designed by the architect Toshiko Mori, and they will be presented with labels identifying only their creators and the years they were made. The packaging and brand names usually associated with them - Chanel No. 5 will be among the greatest hits - will not be seen.

In principle, HTML 5 will allow sites you visit to know your physical location and will make it easier for them to keep track of your browsing and shopping history.

One of the quirkiest, kookiest clans in popular culture is headed to Broadway for the holiday season: not the Addams family, which is already firmly entrenched in the theater district, but the Osmond family. The sibling entertainers Donny and Marie Osmond, who between them have dozens of gold records -- not to mention dozens of the most lustrous teeth in show business -- are headed to the Marquis Theater for a 12-performance run in December, publicists for the show said on Tuesday. "Donny & Marie - A Broadway Christmas" will be the first time that Mr. Osmond, the teen heartthrob turned "Dancing With the Stars" champion, and Ms. Osmond, the performer and lone sister to eight Osmond brothers, have shared a Broadway stage together. Mr. Osmond previously played Gaston in the Broadway production of "Beauty and the Beast," and Ms. Osmond played Anna in a Broadway revival of "The King and I" in 1997. The limited run is from Dec. 9 (Donny's birthday!) through Dec. 19, and is produced by Greg Young, Jon B. Platt and Magic Arts & Entertainment in association with Eric Gardner and Greg Sperry.

The largest pumpkin ever grown measures more than 15 feet around and is 4½ feet tall. It weighs 1,810½ pounds and contains enough flesh to make about 900 pies. On Friday, it left New Richmond, Wisc., in the back of a 2010 Dodge Ram pickup.

Bruno Frisoni, the artistic director of Roger Vivier, has an important date in New York this week. He's here to introduce his latest collection, the limited-edition Rendez-Vous. "I wanted this collection to be more affordable than couture and more accessible in terms of design," says the designer, who played with a range of natural materials including wood, cord and horn. (Orders start in December and are limited to 10 per style.) New Yorkers will be the first to see the collection at a party tonight at Saks Fifth Avenue's shoe mecca, 10022, hosted by Stephanie Winston Wolkoff, Lincoln Center's director of fashion. But this week isn't all business for Frisoni. He "loves the old charm and the shabby chic suites," at the Carlyle Hotel and dining at the downtown bistro Da Silvano, "for the Italian-like atmosphere and sunny terrace." Still, you never know when another bag or shoe idea will strike. His biggest inspiration, he says, "comes from the graphic lines of the city and the crisp skies."

It has been a busy year inside Microsoft: the company is getting ready to introduce an entirely new mobile platform and a new type of Xbox gaming interface that uses the human body instead of a traditional controller. Now it is offering a new kind of Microsoft Office suite, called Office 365, which is based in the cloud.

Foodies take note: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday voted to deny the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum's application to install a food kiosk outside its entrance. The commission determined that the kiosk would disrupt the entryway and introduce a visual interruption to Frank Lloyd Wright's museum.

If the road to N.B.A. superstardom were paved with All-Star votes and YouTube highlight reels alone, Derrick Rose would already be a player of legend. He would be the subject of folk songs, star in countless tall tales, and be immortalized in bronze alongside Michael Jordan outside Chicago's United Center. Unfortunately for Rose, such are the spoils reserved for the game's true elites, and while the young Bulls guard is among the brightest up-and-comers on today's N.B.A. scene, Rose's rise hasn't quite mirrored the meteoric brilliance of, say, Kevin Durant.

The Indianapolis Symphony named a 28-year-old Pole, Krzysztof Urbanski, as its music director, starting in September. Mr. Urbanski, who succeeds Mario Venzago, graduated from the Chopin Music Academy in Warsaw just three years ago and was named chief conductor of the Trondheim Symphony Orchestra in Norway in 2009.

Ted Muehling is known for designing objects, like jewelry, porcelain vases and crystal bowls, that are based on forms found in nature, like a lily pad, coral or a tortoise shell. His first foray into book design, a collaboration with the neurologist and writer Oliver Sacks and the photographer Abelardo Morell, is no exception. "The Island of Rota" is a mysterious and seductive book about the natural history of an island in Micronesia. Its text is taken from Sacks's book "The Island of the Colorblind"; its rich, cliché-verre photographs of ferns and cycads (very early plant forms that grow on Rota) are by Morell; and the book itself, a highly textured, handmade, sensual object, was designed by Muehling.

Overview | Did the German people elevate Hitler, or did Hitler victimize the Germans? How do historians formulate claims about complex historical events? In this lesson, students consider competing historical claims about responsibility for the rise of Adolf Hitler and then examine primary sources to generate and support their own historical claims. They also consider what the significance of these claims might be for contemporary society.

The romance is over for Électricité de France and the Constellation Energy Group, partners in a nuclear power joint venture. Their very public squabble was ostensibly set off by Constellation's withdrawal of its application to the Energy Department for a loan guarantee for the Calvert Cliffs 3 nuclear project in Maryland. E.D.F. publicly responded with a letter scolding Constellation and asserting its willingness both to proceed with the Calvert Cliffs project and buy out Constellation's 50 percent interest in their UniStar joint venture, the corporation formed to develop Calvert Cliffs.

I sit comfortably in New York City, knowing that I can find just about any wine that interests me at one of our many excellent retail shops. On the rare occasion that they all fail me, I can quickly search stocks around the country using a convenient tool like wine-searcher.com. And, last week, some very good friends of mine were reveling: they had just received one of their twice-a-year deliveries from Garagiste, an unusual Internet wine retailer that makes it easy for people in 33 states and Washington to find the sort of esoteric wines that ordinary retail shops might not carry.

Muslim organizations have kicked off a "week of dialogue" and mosque open houses across the United States, encouraging their members to invite neighbors and non-Muslim friends to attend Muslim prayers and question-and-answer sessions at mosques, and, in turn, to explore churches, synagogues and other houses of worship.

SAN FRANCISCO - There is no way of knowing, right now, whether Chicago Cubs General Manager Jim Hendry made the right call Tuesday by hiring Mike Quade as manager. Quade, 53, paid his dues as a minor league manager for 17 seasons. The Cubs played hard for him this summer, going 24-13 after Lou Piniella resigned. He knows the Cubs, having spent four years as their third-base coach. He is personable and outgoing, and should handle the scrutiny well.

Pulling in billions of dollars quarter after quarter, Apple has provided Silicon Valley with a seemingly endless guessing game about possible mergers and acquisitions -- but one that has largely gone on up to now without the participation of Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive.

A stalled economy, a bitter election year, a shaky music business -- none of those can thwart the annual CMJ Music Marathon, which starts today and once again, for five days, will fill New York City's clubs with musicians eager to be heard by the right people, whoever they might be. The marathon includes places from Madison Square Garden -- a concert on Wednesday by Phoenix, Dirty Projectors and Wavves -- to clubs barely bigger than a studio apartment. Its epicenters are the Lower East Side of Manhattan and Williamsburg, Brooklyn, which also happen to supply a good number of the bands.

Junot Díaz was here for an event at The Times last night, and in the course of the evening he rattled off the names of several authors and books that have greatly influenced his work - or simply flat-out floored him. Among them: "Family Installments: Memories of Growing Up Hispanic," by Edward Rivera, a 1982 memoir "noisily brimming with life," as Phillip Lopate described it in the Book Review; "Poison River" and "The Death of Speedy," two collections of the Love & Rockets comics by Gilbert and Jaime Hernandez; "The Keepsake Storm," a collection of poetry by Gina Franco; and "The Housekeeper and the Professor," by the Japanese writer Yoko Ogawa, about a brilliant mathematician whose short-term memory is impaired after an accident, and who develops a close relationship with his caretaker and her 10-year-old son. (Dennis Overbye described it in the Book Review last year as "deceptively elegant," "written in such lucid, unpretentious language that reading it is like looking into a deep pool of clear water.")

Saab has previewed its new 9-4X model ahead of its introduction at the Los Angeles Auto Show media preview days, beginning Nov. 17. The medium-size crossover is a legacy from General Motors, the Swedish company's previous owner, to the new owner, Spyker. It gives dealers a much needed third item to display in their windows beside the 9-3X and the new 9-5 -- and one with available 4-wheel drive. A 9-5 SportCombi or station wagon is also due later.

Guy Hands, the charismatic British financier, took the witness stand on Tuesday before a packed federal courtroom in Lower Manhattan to pursue his fight with Citigroup. Mr. Hands's private-equity firm, Terra Firma Capital Partners, has sued the bank over its failed buyout of the EMI Group, accusing Citigroup of lying to him about the presence of another bidder during the auction of the music company.

In New York, two of the fall's most discussed phenomena have been the openings of Lincoln and Osteria Morini; both restaurants take an almost obsessive approach to pared-down, classic Italian cuisine, and both are fronted by a well-promoted star chef with proven talent (Jonathan Benno and Michael White respectively).
Johnson & Johnson said on Tuesday that its third-quarter sales this year fell by 0.7 percent to $15 billion, largely due to recalls at its McNeil Consumer Healthcare unit.

Economix has a report on a new study which found that people who purchase their groceries with credit cards are more likely to buy cookies, cakes and pies ("vice items," in the researcher's parlance) than consumers who pay cash. The design of the study, in the Journal of Consumer Research, does not control for all variables, but the findings offer an intriguing suggestion that shoppers might be able to curtail calorie-laden impulse buys simply by carrying a fat bankroll (which, you will be thrilled to learn, you can assemble yourself with an elastic taken from a bunch of broccoli.)

I suppose it is like this with other sports, too, that if you're partial to golf or boxing or auto racing, you will find yourself smiling at just as many sidelights. ROCHESTER, Minn. -- For those who follow hockey closely but not the National Football League, the news that the N.F.L. is "considering" suspensions after a series of severely injurious helmet-to-helmet hits is astonishing -- and highlights the comparatively progressive stance of the N.H.L. in its longstanding policy of levying suspensions for dangerous plays. The three-game suspension of Shane Doan of Phoenix, handed down Monday, for his egregious sideswipe of Anaheim's Dan Sexton is an example of the N.H.L.'s policy in practice -- in particular its new rule against blindside hits to the head, for which this suspension is the stiffest so far:

A life-size sculpture of Ariel Sharon, the former Israeli prime minister who suffered a debilitating stroke in 2006, will be put on display in a gallery in Tel Aviv, BBC News reported. The sculpture, by the Israeli artist Noam Braslavsky, depicts Mr. Sharon in a hospital bed with his eyes open and his chest rising up and down as the work appears to breathe. Mr. Sharon, who never regained consciousness after his stroke, remains hospitalized in Tel Aviv.

"Sunglasses are symbolic of life in Los Angeles," says the California native and first-time eyewear designer Alex Israel. His collection, aptly called Freeway, includes five styles named after Route 1, Interstate 15, and the 10, 110 and 405 freeways. Each model was designed "to literally represent the landscape," Israel says. "Like, the 405 freeway covers territory from San Diego to Brentwood; the shape of the frame is a classic Kurt Cobain meets Jackie Kennedy. I envision the glasses on San Diego punk kids and Brentwood moms." If you can't beat the traffic, stop it. Grab a pair of modestly cool sunglasses from Freeway out of the glove compartment and have all eyes on you.Freeway Eyewear is available at Gagosian Shop, Barneys and Maxfield.

Nobody tell the Reverend Lovejoy, but Homer Simpson, the patriarch of the animated clan on Fox's "The Simpsons," is Catholic -- at least, according to the official newspaper of the Vatican, Reuters reported. In an essay published over the weekend in the newspaper, L'Osservatore Romano, Luca M. Possati writes: "Few people know it, and he does everything to hide it. But it's true: Homer J. Simpson is Catholic." As proof the essay cites a Jesuit priest's study of the 2005 "Simpsons" episode "The Father, the Son and the Holy Guest Star," in which Bart attends a Catholic school and Homer tries out the practice of confession. The study concludes that "The Simpsons" is "among the few TV programs for kids in which Christian faith, religion and questions about God are recurrent themes." (Never mind that Homer has said he is a follower of "that religion with all the well-meaning rules that don't work out in real life," which he explains to mean Christianity.)

A camera-store salesman recently steered me away from the compact, ultrahigh-tech camera I thought I wanted. Smaller is fine, he told me, but only if it fits in your pocket -- any bigger will end up hanging from your shoulder anyway, so what's the advantage? And don't buy based on fancy features, he added; the differences between comparable models rarely result in better pictures for amateurs. The one feature you'll really appreciate, he said, is how the camera feels in your hand.

Rodney Glassman, the Democrat who is running a long-shot campaign to unseat Senator John McCain of Arizona, lacks money, time and attention. But he does have his vocal chords and years of singing training. So why not sing his stump speech? To the tune of ''Sweet Home Alabama,'' that 1970s tune from Lynyrd Skynyrd, Mr. Glassman has begun distilling his attacks on Mr. McCain's leadership into lyrics and performing at campaign events. On Saturday night, he drew the most applause of anyone at a candidates' forum held by the Tohono O'odham Indians at the Desert Diamond Casino just outside Tucson.

6:06 p.m. | Updated The tumultuous Alaska Senate race thrust itself into the national spotlight again over the weekend, when private security guards hired by Joe Miller, the Republican nominee, handcuffed and detained the editor of an online news site at a campaign event in Anchorage on Sunday. The Miller campaign said in a statement late Sunday that the editor, Tony Hopfinger of Alaska Dispatch, was trying to create a ''confrontation'' with the candidate. The campaign, which described Mr. Hopfinger as a ''liberal blogger,'' also accused him of assaulting someone during the incident, a question and answer session with voters at a public school, and of ''making threatening gestures and movements towards the candidate.''

MOSKOWITZ--Leon D.,born October 21, 1925 died suddenly of a heart attack on October 15th after spending a joyous weekend with friends and family. Leon had a long and productive professional life, working at Met Life and developing the field of group health and life insurance. Leon was married to Gloria Levy for over fifty years. After Gloria died in 2001, Leon married Ruth Eisenberg. Leon is also survived by three sons, Mark who is married to Joey, Roy who is married to Anne, and Edward; and five grandchildren, Peter, Danny, Susan, Eli and Eva.

Three short hours from the cosmopolitan city of Brisbane, Australia, and a world away, I have arrived in the Solomon Islands. Stepping from the crisp tubular world of jet travel into the familiar thickness of tropical air, I descend the gangway into a place that once echoed with the thunder and stench of the Battle of Guadalcanal, a place first visited by American Museum of Natural History biologists nearly a century ago during an expedition that really did change the world, and a place still alive in a timeless blend of biological and cultural wonder that inspired my career as a biologist. I arrived here at Henderson Field on Guadalcanal nearly 15 years ago to study elusive forest birds. That was before I knew the details of the bloody battles that brought tens of thousands of American soldiers through this airstrip between 1942 and 1943, before I knew that my great-uncle preceded me here as a Marine, falling injured in the tawny hills.

When federal agents raided a home in central New Jersey on Wednesday, they discovered nothing short of a private armory, with pistols and rifles hidden throughout its 25-plus rooms. But they found something else - something, it would become clear later, that should give earthlings pause. First, the cache: Agents with the office of the inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services - the key word being ''human'' - raided the home in tandem with dozens of arrests in New York, California and elsewhere in a sprawling Medicare fraud case. In indictments unsealed on Wednesday, prosecutors accused people described as Armenian-American gang members of stealing doctors' and patients' identities online and submitting bogus claims to Medicare, reaping about $35 million over at least four years. The New Jersey home belonged to one defendant, who lived there with an extended family that included wives and children, but the inspector general's office declined to give his name or its address on Friday, because the investigation was ongoing. All that is knowable about the man, then, is contained within the four edges of a photograph snapped by an agent on his cellphone and provided to The New York Times. Whether the agent found the cache to be run of the mill or was understandably agog at what was spread before him remains unknown. ''This is not your grandfather's fraud anymore,'' said a deputy inspector general, Gerald Roy.

The troubled McNeil Consumer Healthcare unit of Johnson & Johnson said on Monday evening that it was voluntarily recalling nearly 128,000 bottles of Tylenol eight-hour caplets. McNeil said it had taken the action after some consumers complained of a musty or moldy odor in the products which are sold in the United States and Puerto Rico. In a statement, the company said that even though the risk of problems is remote, people should stop using the Tylenol caplets involved in the recall.

8 P.M. (ESPN) TIM RICHMOND: TO THE LIMIT Some say Mr. Richmond, above, lived life the way he raced cars: wide open. Nicknamed Hollywood, he was a wealthy outsider on the Nascar circuit, which is dominated by Southern, blue-collar, dirt-track racers, and he was a flamboyant showman who relished attention from the news media -- and from female admirers. In 1986, when he won seven Nascar races and finished third for the year in points, he seemed to be on the verge of stardom. But soon he would withdraw from racing, reportedly suffering from double pneumonia. The real culprit was AIDS, and on Aug. 13, 1989, Richmond died, a recluse at 34. Rory Karpf directed this latest entry in the ''30 for 30'' documentary series. 8 P.M.
