Esther Tuttle is nearing the end of the 10th decade of a remarkably productive and adventurous life. If all continues to go well for her, next July 1 she will join the rapidly growing clan of centenarians, whose numbers in the United States have swelled to 104,099 in 2009 from 38,300 in 1990. At 99, she has an acute memory of events, names, dates and places. Thirty years her junior, I couldn't begin to recall the kinds of details that remain fresh in her still very active mind. I can only hope, should I live that long, to be as vibrant and fit as she is.

After 12 hours of walking, climbing and crawling through tangles of huge roots, fern trees and bamboo, our full team has reached and settled into our high camp. We are perched in a small cleft at 1,600 meters elevation on the flanks of Veve, the highest point on Kolombangara. Moving about here is like balancing in the canopy of a huge moss-covered tree, the ground one or two meters beneath a lattice of roots and prostrate trunks of trees that twist up, stunted, into the mist that drips incessantly.

I awoke in the Solomon Airlines Twin Otter yesterday afternoon and looked groggily out the window. Below sprawled a bewildering array of islands, reefs and tropical ocean blues. On the short one-hour flight between Guadalcanal and my destination in the New Georgia Islands, we traversed the entire geographic ranges of numerous bird species. Laid out almost like a textbook diagram, the geography has helped shape our concept of what a species is. After landing in Munda on New Georgia Island, we had to lug all 140 pounds of my gear to the wharf, pack and rainproof it in our trusty motor canoe, called Imasa -- which in Roviana means ''to linger somewhere on the way to someplace else'' -- and then pick up 200 liters of fuel (about 53 gallons) that had to be pumped from old 200-liter drums and poured into our running and auxiliary tanks in five-liter pitchers.

The right of photographers to stand in a public place and take pictures of federal buildings has been upheld by a legal settlement reached in New York. In the ever-escalating skirmishes between photographers and security agencies, the most significant battlefield is probably the public way - streets, sidewalks, parks and plazas - which has customarily been regarded as a vantage from which photography cannot and should not be barred.

Sometimes Kanye West gets what he wants and sometimes he doesn't: while a new film he has written and directed will soon make its television debut, the cover art he proposed for his new album will not be hitting stores any time soon. We'll just have to assume he's O.K. with that. On Monday press representatives for Mr. West said that his film ''Runaway,'' based on his single of the same title, would be shown Saturday at 8 p.m. Eastern time on MTV, BET and MTV2, and would also be streamed live on MTV.com, BET.com and VH1.com. A news release described the film, which stars Mr. West and the fashion model Selita Ebanks, as a ''tale of loss and renewal'' through which the rapper has been able to realize his dream of ''bringing his music to life in the form of film.'' The television broadcasts of the film will be followed by a live interview with Mr. West.

DreamWorks Theatricals, which made its first attempt to transform a movie property into a Broadway show in 2008 with ''Shrek the Musical,'' is now teaming up with Broadway Across America for DreamWorks's first live family touring show based on its ''Madagascar'' film series, the two companies announced on Monday. The 90-minute stage show, titled ''Madagascar Live,'' is expected to visit more than 70 cities across the United States beginning in January, including a run at New York's Radio City Music Hall, April 15-24. The stage show will feature the main characters from the movie series, about a group of animals who escape from the Central Park Zoo and wind up stranded in far-off Madagascar.

At this stage of a campaign year, the fight to get voters out to the polls joins at every level -- in the air (that is, TV), on the ground (door-to-door canvassers), in cyberspace (e-mail, Twitter, text messages) and, yes, in old fashioned, but ever-reliable, mail boxes, which are about to start bursting with political pitches and attacks. In his DealBook column, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes about a conversation with Felix Rohatyn, the veteran investment banker who helped save New York City from bankruptcy in the 1970s, advised RJR Nabisco on its sale to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in the 1980s and sold Columbia Pictures to Sony in the 1990s. About to publish a memoir about his major deals in finance, Mr. Rohatyn reveals some uneasiness about his own industry and its effect on society. ''No matter how much I try to be really objective, the financial community has not covered itself with glory in these last 50 years,'' he said.

MARKS--Richard A.,MD. It is with deep sadness that the entire community at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center acknowledges the passing of our dear friend and devoted colleague, Richard A. Marks, MD, who served with great distinction in many important roles at SLR during his more than 40 years of service. Dr. Marks began his association with SLR as an intern and resident in the mid 1960s, and quickly became one of our busiest general surgeons. In the early 2000s, at the request of the Board of Trustees, he became Interim Chairman of the Department of Surgery while a search was conducted for a new, full-time clinical chairman. Following that search, he continued to serve in the key leadership role as Vice Chairman of Surgery, a position he held until his retirement a few years ago. Dr. Marks was an extraordinarily productive and devoted surgeon whose skillful work helped thousands of patients. His gentle demeanor, extreme attention to detail and playful sense of humor were appreciated by all who knew him, worked with him and were treated by him. We extend heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Ronni, his children Michael, Rebecca and JoAnna, the entire Marks family and all of his loved ones. He will be greatly missed. Frank J. Cracolici, President Oscar Garfein, MD, President, Medical Board George J. Todd, MD, Chairman, Dept. of Surgery

In his DealBook column, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes about a conversation with Felix Rohatyn, the veteran investment banker who helped save New York City from bankruptcy in the 1970s, advised RJR Nabisco on its sale to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in the 1980s and sold Columbia Pictures to Sony in the 1990s. About to publish a memoir about his major deals in finance, Mr. Rohatyn reveals some uneasiness about his own industry and its effect on society. OFFNER--Elliot Melville, 79, of Washington Avenue in Northampton, MA, passed away peacefully on Friday, October 15, 2010 at his home with his beloved wife, Rosemary at his side, after a long battle with cancer. Offner was born in Brooklyn, NY on July 12, 1931, the son of the late Samuel and Helen (Wolowitz) Offner. He was raised in Brooklyn and attended Erasmus Hall High School and the Cooper Union before receiving a B.F.A. and an M.F.A. from Yale University. In 1960 he joined the faculty at Smith College, where he was appointed Andrew W. Mellon Professor of the Humanities in 1974. He has been a Visiting Artist at Brandeis, Yale, the Royal College of Art in London, and various colleges at Cambridge University in England. He was a Life Fellow of Clare Hall, Cambridge. Offner is best known as a sculptor in the academic tradition, working in many sculptural media, including carved wood, clay, plaster, and bronze, and his subjects included both animals and human figures. But he was also known for the great variety of his artistic outlets which included bookmaking, painting, graphic art and photography. Offner has received many honors during his long and distinguished career, including awards from the Louis Comfort Tiffany Foundation, the National Institute of Arts and Letters, the National Council on the Arts and Humanities, and gold medals from the National Sculpture Society, of which he is Past President, and the National Academy of Design, of which he was First Vice President. Offner was named Master Wildlife Artist for 2003 by the Leigh Yawkey Woodson Art Museum in Wausau, WI. Along with the exhibition, Offner was the focus of an impressive four-page spotlight on sculpture in the prestigious contemporary art magazine American Art Collector. His art work - both sculpture and graphic arts - is found in many private and public collections including the Hirshhorn Museum, the Brooklyn Museum and Sculpture Garden, the Huntington Sculpture Garden, the Museum of Fine Arts in Springfield, MA, and Brookgreen Gardens in Pawleys Island, SC, which dedicated the Elliot and Rosemary Offner Sculpture Learning and Research Center in 2007. His many commissions include a monumental bronze and granite water sculpture in downtown Minneapolis, sculptures at Converse College (South Carolina), Smith College and the Darien (CT) Library, and a Holocaust Memorial in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York. Offner is survived by his wife of 53 years, Rosemary (O'Connell) Offner, his children Helen Ong of Norwalk, CT, Daniel Offner of Santa Monica, CA, and Emily Hollidge of Eagan, MN, his brother Arnold Offner of Newton, MA, and nine grandchildren. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Interment services will be private at the convenience of the family, and the Czelusniak Funeral Home of Northampton has been entrusted with services. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston. (www.dana-farber.org).

The New York Philharmonic took a step closer to filling a key position this weekend, offering its vacant principal clarinet job to Ricardo Morales, who holds the post at the Philadelphia Orchestra. Mr. Morales sat in as a guest principal with the Philharmonic last week and was offered the job by the orchestra's music director, Alan Gilbert, before the performance on Saturday night, the Philharmonic spokesman Eric Latsky said on Sunday. Mr. Latzky said he had no immediate word on whether Mr. Morales would accept the position, adding that finishing any contract would be put on hold while the orchestra is on tour in Europe.

One of the feats that elite chess players can do that always seems to amaze people who do not play chess (or play it very little) is competing against many opponents at the same time. New technologies have always brought new ways of telling stories. On this week's New York Times Tech Talk podcast, J.D. Biersdorfer talks to Anthony Zuiker, the creator of the hit TV show "CSI: Crime Scene Investigation," about his latest digi-novel, "Dark Prophecy." What's a digi-novel? As Mr. Zuiker explains, it's "the best of publishing, motion picture and social communities all kind of meshed into one experience." Every 25 pages, readers get a code they can take to a Web site, where they can watch a video segment that bridges the chapters. "Dark Prophecy," a thriller, is the second book in Mr. Zuiker's "Level 26" series. He tells Ms. Biersdorfer that an iPad app with interactive features is expected next month.

We left Kolombangara on our first clear morning. By midday, gushing rain transformed the lower-elevation forests into torrents of braided streams that formed and reticulated as we wandered, obliterating all signs of our passage. What little there was of a trail was gone, turned streambed. So we just went down, followed water, became it in the steady downpour.

Creative multitasking seems to run in the Spade company, well, in spades. Kate Spade New York's president and creative director, Deborah Lloyd for one, is sporting the hat of publisher these days with the release of "She Is Quick and Curious and Playful and Strong," a collection of short stories produced in conjunction with the Strand bookstore. Among the seven authors commissioned for the project is Laurie Baker, whose "Go in Peace, Not in Pieces" explores the youthful desire to surrender oneself to love. In the story, which is set in Swaziland, South Africa, the narrator and her companion spend a few days in the Malolotja Nature Reserve, home to a myriad of animals, including zebras, the inspiration for the book's cover art. Baker, along with her fellow writers Bridie Clark, Hannah Seligson and Sara Vilkomerson, will give a reading at the Strand on Oct. 27 from 7 to 8. The complete boxed set is $35 at Kate Spade New York shops, the Strand and katespade.com.

The French designer Jean-Michel Frank lived a short life - he committed suicide in 1941, at the age of 46 - but his interior and furniture designs became among the most influential of his century, and they haven't lost their power to astonish. A case in point is the exhibition "Jean-Michel Frank in Argentina," which opens today (and runs through Nov. 19) at Gallery BAC in SoHo. The gallery - which was founded in 2001 by the architect Carlos Aparicio to sell 20th-century design of the elegant, pared-down style that Frank epitomized - is showing more than 30 objects in this exhibition, the first devoted to Frank's work in, and influence on, Argentina in the 1930s and 1940s. (A catalog, with an essay by the gallery's director, James Buresh, offers plentiful illustrations.)

Does a hard-working woman sweat like a man? That question, which has figured in many an antiperspirant commercial, has received surprisingly little scientific scrutiny. But a new study published this month in the journal Experimental Physiology provides persuasive evidence that women do sweat copiously during exercise. (Did anyone really believe they misted?) But fit women seem to sweat differently than unfit people of either sex, and quite differently than fit men, a fact that has implications for sports performance. It also may have some bearing on what it has meant, since prehistory, to be female.

GULKER--Barbara. Barbara's daughter Nancy, and her family and friends mourn her death on Tuesday, October 19, 2010. She died peacefully at home after a short illness. She was a talented artist, crossword puzzle aficionado, and spent as much time at the beach as possible. She was an avid Miami Hurricanes fan and loved the New York Jets. She was the smartest woman we knew and she will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, please donate to your favorite charity.

Nobody tell the Reverend Lovejoy, but Homer Simpson, the patriarch of the animated clan on Fox's ''The Simpsons,'' is Catholic -- at least, according to the official newspaper of the Vatican, Reuters reported. In an essay published over the weekend in the newspaper, L'Osservatore Romano, Luca M. Possati writes: ''Few people know it, and he does everything to hide it. But it's true: Homer J. Simpson is Catholic.'' As proof the essay cites a Jesuit priest's study of the 2005 ''Simpsons'' episode ''The Father, the Son and the Holy Guest Star,'' in which Bart attends a Catholic school and Homer tries out the practice of confession. The study concludes that ''The Simpsons'' is ''among the few TV programs for kids in which Christian faith, religion and questions about God are recurrent themes.'' (Never mind that Homer has said he is a follower of ''that religion with all the well-meaning rules that don't work out in real life,'' which he explains to mean Christianity.) Al Jean, an executive producer and show runner of ''The Simpsons,'' advised not to take the Osservatore essay as gospel. In an interview with EW.com, the Web site of Entertainment Weekly, Mr. Jean said the Simpsons family attends the First Church of Springfield, which is ''Presbylutheran,'' adding: ''We've pretty clearly shown that Homer is not Catholic. I really don't think he could go without eating meat on Fridays-for even an hour.''

MITZNER--Melvyn. The members and staff of Keane & Beane, P.C. mourn the loss of Mel Mitzner, our great friend and highly esteemed Senior Counsel. We extend our deepest condolences to Roz, Jeff and Meryl, Elaine and Steven and the entire Mitzner family.

If you haven't had the pleasure, get hold of the book ''Naked City'' by the photographer known as Weegee. Chapter Nine begins: ''The crime Teletype machine was quiet at Police Headquarters ... so I decided to sneak away and go to the opening of the opera.'' This describes Weegee perfectly. Not only his range of interests, but his energy. He photographed all things urban: accident scenes, fires, showgirls, drunks, families sleeping on fire escapes, murderers being arrested, and countless victims of misfortunes. But this Coney Island spectacular, taken on July 22, 1940, never fails to amaze. You have to ask: How could this be? Was it a special occasion? Weegee himself answers, again in ''Naked City'': ''And this is Coney Island on a quiet Sunday afternoon.'' Earlier photographs in the series are at nytimes.com/lens.

I walked into my office last Nov. 2, the day after the New York City Marathon, feeling pretty good about myself. Actually, I limped in, to be precise. But that didn't dull the glow even the slightest. A year and a half before, having wandered into the clichéd midlife morass of malaise and discontent, I'd set a goal of running the 26.2 miles as a personal reclamation project. Thirty pounds lighter, I crossed the finish line in 4 hours 30 minutes and a shade under 1 second, dragging my happier, more settled soul across with me.

ANN ARBOR, Mich. -- Representative John D. Dingell, the longest-serving member of the House, remembers his first campaign, in 1955, when his political ears were damp and a host of popular candidates unnerved him. Mr. Dingell can recall in stinging detail the primary battle of 1964, when he faced off with an opponent who did not support the Civil Rights Act as he did. And then there was 2002, when redistricting forced him into a contest with a sitting congresswoman. He even recalls the election fights waged by his father, who held the same seat from 1933 until 1955. About this year he is unequivocal.

HENKIN--Louis. Yeshiva University mourns the passing of a humble giant called the "Father of Modern Human Rights Law" and a classic legal scholar and author on works of constitutional law and international law and foreign policy. Scion of the revered Rabbi Yosef Eliyahu Henkin, of blessed memory, he was an alumnus of the Marsha Stern Talmudical Academy, Yeshiva University High School for Boys, and Yeshiva College, where he earned a bachelor's degree before his acceptance to Harvard Law School. He was a founding member of Yeshiva University's Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law and later served as an honorary director. Yeshiva University conferred upon him an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree in 1963 as an expression of the pride he brought to his alma mater through his universally recognized achievements in service to our nation as a legal scholar, Silver Star awardee from the Armed Services, and author on legal and foreign affairs, and his fidelity to the Jewish heritage. Heartfelt condolences to his wife, Alice Hartman Henkin, and his sons, Joshua, David and Daniel and their spouses, and his five grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor

Economic and political uncertainties are casting a long shadow over Wall Street. Goldman Sachs, which consistently manages to outsmart its rivals when it comes to making money, posted rather ordinary results on Tuesday for the third quarter. The earnings report was the most telling illustration yet of how the slowdown in trading has dented the Wall Street profit machines. Global markets remain fragile two years after the credit crisis unleashed the worst economic rout since the Great Depression. Investors, stung by the May flash crash when the Dow Jones industrial average briefly plunged more than 900 points before recovering, remain shaken and are staying close to the sidelines.

A life-size sculpture of Ariel Sharon, the former Israeli prime minister who suffered a debilitating stroke in 2006, will be put on display in a gallery in Tel Aviv, BBC News reported. The sculpture, by the Israeli artist Noam Braslavsky, depicts Mr. Sharon in a hospital bed with his eyes open and his chest rising up and down as the work appears to breathe. Mr. Sharon, who never regained consciousness after his stroke, remains hospitalized in Tel Aviv. In a video interview with the BBC, Mr. Braslavsky said, ''I choose to take Sharon because Sharon is kind of an open nerve in Israeli society which activated all the spectrum of emotional feelings to what being an Israeli is.'' Curators for the installation, which will be displayed at the Kishon Art Gallery starting on Thursday, told the BBC it was an allegory for the ''inertia of Israeli politics.''

Predeceased by her son Philip, she is survived by her daughter Gloria Craighead Mancuso, son-in-law Michael, and her grandchildren Matthew Philip and Caroline Frances, all of Glen Rock, NJ. OSAKA, Japan -- For years, promoters of sumo wrestling have been pushing for the sport's inclusion in the Olympic Games. To get there, the International Sumo Federation has thrown its weight behind a form of the game that would offend purists and surprise most everyone else: women's sumo. Sumo officials have long tried to get their sport, for years identified with giant men slapping each other in the ring, into the Summer Games. But when the International Olympic Committee declared in 1994 that single-sex sports could no longer qualify as candidates for the Games, that was enough to turn tradition on its head. Since then, sumo has been coming into its own internationally as an equal opportunity sport.

GOLDSMITH--John Frank, on October 14, age 92, beloved husband of the late Caroline Steinholz Lerner and longtime resident of New York City and Chappaqua, NY. Father of Katherine Paradise of Boston, Elizabeth Hilton of Fairfax, CA, and John Goldsmith Jr. of Plainfield, IL, stepfather of David Lerner, grandfather of Alisse Wissman, Chris Goldsmith and Alex Hilton, and brother-in-law of Elizabeth Goldsmith. Survived also by dear friend Margot Tallmer. Graduated from Bronxville high school in 1936, attended Bard College for two years, and graduated from University of Colorado in 1940. In World War II, led an infantry platoon in Italy and France; wounded out of action and awarded a purple heart; subsequently assigned to stevedore battalion and eventually stationed 12 miles from Hiroshima. Long and successful writing and editorial career -- chief editor of Housing magazine (fka House & Home), managing editor of Fleet Owner, and on staff of Factory magazine. Caring and committed family man, steadfast friend, and passionate supporter of liberal and humanitarian values. We will miss your grit, your intense loyalty, your deep convictions, your physical determination, your love of words and ideas, and your commitment to making the world a better place. In lieu of flowers, donations in John's name to Center for Victims of Torture, www.cvt.org or 1-877-265-8775.

FUCHS--James E. of New York City, passed away peacefully, surrounded by his family, on October 8, 2010. He was 82 years old. He was a champion - athletically, in business, philanthropy and as a loving father, husband and grandfather. A man among men with a broad smile and hearty shake, he was treasured by all. Since its inception in 1982, he was President of the Silver Shield Foundation, an organization founded by George M. Steinbrenner, III and Mr. Fuchs, which provides financial support for the education of children and widows of Police Officers, Firefighters and State Troopers in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, who are killed in the line of duty. Mr. Fuchs was President, Chairman and CEO of Fuchs, Cuthrell & Co., Inc., a pioneer in corporate executive out placement and executive consulting, from 1971 to 1994. He was a 1950 Yale Graduate, a medalist in the 1948 and 1952 Olympic Games, and gold medalist in the shot put and discus in the first Pan American Games in 1951. Mr. Fuchs, a world record holder in indoor and outdoor shot put, is listed in the "Guinness Book of Track and Field Facts" for winning 88 consecutive shot put competitions - a record at the time and still second in history for male athletes. He is survived by his brother, Richard G. Fuchs, Jr. of California; his fiancee, Mary St. George; his seven children, Bettina Barrington McCarthy, Barrington "Bingy" Greenough, Holly Armstrong Fuchs, Victoria Holland and Kimberley Corbin "K.C." Fuchs and their mother Barrington King Fuchs; Nicholas and Slater Fuchs and their mother, Anne Sutherland Fuchs and seven grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held at Frank E. An Associated Press report in some copies of the N.F.L. Roundup column on Tuesday about the Tennessee Titans' 30-3 victory over Jacksonville on Monday night misstated the extent of the Jaguars' futility on offense. The Jaguars entered the Titans' territory three times, not two.

Reuters Breakingviews, a news service whose market-analysis articles are published in the business pages of The Times, has identified several past articles in which a writer had a financial interest in the subject or traded in related investments before or after publication. Three of those articles appeared in The Times: on June 4, about BP; and on March 9 and last Dec. 28, involving Lloyds Banking Group. The Times prohibits staff reporters and editors from owning stock or having any other financial interest in a company that they cover, and Reuters said the articles in question also violated its own rules on conflicts of interest. The Times would not have published the articles if editors had known of the conflict.

The Cutler Chase Is On Although Kyle Orton's current form suggests that the Broncos got the better of a big swap withthe Bears, JAY CUTLER's numbers have improved to the point where he is fourth in my adjusted quarterback ratings -- and has a traditional rating in the 90s. One problem: He's running for his life. While I generally prefer to focus on the empirical, I applied the''eyeball test'' while watching the Bears game on Sunday against Seattle, and every play looked like a game of playground football -- with Cutler playing the unlucky guy who is constantly running away from the bully who counted five Mississippis too fast. According to ProFootballReference.com, Cutler is being sacked on 14 percent of his drop-backs (sacks plus pass attempts)-- worst in the league. This would represent the highest sack rate in the N.F.L. since Andrew Walter was sacked on 14.3 percent of his drop-backs in 2006.Studies have shown that quarterbacks are partly responsible for their sacks -- they can't all be blamed on the offensive line. But in 2008, Cutler's last season in Denver, he was sacked on only 1.8 percent of his attempts --11 times (or, two more than hewas in one half against the Gi-ants) on 616 attempts. Before this season, his average sack rate was4.8 percent. Jumping from a career average of 4.8 percent to 14 percent represents a statistical anomaly that puts more of the on us -- in this case -- on the offensive line.LUIS DeLOUREIRO

''Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo,'' an Iraq War play by Rajiv Joseph that had an acclaimed production in Los Angeles, may come to Broadway in the spring with Robin Williams in the title role. Moises Kaufman, who directed the Los Angeles production, said Monday that a New York engagement depended on continuing negotiations among the producers, Robyn Goodman and Kevin McCollum, and Mr. Williams. While he said it was not yet a sure thing, Mr. Kaufman expressed optimism that the play, a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize in drama this year, would arrive on Broadway. (The website Broadway.com first reported that the production would open on Broadway in the spring.)

9 P.M. (History) I AM ALIVE: SURVIVING THE ANDES PLANE CRASH Before the Chilean miners there were the Uruguayan rugby players, who, on Oct. 13, 1972, were stranded on a glacier at 12,000 feet when their charter plane crashed in the Andes, straddling the border between Chile and Argentina, above. More than a quarter of the 45 passengers on board, including friends and relatives of the team, died in the crash; others perished in the days to come. Eventually the last 16 survivors resorted to cannibalism to stay alive for nearly two and a half months. In this episode one survivor, Nando Parrado, recounts his weeks on the peak and his marathon journey in search of help. Mr. Parrado wrote about his experiences in ''Miracle in the Andes: 72 Days on the Mountain and My Long Trek Home,'' his 2006 best seller with Vince Rause, which Jon Krakauer, the author of ''Into Thin Air,'' called ''an astonishing account of an unimaginable ordeal.'' 4 P.M. Regulators have rejected a new diabetes drug, Bydureon, made by Eli Lilly & Company and Amylin Pharmaceuticals, the companies said late Tuesday. The companies said that study could delay approval for about two years.

If there was a political attack that could have been predicted, it has to be this one: national Republicans are hitting Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader from Nevada, for living at the Ritz-Carlton. When he is in Washington, Mr. Reid lives in an apartment at the posh hotel. The optics of that would be bad for a politician at almost any time. But it's especially unfortunate at a moment when Mr. Reid's home state is ground zero for the housing and foreclosure crisis.

The Wines of The Times column last Wednesday, about Sonoma zinfandels, misstated the provision of the federal labeling law on alcohol content. Wines listing an alcohol content of 14 percent or less by volume are permitted a 1.5 percentage-point margin of error, as long as the actual content does not exceed 14 percent, and wines listing an alcohol content above 14 percent are permitted a 1 percentage-point margin of error, as long as the actual content is more than 14 percent. In each case, the allowable margins of error do not apply on a plus/minus basis. Because of this error, the column also misstated the possible alcohol content of two wines. The 2007 Nalle Dry Creek Valley, labeled at 13.8 percent, could be no higher than 14 percent, not as high as 15.3 percent. The 2007 Porter Creek Old Vine, labeled 14.7 percent, could be no lower than 14.1 percent, not as low as 13.7 percent.

He didn't stand in the way of ''The Village'' or ''Predators,'' but Adrien Brody doesn't want anyone to see a new horror movie he stars in and which is slated to be released Tuesday on DVD. Mr. Brody, the Academy Award-winning star of ''The Pianist,'' has filed suit against the makers of ''Giallo,'' an Italian horror movie directed by Dario Argento, whose past films include ''Suspiria,'' The Hollywood Reporter said. In ''Giallo,'' which never received a theatrical release in the United States, Mr. Brody plays a detective who is helping a woman find her sister, who has been kidnapped by a serial killer. Mr. Brody said in a lawsuit filed Thursday in California that his deal for the film guaranteed he would be paid whether it was made or not. But after about a week of production, Mr. Brody said, its producers failed to pay $640,000 into an escrow account. Instead they signed the actor to a new agreement under which he would finish the film in exchange for the ''absolute right to withhold consent to the use of his likeness'' until he was fully paid, according to The Hollywood Reporter. After his work was completed, Mr. Brody said, he was never paid, and the producers ignored his demands.

FULLER--R. Clinton, Professor Emeritus at University of Massachusetts, passed away on October 18, 2010, at the age of 85. He was predeceased by his wife of 63 years, Carol Seager Fuller, in December 2009. He leaves his four children, David, Lynn, Jonathan Fuller and Katherine Tolsdorf. Clint graduated from Brown University ('46) before earning his Ph.D. at Stanford in Microbiology. This began a long productive career in science that produced hundreds of published journal articles. Clint was a progressive educator and scientist, believing in an international scientific community without political boundaries. He was a recipient of the Alexander von Humboldt fellowship at the University of Freiburg, and was awarded an honorary doctoral degree at Moscow State University. Clint's scientific research, especially into the biochemical mechanisms of photosynthesis, remains pivotal to the understanding of how plants turn sunlight into energy. Clint received his doctoral thesis under Edward Tatum, worked for Melvin Calvin, and did postdoctoral research with Sir Hans Krebs. Clint often joked that he gave these Nobel Laureates his best ideas. He was a man of great energy, enthusiasm, and intense curiosity who worked tirelessly to help promote and encourage his young graduate students. He is greatly loved and will be missed. A memorial service for friends and family will be held in Providence at the chapel at Swan Point Cemetery at 12:00noon on Friday, October 22. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Machiasport Historical Society, Rt. 92, Machiasport, ME 04655. Personal messages may be sent to Jonathan Fuller at 18 Bellaire Dr., Huntington, NY 11743.

The award-winning fashion designer Richard Chai has partnered with Daniel Arsham and Alex Mustonen of the avant-design firm Snarkitecture to create an elaborately carved "ice" cavern for a new pop-up shop opening Thursday evening. Conceived by Boffo, an art and culture nonprofit group, and the architect/writer Spilios Gianakopoulos to promote visibility for designers and artists, the project - titled Building Fashion - consists of a series of five rotating installations in a space underneath the High Line (504 West 24th Street). The five participating fashion designers (Simon Spurr, Heather Huey, House of Waris, Richard Chai and Siki Im), none of whom has a freestanding store, were each given the opportunity to create a three-dimensional representation of his or her brand. Chai said he wanted to avoid "the straightforward clothes-on-a-rack retail space" in favor of creating "an environment, a feeling, more of an emotional experience." The "cave," which is hand carved from high-density Styrofoam, also allows for irregular crevices and crannies to display merchandise. The store will carry  Chai's men's and women's collections and will be open to the public until Oct. 31 (noon to 6 p.m.), so head over there quickly before it "melts."

Just nine days after the Obama Administration lifted the deepwater drilling moratorium, Chevron announced on Thursday that it was going forward with a $7.5 billion project to develop two giant deepwater fields in the gulf. The Jack and St. Malo fields hold in excess of 500 million barrels of recoverable hydrocarbons, the company said. That's roughly equal to the world's oil consumption in about five days -- nothing to sneeze at.

Dancers from New York City Ballet will perform at the International Ballet Festival in Havana next month, it was announced on Thursday. For the trip, under the auspices of the New York-based Cuban Artists Fund, eight principal dancers are going: Jared Angle, Tyler Angle, Megan Fairchild, Joaquin De Luz, Abi Stafford, Tiler Peck, Teresa Reichlen and Andrew Veyette. The program includes George Balanchine's "Tarantella"; pas de deux from his "Chaconne" and "Stars and Stripes"; and a concert version of "Who Cares." The dancers will also perform Jerome Robbins's "In the Night" and "Other Dances" and Christopher Wheeldon's "Liturgy." The performances will take place at the Teatro Mella on Nov. 1 and 2. American Ballet Theater is also performing at the festival.

The soprano Renée Fleming is dropping her longtime publicist, Mary Lou Falcone, and assigning public relations duties to employees of her own office, the singer's representatives said on Thursday. Ms. Falcone, one of the classical music industry's main P.R. agents, said the parting - which becomes official at the end of the year - was entirely amicable. "It's the conclusion of a very wonderful business relationship, which still remains in terms of friendship," Ms. Falcone said. "It's just simplifying her business situation by putting everything in house." Ms. Fleming was in Germany for a performance and unavailable for comment, her representatives said.

Yulianna Avdeeva, a 25-year-old Russian, won the top prize in the 16th Chopin International Piano Competition, officials in Warsaw announced on Wednesday. Second prizes were awarded to Lukas Geniusas of Russia and Lithuania and Ingolf Wunder of Austria. The event takes place every five years and is one of the most prestigious on the piano competition circuit. This year's winner, Ms. Avdeeva, is scheduled to perform with the New York Philharmonic on Oct. 29 in Warsaw, where the orchestra will stop while on a European tour, and on Jan. 4 in New York.

Elle Muliarchyk has seen enough psychics to take their soothsaying with a pinch of sodium chloride. A model turned photographer, she believes that the clothes she has worn on the day of her readings have influenced the prognostications she has received. During the making of "Somnambuli," Ms. Muliarchyk's fashion video, shot exclusively for T, about the power of clothes to affect our destiny, the model Meghan Collison underwent a series of high-fashion transformations and had her fortune read by various New York clairvoyants. "The same psychic who told the model to clean up her act when she was dressed like a hippie," Ms. Muliarchyk recalled, "saw Harvard in her future a few days later when she was dressed up like an Upper East Side lady." Spooky, huh?

The Juilliard String Quartet has named a new first violinist, only the fourth in its 64 years. He is Joseph Lin, 32, a Harvard University graduate who is a professor at Cornell University and an active soloist and chamber musician with a strong interest in Chinese culture. Mr. Lin will start with the quartet next year. He replaces Nick Eanet, who joined the quartet last season but had to withdraw for health reasons. Robert Mann, the founding first violinist, retired in 1997 and was succeeded by Joel Smirnoff, who was named president of the Cleveland Institute of Music in 2008.

In Wednesday's paper, David Leonhardt wrote about a proposal by Peter Bach of Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center and Steven Pearson of Mass General to reform how Medicare paid for new treatments and technologies. Under the plan, they would be reimbursed in full for three years. If they hadn't proven to be more effective than previous treatments and technologies after three years, however, they would be reimbursed at the (lower) rate of those previous technologies.

As I've become more aware of the urgent need to eat more sustainable seafood, I've been reaching for squid, clams, sardines, and especially mackerel whenever a fishy hunger strikes. Mackerel is a good fish that's gotten a bad rap, something I wrote about in my column yesterday. Many cooks have sworn off it, saying it's too heavy, too oily. And when it comes to the canned stuff, they're right. But mackerel can be mild and buttery, especially when very fresh. But, more importantly to me, it's the oiliness of mackerel that imparts its uniquely briny flavor. When cooked just so, mackerel is a fish you can love to serve as well as eat. And it's also relatively inexpensive.  Check out these links from the Monterey Bay Aquarium and The Guardian about mackerel sustainability. Recipes:

A while ago, just on the seam between summer and fall, I had a good dinner at a blessedly calm London restaurant called Gauthier. My first dish, after the initial sequence of snacky things, was a pair of olive-oil crisps with vegetables sandwiched between them. Kind of like a ratatouille, to give you some sense of the intensity of flavor. But this set of vegetables went beyond the usual summery Mediterranean standbys - eggplant, zucchini, peppers - to include things like carrots (which also grow in the summer, of course), all deeply flavorful both because they'd been carefully purchased and impeccably cooked. I'm guessing that each element of the mixture had been prepared separately - how else to account for eggplant and carrots that were both optimal?

LOS ANGELES-The tussle between producers of two planned films based on "The Hobbit" and a New Zealand union is still going on, despite a move on Wednesday by the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists to lift a ban that had kept members from working on the films. As of Thursday morning, according to a person briefed on the matter, Warner's New Line unit, which is supervising the production for Warner Brothers and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, was still considering a move to another country, in part because, in the studios' view, the New Zealand actors, despite having withdrawn their call for an international union boycott, are continuing to insist that the "Hobbit" producers conduct discussions that would run afoul of New Zealand law. A team of Warner executives is expected to be in New Zealand by Tuesday, both to assess the situation and to consider plans for production elsewhere.

Cire Trudon, the cult candle maker that once dipped tapers for Marie Antoinette, has transformed the corner of Bond Street and the Bowery into a tiny version of Versailles's Galerie des Glaces. The company's first Stateside outpost, which opens this week on the lower-ground level of the old Bouwerie Lane Theater, is filled with antique mirrors and historical French moldings and hardware - the perfect surroundings for perfumed candles, pillars and room sprays that conjure waxed palace floors and Madame de Pompadour's boudoir. Cire Trudon's 36-year-old owner, Ramdane Touhami, a forward-thinking classicist if ever there was one, invites customers to linger in the space for as long as they like. "Choosing a scent for your home should be like choosing one for your body," he says. "It takes time."

Because of growing alarm about the spread of MRSA and other hardy "superbugs," precautions like hand washing, physical isolation, gloves and masks have become a routine part of clinical life in hospitals. But despite their widespread use and acceptance, only a few studies have acknowledged that the rigidity and isolation inherent in such limitations may themselves lead to problems.
Fear of contagion and the masks, gloves and isolation it entails can compromise the quality of patient care.

Not that a Luxe City Guide ever took up much space in your pocket - its slim profile was always its genius. But these days it's always a cause for celebration when a traveler can dispense with paper altogether (however gorgeously laminated it may be) and bring all his intelligence with him on his smartphone. Our friends at Luxe have rolled out a wide collection of their snappy directories for iPhone, covering 20 cities in total, among them Los Angeles, Florence, Venice and Beijing. Now the hotels listings come with pictures; there are GPS-enabled maps and automatic updates; and the whole guide can be searched and personalized with itineraries based on your favorites. What remains from the dead-tree versions, of course, are the cheekily concise summations of a smart selection of accommodations, restaurants, shops, clubs and culture - along with sundry raves, grievances and anecdotes. If there's one thing lacking, it's that we might like to read more of what the Luxe founder Grant Thatcher and his team have to say about the three bistros we're trying to decide between (seriously, Thatcher's hilarious). In the Luddite version of the guide, each gets only a sentence. But now that we're measuring in megabytes and not column inches, why not gas on a bit?

NATIONAL An article and a chart on Wednesday about Representative John Dingell's campaign for re-election to Congress misstated the number of times that the Michigan Democrat has been elected to the House. And because of that error, the headline referred incorrectly to his expectations for a victory in November. Starting with the 1955 special election to complete his father's term, Mr. Dingell has won 28 times -- not 29, as the article and chart said. Therefore he is ''counting on his 29th victory'' -- not his 30th, as the headline said.

Peter Jackson said that preparations were under way to move the production of a two-film adaptation of ''The Hobbit'' from New Zealand to another country because of a labor dispute with actors' unions in New Zealand and Australia, The Press of New Zealand reported. In a statement reported by The Press, Mr. Jackson, the producer and likely director of the ''Hobbit'' films, and Fran Walsh, his wife and production partner, said that even a lifting of a ban sought by the actors' unions would do ''nothing to help the film stay in New Zealand.'' Mr. Jackson and Ms. Walsh added that ''the damage inflicted on our film industry'' is ''long since done.''

A headline on Wednesday about explanatory videos featuring the chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers misspelled his surname. As the article and a caption correctly noted, he is Austan Goolsbee, not Gooslbee.

WARREN--William B. The partners, counsel, associates and administrative staff of Dewey & LeBoeuf mourn the passing of William Warren, our former colleague and dear friend. Bill joined the firm in 1959 after attending Harvard for both his undergraduate and law degrees. He was elevated to partner in 1968 and later became chairman of the Trusts and Estates Department. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Arete Swartz Warren, his children and there family. We all remember Bill as a devoted friend and colleague. He will be missed.

Media Matters, the liberal activist group that wages a rhetorical war against Fox News Channel and others in the conservative press, will announce on Wednesday the receipt of a $1 million donation from the philanthropist George Soros. In a statement obtained by The Caucus, the organization says it plans to use the money to intensify its efforts to hold the Fox host Glenn Beck and others on the cable news channel accountable for their reporting.

It is becoming something of a monthly ritual, as campaign finance reports are filed with the Federal Election Commission, to gape at the kinds of outsize checks from wealthy donors flowing into the independent groups that are playing such a large role in the midterm elections this year. At the center of attention has been American Crossroads, one of two third-party groups tied to Karl Rove. The group's reports, filed on Wednesday with the commission and covering the period from Sept. 1 to Oct. 13, did not disappoint.

Cory Gardner's latest campaign ad seems to have hit a bit off the mark - er, make that, off the Markey. In a 30-second spot released Tuesday, Mr. Gardner, a Republican running against Representative Betsy Markey, the incumbent Democrat, to represent Colorado's Fourth Congressional District, begins his ad by trying to tie Ms. Markey to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California. As images of Ms. Markey flash by, the ad says she voted for ''the most fiscally irresponsible budget in history.''

COOPER--Helen S. The Board of Directors and staff of Citizens' Committee for Children of New York (CCC) mourn the passing of Helen S. Cooper. Mrs. Cooper took CCC's Community Leadership Course in 1962, became a member of CCC in 1963, and served on the Board of Directors for 24 years, from 1979-2003. Her love of the arts was evident in the many art-related fundraisers Mrs. Cooper helped plan for CCC, from the 1960s on, but her enduring interest was in juvenile justice, where she received several statewide appointments and was a force to be reckoned with. We extend our condolences to her family and friends. Marcy Sandler, Chairman Chris Stern Hyman, President Jennifer March-Joly, Executive Director

FRONT PAGE An article on Wednesday about a telephone message left by Virginia Thomas, the wife of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas, seeking an apology from Anita Hill for having accused him during his confirmation hearings of sexual harassment misstated, in some copies, the circumstances under which Justice Thomas joined the court. The vacancy he filled was created by the retirement of Justice Thurgood Marshall, in 1991 -- not by his death, in 1993.

PORTLAND, Ore. -- President Obama began his four-day campaign swing on Wednesday to fortify a Democratic firewall on the West Coast, telling a crowded rally here to ''defy the conventional wisdom just like you did in 2008,'' when Oregon overwhelmingly backed him for president. With two weeks to go until the midterm elections, Mr. Obama is trying desperately to shore up the Democratic base, appealing to voters in Oregon, Washington and California -- traditionally blue states where Republicans have been running competitive campaigns.

The Donald, and an astonishing $7 million from Bob Perry. They are among the highlights in a pair of campaign finance reports filed on Wednesday by American Crossroads, one of a pair of independent groups tied to Karl Rove that has drawn so much attention this year.

Nearly a decade after Derek Zoolander set out to find if there was ''more to life than being really, really, ridiculously good looking,'' that obliviously self-centered male model is coming back - this time, as a cartoon character on the Internet. Zoolander, the fashion plate played by Ben Stiller in his 2001 comedy of the same name, is one of two characters that Mr. Stiller will portray in a series of Web-based digital shorts for Paramount Digital Entertainment.

STERNHEIM--Robert, born in Leipzig, Germany, passed away at home on October 20, 2010 after a long illness. Devoted and loving husband and best friend of Lilly for 66 years. Beloved father of Susan (Neil) Glasgall and Judy Perline. Treasured and proud grandfather of Jason Schlessel, Stephanie Glasgall, Justin and Chloe Perline. A very caring and committed family man, very gentle and a very kind human being who will be greatly missed. Services: Thursday, October 21, 2010 1pm at Jewish Community Center of Harrison, 130 Union Avenue, Harrison, NY 10528.

Remote controllers for home electronics, be they weighty or featherweight, thick or thin, backlit by tiny bulbs or glow-in-the-dark buttons, have one bottom-line reason to live: functionality. Two new television products, both released to consumers this week, represent different concepts on the future of home entertainment, and different philosophies about the use and design of remote controls.

In the car industry, the preferred term for ''used'' is ''certified pre-owned.'' It would appear the term is becoming popular in the phone industry as well. Here's the lay of the land. Sprint has announced a new program that will sell previously owned phones at a deep discount. The inaugural deal offers a BlackBerry Tour for $80, a Samsung Reclaim for $50, or a Sanyo 2700 for $50. The Sprint refurbs carry a 30-day warranty, compared with one year for the same phone new. Also like new phones, refurbs come in a box with all of the accessories and manuals.

ROME -- Pope Benedict XVI named 24 new cardinals on Wednesday, adding fresh blood to the institution that will one day elect his successor and raising the chances that more electors of the next pope will be Italian. The group of cardinals, which is to be installed next month, includes two Americans: Archbishop Donald W. Wuerl of Washington, an expert in doctrine who delivered a prayer at President Obama's inauguration but has opposed some of the administration's social policies; and Archbishop Raymond L. Burke, the prefect of the Vatican's supreme court, who has been vocal in his criticism of the Democratic Party's support of abortion rights.

Combine the advances in capacity for solid-state drives with the increases in data transfer speed afforded by the new U.S.B. 3.0 platform, and the result looks something like Iomega's black slab. It's not called the black slab; in fact, the name, the Iomega U.S.B. 3.0 External SSD Flash Drive, doesn't conjure up an exotic piece of gear. Yet it is just that.

CHARNEY--Nellie Goodman. Born March 15, 1911 in London, England, she lived in Brooklyn, NY and East Hanover, NJ before moving in 2001 to the Lester Senior Housing in Whippany, NJ. Predeceased by her beloved husband Stanley in 1992, siblings Anna, Sara and David, she is survived by her devoted children Howard of Northridge, California and Carol Rosenblatt (Don) of West Orange, NJ (formerly of Livingston). Adored grandchildren are Cathy Beckman (Dr. Ken) of Randolph, NJ and Steven Rosenblatt of Manhattan. Treasured great-grandchildren are Carly Beckman and Matthew Beckman. Nellie was a multitalented force of nature, cherished by her family and friends. Services Friday, October 22, 10:30, at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Chapel, Livingston, NJ.
There are so many questionable aspects to this thing it's scary. REBEL A. COLE, professor of finance and real estate at DePaul University, on banks' handling of mortgages. [A1]

TUCCI--Paul, MD. The Board of Trustees, President and Faculty of the New York College of Podiatric Medicine note with sadness the passing of Paul Tucci, MD, long-time member of the Board of Trustees. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Stanley S. Mandel, Chairman Louis L. Levine, Pres. & CEO

MARKS--Richard, 68, passed away on October 15, 2010. He is remembered with admiration by many friends from City High in Iowa City, to Harvard College and Medical School in Boston, to St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in NYC. An extraordinary surgeon, he earned the esteem of his colleagues and the gratitude of his patients. His genuine passion for medicine was rivaled only by a devotion to family. Richard is loved and honored by his wife of 38 years, Roni; Aunt Marge and Uncle Jack Demitroff; cousins John and Anne, Amy and Heidi; children Michael, Rebecca and Joanna; grandchildren Emma and Jackson. A memorial service in celebration of life is planned for Saturday, November 20, 2pm at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center 1000 Tenth Avenue, NYC. Forever in our hearts, Roni, Michael, Rebecca and Joanna

The director Mike Nichols confirmed on Wednesday that he would mount a Broadway revival of ''Death of a Salesman'' next fall starring Philip Seymour Hoffman as Willy Loman and Linda Emond as Linda Loman. Mr. Hoffman, an Academy Award winner for ''Capote'' and a Tony Award nominee for ''True West'' and ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' has been eager to play Willy for some time, Mr. Nichols said in a telephone interview, and the two men have been making plans for a production for months. For Linda they both wanted Ms. Emond, who is perhaps best known for her multiple-award-winning performance as the Homebody in New York Theater Workshop's 2001 production of Tony Kushner's ''Homebody/Kabul.''

deMEIRELLES--Maria B.,on October 20, 2010. Wife of the late Luis. Mother of Kim Clendenin, Bill Lyons, George Caesar and Gigi Fitzgerald. Sister of Spruille Braden. Also survived by ten grandchildren and twelve great-grandchildren. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, 11am, St. John The Evangelist Church, East 55th St. and First Ave. Interment: Gate of Heaven Cemetery.
SCHLEIFER--Marjorie Minskoff (1916-2006) You are with us in loving memory. All our love. Jim, Jeannie, Alan, grandchildren & great-grandchildren

9 P.M. (CNN) ALMIGHTY DEBT ''Debt is a bigger problem than racism,'' says the Rev. DeForest B. Soaries Jr., pastor of the First Baptist Church of Lincoln Gardens in Somerset, N.J. In this latest entry in the ''Black in America'' series Soledad O'Brien (above, with Dr. Soaries) reports how some of Dr. Soaries's 7,000 parishioners are addressing financial challenges. Ms. O'Brien also moderates a discussion among Dr. Soaries; Bishop T. D. Jakes, senior pastor of the Potter's House, a megachurch; Michelle Singletary, a financial columnist for The Washington Post; Terrie Williams, a social worker and public relations executive; and Cornell Belcher, a political pollster. 8 P.M. (Fox Business Network) TAPPED OUT -- AMERICA'S VANISHING WATER In this special edition of ''Follow the Money'' the financial analyst Eric Bolling and industry players weigh claims that the country's water supply is being stolen and wasted. In ''Stossel,'' at 9, John Stossel and his guests examine what will happen if Republicans take the House on Election Day and debate two common political misconceptions: that Republicans shrink government, and that Democrats favor abortion rights. The panel includes Angelo Codevilla, author of ''The Ruling Class,'' in which he suggests that whichever party is elected, government will grow and require more taxpayer money; Joe Trippi, a Democratic strategist; Matt Welch, the editor of Reason magazine; Deroy Murdock, a libertarian columnist for the Scripps Howard News Service; John Fund, a conservative columnist for The Wall Street Journal's Web site; and Karl Rove, former senior adviser to President George W. Bush.

MAKLA--Robert M.,of Brooklyn, NY passed away on October 14, 2010. Bob was beloved by his sisters Grace and Alice and his nieces and nephew. A tireless and inspiring advocate for the city's parks, Bob founded several park conservation organizations to provide tree care and maintenance to the park's natural treasures. He was known for introducing cyclists to the wonders of the city through his middle-of-the-night bike tours. Bob served in WWII and the Korean War, graduated from Princeton and Yale Law and was an active and devoted partner at the law firm of D'Amato & Lynch. Contributions may be made to the Prospect Park Alliance, Development Office, 95 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, NY 11215 (designate "tree care") or to The Tree Trust, Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60th St., 8th Floor, New York, NY 10022.

Simon Jones, a co-artistic director of the Actors Company Theater, has withdrawn from a key role in the company's coming production of Vaclav Havel's ''Memorandum'' after being hurt in a car accident, the company said on Wednesday. In a news release, the Actors Company Theater said Mr. Jones and his son Tim were hit by a car on Oct. 8 after attending a performance of ''Brief Encounter.''

RICE--Robert P.,age 71, of New York City and Merida, Yucatan, passed October 13, 2010. He was a gallant fighter in his battle against a terrible cancer. He is survived by three children. Service will be October 23, 10am at St. John The Evangelist Church at East 55th St. and First Ave. Donations to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

BUSINESS DAY A picture with the Transactions column in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about a property for sale at 236 Second Avenue was published in error. The photograph was of a building at 236 East 15th Street.
Morgan Stanley says it needs more time to reshape its battered franchise. But its latest results suggest the firm is falling farther behind its rivals.

Oh, for the good old days of postdebate spin rooms. There was a time when campaign operatives would search for just the right person -- usually a like-minded partisan not connected directly to the campaign -- to assert that their candidate had emerged from a debate victorious.

HELD--Leonore (Lee) Nemeroff, died at home in Manhattan peacefully on October 19, 2010. Lee was born in Brooklyn in 1928. She was the mother of Pamela, grandmother of Meg and Ben, great-grandmother of Grace Ann and Harper Leonor, sister of Phyllis and Robert and wife of John. Lee was a wonderful homemaker, devoted wife and mother as well as a friend to all. She is missed.

An article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about three building projects on Avenue of the Americas misidentified, in some editions, a labor council that participated in negotiations on a cost-savings measure, the Economic Recovery Project Labor Agreement. It is the Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York, not the New York State Building and Construction Trades Council.

STERNHEIM--Robert. The Jewish Community of Harrison announces with profound sorrow the loss of our esteemed member. We extend deepest sympathy to his wife Lilly, his daughters Susan and Judy and to the entire family. Aubrey L. Glazer, Rabbi Israel Singer, Cantor Karen Goldstick, President Glen Gilbert, Chairman

If Dannel P. Malloy's gubernatorial campaign had the authority to set Connecticut's court calendar, it probably would have scheduled the state's most sensational murder trial for some other time. Like after Election Day. As it is, the trial of Steven J. Hayes , one of two men accused of rape and murder in a Cheshire home invasion, has been riveting the state all fall, increasing the majority of voters who tell pollsters they support the death penalty.

Kristi Noem, a Republican challenging Representative Stephanie Herseth Sandlin in South Dakota, told a local newspaper on Wednesday that she would not commit to supporting the House Republican leader, John A. Boehner of Ohio, to be the next speaker if Republicans win control. The reluctance of Ms. Noem, one of her party's most promising young prospects to endorse Mr. Boehner, highlighted the distance that many new candidates are keeping between themselves and the political establishment. And it is a sign that newcomers to Congress may seek to use that voter discontent to exert more influence than is normally permitted of freshmen.

EDELSON--Charles D. Loving husband to his late wife, Clair. Devoted father to his son, Matthew. Caring brother to Irving and Donald, and supportive brother-in-law and uncle to Donald's family: Dolores, Jeffrey, and Marci. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Services today, Thursday, Noon, at Riverside-Nassau No. Chapels, 55 No. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

SCIENCE TIMES An article on Tuesday about the increasing use of prescription drugs in the last decade misstated the proportion of Americans older than 60 who reported taking five or more medicines. It is more than one-third, not more than two-thirds.

JUST based on the new luxury jets that were the hottest items at the National Business Aviation Association annual convention in Atlanta this week, it would be easy to overlook that the private jet business has been mired in a depression for two years. But at the very highest niche, where customers can easily pay well over $40 million for a jet and more than $8 million to outfit the cabin, the business appears to be surviving the economic downturn. On the eve of the convention, for example, the Canadian manufacturer Bombardier stunned its high-end competitors by introducing with great fanfare two top-of-the-line, formerly hush-hush, large jets -- the Global 7000 and Global 8000 -- at an eye-popping price of about $65 million apiece.

TUCCI--Paul, MD, passed away on October 18th. A remembrance of his life will be held at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY from 1-4pm on Thursday, October 21st. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to: Calvary Hospital Hospice, Bronx, NY.

CRAIGHEAD--Frances Upshur, 78, of Briarcliff Manor passed away on October 12 at her home after a long illness. Born in New York on June 9, 1932, she was the only child of Dr. Alfred and Frances Moore Upshur. She graduated from the Brearley School and Smith College. Upon graduation, she was a flight attendant with Pan Am before marrying and starting a family. She was an Editor at Reader's Digest International Editions for over 25 years before retiring in 1993. Predeceased by her son Philip, she is survived by her daughter Gloria Craighead Mancuso, son-in-law Michael, and her grandchildren Matthew Philip and Caroline Frances, all of Glen Rock, NJ. Frances will be remembered for her love of the written word, her enthusiasm for life and her devotion to family and friends. Condolences may be expressed at: www.leachandthomas.com.

Walt Disney Studios confirmed a report on the blog CartoonBrew.com that Brenda Chapman - heralded as the first woman to direct a Pixar film, the forthcoming ''Brave'' - had been replaced at the helm of that picture by Mark Andrews, the director of the 2005 Pixar short ''One Man Band.'' Pixar has faced criticism from some corners about its lack of gender diversity behind the camera. All 11 of the celebrated animation studio's features have been directed by men. Some movie critics, bloggers and others have also faulted Pixar for a shortage of leading ladies on screen, with most of its films - ''Up,'' ''Toy Story,'' ''Cars,'' ''Monsters Inc.'' - focused on male characters.

SEIDEN--Howard. Temple Shaaray Tefila records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife Bari, son, Evan and their family. May his memory be for blessing. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein Lois S. Nyren, President

OTTAWA -- He had a privileged upbringing, a highly successful career and sadistic sexual urges that would qualify as extreme even by the morbid standards of serial killers. Yet for those who track such cases, perhaps the most striking element in the crimes of Col. David Russell Williams, a former Canadian military commander hanging his head in an Ontario courtroom this week, is how late in life it apparently started, experts say -- and how quickly it escalated.

Because of an editing error, an article last Thursday about the lacrosse player Paul Rabil referred imprecisely to his scoring records at Johns Hopkins University. Although he holds records in National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament games, Terry Riordan has the most career goals over all for the university, among other records. And because of an editing error, the article referred incorrectly to a Duke University student who wrote a mock PowerPoint thesis about sexual exploits with student-athletes, including lacrosse players. She was a senior, not a graduate student.

After the launch of the unprinterlike Envy 100 e-All-in-One from Hewlett-Packard, Lexmark has engineered its own slick all-in-one printer. The coming Lexmark Genesis is unmistakably a printer, albeit a handsome one, but it has impressive new technology under the hood: a digital camera that can scan documents and photos in a whizzy three seconds. Lexmark says its primary goal in designing the Genesis was to create an all-in-one inkjet (it prints, scans, copies and faxes) that can more quickly scan and copy documents. To do so, Lexmark replaced the traditional scanning mechanism with a 10-megapixel wide-angle digital camera.

Let me suggest a broadcast journalism rule of thumb: if you start a statement with the words "I'm not a bigot, but ..." just stop talking. Trust me - it's not going to end well. And for Juan Williams and NPR, things have not ended well at all.

Republican chances of taking over the House are now up to 80 percent, according to the FiveThirtyEight forecast model; they had been 75 percent two days ago.

Friday was another windy yet gorgeously sunny afternoon for CMJ, which made trolling through dank, loud subterranean clubs all day feel that much more unnatural. I don't smoke, so my excuse for all the extra trips to the sidewalk was that the cell service is better out there. Well, it is!
Mark Bittman lightens up gnocchi by substituting ricotta for the traditional potatoes.

When we started Fixes, we were hoping that interested readers would write in with their own ideas and experiences.  Anyone who read the comments on our debut column, "Health Care and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance,"  knows that this is exactly what happened.  Readers responded to our column on Riders for Health ─ an organization that maintains the motorcycles used by health care workers in rural Africa ─ with a variety of ideas for improving transportation on that continent.  They also proposed many intriguing fixes of their own ─ some of which we will look into for future columns.

Depending on the realtor, the New York outpost of Alex Calderwood's Ace Hotel is either located in NoChe (short for North Chelsea) or NoMad (for North of Madison Square Park), but regular people just think of the area as a place to buy knockoff handbags. Inside the hotel it's a different scene, like some dreamy Epcot Center version of the Pacific Northwest, especially on this Friday afternoon, when Colin Meloy, the frontman of the Portland-based Decemberists, began tuning up for a solo show, sponsored by KEXP, the great Seattle radio station that moved into the lobby of the hotel for three days during CMJ. "I'm so glad this pocket of Portland is here," Meloy said of the hotel, which was founded in Seattle but is now headquartered in Stumptown. "Now I feel safe in New York." His set - which was prefaced by 15 minutes of lovely droning gibberish from Nick Urata's gypsy punk band DeVotchKa - began with a trio of appropriately transportative songs that Meloy called "Pacific Northwest folk." Word. It was new stuff, from the band's forthcoming album, which sounded like a welcome return to the moody lyricism of "Castaways and Cutouts," the 2003 record that launched 1,000 indie-girl obsessions.

The themes of antigovernment revolution have occasionally seeped into comments of Tea Party-backed candidates or their supporters this campaign season, and now a Republican House candidate in Texas has added his thoughts.

The Texas Rangers scored four runs in the fifth inning to break a 1-1 tie and went on to beat the Yankees, 6-1, in Game 6 of the American League Championship Series on Friday night. The Rangers won the series, four games to two, and advanced to their first World Series. The franchise began play in 1961 as the Washington Senators.

What did we learn last night? Among other things, that to compete on the catwalk with a poodle - especially one sporting a heavy metal hairdo - requires quite a lot of black latex. The latex was supplied by the Japanese lingerie designer Atsuko Kudo (a Lady Gaga favorite), who made her American runway debut as part of Lingerie New York, an event thrown at Cipriani's by the Seven Bar Foundation, a nonprofit organization that has helped poor women in India, Mexico and Brazil start their own businesses. Yes, it was all for a good cause (some seats sold for $25,000 a pop), a fact that was alluded to if not entirely conveyed by the event's tagline: "Empowering women on a g-string rather than a shoe-string." The Belgian-based designer Carine Gilson also offered up her own fantasy twists on linge de corps, which Carine Roitfeld, the editor in chief of French Vogue, has described as "the most refined lingerie in the world."

From The Montreal Gazette's Habs Inside/Out blog, this post discusses two newspaper surveys on whether fans and corporations would pay higher costs for N.H.L. hockey and the plight of the Ottawa Senators.

Last year, "Paranormal Activity" proved itself to be "The Blair Witch Project" of its generation: a gritty, indie, ultra-low-budget horror picture that word-of-mouth powers into the box office stratosphere. "Paranormal" cost $10,000 to make and sold $193 million at the global box office.

Ron Suhanosky and Colleen Marnell-Suhanosky, the couple who founded Sfoglia on Nantucket and its intimate offshoot on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, where customers tended to fill up on her delicious bread before the rest of the meal arrived, are no longer involved with either restaurant.

Next week select members of the United States Green Building Council will begin casting ballots on whether to overhaul how the organization awards sustainability credits for wood products.

The University of Virginia has released its audit investigating workplace conditions at the Virginia Quarterly Review, the prizewinning literary journal it oversees, but nearly three months after the suicide of its managing editor, Kevin Morrissey, the journal is still on hold. Carol Wood, a spokeswoman for the university, said on Friday that Ted Genoways, the editor of VQR, had been invited to stay on as editor, and Mr. Genoways confirmed in an e-mail that "Yes, I will be remaining on as editor."

The Tribune Company's board today resolved what had been its preoccupation for at least a week: orchestrating the ouster of Randy Michaels, the chief executive whose boorish behavior and sexual antics became a dark sideshow to the bankrupt company's financial struggles.

New Jersey's governor, Chis Christie, has said he will spend the weekend contemplating whether to put a stop to the planned rail tunnel under the Hudson River. As he does so, he has some very big numbers to consider.
All the fashion news of the week that's fit to reprint.

The At War blog is following reaction to the release of classified American field reports from the Iraq War, which contain information about many episodes never made public in such detail. The New York Times had access to the documents and published a series of reports.

John Moore of Getty Images has visited American-run detention centers in Iraq, including Abu Ghraib and Camp Cropper; prisons for Taliban fighters in Afghanistan run by that country's National Directorate of Security; the Pul-e-Charki prison outside Kabul; and, more recently, the Guantánamo Bay detention center. He is gathering these images in a longterm project, "Detained." James Estrin and David Furst interviewed him by telephone in August. The transcript of their conversation has been edited.

Put "Beach" in a band name, and the word "sunny" will inevitably appear in descriptions of the music. Especially if it's true, as it is with Beach Fossils, from Brooklyn. They're simply asking for it, with peppy, major-key songs and lyrics full of hopeful romance: "I let the time pass by/Soon I'll be by your side." The guitars mesh and cascade, splashed in surf-rock reverb, through picking patterns of stuttering notes and arpeggios, stratified like the 1980's arrangements of New Order or the Cure, but much, well, sunnnier. New Order goes surfing?

In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan writes about how "green" investing has been getting more attention, both because of increasing attention to climate change and because traditional investments have been generating low returns.

I find images of unpeopled interiors infinitely more satisfying than pictures of populated rooms. I love the way they appear to wait in quiet anticipation. This is probably why I never tire of looking through decades-old back issues of World of Interiors or Country Life. Empty rooms, especially other people's, are like handwritten invitations, not to mention oblique self-portraits of the artists who make them.
Eric Molinsky draws people riding New York's subway using the Sketchbook application for the iPhone.

In 2006, a gay man named Michael J. Sandy was lured to a rest area off the Belt Parkway by three young men who tried to rob him and chased him onto the highway, where he was killed by a car. His attackers were convicted of hate crimes. On Friday, a park bench at the rest area was dedicated to Mr. Sandy's memory.

The Palasport Olimpico, built for the 2006 Winter Olympics in Turin, Italy, saw the opening ceremony of another sort of worldwide delegation on Thursday: Terra Madre 2010. Instead of athletes, there were farmers, fishermen and artisanal food producers, along with other sustainable food idealists (young and royalty alike) -- from Pavlos Georgiadis, a student from Thrace, Greece, who helped create an edible garden at his university in Stuttgart, Germany, to Alice Waters.

Jessica Larrabee, the guitarist and singer in the Brooklyn duo She Keeps Bees, has a gift for opening lines. "Brick by brick, she's gonna take you down," she warned in one song. "Don't follow me, honey, not the road you want to be on," went another. The songs smolder and ignite from there, as her voice rears up and she strums blaring, increasingly frenetic chords on her electric guitar.

Wayne Rooney was upset that his club, Manchester United, didn't want to win as much as he did. Despite Sir Alex Ferguson's "genius," his teammates' talents and efforts, management wasn't willing to spend lavishly on international stars to complement Rooney.

Pots of chili, consommé, chicken noodle soup and more will be simmering during the Smith Street Soup Festival in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, on Saturday. Admission is $5 a person or $10 a family. Local restaurants will sell four-ounce samples of soups from 1 to 4 p.m. on Smith Street between Carroll Street and Atlantic Avenue. Proceeds will go to benefit a new culinary arts program at the High School for International Studies on Baltic Street.

Athletes have received nasty messages from fans since the day of the first sporting competition back in ancient Greece. Things have evolved from verbal taunts to written notes. Back in the day, athletes received hate snail mail.

Each October, Madison Avenue not only thinks pink, it turns pink, as marketers seek to show how much they support the fight against breast cancer. Products are re-dressed in pink packaging, appliances are sold with pink tints, pink ribbons festoon apparel and some newspapers even tint their pages pink.

"Like Milan without the riffraff" is the way that a representative of an important European furniture manufacturer recently described Intérieur, the biennial contemporary design fair (which runs through Sunday) in Kortrijk, a Flemish town near the Franco-Belgian border. Kortrijk is small and friendly, the taxis are free (at least to and from the Expo fairground), and it's a mere 18 miles away from a Eurostar connection, which is music to the ears of any design editor who was grounded by the ash cloud in April.
