The National Republican Senatorial Committee has taken out a $10 million line of credit less than two weeks before the midterm elections, an indication of the large number of competitive - and costly - states that both parties are battling over.
The agencies conducting the main federal investigation into the BP Deepwater Horizon explosion and spill said Friday that they had asked for and been given extra time to complete their report.
General Motors is recalling 303,000 2009-10 Chevrolet Impalas because the front seat belts could come loose in a crash. The recall comes more than a year after G.M. first learned of the problem.

Suuns, from Montreal (pronounced "Soons" and formerly called Zeroes), are drone scholars. They bear down on one chord, or just one repeated note, in all sorts of ways, as their lead singer, Ben Shemie, croons ominious thoughts in a high tenor with sociopathic gentleness: "Don't you be yourself/you are someone else," he intoned.

Overview | What do we say about ourselves when we quote lines from movies or elsewhere? Why do famous quotes from movies, literature and history resonate with many people? In this lesson, students consider the power of their favorite movie lines and other famous quotes, then write essays interpreting and commenting on a selected quotation.

As my colleagues Dan Bilefsky and Doreen Carvajal report, European countries have apparently reduced the pressure on Serbia's government to arrest Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb general still wanted on war crimes charges by an international tribunal in The Hague for his part in the massacre of 8,000 men and boys after forces under his command seized the Bosnian town of Srebrenica in 1995.

Naples, Italy, has been hard at work lately distancing itself from its reputation as a city of lawlessness and litter. It has invested millions in restoration and transportation projects, not to mention improving its tourism infrastructure with the likes of the new Romeo Hotel.

Nevada's unemployment rate was 14.4 percent in August, the highest of all the American states. That figure also tied its rate in August as the highest ever recorded for the Silver State since the Labor Department began keeping track in 1976, according to a report released Friday.

Two days after being fired by NPR, Juan Williams is, as the NPR media correspondent David Folkenflik put it, "now enjoying the full embrace of Fox News, which has given him a new three-year, $2 million contract and a guest slot, Friday night, as host of The O'Reilly Factor."

One of my favorite (and most delicious) things to compare the college football season to is a pint of Guinness. It takes some time to settle. You think you're ready for that first sip, but you're not. Patience, things are still settling. You stare at it. Still settling. Sometimes (often when you are thirstiest) it feels like it will never be ready to drink. (Anyone else getting thirsty?) That's how this season is going. It's taking forever to settle. The picture is still hazy. Just when it seemed like we knew what was going on the No. 1 team started losing every week. Now it seems we know even less. Will Oklahoma be the third straight No. 1 to go down? Don't sleep on Missouri and its nasty defense. Who will remain as the last unbeaten in the SEC after Auburn hosts L.S.U.? Will Cameron Newton's stock continue to rise? Or will he pull a Taylor Martinez/Denard Robinson when he faces a tough L.S.U. defense? Can Iowa take control of the Big Ten? Can Nebraska bounce back? Let's all get a pint of Guinness and wait to see what happens.

When I first met Ryan Hall, in the spring of 2007, his coach Terrence Mahon was at his side, literally, running next to him as the two jogged from their Midtown Manhattan hotel into Central Park to begin a training run on the 2008 Olympic trials marathon course. About a month earlier, Hall ran the second-fastest debut for an American in the marathon at London in 2 hours 8 minutes 24 seconds. Suddenly, Hall had become a favorite to win the trials, to be held the following November in New York. In fact, he went on to win that race, propelling himself to the top of the thin list of world-class American male marathoners.

The candidate seen as the Republicans' best chance of picking up a House seat in Massachusetts is back under scrutiny over whether he witnessed and covered up the assault of a female teenager when he was a police sergeant nearly two decades ago.

Gov. David Paterson dismissed Alexander B. Grannis, New York State's top environmental official, Thursday night in a dispute over budget cuts. Last spring, Mr. Grannis shared his views with the Green blog on the 40th anniversary of the first Earth Day, which he helped organize in his youth.

A Los Angeles judge ordered Lindsay Lohan to remain in a drug rehabilitation program until Jan. 3 after Ms. Lohan violated the terms of her probation, CNN.com reported. Judge Elden S. Fox of Los Angeles County Superior Court, who made the ruling on Friday morning, had previously ordered Ms. Lohan, the star of "Mean Girls" and "Freaky Friday," to be sent to jail in September and to be held without bail after she failed a drug test she had been ordered to take as a condition of her probation. But that decision was quickly overturned and Ms. Lohan, after being freed on $300,000 bail, checked into the Betty Ford Center. Ms. Lohan, who faced up to 30 days in jail for the violation, was ordered to return to the court on Feb. 25.

When I started writing this article a little more than a month ago, I hadn't yet had two bulging disks flare up, putting me in excruciating pain. I hadn't yet had a neck epidural where, as I sat in a hospital gown designed for someone three times my size, the R.N. inserted the IV into the arm on the side that was in such distress. I hadn't had to spend my half hour of recovery time in a Nightingale ward - those wards with rows of beds divided by the thinnest of sliding curtains that allow you to hear all the particulars of your neighbors' condition and all the sounds of their discomfort. I hadn't had to sit in a row of wheelchairs (no other seating was provided) while waiting to consult with the surgeon after the procedure.The procedure went fine and I'm slowly improving, but in my woozy post-op state I had ample time to think yet again about how the experience of health care could be so vastly improved.

A sculptural screen of 800 floating metal panels by the artist Harry Bertoia is being dismantled and moved from its home on the second floor of the Fifth Avenue building that is now owned by JPMorgan Chase. The 1954 building, which Gordon Bunshaft originally designed for Manufacturer's Hanover Trust, is a landmark, but that designation protects only the exterior of the building, not the interior or Bertoia's 70-foot-wide, 20-foot-high screen.

Melissa Muller-Daka is serious about the cooking of her native Sicily. At Eolo she has devised a menu [pdf] as a showcase for dishes like maccu cu grancio (fava bean puree with ricotta, carb and wild fennel), tummala del gattopardo (a round of pastry filled with pasta and meatballs), pisci spada cu cus-cusu (swordfish with cous cous). She is in the kitchen and her husband, Tarek Daka, is running the little restaurant named for the Aeolus, god of winds of Greek mythology, in homage to Sicily in ancient times as Magna Graecia.

People tend to think of Laura Ashley as being ironically fabulous; actually, she was genuinely fabulous. When Ashley introduced mix-and-match home furnishing fabrics in tiny florals in the '60s, it was the shot heard 'round the world. Prints with reversible ground and motif colors became her signature. Some of them were twee, but they raked in millions. It's a look the industry has been feeding off ever since.

Honda is saying that 470,000 vehicles could be involved in its latest recall, for brake fluid leaks, reports The Detroit News. When Texas lost to U.C.L.A. earlier this season, it looked as if it might be a rough year for the Big 12. But then Oklahoma, Missouri and Oklahoma State kept on winning. Those three are still undefeated, but this is the weekend when the Big 12 promises to shake itself out. Texas knocked Nebraska from the ranks of the unbeaten last week. Will the Cornhuskers be able to bounce back from that loss and do the same to Oklahoma State? Oklahoma travels to Missouri as the No. 1 team in the Bowl Championship Series standings, and the Tigers would love to prove their legitimacy by knocking off the Sooners. Speaking of legitimacy, Texas Christian does not seem as if it will get a legitimate chance at the national title, even if it keeps dominating opponents. The Horned Frogs face Air Force, which had been ranked until a loss last week. In the SEC, Louisiana State and Auburn are undefeated and in the top 10, but both seem to be searching for respect. Many think it is simply luck that has kept Les Miles's bunch undefeated, while Cam Newton has kept Auburn winning despite a woeful defense. In the Big Ten, Wisconsin is coming off a huge win over Ohio State. Now the Badgers travel to Iowa, where they hope the running back duo of John Clay and James White will continue their productivity. It's a weekend where many teams will find out where they stand, and so will our prognosticators. As always, if you agree or disagree with the picks, or merely find them laughable, feel free to drop in a comment.

APFEL--Edwin R.,1934-2010. Ed Apfel died August 4, 2010 in Manhattan after a long battle with myeleo-displasia syndrome. A screenwriter and former member of the Council of Writers Guild of America, East, Mr. Apfel wrote the Emmy award Winning - "Edward R. Murrow: This Reporter for the Public Television American Masters Series" and co-wrote with Gloria Naylor - "Porgy and Bess: An American Voice" - for the Public Television Great Performance Series. He also wrote the film "The Last Home Run" and the play "Janus". During the 1980's and 1970's he was a principal of Eleuthyra Films that produced advertising, marketing and promotional material for the movies. He also wrote, produced and directed television documentaries about film directors on location (John Huston, John Schlesinger, Norman Jewison, John Frankenheimer and Brian De Palma). In the 1960s he was director of advertising for Embassy Pictures Corporation, director of advertising and creative services for MGM Records and advertising manager for Metro-Goldwyn Mayer. Mr. Apfel left no immediate survivors. A private memorial service will be held in early November.

SEIDEN--Howard. Leonard and Evelyn Lauder extend their deepest sympathies to Bari Seiden, our dear friend and esteemed colleague, whose devoted husband Howard died after a long and valiant fight against cancer. Howard will be deeply missed. Our hearts and profound condolences go out to Bari, their son Evan, Howard's parents and their entire family during this very sad time.

PAOLA, Kan. -- This state has been painted, unwillingly at times, as a caricature of a certain brand of conservatism. It was here that the State Board of Education challenged the theory of evolution, that an abortion provider was fatally shot at his church, and that a writer set his polemic ''What's the Matter with Kansas?'' But while Republicans dominate the State Legislature and the governor was once chairman of the state party, the reality about those who currently control Kansas is far subtler -- the effective majority in the Legislature is a coalition of moderate Republicans and Democrats, while the governor defected to the Democratic Party.

BARNETT--Michele Anne, of Nantucket, MA and Naples, FL died on October 20, 2010. Ms. Barnett was born in Oceanside, Long Island and lived most of her youth in Rockville Centre, NY. She was one of six children of Rita and John Molloy. She spent her career working in the financial industry at Rockefeller Bros. and Mackay Shields. She is survived by her two brothers, Patrick and Sean Molloy, and her three sisters, Casey Mitchell, Sheilagh Roberti and Megan Walsh. "Mike" as she was known by many had a great sense of humor. She loved traveling, playing golf at Sankaty Head Golf Club and was an avid reader. She was a woman of great faith and had a heart of gold. She will be greatly missed by her family and friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the American Cancer Society and/or Autism Speaks. Mass of Christian burial will be held at St. Agnes Church, Rockville Centre, NY on Tuesday, October 26th at 10:00am.

An article on Oct. 8 about Charles T. Munger Jr., a Stanford researcher, and his support for Proposition 20, a state ballot initiative to transfer power for redistricting from legislators to a citizens panel, stated incorrectly that the proposed Citizens Redistricting Commission would be the first in the nation to draw district lines for both the state legislature and Congress. Other states, including Arizona, Washington and New Jersey, have panels with similar powers. Also, due to an editing error, the article said that Jason McDaniel, a political scientist at San Francisco State University, said Proposition 20 ''might have a marginal effect on the number of moderates in the Legislature.'' Mr. McDaniel was referring to Congress, not the State Legislature.

Updated: Eli Lilly & Company, confronted with research setbacks and pending patent losses, reported a quarterly profit on Thursday that beat Wall Street estimates. It also raised its forecast for full-year 2010 profits, saying one reason was that the health care overhaul passed by Congress was costing it less than expected.

BECK--Martin F. Passed away peacefully at his home on October 21, 2010. Adored and adoring husband of Lorraine for 69 years. Cherished father of Susan and Jim Champlin and Stuart and Tulik Beck, loving grandfather of Michael, Julie, Emma, Chip, Johanna, Sam and great-grandfather of Joshua, Benjamin, Jack and Coco. Martin was a highly regarded leader in the broadcast industry and was recognized in 1992 with the NAB National Radio Award, in 1999 with the Broadcasters Foundation Pioneer Award and in 2005 he was an Inaugural Inductee into the New York State Broadcasters Hall of Fame. He introduced FM radio to Long Island and he nurtured hundreds in the broadcast industry. Services 1pm today at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

The other day, Glyna Aderhold, a retired 67-year-old real estate broker from Nashville, was crossing the lobby of the mall at the Time Warner Center, the soaring castle of commerce and culture at Columbus Circle, when she passed a monumental bronze sculpture of a man and saw something that made her pause. ''I walked up and I was looking at his head and boom! This thing hits me right in the face,'' Ms. Aderhold said.

WEINREB--David, of East Meadow. Beloved husband of Ruth. Father of Jack, Jeffery, Robert. Grandfather of Ava, Sam, Danny. Funeral service Sunday, October 24, 10am at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, Hempstead, NY.

GROSSMAN--Ginger. Ginger Grossman, a leading political activist in Aventura and N. Dade County, FL, died October 18 at age 91. She is survived by her adoring husband of 70 years, Arthur; daughters, Boni Smith of FL and Lynn Grossman of NY; son-in-law, Bob Balaban; granddaughters Mariah and Hazel Balaban. At the time of her death she was actively involved in three political campaigns. As Founder and President of the North East Dade Involved Democrats, she developed a large and vocal bloc of senior voters and her support was actively sought by Democratic candidates on the local and national level. She was an active board member or founder of more than thirty political and social welfare organizations. She liked to quote Muhammad Ali: "Service to others is the rent we pay for our place here on earth." Ginger lived most of her long, good life paying that rent. Services: Sunday, October 24, 11:30am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam and 76th St.

5:52 p.m. | Updated If you take it from the ads running in swing districts around the country, every Democrat is a clone of President Obama, Representative Nancy Pelosi or Senator Harry Reid. But nationalizing the race has been harder for Democrats, since it seems few know who John Boehner, who, as House minority leader, is the party's top-ranking figure, is. So rather than nationalizing, some Democratic house candidates are state-izing, tying their Republican opponents to an attention-grabbing, Tea Party-backed Senate candidate. For example, a commercial for John Carney, the Democratic candidate for Delaware's at-large Congressional district, says his Republican opponent, Glen Urquhart ''and Christine O'Donnell want to shift the tax burden from the wealthy to the middle class'' while showing a photo of Mr. Urquhart clasping hands with the Republican Senate nominee.

Dianna Agron, one of three members of the cast of ''Glee'' who is featured in a racy cover shoot in GQ magazine, apologized on her blog for the shoot while defending its contents. Ms. Agron, a 24-year-old actress who portrays the high school cheerleader Quinn Fabray on ''Glee,'' appears in photographs on the cover and inside pages of the November issue of GQ with her co-stars Lea Michele and Cory Monteith. The pictures, taken by Terry Richardson, depict the actors in high-school settings, wearing revealing clothing and standing in suggestive poses.

SCHULMAN--Robert, former Senior Vice President, and General Counsel of Kimco Realty Corporation, unexpectedly died of a brain hemorrhage on October 20, 2010, while traveling in Europe with his wife, Marjorie. Mr. Schulman, graduate of NYU Law School, handled Kimco's legal affairs for over 30 years, after his "technical" retirement, Mr. Schulman continued to represent Kimco on special matters. Mr. Schulman had a multi-faceted legal career spanning a broad spectrum, which included civil rights law, litigation and highly complex commercial transactions of various types. He was an adjunct professor of law at NYU. His life was distinguished by a relentless pursuit of excellence, fair dealing and integrity. Colleagues and associates respected him not only as a conscientious, dedicated and consummate professional, but also for the breadth of his wisdom, good humor and charm. He enjoyed mentoring junior lawyers and generously spent many hours to help them sharpen their skills. Those that worked with him will miss his keen intellect and perceptive insight. Mr. Schulman, a native of The Bronx, is survived by his wife, Marjorie by his daughters, Claudia and Janet; by his sons, David and Andrew; and by eight grandchildren. The associates and friends of Kimco mourn the loss of this very fine man, and extend their deepest sympathies to the Schulman family. The entire staff of Kimco Realty Corporation

In Washington for a rally several weeks ago, the leader of one of the country's largest Tea Party groups found himself stumped by a reporter's question. Asked whether the Tea Party had a foreign policy platform, and if so, what it was, Dick Armey, the founder of FreedomWorks, hesitated only briefly before admitting, ''I don't think so,'' and then turning to a colleague to ask, ''Do you see a common thread there?''

HOGAN--Jerry, 77, an agent for theatre, television, and film for over 45 years died in Calvary Hospital from lung cancer after a short illness on October 20th. He is survived by George Lutsch, his business partner, a sister, three brothers, and Geoffrey Johnson, his companion of 52 years. A remembrance of his life will be announced later by Henderson-Hogan Associates, which he co-founded, and by his past and present clients, and by his family.

A Manhattan federal judge on Thursday confirmed a reorganization plan for General Growth Properties, capping one of the biggest and most complicated commercial real estate bankruptcy cases on record. The company expects to emerge by about Nov. 8.

Bill Daly, the N.H.L. deputy commissioner, said Thursday that the league is ''comfortable with the steps we have already taken'' to reduce concussions and had no plans to modify its new head-checking rule. His remarks came in response to the Mayo Clinic's recommendation that the N.H.L. outlaw all contact with the head.

The Republican National Committee raised close to $10 million in September but ended the month essentially under water financially, with only about $3.4 million in cash on hand but $4.6 million in debts and obligations. The struggling national party committee also took out a $2.5 million loan. By contrast, the Democratic National Committee ended the month with almost four times as much cash on hand, $13.4 million, with $7.7 million in debt. Both committees have continued to raise millions more in the first two weeks of October.

Hugh Hefner had ''the mansion'' out there in California, with the bunnies and the bacchanalia. Dershowitz, the Harvard law professor whose client list has included Claus von Bulow, Leona M. Helmsley and Mike Tyson - said on Thursday that he never, ever saw a naked woman at the house.

WEALTH A picture caption on Thursday with an article about different approaches taken by investment advisers referred imprecisely to the location of Stephens Inc., a privately held bank. While Stephens has offices in New York and other locations, and while the photograph showed Warren Stephens, who runs the bank, in his office in Manhattan, the bank's headquarters are in Little Rock, Ark.

Conan O'Brien's very first guest on his new TBS show could be anyone from Pope Benedict XVI to Vladimir V. Putin to Thomas Pynchon, but he has more concrete plans for the other celebrities and the performers who will appear on the first week of his show. Representatives for Mr. O'Brien said on Thursday that ''Conan,'' his TBS show making its debut on Nov. 8, will feature as its first guest the winner of an online vote posted at teamcoco.com. Among the more fanciful candidates in the vote are the Pope, Mr. Putin, Mr. Pynchon and Gerhard Ertl, winner of the 2007 Nobel Prize in chemistry; other more realistic options include Jack Nicholson, Justin Bieber and Lady Gaga. Mr. O'Brien's first show will be rounded out by the actor Seth Rogen and the musician Jack White.

This week I answer questions about Canton and dining alone. Keep the queries coming! Send them to dinejournal@nytimes.com or Twitter.com/samsifton. Q. For years my family and I went to special-occasion Chinese dinners at Canton on Division Street. It seems the place has since closed. I remember never getting a menu, and always letting Eileen, the owner and hostess, ''take care of us.'' The food was always amazing. I particularly remember their squab lettuce wraps and their perfect preparations of whole fish. Yes, the bill was always steep and the cash-only policy sketchy, but I want to know where I can find food of similar quality in New York.
''Did Sam Israel come to the dinner? Has Bayou ramped it up yet?'' asked a top Goldman Sachs executive in a 2004 e-mail.

DALLAS -- For the first two years, George W. Bush managed his return to private work in Texas as a quiet transition. While anonymous donors put his photograph on highway billboards that say ''Miss Me Yet?'' Mr. Bush all but shuttered his ranch near Crawford, scene of some of the more spectacular protests against his administration, moving instead to a quiet cul-de-sac in the upscale Preston Hollow enclave of Dallas. He even waited until his beloved Texas Rangers began their current baseball playoff run to openly attend games.

School cafeterias are much criticized for offering the kind of snack foods and desserts that contribute to childhood obesity. But banning junk food from cafeterias, as some schools have tried, or serving only escarole or tofu, can backfire. Students then skip lunch, bring in their own snacks or head out for fast food. We've even seen some pizzas delivered to a side door. Children and teenagers resist heavy-handed nutritional policies -- and the food that is associated with the heavy hand. No food is nutritious, after all, until it is actually eaten.

DeSANTIS--Arthur Anthony, January 1, 1913 October 20, 2010. Arthur was born in the Bronx and emigrated to Rome at age 11. Attended college in Rome, then lived in Antwerp. During World War II, he was interned by the Nazis, then was acting colonel with the U.S. Army after liberation. Married writer Florence Catharine Stevenson in 1950, settling in Bayside, Queens. He was Executive Secretary of the Italy-America Chamber of Commerce for three decades and a member of the New York Fencers Club. Predeceased by Florence in 1995 and retired to Northampton, MA in 2000. Survived by daughter Solange De Santis, son Arthur (Jayce) De Santis and partner Mary Tatro, and granddaughter Florence De Santis Peters.
SMOLIN--Jay H. November 29, 1919 - October 21, 2010. He will be cremated promptly. There will be no service.

Food for firefighters need meet only a few basic criteria, firefighters say: It has to be stick-to-the-ribs filling and easy to prepare in firehouse kitchens. It must also stay edible - even after it has been sitting for hours, as an alarm inevitably sends firefighters scurrying to their trucks instead of digging into dinner. At the fourth annual Firefighter Cook-Off, held at the New York City Fire Museum on Spring Street on Wednesday night, more than a dozen firefighters from companies across the city tried to prove that their fare can also be delicious.

Contrary to what you may have heard, the Yankees do have a fighting chance of beating Cliff Lee if they can force a Game 7 against the Rangers. There'is no denying that Lee has been outstanding this postseason, pitching a pair of gems against the Rays in the division series and following those performances with a dominant outing in Game 3 of the American League Championship Series against the Yankees,. But hope for the defending champions comes in the form of history, which suggests that Lee is unlikely to be quite as sharp facing the Yankees the second time around.

First Christine O'Donnell dabbled in witchcraft, then she was emphatically ''not a witch.'' But apparently, the Republican candidate for Delaware's Senate seat can't seem to leave the coven behind her entirely. On Thursday, Ms. O'Donnell made news on the supernatural front in an exclusive interview with Jonathan Karl on ''Good Morning America.'' When Mr. Karl ended the otherwise straightforward interview by asking Ms. O'Donnell about her Halloween plans, she volunteered the surprising tidbit that she regrets her first political ad, a spot that opens with her saying, ''I'm not a witch.''

WEBER--Barry H.,59, adoring husband, best friend, incredible father and loving son died October 19, 2010 after fighting bladder cancer. He moved to Long Beach, NY in 1976 with Sonja and they were married at Temple Emanu-el in 1979. Also in 1979, he became President of Edith Weber Antique Jewelry, NYC at the Carlyle Hotel. He appeared on the Antiques Roadshow for 15 seasons as a jewelry appraiser. His passion for music was paramount. He loved the blues and played great slide guitar with his music family from coast to coast. Mr. Weber was a teacher and mentor in the field of jewelry and guitar. Barry is survived by his wife, Sonja, son Adam, and his mother Edith. His funeral services will be held Sunday, October 24, at 1pm at Temple Emanu-el, 455 Neptune Blvd., Long Beach, NY. His family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations sent to MSKCC, "The Drs. Bajorin/Russo Bladder Cancer Research Fund."

Tuesday, Nov. 16, 6:45 p.m. | UpdatedA fund and a Web site, Support Joao Silva Photojournalist, have been set up by Greg and Leonie Marinovich, friends of Mr. Silva, to help him and his family as he goes through rehabilitation. Money is being raised through outright donations and the sale of prints by Mr. Silva. "We have little doubt he will continue photographing but he will certainly not be able to go to war zones," the Marinoviches said. "We estimate he will not be able to work for about two years." Mr. Silva is at Walter Reed Army Medical Center. The New York Times has told the Pentagon that it will be responsible for his treatment and care, and is assisting his family in other ways. Should the fund collect more money than is needed, the Marinoviches said, what is left will be donated to a charity chosen by Mr. Silva.

My Sunday column from Kabul argues that we do Afghan women no favors by prolonging an unsustainable war in their name. Yes, there's reason to worry about what will happen if the Taliban gain more influence. And, yes, I'm particularly concerned that fundamentalist values will gain ground even in areas where the Taliban are not formally ruling. But as I write in the column, Afghan women themselves told me that they favor a peace deal with the Taliban because war victimizes them just as much as the Taliban does. And the present course is just not sustainable.

With dozens of clubs hosting hundreds of bands on ludicrously tight schedules, it's all but a guarantee that even the best laid CMJ plans will go awry. Last year, I'd planned a night around catching a set by the Korean-American Los Angeles party-rap group Far East Movement, but when I arrived at the venue at the appointed time, they were still two hours from going on. In the meantime, I waited through one terrible act, who shall remain nameless, and stumbled on another, Chiddy Bang, who turned out to be fantastic. I never saw Far East Movement except for in the crowd, wearing matching silvery jackets. They currently have the number one single in the country, "Like a G6." At least I can say I was (almost) there way back when.

STURZ--Elizabeth. The board and staff of Wildcat Service Corporation extend our heartfelt sympathies to the family of Elizabeth Sturz whose innovative and caring contributions to New York's underserved were unequaled. We mourn her loss and honor her memory.

A sculptural screen of 800 floating metal panels by the artist Harry Bertoia is being dismantled and moved from its home on the second floor of the Fifth Avenue building that is now owned by JPMorgan Chase. The 1954 building, which Gordon Bunshaft originally designed for Manufacturer's Hanover Trust, is a landmark, but that designation protects only the exterior of the building, not the interior or Bertoia's 70-foot-wide, 20-foot-high screen. ''This is from Bertoia's heyday,'' said Russell Flinchum, archivist for the Century Association Archives Foundation in New York, who sounded the alarm about the sculpture. ''Chase may own it, but it is part of New York's cultural patrimony.''

The University of Virginia has released its audit investigating workplace conditions at the Virginia Quarterly Review, the prizewinning literary journal it oversees, but nearly three months after the suicide of its managing editor, Kevin Morrissey, the journal is still on hold. Carol Wood, a spokeswoman for the university, said on Friday that Ted Genoways, the editor of VQR, had been invited to stay on as editor, and Mr. Genoways confirmed in an e-mail that ''Yes, I will be remaining on as editor.'' Staff members have not yet returned to work, Ms. Wood said. The nine-page audit, made public this week, was ordered after Mr. Morrissey's suicide, when some of his family and friends suggested that Mr. Genoways and stresses in the workplace contributed to his decision to kill himself. The audit said that there were ''no specific allegations of bullying or harassment prior to July 30th,'' the day Mr. Morrissey died, but also recommended that Mr. Genoways's ''responsiveness on administrative matters and his management style'' needed to be addressed.

SCHULMAN--Robert, former Senior Vice President, and General Counsel of Kimco Realty Corporation, unexpectedly died of a brain hemorrhage on October 20, 2010, while traveling in Europe with his wife, Marjorie. Mr. Schulman, graduate of NYU Law School, handled Kimco's legal affairs for over 30 years, after his "technical" retirement, Mr. Schulman continued to represent Kimco on special matters. Mr. Schulman had a multi-faceted legal career spanning a broad spectrum, which included civil rights law, litigation and highly complex commercial transactions of various types. He was an adjunct professor of law at NYU. His life was distinguished by a relentless pursuit of excellence, fair dealing and integrity. Colleagues and associates respected him not only as a conscientious, dedicated and consummate professional, but also for the breadth of his wisdom, good humor and charm. He enjoyed mentoring junior lawyers and generously spent many hours to help them sharpen their skills. Those that worked with him will miss his keen intellect and perceptive insight. Mr. Schulman, a native of The Bronx, is survived by his wife, Marjorie by his daughters, Claudia and Janet; by his sons, David and Andrew; and by eight grandchildren. The associates and friends of Kimco mourn the loss of this very fine man, and extend their deepest sympathies to the Schulman family. The entire staff of Kimco Realty Corporation

Is the traditional concept of retirement likely to become a casualty of the latest recession? The people at Sun Life Financial, a financial services company, seem to think so. ''The traditional view of retirement, stopping work when government benefits become available, is changing,'' wrote Alexi Maravel, a Sun Life spokesman, in an e-mail to Bucks. ''More and more, Americans are choosing to be 'unretired,' that is, continue to work full- or part-time after the age when they are eligible to receive full Social Security benefits.''

ARTS & LEISURE A classical music entry in the Week Ahead report this weekend about the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra concert next Saturday at Carnegie Hall gives outdated information about the program. After the section had gone to press, Carnegie Hall announced that the orchestra would perform Arvo Pärt's ''Fratres'' instead of Ligeti's ''Atmosphères.''

The National Republican Senatorial Committee has taken out a $10 million line of credit less than two weeks before the midterm elections, an indication of the big number of competitive -- and costly -- states that both parties are battling over. Documents filed with the Federal Election Commission show that the Republican committee took out the loan on Wednesday. Such financial moves are not uncommon in the waning days of a heated election season. And this campaign has been especially costly as Republicans have expanded the playing field to more than a dozen highly competitive Senate races, including some in states with the largest media markets.

8 P.M. (HBO) INVICTUS (2009) In Clint Eastwood's rousing drama, inspired by a true story of revenge, reconciliation and athletic triumph, and based on John Carlin's book ''Playing the Enemy,'' Morgan Freeman (above right) portrays Nelson Mandela, newly elected as South Africa's first black president. Matt Damon (above left) is François Pienaar, the captain of the Springbok rugby team, a source of Afrikaner pride despised by most blacks -- and the vehicle, Mandela thinks, for bringing the country's races together, especially if the team wins the Rugby World Cup, which South Africa is to host. A. O. Scott, reviewing this film in The New York Times, wrote that Mr. Freeman played Mandela -- a role that earned him an Oscar nod for best actor -- ''with gravity, grace and a crucial spark of mischief,'' and that Mr. Damon, nominated for best supporting actor, matches him ''with crisp, disciplined understatement (and utter mastery of a devilishly tricky accent).'' He added: '' 'Invictus' has implications beyond its immediate time and place that are hard to miss. It's an exciting sports movie, an inspiring tale of prejudice overcome and, above all, a fascinating study of political leadership.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Lucky Severson reports on the Nov. 2 vote in California on Proposition 19 -- a ballot initiative that would allow anyone over 21 to possess up to an ounce of marijuana and permit municipalities to tax and regulate the substance -- and the debate that's dividing politicians and some religious voters.

STURZ--Elizabeth Lyttleton. The Board of Directors and staff of Argus Community, Inc. mourn the loss of Elizabeth Lyttleton Sturz, the Founder of Argus, its President and its inspiration. Elizabeth was an artist and poet. She created Argus, a multiservice agency in the South Bronx, in 1968 and left an indelible mark. She changed lives, through her creativity, tenacity and concern, and her contributions continue to be felt, every day, as those she taught and inspired carry on her work. We share the grief of her family and extend our condolences to her beloved husband Herbert J. Sturz, her daughters, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren.

The key to delicious Canada goose, Jackson Landers says, begins at the moment of death. ''When people taste a Canada goose and say 'this is terrible,' '' Mr. Landers said, ''usually when you track down the history of how the animal was taken and butchered, you might have an animal that's gut shot and left to sit for a few hours in the back of a truck. If you handled a cow or a domestic chicken the way that a lot of hunters handle their meat, it would taste gamy and vile as well.''

BUSINESS DAY An article on Friday about whether Goldman Sachs was aware of improprieties at the Bayou Group, a hedge fund for which Goldman cleared trades and which later collapsed amid fraud inquiries, quoted incorrectly in some editions from a 2004 Goldman e-mail message. The e-mail, sent by Duncan L. Niederauer, then a Goldman executive, and referring to Samuel Israel III, Bayou's manager, said: ''Did Sam Israel come to the dinner? Has Bayou ramped it up yet?'' -- not ''Has Sam Israel ramped it up?''

The Federal Communications Commission tried Friday to step up the pressure on Cablevision and Fox's parent, the News Corporation, to reach a deal in their fee dispute. The agency demanded that the two sides ''provide evidence'' of good-faith negotiations, which are required by law in disputes over what is known as retransmission consent -- deals that allow cable systems to carry programming on broadcast channels. But the options for the F.C.C. remain limited, and the dispute shows no signs of resolution. For the first time since Saturday, when stations owned by the News Corporation -- including Fox's New York station, WNYW -- began being blacked out in homes serviced by Cablevision, the two sides held no negotiations Friday. Still, the F.C.C. request could be significant because if the commission determines that one side or the other is not acting in good faith, it may be able to impose a fine.

With all the electronic devices we now carry when we travel, finding a good seat at the airport gate is often all about making sure to be near an electrical outlet, if you can find one. But finding an outlet and actually being able to use it can be different stories. To be sure, it may not be right to get free use of airport electricity in the first place. Some airports are also outfitted better than others with outlets and new power sources. And one day, every airport seat may have its own outlet or, at the least, airports may be better adapted to our increasing electricity needs.

SPORTS An article on Friday about the Philadelphia Phillies' victory over the San Francisco Giants in Game 5 of the National League Championship Series misstated, in some copies, the scoring margin of the Giants' three victories in the series. The Giants won two games -- not all three -- by one run. (They won Game 3 by 3-0.)

INTERNATIONAL An article on Thursday about a sentencing hearing for Col. David Russell Williams, a former Canadian military commander who had confessed to scores of crimes, described incorrectly, in some copies, part of the nickname of another serial killer. That man, Dennis L. Rader, was known as ''the B.T.K. killer'' -- for bind (not blind), torture and kill. (On Thursday, a judge sentenced Colonel Williams to two life terms for two murders, plus 102 years for other crimes.)

The themes of antigovernment revolution have occasionally seeped into comments of Tea Party-backed candidates or their supporters this campaign season, and now a Republican House candidate in Texas has added his thoughts. Stephen Broden, a pastor and Tea Party-backed contender engaged in a long-shot bid in a heavily Democratic district in the Dallas area, suggested in an interview that violent overthrow of the government was a possibility that could not be dismissed. ''Our nation was founded on violence,'' Mr. Broden told Dallas-Fort Worth's WFAA-TV, according to a video posted Thursday on the station's Web site.

A Los Angeles judge ordered Lindsay Lohan to remain in a drug rehabilitation program until Jan. 3 after Ms. Lohan violated the terms of her probation, CNN.com reported. Judge Elden S. Fox of Los Angeles County Superior Court, who made the ruling on Friday morning, had previously ordered Ms. Lohan, the star of ''Mean Girls'' and ''Freaky Friday,'' to be sent to jail in September and to be held without bail after she failed a drug test she had been ordered to take as a condition of her probation. But that decision was quickly overturned and Ms. Lohan, after being freed on $300,000 bail, checked into the Betty Ford Center. Ms. Lohan, who faced up to 30 days in jail for the violation, was ordered to return to the court on Feb. 25. This summer, Ms. Lohan served less than two weeks of a 90-day jail sentence and spent 22 days in a rehabilitation facility after she missed a probation hearing in May that stemmed from 2007 arrests on charges of drunken driving and drug possession.

GROSSMAN--Ginger. Ginger Grossman, a leading political activist in Aventura and N. Dade County, FL, died October 18 at age 91. She is survived by her adoring husband of 70 years, Arthur; daughters, Boni Smith of FL and Lynn Grossman of NY; son-in-law, Bob Balaban; granddaughters Mariah and Hazel Balaban. At the time of her death she was actively involved in three political campaigns. As Founder and President of the North East Dade Involved Democrats, she developed a large and vocal bloc of senior voters and her support was actively sought by Democratic candidates on the local and national level. She was an active board member or founder of more than thirty political and social welfare organizations. She liked to quote Muhammad Ali: "Service to others is the rent we pay for our place here on earth." Ginger lived most of her long, good life paying that rent. Services: Sunday, October 24, 11:30am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam and 76th St.

The comedian Chris Rock will make his Broadway debut this spring in Stephen Adly Guirgis' new play ''The ---------------- With the Hat'' (obscenity deleted) as an Alcoholics Anonymous sponsor working with a recovering addict (to be played by Bobby Cannavale) whose long-time love (Elizabeth Rodriguez) remains in the grip of drugs and alcohol. Anna D. Shapiro will direct the play, her first on Broadway since winning a 2008 Tony Award for ''August: Osage County.'' The production's ensemble cast will also include Annabella Sciorra and Yul Vazquez.

Dancers from New York City Ballet will perform at the International Ballet Festival in Havana next month, it was announced on Thursday. For the trip, under the auspices of the New York-based Cuban Artists Fund, eight principal dancers are going: Jared Angle, Tyler Angle, Megan Fairchild, Joaquin De Luz, Abi Stafford, Tiler Peck, Teresa Reichlen and Andrew Veyette. The program includes George Balanchine's ''Tarantella''; pas de deux from his ''Chaconne'' and ''Stars and Stripes''; and a concert version of ''Who Cares.'' The dancers will also perform Jerome Robbins's ''In the Night'' and ''Other Dances'' and Christopher Wheeldon's ''Liturgy.'' The performances will take place at the Teatro Mella on Nov. 1 and 2. American Ballet Theater is also performing at the festival. An earlier version of this post said City Ballet was sending the dancers.

Half a century ago the British scientist and novelist C. P. Snow bemoaned the estrangement of what he termed the "two cultures" in modern society - the literary and the scientific. These days, there is some reason to celebrate better communication between these domains, if only because of the increasingly visible salience of scientific ideas. Still a gap remains, and so I'd like here to take an oblique look at a few lesser-known contrasts and divisions between subdomains of the two cultures, specifically those between stories and statistics.

Last summer, the Senate, while debating what eventually became the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act, took a stab at reining in fees for debit and credit cards. The amendment, proposed by Democratic Senator Dick Durbin of Illinois, would have ended the card networks' practice of preventing merchants from using incentives to steer customers toward other credit cards and credit card brands. When the bill reached the president's desk, however, that provision had been replaced by one that allows merchants to offer discounts only for certain forms of payment.

9 P.M. (13, 49) SHERLOCK: A STUDY IN PINK Benedict Cumberbatch (''Atonement''), right, plays a contemporary version of Arthur Conan Doyle's London sleuth, and Martin Freeman (BBC's ''Office'') is Dr. John Watson, his loyal sidekick and a veteran of the war in Afghanistan, in this three-part ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' production created by Steven Moffat and Mark Gatiss of ''Doctor Who'' fame. In this first episode, the flat mates tackle a case of serial suicide in which three people have disappeared under identical circumstances and later turned up dead, having taken the same self-administered poison. Then a fourth victim is discovered, dressed entirely in pink and found with the word ''Rache'' scratched into the floor where she died. Rupert Graves plays Detective Inspector Lestrade, who asks Sherlock to help him decipher what it all means. ''The appeal is elementary,'' Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times, ''good, unpretentious fun, something that's in short supply around here.'' 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Ms. Crowley moderates a debate among the Senate candidates in Florida: Gov. Charlie Crist, an Independent; Representative Kendrick B. CUMMINGS--Robert Thomas (Tom), 88, died on October 13, 2010 at his home in Vero Beach, Florida. He retired as President of the Fibers Division of AlliedSignal in 1984. Tom was known by all for his intellect, unbelievable sense of humor, generosity, and love of children. He is survived by his wife Carol Cummings, three daughters, Sarah Post, Katie Cummings and Christine Cummings, and two stepdaughters Lynn Corson and Lisa Corson.

STURZ--Elizabeth Lyttleton. The Board of Directors and staff of Argus Community, Inc. mourn the loss of Elizabeth Lyttleton Sturz, the Founder of Argus, its President and its inspiration. Elizabeth was an artist and poet. She created Argus, a multiservice agency in the South Bronx, in 1968 and left an indelible mark. She changed lives, through her creativity, tenacity and concern, and her contributions continue to be felt, every day, as those she taught and inspired carry on her work. We share the grief of her family and extend our condolences to her beloved husband Herbert J. Sturz, her daughters, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren.

This post is part of the first-ever themed issue of The Times's Sunday Metropolitan section, which is devoted to New York's subway system. Go to The Subway Issue There are so many sins of subway etiquette that it is difficult to rank the effrontery. Are the nail clippers the worst? The people consuming smelly Big Macs? Or how about those who tote their yappy little dogs, without a lick of concern for the allergies of fellow riders?

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Saturday, October 9th 2010, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

Anyone who watched late-night programming in the 1980s will be familiar with the Mount Airy Lodge. ''All you need to bring is your love for everything,'' went the jingle of one of the Pocono resort's famouscommercials. After a heyday in the '60s and '70s, though, the resort had fallen into disrepair by the late '90s, and it finally closed in 2001. The property and name -- though not much else -- are now back, in the form of the Mount Airy Casino Resort, a $400 million property that opened in 2007 and more recently added an 18-hole golf course, and in July, casino table games, after the state of Pennsylvania legalized them earlier this year.

Kerrilynn Pamer, the owner of the stylish downtown clothing shop Castor & Pollux, always has eventual heirlooms in the back of her mind. These weighty brass bracelets were cast from vintage versions that belonged to her Aunt Maggie, who passed away last March. ''She always wore three of them - two thick and one thin,'' Pamer says. ''She had the most pitch-perfect style imaginable.'' The bracelets are $172 (for the thin style) and $182 at Castor & Pollux, 238 West 10th Street, or go to castorandpolluxstore.com. An obituary on Oct. 10 about Johnny Edgecombe, who was involved in the scandal that led to the resignation of the British government minister John Profumo, referred imprecisely to the place where Mr. Edgecombe's girlfriend, Christine Keeler, spoke of swimming nude. PALMER--R. Carl, Jr.,respected banker throughout South Florida, passed away Sunday, September 26 at his home on Martha's Vineyard, MA. He was 69 years old. Carl's banking career began in New York with Chemical Bank. Moving to South Florida in 1979, Carl continued his career with several banks large and small, most recently serving as the Chairman and CEO of Pointe Bank, a community bank based in Boca Raton, FL. Community banking was his calling, where he built community in addition to serving it. Carl was born in Shaker Heights, OH and attended Euclid Sr. High School, Class of 1958. There he met and fell in love with Mary Virginia Nowacek, who was to become his beloved wife and companion for more than fifty years. Carl graduated from Dartmouth College in 1962 and received his MBA from the Tuck School of Business in 1963. He graduated from New York Law School, receiving his JD in 1969. Mary V. and Carl made their home in many wonderful places over the years, from Summit, New Jersey to Coral Gables, Naples and Boca Raton, FL. In addition to his wife, Carl is survived by four children, Mary Susanna, Emily Lynore, Carl Patrick and Rebecca Ruth and eight grandchildren to whom he was Nono, and in whom his giving spirit lives on. A memorial service will be held at Plymouth Congregational Church on Saturday, November 6th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Camp Jabberwocky. PO Box 1357, Vineyard Haven, MA 02568.

MALLOY--Henry Lawrence, of Waccabuc, NY passed away on October 22, 2010 after a courageous battle with cancer. Born in New York City on January 26, 1931, the son of Henry Thomas Malloy and Ellen Neville Malloy. He graduated from Mamaroneck High School, class of 1948, attended Colby College, and graduated from Villanova College with a BS in Economics, class of 1953. Mr. Malloy enlisted in the US Navy from 1953 to 1955 attaining the rank of Lieutenant. His employment career spanned from Hearst Publishing, BBD&O advertising agency, Bergdorf Goodman as head of customer service and then onto Republic Hogg Robinson currently known as Wells Fargo Insurance where he retired as Vice President in P&C insurance. He was also a former member of Westchester Country Club in Rye, NY, and an active member of Waccabuc Country Club in Waccabuc, NY, Shinnecock Hills Golf Club in Southampton, NY, and Stratton Mountain Country Club in Stratton, VT and The Turf and Field Club. He married the former Vivien Goodman on January 12, 1957. He is survived by his wife Vivien Malloy; five children: Andrew of Castle Rock, CO, Debby Winkler of Warendorf Germany, Kenneth of Rye, NY, Mark of Los Angeles, CA and Vivi Hanson of Chicago, IL; grandchildren: Courtney, Conor, Caitlin, Maggie, Kenny Jr., Shane, Owen and Julia, step granddaughter Bailey, step grandson Jack, and Lily; one brother John N. Malloy of Harrison, NY. Henry, known to all his friends as Harry, enjoyed golf above all the other activities that he shared with so many family and friends. He fell in love with Stratton Mountain in 1968 and spent weekends and holidays there skiing with his family. As owner of New York's Edition Farm, he enjoyed his time at the races rooting for his thoroughbreds. There will be many friends that will miss his great sense of humor and camaraderie they shared with him over the years. Contributions can be made to the charity of one's choice in honor of Henry L. Malloy. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, Rye, NY, on Monday from 4pm-8pm. A mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Church of the Resurrection on Tuesday at 10am.

MARTIN--Ralph H.,of Stuart, FL and Sandwich, MA died October 15, 2010 at the age of 86. He is survived by his wife Marsha Martin; two children from his first marriage, Dr. L. Elizabeth Cooper-Martin of Rockville, MD and Jeffrey S. Martin of New York, NY; four grandchildren; two stepsons; and four step-grandchildren. A prodigy in chemistry, Mr. Martin was valedictorian at Warren G. Harding High School and attended Carnegie-Mellon University as a Westinghouse Scholar. During World War II, Mr. Martin was an officer in the US Naval Reserve, assigned to rocket development. In 1945, Mr. Martin married the former N. Suzanne Scott, a classmate at Carnegie-Mellon. That marriage ended in divorce in 1994. After a career in manufacturing, Mr. Martin retired in 1985 from The Dexter Corporation where he was Executive Vice President and a director. Mr. Martin was an accomplished golfer, with six holes-in-one and numerous championships to his credit, and shot his age on several occasions. A memorial celebration in Mr. Martin's honor is planned for the second weekend in November.

WEBER--Barry H.,59, adoring husband, best friend, incredible father and loving son died October 19, 2010 after fighting bladder cancer. He moved to Long Beach, NY in 1976 with Sonja and they were married at Temple Emanu-el in 1979. Also in 1979, he became President of Edith Weber Antique Jewelry, NYC at the Carlyle Hotel. He appeared on the Antiques Roadshow for 15 seasons as a jewelry appraiser. His passion for music was paramount. He loved the blues and played great slide guitar with his music family from coast to coast. Mr. Weber was a teacher and mentor in the field of jewelry and guitar. Barry is survived by his wife, Sonja, son Adam, and his mother Edith. His funeral services will be held Sunday, October 24, at 1pm at Temple Emanu-el, 455 Neptune Blvd., Long Beach, NY. His family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations sent to MSKCC, "The Drs. Bajorin/Russo Bladder Cancer Research Fund."

WARREN--William B. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Academy of American Poets mourn the passing of our beloved colleague, William B. Warren. Bill joined the Board of the Academy in 1993 and served as Vice President since 2003. His knowledge of poetry was deep, his love of literature infectious, and his use of language impeccable. He widened the Academy's circle of friends with a never-failing wit that made our work together delightful, and he offered a steadying hand during hard times. The Academy has lost a dear friend, and poetry has lost a gallant champion. In the words of a poet he knew and admired, "Peace! Peace! To be rocked by the Infinite! As if it didn't matter which way was home; as if he didn't know he loved the earth so much he wanted to stay forever." - Stanley Kunitz, "The Long Boat"

It's a sign of how poorly liberals market themselves and their ideas that the word ''liberal'' is still in disrepute despite the election of the most genuinely liberal president that the political culture of this country will probably allow. ''Progressive'' is now the self-description of choice for liberals, though it's musty and evasive. The basic equation remains: virtually all Republican politicians call themselves conservative; few Democratic politicians call themselves liberal. Even retired Classic Coke liberals like Walter F. Mondale are skittish about their creed. ''I never signed up for any ideology,'' he writes in his memoirs. That would be fine (people are sick of labels) if clarity weren't such an obvious political advantage. Simple ideology routinely trounces nuanced pragmatism, just as emotion so often beats reason and the varsity fullback will most likely deck the captain of the debate team in a fistfight. For four decades, conservatives have used the word ''liberal'' as an epithet, while liberals have used ''conservative'' defensively (''I'm a little conservative on . . .''). And Fox fans range out of factual bounds (''death panels'') more than their NPR-listening counterparts in the liberal ''reality-based community'' (a term attributed to a Bush White House aide by the author Ron Suskind).

Undeterred by travel warnings and frightening headlines about safety in Mexico, an increasing number of international touristsare flying to the country, according to the Mexico Tourism Board. The number of international tourists who flew to Mexico (Sumidero Canyon in Chiapas state, above) from January to August increased 19 percent over the same period last year, according to the board, and most were from the United States. More than four million American citizens flew to Mexico, an increase of 15 percent over the same period last year. The surge in tourism is being matched by a surge in flights from North American hubs: Continental, United Airlines and Delta have all announced plans for additional flights to Mexican destinations, including Mexico City and Cancún. MONICA DRAKE

This post is part of the first-ever themed issue of The Times's Sunday Metropolitan section, which is devoted to New York's subway system. Go to the Subway Issue Endlessley pored over, chronically criticized, instantly recognizable - the subway map is like the city's wallpaper. (Or, say, shower curtain; many versions available for under $30.) In June, the 1979 design got its first overhaul in a decade, with Manhattan magnified, Staten Island shrunk, and a lighter taupe background and new gray outlines to make it more readable. But what if everybody designed his and her own maps? There are eight million subway systems in the city: we all ride the same trains, but we experience them differently. Inspired by map remixes posted on the Internet, Metropolitan decided to ask several prominent and interesting New Yorkers to reimagine the map in their own image, and a gallery of them has been published online. Now, we want you to show us your personal subway map. Use this tool to print or download a template and send us your designs.

4:51 p.m. | Updated An earlier version of this post said the next Mazda 2 would get 70 miles per gallon. A Mazda spokesman clarified late on Thursday that the result was achieved from the Japanese test cycle. Fuel economy numbers will be lower in the United States. After the deluge of publicity surrounding the Chevrolet Volt and Nissan Leaf -- two cars bearing the exclusivity of low production numbers and high prices -- people seeking high mileage at low cost might find some solace in Mazda's announcement this week that its coming fourth generation Demio (Mazda 2 in the United States) would get 15 percent better gas mileage than the existing model.

Cire Trudon, the cult candle maker that once dipped tapers for Marie Antoinette, has transformed the corner of Bond Street and the Bowery into a tiny version of Versailles's Galerie des Glaces. The company's first Stateside outpost, which opens this week on the lower-ground level of the old Bouwerie Lane Theater, is filled with antique mirrors and historical French moldings and hardware - the perfect surroundings for perfumed candles, pillars and room sprays that conjure waxed palace floors and Madame de Pompadour's boudoir. Cire Trudon's 36-year-old owner, Ramdane Touhami, a forward-thinking classicist if ever there was one, invites customers to linger in the space for as long as they like. ''Choosing a scent for your home should be like choosing one for your body,'' he says. ''It takes time.'' Cire Trudon, 54 Bond Street; (212) 677-1200; ciretrudon.com.

JOHNSON--Wayne, Jr.,88, formerly of Greenwich, Connecticut, passed away in Southampton, New York on October 20, 2010. He was born in New York City on July 11, 1922 to Wayne Johnson and Gladys Royer Johnson. A graduate of St. Paul's School of Concord, New Hampshire, he received a BA from Harvard in 1944 and LLB from Harvard Law in 1948. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Polly Goodrich Johnson, four children, Jennifer Johnson Clark of Rye, New York, Lorry Johnson Prentis of New York, New York, Polly Johnson Neely of Santa Monica, California and Wayne Johnson III of Atlanta, Georgia and six grandchildren. He had a distinguished career as an analyst and broker at H. G. Wellington, formerly Stillman Maynard. Prior, he was a legal associate at Putney, Twombly, Hall & Skidmore before joining Owens Corning Fiber Glass. A memorial service will be held on October 30th at 12noon, St. Andrews Dune Church, Southampton, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the East End Hospice, Westhampton Beach, New York.

As the first frost arrives, a fashion look has been revived: the cape. A new generation of women in New York and Paris is discovering its drama and convenience. The cape, which fits the shoulders, dominated women's outerwear in the 19th century. Today, it is seen as the ideal topping for both multilayered sportswear and dresses. The sweater-like cape, with tablecloth-pointed hems, is also popular (bottom right).

Subsumed by the Nascar juggernaut, Formula One barely registers on the radar of most American motorsport fans, lending wheel-to-open-wheel racing a dose of underground cachet. It is so underground, in fact, that one Michigan man channeled his love of Formula One into a veritable basement fight club. James Harlan, by his estimation, presides over the most elaborate slot-car racetrack in the country, which he built in his 1,000-square-foot basement and modeled after some of the Formula One race circuit's most notoriously challenging track features. ''I suppose I've taken it pretty far beyond what's been done,'' he said.

Barbour, the U.K.-based outerwear company and holder of the warrant to supply ''waterproof and protective clothing'' to England's royal family, has created a limited-edition collection of boots with the New England-based shoemaker Rockport. The signature rain-resistant waxed cotton used in Barbour's weatherproof jackets has been hand-stitched to rough, textured leathers in three styles of boots that incorporate the advanced technology in walking comfort for which Rockport is known. Though a bit rugged for most workplaces, they're a perfect match for the tweed pants and suits now hitting stores for the coming winter - and will most certainly weather any storm, be it in a peat bog or a concrete canyon. THE NEWS NPR terminated its contract with Juan Williams, a senior analyst, after he said, on a Fox News Channel broadcast, that he has some fears when he sees people in ''Muslim garb'' on airplanes. NPR said he had ''undermined his credibility as a news analyst.'' BEHIND THE NEWS Like most news organizations, NPR expects its journalists to keep personal opinion out of their reporting, and Mr. Williams's work for Fox as a commentator on programs like ''The O'Reilly Factor'' had made NPR uneasy for some time. For its part, Fox jumped to Mr. Williams's defense and offered him a new $2 million contract.

A huge trove of secret field reports from the battlegrounds of Iraq sheds new light on the war, including such fraught subjects as civilian deaths, detainee abuse and the involvement of Iran. The secret archive is the second such cache obtained by the independent organization WikiLeaks and made available to several news organizations. Like the first release, some 77,000 reports covering six years of the war in Afghanistan, the Iraq documents provide no earthshaking revelations, but they offer insight, texture and context from the people actually fighting the war.

When it comes to the point where you occasionally look forward to being in prison on the basis that you might be able to spend a day reading a book, the realization dawns that perhaps the situation has become a little more stressful than you would like. A picture caption on Oct. 10 with an article about Turku, Finland, which has been named a 2011 European Capital of Culture, misidentified a square in the city. The photograph showing a bicyclist crossing a square is of Old Great Square, not Market Square.

SIRIS--Charlotte (nee Gidding), 94, died October 18, 2010. Wife of Sydney M. Siris, DDS (deceased) she is survived by her son, Samuel Siris, MD (Ethel Siris, MD), two grandchildren, Rabbi Benjamin Siris (Tzipi Siris) and Sara Siris Nash, MD (Bradley Nash) and four great-grandchildren.

The cover story on Sept. 26 about an opera-lover's visit to Zurich referred incorrectly to the location of the city's opera house. It is a few blocks from the mouth of the Limmat River by Lake Zurich, into which the river flows; it is not alongside the river.

An article on Oct. 10 about the architect Bing Thom referred imprecisely to the Kogod Cradle, a theater building in the new Arena Stage complex in Washington designed by Mr. Thom. While it is a small site intended for staging new and developing productions, like a black box theater, it is not a highly flexible, unadorned space and thus is not a black box theater.

IT used to be that the only thing keeping Gary D. Warshauer up at night was the chatter of crickets and the howl of coyotes. There was little about this 23-square-mile municipality in northeastern Westchester to trouble Mr. Warshauer, its town supervisor: the underground water supply, all 11 aquifers of it, was untainted; more than a third of town land had been set aside as open space; and the minimum residential lot size was an acre.

BASICS Rafayel on the Left Bank may sound Parisian, but the hotel actually occupies several floors in a large apartment complex in Battersea, a former industrial area on the south bank of Thames in London. The neighborhood has enjoyed a real estate boom, along with the rest of the city, in the last few years, and the Rafayel, which opened in April, has an enviable location on the river. There's LED lighting in the rooms, little paper at checkout and no plastic bottles or heated towel racks anywhere. The Rafayel advertises itself as ''one of the world's first environmentally-conscious luxury hotels.'' Its mission, according to the developer, Iqbal Latif, is to reduce the carbon footprint of the average night's stay by 25 percent without inconveniencing guests.

The Food and Drug Administration has declined to approve what would have been the first new prescription diet pill in more than a decade. The agency's rejection of the drug, called lorcaserin, was announced late Friday by the drug's developer, Arena Pharmaceuticals, and its marketing partner, Eisai.

DWEK--Cyril. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of our esteemed benefactor. To his children, Nevil and Alicia, and to the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. Rabbi Marc Schneier Morris Tuchman, President Seymour Siegel, Treasurer

STORICH--Albert. Al and Del lived happily in Northern California where their beloved daughter, Nikki Yvette, once resided and grandson Cassady currently resides. Al died peacefully nearby his favored Emeryville marina. 1918-2010.

Joe Adams, left, of No. 21 Arkansas returned a punt 97 yards. It was his first return for a touchdown, and it set a team record, eclipsing a 95-yard return by Ken Hatfield against Tulsa in 1965. Maryland safety Antwine Perez, a preseason all-A.C.C. selection, had two interceptions and a fumble recovery to help lead the Terrapins to a 24-21 victory against host Boston College.

This post is part of the first-ever themed issue of The Times's Sunday Metropolitan section, which is devoted to New York's subway system. Go to The Subway Issue Eric Molinsky does not like to get caught. One recent afternoon on a Manhattan-bound R train, Mr. Molinsky, a freelance radio producer and inveterate people-watcher, slid into position. He scanned the not-yet-packed car. At one end, two aging New York dames laughed. Mr. Molinsky, 39, set his sights on the blonde.

A LITTLE TRICKERY Fake punts played key roles in the Big Ten. Wisconsin, left, used one to extend its winning drive at Iowa, and unbeaten Michigan State to avoid an upset at Northwestern. A FIRST FOR TEMPLE With a convincing 42-0 win against host Buffalo, Temple became bowl-eligible for a second straight season for the first time in its history. It was the Owls' first shutout since 1992.

LEVI--Lisa Schwab. It is with great sadness that we announce the death of Lee/Lisa Schwab Levi on October 9, 2010. Born Lisalotte Schwab in Frankfurt (am Main), Germany on August 12, 1916, she came to the United States in 1939. She attended Roedean School in Brighton, England, worked her way through college at Northwestern University, and then at the University of Pennsylvania, where she earned an MA in Social Work. Mrs. Levi was a trailblazer in psychiatric and social services work, helping create the New York Mobile Crisis Unit. Her deeds of loving kindness were legendary, playing a key role in facilitating German Jews to emigrate from Germany to England before WWII, and assisting refugees in Europe through the United Nations after the War. She was predeceased by her soul mate, her husband Fritz Levi, and a daughter Scarlett Ginsberg, and is survived by her daughter Susan (Chazz) Levi (and her husband Howard Courch) of Red Hook, NY, along with their children, Tali and Cole Levi-Crouch of New York City, as well as grandsons Jacob Ginsberg (and his wife Elizabeth), with their daughters, Cate and Sarah Ginsberg, and Judge Carl Ginsberg, both of Dallas, TX. To continue her legacy of kindness, please send donations to Ramapo for Children, PO Box 266, Rhinebeck, NY 12572. She selflessly dedicated herself to others and her deeds left this world a better place.

Q.We are going to spend four days in Chicago the first week of December for our 25th anniversary. What romantic suggestions do you have for dining and sightseeing? Kathy Turken, Phoenix, Ariz.A.Chicago will be cold in December, so dress accordingly and plan frequent indoor breaks. You might begin your anniversary day with a tour of the city's architectural gems. The Chicago Architecture Foundation (caf.architecture.org) offers a two-hour ''Historic Downtown (south): Rise of the Skyscraper'' walking tour, which highlights the oldest high-rises in the Loop and begins daily at 10 a.m., year-round. Or, for a warmer experience, take its ''Highlights by Bus'' tour, available on Saturdays and Sundays at 9:30 a.m. in December.

Polls will not open for more than a week, but millions of Americans have already cast their ballots, and both parties see reason to be pleased by the early results. Democratic officials overseeing House races say a $20 million voter turnout program is producing results. In Iowa, for example, the percentage of ballots already returned by Democrats exceeds Democratic registration by 12 or more percentage points.

When Max Lieberman saw a break in the line, he ran. Officers leading the Auschwitz death march shot him, but he kept sprinting through the woods until he collapsed in a field. Farmers nursed him to health, and he never wanted to run again. More than 65 years later, Izzy Lieberman will traverse the five boroughs of the New York City Marathon to honor his father's escape in Poland and to help others whose post-Holocaust journeys have become increasingly difficult to bear.

HARRIS--Jane Merryweather, a Salisbury, CT resident for 63 years, died peacefully at Sharon Hospital surrounded by her family on October 18, 2010. Mrs. Harris, 88, was the wife of the late David Farnum Harris for 61 years until his death in 2004. Mrs. Harris was born in Denver, Colorado on February 19, 1922. She was the daughter of Weir Orford Merryweather and Margaret Owen Dorsey. She was raised in Denver and attended Bennett College in Millbrook, NY. Mrs. Harris and her husband spent many of their summers at a second home on Fishers Island, NY. Mrs. Harris enjoyed using her many creative talents. As an active member of The Millbrook Garden Club, she especially enjoyed preparing flowers for St. John's Episcopal Church in Salisbury and The Fishers Island Club. Mrs. Harris was the first woman elected to serve on the Board of Governors of The Fishers Island Club and for many years was an active member of The Society of The Colonial Dames of America. As a local entrepreneur, Mrs. Harris was a co-owner of the White Hart Inn in Salisbury. Mrs. Harris was most devoted to supporting her husband's philanthropic efforts and spending time with her family, considering raising her three children her most satisfying achievement. Survivors include her children, David Farnum Harris, Jr., of Salisbury, Gwendoline A. Harris Milliken and her husband, Seth, of Salisbury, and John Montgomery Harris and his wife, Kathryn, of Manchester-by-the Sea, MA, and their three children, Dorsey Harris Miller and her husband, Douglas, Kathryn Houghton Harris, and John Montgomery Harris, Jr. She is also survived by her sister, Anne Merryweather Close, and her husband, Edward, of Littleton, CO. A memorial service will be held at 11am, Friday, October 29th, at St. John's Episcopal Church, 12 Main St., Salisbury, CT. Contributions may be made to the Salisbury School Annual Fund in memory of Jane M. Harris, 251 Canaan Road, Salisbury, CT 06068 or the Heritage Fund of The Millbrook Garden Club in memory of Jane M. Harris, 18 Grandview Lane, Sharon, CT 06069.

With regard to transportation, the best weekly deal offered by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (mta.info) is the Seven-Day Unlimited Ride MetroCard for $27 ($29 starting Dec. 30).

DRIER--Thelma. 93, October 20, 2010. Devoted wife of the late Elmer Drier, predeceased by her dear sisters Helen Arzt and Lillan Burgeman and brothers-in-law Irving Arzt and Harry Burgeman. Beloved aunt of Sondra and Joel Spector and nieces and nephews. Thelma lived and loved life to its fullest. She traveled the world with her beloved Elmer and leaves us treasured photographs that document her experiences. Thelma was as strong-willed as she was sensitive, always ready to support a cause in which she believed. Thelma leaves behind a legacy of kindness, concern for others and a sense of humor that will remain with us forever.

Atlantis, Paradise Island, in the Bahamas, will host the first ''Battle at Atlantis,'' a four-team Division I doubleheader featuring Mississippi State, Virginia Tech, Georgia Tech and the University of Richmond on Dec. 18. The resort is spending about half a million dollars to convert its conference center -- usually host to big-name pop concerts featuring the likes of Rihanna and the Jonas Brothers -- to create a temporary 4,200-seat arena with live broadcasting capabilities. It is also offering a package for sports fans, with rates starting at $149 a night, including two tickets to a preferred game (two-night minimum).

Elle Muliarchyk has seen enough psychics to take their soothsaying with a pinch of sodium chloride. A model turned photographer, she believes that the clothes she has worn on the day of her readings have influenced the prognostications she has received. During the making of ''Somnambuli,'' Ms. Muliarchyk's fashion video, shot exclusively for T, about the power of clothes to affect our destiny, the model Meghan Collison underwent a series of high-fashion transformations and had her fortune read by various New York clairvoyants. ''The same psychic who told the model to clean up her act when she was dressed like a hippie,'' Ms. Muliarchyk recalled, ''saw Harvard in her future a few days later when she was dressed up like an Upper East Side lady.'' Spooky, huh? A fashion shoot featuring still images from ''Somnambuli'' appears in the current issue of Dossier magazine.
