One Alderman's Strategy Includes Taking Risks With municipal elections less than five months away, many members of the Chicago City Council are wary of saying or doing anything that could antagonize voters. Alderman Freddrenna Lyle of the Sixth Ward, however, does not appear to be one of them.

Louise Bourgeois was reportedly a notorious hoarder. The artist, who died this year at the age of 98, accumulated all manner of tablecloths, napkins, clothing and bed linens - a lifetime's worth of material, really - which she began to cut up and reassemble into ''drawings'' in the mid-1990s. Her Collyer Brothers tendencies aside, Bourgeois no doubt found precarious comfort in the nest of this critical mass; she grew up surrounded by textiles in her parents' tapestry restoration workshop, and the act of sewing, she said, was her attempt to keep things together and make them whole. In this context, the more than 70 pieces in ''Louise Bourgeois: The Fabric Works,'' an exhibition that aptly christens Hauser & Wirth's new space on Savile Row in London, are as poignant as they are vibrant. But taken purely at face value, these pieces make one lament the fact that Bourgeois never moonlighted as a textile designer. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Spending on television advertisements rose significantly for one candidate - but not the other - in more than a dozen House races last week, usually due to the involvement of an outside group. Below, a sampling of such races.

Berlin's gritty, working-class Neukölln district, settled nearly 300 years ago by (actual) Bohemians fleeing religious persecution, is once again a destination for (modern) bohemians -- this time, thanks to artists fleeing rent hikes elsewhere in the city. A hundred years ago the area, then called Rixdorf, was best known for dance halls and fistfights. In an effort to burnish its image, officials renamed the place Neukölln, but by the 1990s its reputation was so bad there was talk of going back to Rixdorf. The last few years, though, have seen a wave of international creative types, leading, in turn, to new artist-run spaces and bar-slash-galleries; they're popping up in derelict storefronts and corner pubs, as well as cafes, wine bars, the odd organic grocery and Nowkoelln Flowmarkt (nowkoelln.de), an unusually hip monthly flea market that started in May. SALLY McGRANE

MAKLA--Robert M.,of Brooklyn, NY passed away on October 14, 2010. Bob was beloved by his sisters Grace and Alice and his nieces and nephew. A tireless and inspiring advocate for the city's parks, Bob founded several park conservation organizations to provide tree care and maintenance to the park's natural treasures. He was known for introducing cyclists to the wonders of the city through his middle-of-the-night bike tours. Bob served in WWII and the Korean War, graduated from Princeton and Yale Law and was an active and devoted partner at the law firm of D'Amato & Lynch. Contributions may be made to the Prospect Park Alliance, Development Office, 95 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, NY 11215 (designate "tree care") or to The Tree Trust, Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60th St., 8th Floor, New York, NY 10022.
An article last Sunday about the tenor Vittorio Grigolo misspelled the name of the character played by Mr. Grigolo in a production of ''Lucrezia Borgia.'' The character is Gennaro, not Genarro.

In Vietnam’s north, ethnic minorities thrive in a region of slopes and cliffs that is just being discovered by visitors.

Democrats have made progress in several states in our latest gubernatorial forecast. Although it remains very probable that Republicans will control the majority of the nation's governorships after Nov. 2, it is now more likely that Democratic and independent candidates can hold Republicans to victories in 20 to 23 of the 37 contests that will be held on Election Day.
Mark Schmitt, left, of The American Prospect and Timothy Noah of Slate debate the political power of “The Daily Show.”

While Republicans' position is holding steady in the House -- where they are 4:1 favorites to win control of the chamber according to our analysis -- their chances of also taking over the Senate declined in today's forecast. Those chances are now 16 percent, down from 19 percent in our forecast over the weekend.

Thélème Partners, a new hedge fund founded by a former Merrill Lynch banker, Patrick Degorce, has raised over $700 million, making it the largest equity hedge fund started since the financial crisis began, The Financial Times reported.
In next Tuesday’s election, a number of Democratic members of Congress from Arizona are facing stiff challenges. Voters are listening to both sides at candidate forums and debates.

TUESDAY'S PUZZLE - There is a certain timelessness about typical New York Times crosswords. They eschew topical references for several reasons: there is a long lag between construction and publication, syndicated solvers get the puzzles more than a month after that, and most important, puzzles live long and happy lives well beyond their birth dates. They are collected in books that may be sold many years later.
As regulators extend their reach, insider trading is harder to define, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his DealBook column this week.
ExxonMobil is scheduled to start shipping natural gas through a 450-mile pipeline through the Southern Highlands, the most impoverished region in one of the world’s poorest countries.

The campaign behind the California ballot initiative that would legalize, tax and regulate marijuana has released its first television advertisement, one that seeks to convey a simple message: the current approach is not working.

Democratic chances of retaining control of the House are essentially unchanged in today's FiveThirtyEight forecast. They have a 21 percent chance of doing so, up from 20 percent on Friday; that means Republicans have a 79 percent chance of instead claiming control. The average projection returned a result of 205 Democrats in the House and 230 Republicans, which would reflect a gain of 51 seats for the G.O.P.; this figure is unchanged.

Mr. Cullum, a classic gag cartoonist whose visual absurdities were underlined by captions reeled in from deep left field, published 819 cartoons in The New Yorker.

A 41-35 whipping of the Cowboys on Monday left the Giants looking like perhaps the top team in the National Football Conference. In winning their fourth straight game, the Giants (5-2) claimed sole possession of first place in the N.F.C. East, and they looked the part, despite a sloppy finish that allowed the Cowboys to climb back on the scoreboard.

We've all seen the ads for fair trade coffee with the beautiful photos of villagers hand picking coffee cherries in exotic regions around the globe. Fair trade is one of those ideas that's always in the air, but we don't often consider what it means. What does it really take to connect rural producers in the developing world with consumers in wealthy countries - so that everybody benefits?
Amazon.com is more than happy to shout about the success of its Kindle tablet. But it always does so without disclosing specifics about the number of Kindles actually sold.
The Miami Heat compiled a conglomerate of superstars, but the Orlando Magic built around the edges and still has what Miami does not — depth and a natural All-Star center.

A few weeks ago, the Cardozo School of Law mounted a conference marking the 20th anniversary of Employment Division v. Smith (1990), a case in which the Supreme Court asked what happens when a form of behavior demanded by one's religion runs up against a generally applicable law - a law not targeted at any particular agenda or point of view - that makes the behavior illegal. (The behavior at issue was the ingestion of peyote at a Native American religious ceremony.) The answer the court gave, with Justice Antonin Scalia writing for the majority, was that the religious believer must yield to the law of the state so long as that law was not passed with the intention of curtailing or regulating his or anyone else's religious practice. (This is exactly John Locke's view in his "Letter Concerning Toleration.")
Tuesday's Science Times profiles an art conservator who uses scientific techniques to bring contemporary art back to life.

The high-stakes feud between the News Corporation and Cablevision reached the point of filing grievances before the Federal Communications Commission on Monday, with each side trying to prove that it had been bargaining in good faith -- while charging that the other side had not.

In this week's Critics' Pick, A. O. Scott looks back at Clint Eastwood's 1993 drama, "A Perfect World." The film focuses on the relationship between a young boy (T. J. Lowther) and the prison escapee (Kevin Costner) who takes him hostage. Mr. Eastwood plays the police officer in pursuit.

"Hipster" is more than a noun - it's a lifestyle. An overused, albeit elastic, coinage, it can describe everything from vintage T-shirt connoisseurs to anyone who kinda sorta maybe knows Cory Kennedy. And now it's a subject of highbrow discourse. N+1, the Dumbo-based "journal of politics, literature and culture," aims to shed new light on the phenomenon with the release of "What Was the Hipster?: A Sociological Investigation" (n+1 Foundation, $10), a pocket-size pop theory text on topics ranging from the aesthetics of party photography to the, ahem, "hipster Other."

John Baldessari was not the first conceptual artist or appropriationist, but he has to be the funniest. Take his primitive 1971 video, "I Am Making Art," in which the burly, 6-foot-5 Los Angeleno deadpans the title phrase while improvising mechanical hand and elbow gestures that lie somewhere between sign language for the blind and the body language of a traffic cop. It's hilarious. And somehow poignant.

In a chaotic universe where all empirical stimuli is subjectively interpreted by imperfect observers, who is to say what does or does not happen? Jean-Luc Godard, for one: Mr. Godard, 79, the irascible filmmaker and a pioneer of the French New Wave movement, will definitely not be attending a special Oscars ceremony on Nov. 13 to pick up an honorary Academy Award, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Monday.

A new poll from the University of Southern California and the Los Angeles Times shows that the Democratic candidates in gubernatorial and Senate races, Jerry Brown and Barbara Boxer, respectively, have the lead over their Republican counterparts, Meg Whitman and Carly Fiorina.

The Ladle of Love food truck in Central Park runs on an electric engine, uses containers and utensils made of vegetable products, and serves up a mean goat-cheese salad. One thing it lacks is an overnight parking spot. The maximum speed of 25 miles an hour and limited cruising range make Brooklyn, nighttime home of many of Manhattan's food-vending trucks, a reach. In Manhattan, the owners are having a hard time finding a garage with 10-foot high ceilings. Read the tale of the wandering food truck on Diner's Journal.

Overview | How can real problems be approached and analyzed in ways that lead to practical solutions? What distinguishes effective solutions from ineffective ones? In this lesson, students consider how to work through a practical problem. They identify problems in their school that need fixing, then devise viable solutions to one of those problems, using problem-solving models and drawing on strategies like the social science of behavioral change. They then test some of their proposed solutions in the field and propose them to the school.

Cushing's disease is a rare condition in humans, but common in dogs. As a result, scientists are now hoping that a unique collaboration between veterinarians and human doctors will unlock clues for treating the disease.

For people with typical commutes, the coming Chevrolet Volt plug-in hybrid is likely to be driven as an electric car, producing no tailpipe emissions, much of the time. That would make it effectively cleaner than most cars on the road.

Truly independent directors can be hard to spot. The reason is that the conflicts that create doubt as to a director's independence can be so subtle and hidden. It is easy to know that the spouse of the chief executive is not independent, but what about a best friend from high school? When do relationships, social or otherwise, arise to the level that a conflict is created and director independence is questionable?

As banks resume foreclosure proceedings, many hard-pressed homeowners are questioning why banks are making it so difficult to opt for short sales, according to an article "Short Sales Resisted as Foreclosures are Revived" in Monday's New York Times.

The Slow Food International founder and president Carlo Petrini has a very exacting definition of globalization. It's not using Romanian milk to make Italian cheese. His firm retort to anyone who calls that globalization: "tutte balle" (all lies)! His food-focused vision of the much-tossed-around term lies closer to two words interlinked by two symbols: "Food +/= Places." It's the circular notion of terroir, of food being rooted to a specific place, and of that place expressing itself through its food. It's also the theme of the International Salone del Gusto 2010, the eighth edition of Slow Food's biennial celebration of foods from around the world, which opened on Thursday in Turin concurrently with Terra Madre.
Internet campaign aimed at homosexual youths who may be feeling alone, or suicidal.
Today's "Really?" column explores how sleeping position affects heartburn pain. Studies show that sleeping on your left side is best.

The DVR playback ratings for the third week of the television season arrived Monday and provided much good news for seemingly troubled shows like "The Event" and "Parenthood" on NBC and "Fringe" on Fox, while also sending many successful shows up to ratings well into hit territory.

After conducting a years-long study on food risk factors, the United States Food and Drug Administration has recommended that all restaurants provide on-site, trained and certified food protection managers, according to Nation's Restaurant News.

Trying to guess at the lives of straphangers while riding the subway is an age-old pastime. It can even bear fruit, as Dvora Meyers writes in The Times, when such profiling leads to correct guesses about which seats may be vacated at which stops.

He reports, via Twitter, that Cashman will meet with Manager Joe Girardi's agent on Tuesday to discuss a new contract, and that pitching coach Dave Eiland will not return as the Yankees pitching coach. Wow. I guess I lead an intellectually sheltered life. Until I followed a link from Yves Smith, I had been blissfully unaware that the investment airwaves were full of people yelling that Bernanke is debasing the dollar because the dollar has fallen modestly in recent weeks.

The San Francisco Giants have so far proved the old adage that pitching wins in the postseason. Despite finishing ninth in the National League in offense, they squeaked into the tournament on the back of a vaunted starting rotation of Tim Lincecum, Matt Cain, Jonathan Sánchez and Madison Bumgarner, who combined for a 3.19 earned run average in the regular season.

Gnocchi doesn't necessarily mean "little flour-and-potato pasta" but - actually - "dumpling." They can be made with semolina or, in this case, cheese. The version in this week's Minimalist column is light, easy and delicious.

Back in the 1990s fellow science and technology journalist Charles Mann and I wrote a book uncovering the true story of how a lone, young, cognitively impaired hacker with relatively few computer skills managed to perpetrate what was then the most extensive and scariest series of computer break-ins ever -- government weapons labs, dam control systems and ATM networks were among the hundreds of networks compromised. At the end of the book, we predicted that no matter how much effort was poured into making the Internet safer, hackers would always be able to have a field day, partly for technical reasons but also because companies and individuals would never get it together to take simple precautions critical to safe computing.

At the London Design Festival in September, I came upon so many homespun, handmade objects and installations that within hours I was feeling guilty for not having made my own shoes. The prevailing aesthetic wasn't crafty, exactly - and it certainly wasn't decorative - but it was definitely hand-hewn, mostly in wood, with a less-is-more, whittled-down vibe (and I use the word ''whittled'' advisedly).

At last week's "Back to the Mac" presentation, Steve Jobs touted the "green" aspects of Apple's latest iteration of the MacBook Air. I have no doubt that the company is seriously committed to the environment; as Apple notes on its Web site, every one of its products meets or exceeds Energy Star standards.

The bad news for Beastie Boys fans: it looks as though there will be no "Hot Sauce Committee Part 1," the album that this hip-hop trio planned to release in 2009 -- its first since "The Mix-Up," an all-instrumental record from 2007, and the first with any lyrical content since "To the Five Boroughs" in 2004.

The recent Times article "When a Cancer Therapy Puts Others at Risk" describes the unusual problems surrounding radiation therapy for thyroid cancer, which can pose an immediate risk to other people for up to a week.

The first-ever Korean Grand Prix, held on Sunday in damp conditions, will be a memorable one. The Formula One race was delayed by heavy rain. It started behind the safety car for 17 laps and finished just before darkness fell. But perhaps more than any of that, the grand prix will be remembered as the day Fernando Alonso outlasted his rivals to take a lead in the championship, a position thought to be unlikely as recently as a month ago.

Recently I wrote about how people in six Kansas towns had been motivated to cut their energy use through intertown competitions. The residents were largely skeptical about the science behind climate change but were moved to act by values like thrift and patriotism. In some cases towns reduced their energy consumption by as much as 5 percent over a year, considered a giant drop in this field.

Steve Grasse is a Jedi distiller. As a Draper-league ad man and branding expert, he is able to convey an idea with a couple of words or a single image. As a creator of alcoholic potables, he ferments unexpected ingredients with logic-defying success. He can't practice one without the other. When he developed his tattoo-artist-inspired Sailor Jerry line of apparel, he had to include a rum; when William Grant & Sons wanted to produce a premium gin, the company hired Grasse not just to market Hendrick's but to conceptualize the actual drink as well. (The integral cucumber? That has Grasse's prints all over it.) And, when he launched a new lifestyle concept and retail shop in 2008, he had to do a spirit tie-in. First there was Root, and now Snap.

The Greenland ice sheet melted at a rate that was 25 to 50 percent higher this year than normal, according to Danish research scientists; about 500 gigatons of ice are estimated to have melted this summer. Some scientists express caution on the results but acknowledge that melting has indeed been above average. [Denmark.dk]

On the spectrum of "we don't own a television" to "my children can watch whatever they want," I tend toward the more permissive end. Once my sons reached their early teens, I gave in, deciding to view the ubiquitous sexual innuendo and gender stereotyping, among other things, as fodder for conversation and a means of inoculation against the real world. We regularly watched together, the boys and I, with them slightly mortified that their mother was seeing this inappropriate stuff, and me providing running counterpoint wherever possible.

Newspapers across the country broadly reported falling circulation from April through September, though the rate of decline slowed from the alarming pace in the same period last year, according to figures released on Monday by the Audit Bureau of Circulations.

Simon Bairu, 27, will make his marathon debut in New York on Nov. 7. He won the 2005 and '06 N.C.A.A. cross-country titles at Wisconsin and holds the Canadian record for 10,000 meters at 27 minutes 23.63 seconds. He ran 1:02:08 in finishing fifth in the Philadelphia half-marathon in September. Bairu, along with Tim Nelson and Shalane Flanagan, are part of the Web series "Rookies Vs. the World," presented jointly by the New York Road Runners and Kimbia Athletics. New episodes are broadcast every Tuesday and Friday.

It's a few weeks into the arrival of Julia Stiles on "Dexter'' and we have yet to unpack the meaning of her character's name. For this I blame myself: I was too busy with my "Mad Men'' decoder rings. But now that they have been shelved until the debut of the next season, let's take a look at what it might signify that her name is Lumen Ann Pierce. Raped and tortured by a gang of psychos led by Boyd Fowler, of the motivational tapes and roadkill-cleanup work, Lumen appeared in the opening moments of Sunday night's episode doing strange things to raw sugar packets in a diner. Free from Dexter's captivity, she is unhinged.

Donna Wilson has become the Tim Burton of London's knitting circle. Back when the designer was a student at the Royal College of Art, she began crafting dolls out of old ''jumpers,'' the British word for sweaters. The leggy dolls without noses or mouths were picked up by Couverture, a chic lifestyle shop. Today, Wilson's quirky menagerie includes 30-odd creatures, like the charming hybrid Cyril Squirrel-Fox and Puddle Man (essentially a pool of water with a face), all of which are made from knitted lamb's wool in Wilson's East End workshop, not to mention cushions, throws, ottomans, sofas and rugs. Many of these are commissions from and collaborations with SCP, the British home furnishings manufacturer.

Companies that benefited the most from the Troubled Assets Relief Program have given generously to political candidates this fall - in many cases, to Republicans who opposed the bailout, The Washington Post reports.

For the film and theater director Mike Nichols the play changed how he thought about characters. For the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Doug Wright ("I Am My Own Wife") it established a dividing line for gay-themed theater. For other dramatists like Lisa Kron ("Well"), Tarell Alvin McCraney ("The Brother/Sister Plays") and Sarah Ruhl ("In the Next Room, or the vibrator play") it was inspiration. And for academics and artistic directors, it became the last major stage work of the 20th century to wrestle with.

Tell that to the stuffed silk "fox stole" draped across a teak table in the new 1,400-square-foot lifestyle emporium the couple just opened in the city's Silverlake neighborhood with the European midcentury furniture dealer Amsterdam Modern.

Years ago, Terrance Brennan, the chef-owner of Artisanal, and also the chef-owner of Picholine, both in Manhattan, was in Gruyères, Switzerland, and ate his first raclette. The dish is named after a firm cow cheese used in this almost too-simple, but nevertheless hearty, tasty dish of melted cheese on cooked potato slices.

After talks about a deal to potentially merge Newsweek and The Daily Beast fell apart, it was widely put down to a conflict of personalities between Newsweek's new owner, Sidney Harman, Barry Diller, owner The Daily Beast, and Tina Brown, the editor who runs the online news magazine.

As far as style role models go, we'll take Kate Moss over La Gaga any day. Her signature slinky party dresses, leather cigarette pants, downtown tees and fur jackets have become even cooler -- and more accessible -- since Topshop globalized the supermodel's iconic style. So when rumors swirled that the Kate Moss for Topshop winter collection would be her last, sentiments went wild. (At least there is still Pete Doherty's jewelry line.). "When we started the project we didn't have an end in mind but I'm really proud of all 14 collections," says Moss. "I've learned a lot about the design and development process; experiences that I'd only ever seen informally through being a model." That's great, Kate, but what's in it for us? Well, come Tuesday, lots of sequined dresses and hot pants for the rock chick in Kate and, apparently, all of us, too. Other standout pieces include a tweed cape with a faux fur collar and boho vintage-inspired floral day dresses. Moss's personal favorite? "If I had to pick one I'd go for the pansy dress!" Here's an exclusive peek.

Almost everyone who uses the Internet has been stopped at one time or another by a security feature called captcha, the wavy, distorted letters and numbers often found in a pixelated box that users are asked to type to prove they are human and not a piece of technology.

Therapy is out of fashion and almost off the air. Tony isn't discussing his dreams on ''The Sopranos'' anymore. ''Huff,'' a Showtime shrink played by Hank Azaria, is long gone, and ''Head Case,'' a send-up of psychiatry on Starz, was also canceled. HBO shut down ''Tell Me You Love Me'' after one season. All of Toni Collette's multiple personalities in ''United States of Tara'' are on hiatus until next year. Neurotics and sociopaths are still rampant, of course, from a serial killer on ''Dexter'' to a teacher turned drug kingpin on ''Breaking Bad,'' but for the most part television characters carry on without counseling or medication.

CommScope, the telecommunications equipment maker, said Monday that it had been approached by Carlyle Group with an offer to take the company private, confirming an earlier report in DealBook. Under the terms of the deal, which is not yet agreed to, Carlyle would buy all outstanding CommScope common stock for $31.50 a share in cash, in a deal worth about $2.9 billion. With CommScope shares currently at $23.12 in afterhours trading, the bid represents a 36 percent premium. Private equity firms have been racing to spend their billions of dollars in investor capital, aided by the availability of cheap debt to finance their acquisitions.

KANDALL--Geoffrey A.,age 73, of Hamden, CT on October 19, 2010. Survived by his son Michael, daughter-in-law Nobuko Yamazaki, daughter Rena, grandchildren Joshua and Rachel, and brother Stephen. Geoff graduated valedictorian from Far Rockaway High School in 1954 and summa cum laude from Princeton in 1958. After graduate work in math at MIT and in Library Science, he taught for 50 years at colleges in the northeast. Self-taught, he translated Russian math texts into English and submitted puzzles and solutions to many math journals. He loved word games, folk dancing, Klezmer music, and autograph collecting. His intellectual strength was complemented by his unfailing good humor, humility, generosity, and devotion to family and friends. Contributions can be made to Connecticut Hospice in Branford, CT.

The Cowboys may resort to college-style end zone celebrations if they score this week. After back-to-back weeks of penalties for excessive celebrations (which weren't all that excessive), the Cowboys are down to shaking hands in the end zone, lest a fist-bump be construed as taunting. '' If the penalties continue, Jerry Jones will hire some 17th- century Puritans as humility coaches. The penalty flak has obscured some real Cowboys problems: their offensive line has gotten old and injury prone quickly, their secondary gives up too many big plays and their kicking game needs work. It's easy to cite discipline issues when the Cowboys lose, but there are bigger problems in Dallas than who is leaping over whom after touchdowns. Their supertalented roster isn't all that super once you get past DeMarcus Ware and a few others. MIKE TANIER

OVIEDO, Fla. -- The anonymously financed conservative groups that have played such a crucial role this campaign year are starting a carefully coordinated final push to deliver control of Congress to Republicans, shifting money among some 80 House races they are monitoring day by day. Officials involved in the effort over the midterm elections' final week say it is being spearheaded by a core subset of the largest outside conservative groups, which have millions of dollars left to spend on television advertisements, mailings and phone calls for five potentially decisive Senate races, as well as the scores of House races.

Hoping to capitalize on the popularity of social networking, the well-known venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is teaming up with heavyweights of the social Web to create a $250 million fund to invest in social start-ups. The ''sFund'' was announced by John Doerr, a Kleiner veteran, on Thursday at a star-studded press conference at Facebook headquarters in Palo Alto, Calif. The fund includes investments from Amazon, Facebook, the Zynga Gaming Network, Comcast, Liberty Media and Allen & Company, as well as Kleiner and some unnamed individuals. The chief executives of Amazon, Facebook and Zynga -- Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg and Mark Pincus -- all spoke at the event. They declined to say how much each party put into the fund.

While Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive, and Andy Rubin, the vice president of engineering at Google, fire pot shots at one another over their rival cellphone platforms, the wireless carriers are engaging in their own snipefest behind the scenes. Several media outlets, including Engadget, a technology blog, are reporting that Verizon Wireless is preparing to introduce tiered data plans for its smartphone subscribers.

Almost everyone who uses the Internet has been stopped at one time or another by a security feature called captcha, the wavy, distorted letters and numbers often found in a pixelated box that users are asked to type to prove they are human and not a piece of technology. The text can sometimes be hard to decipher, and now some online publishers are getting ready to replace it with a new video advertising product from NuCaptcha, based in Vancouver, British Columbia.

Among Apple's new product announcements on Wednesday, which included updates to the company's Mac OS X operating system and iLife suite, one product probably sent a chill down the spine of a few software companies: the new Mac App Store. The store is a photocopy of the App Store currently used for the iOS platform, which makes it simple for iPad, iPhone and iPod customers to download apps to their devices. An entire transaction can happen in seconds.

SILVERMAN--Claire J.,74, on October 22, 2010. Devoted and loving mother to Leonard and his wife Leah, and "Bubbie" to grandchildren Alden and Spencer. She will be deeply missed.

SOMERS--Jack A.,beloved husband, father and grandfather passed away peacefully at home in Watchung, New Jersey on October 22 at the age of 97. A lifelong resident of New York City, he retired in 1978 after forty years teaching social studies and economics at the High School of Art and Design in Manhattan. For more than twenty years he was the teacher-in- charge of Wadleigh Evening High School in Harlem. He spent a career being "the most popular teacher". He graduated from Stuyvesant High School (1930) and City College (1934). He earned a Master of Science in Education in 1936. Mr. Somers served in the US Army in the European theater during WW II. He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 67 years, Helen R. Somers, who passed away in February 2010. He is survived by his two children, Howard Somers, MD, of Coronado, CA, and Maura Somers Dughi of Watchung, NJ, daughter-in-law, Jean (Somers) and son-in-law Robert Dughi. He is also survived by his five grandchildren, Lisa, Bobby, and Jamie Dughi, and Richard and Daniel Somers. He showed us all how to appreciate life and to love each other. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be sent to Prevent Child Abuse New Jersey, www.preventchildabusenj.org or CASA of New Jersey, www.casaofnj.org.

KAPLAN--Patricia. Passed away on October 22nd. Surrounded by her loving family and friends. She is survived by her parents Irving and Mildred Lev, sister Karen Silverman, and brother-in-law Harvey Silverman. She was a loving Aunt and great-aunt. Patricia was beautiful, talented, artistic. She was a Honors Master Graduate of Brooklyn College. She was an elementary school teacher for 29 years, and she was loved by all of her students. She will be missed by all who knew her. Services Monday October 25th, 9:30am "The Riverside" 180 W 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave, New York City.

STURZ--Elizabeth L. The Board of Directors and staff of Project Renewal mourn the passing of Elizabeth L. Sturz, who dedicated her life to helping New York City's most vulnerable people. STURZ--Elizabeth Lyttleton. The Board of Directors and staff of Argus Community, Inc. mourn the loss of Elizabeth Lyttleton Sturz, the Founder of Argus, its President and its inspiration. Elizabeth was an artist and poet. She created Argus, a multiservice agency in the South Bronx, in 1968 and left an indelible mark. She changed lives, through her creativity, tenacity and concern, and her contributions continue to be felt, every day, as those she taught and inspired carry on her work. We share the grief of her beloved husband Herbert J. Sturz and entire family. Contributions to honor Elizabeth and to further her work can be made to Argus Community, Inc., 760 E. 160th Street, Bronx NY 10456.

9 P.M. (History) AMERICAN RESTORATION When members of the Harrison family of ''Pawn Stars'' want to return something like a rusty Sinclair gas pump or a decrepit Indian motorcycle to its original luster, they call Rick Dale, above, the owner of Rick's Restorations in Las Vegas. Now Mr. Dale is getting his own spinoff with this new series, which shows him and his team transforming seemingly worthless objects into valuable collectibles. Their first projects are a three-wheeled Marketeer golf cart from the 1960s and a Hopalong Cassidy bicycle from the '50s, followed, at 9:30, by a 1940s Hershey's dispenser and a 1950s Kelvinator refrigerator. ''Pawn Stars,'' at 10, finds Rick Harrison dealing in personal tapes from Sammy Davis Jr. and, at 10:30, a collection of fossils found along Mazon Creek in Illinois. 11 A.M. (Fox Business Network) THE WAR ON BUSINESS WEEK Liz MacDonald and Adam Shapiro explore the politics affecting job creation in the United States in this five-day programming block, shown from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. through Friday.

Burton B. Roberts, a celebrated former justice and chief administrative judge of State Supreme Court in the Bronx and a larger-than-life model for an irascible judge in Tom Wolfe's 1987 best-seller, ''The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' died on Sunday. He was 88. He died of respiratory failure at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, where he had lived for the past year, according to a niece, Amy Roberts.

Not long after Oregon State lost at Boise State on Sept. 25, Oregon State Coach Mike Riley chuckled when a reporter asked how the Broncos compared to Texas Christian. Oregon State had opened its season against T.C.U., and Riley joked that he would be hearing the question comparing both teams for the rest of the year. So he dodged it. Wyoming Coach Dave Christensen finds himself in a similar spot. His Cowboys lost to Boise State, 51-6, and to T.C.U., 45-0. He also politely ducked the million-dollar question.
BERNSTEIN--Sol. 11 years. Like the poet, I carry your heart with me (I carry it in my heart) I am never without it. -Barbara

An article in the special Wealth section on Thursday about the rising demand for large, customized private jets misspelled the city in which Flying Colours Corporation, which installs cabin interiors and equipment on aircraft, is based. It is Peterborough, Ontario -- not Petersborough. The error was repeated in a picture caption.

A picture credit in the Personal Tech pages on Thursday with an article about software for stop-motion animation misspelled the photographer's surname in some editions. Adam Buritsch -- not Buritch -- took the picture of one of the animators working on a scene.

An article on Oct. 13 about the eligibility questions surrounding the University of Kentucky basketball recruit Enes Kanter, who played for a professional club in Turkey, referred incorrectly in some editions to a quotation from his father, Dr. Mehmet Kanter, that appeared in The Sporting News. When Dr. Kanter said, ''he is very smart and academic and loves to study,'' he was referring to Enes Kanter's younger brother, Kerem, not to Enes.

Dennis Keene has been learning some new French words lately. The forklift parked in the center aisle of the church where he is the music director is a ''chariot electrique.'' The hoist above the altar is a ''palans electrique.'' And the packing boxes in the back corner of the sanctuary? They hold more than 5,000 ''tuyaux,'' the essential parts for what he described as the city's first French-made pipe organ-''l'orgue a tuyaux.'' ''We've got quite a mess going on,'' he said, leading the way into the sanctuary at the Church of the Ascension, on Fifth Avenue at West 11th Street. (No French on the door: The sign warning that it was a construction site where hard hats were to be warn was in no-nonsense English.)

Cornerback DeAngelo Hall tied an N.F.L. record with four interceptions, including one he returned for a 92-yard score, in the Redskins' 17-14 win. Only three Bears caught more of Jay Cutler's passes. Darren McFadden scored three touchdowns in the first half, and four over all, in the Raiders' 59-14 win over the Broncos. He scored on two 4-yard runs and a 19-yard catch in the first 22 minutes.
An Associated Press report in the N.H.L. Roundup in some copies on Thursday misstated the given name of the Vancouver Canucks' goalie. He is Roberto Luongo, not Patrick.

DEBATES Monday kicks off the last week of debates before Election Day, and there are a lot of matchups to watch. The Democrat Jack Conway and the Republican Rand Paul will meet Monday for their fifth and final debate in the Kentucky Senate race. In the South Carolina governor's contest, Nikki Haley, a Republican state representative, and Vincent Sheheen, a Democratic state senator, face off twice with back-to-back debates. On Tuesday, Gov. Charlie Crist, an independent; Representative Kendrick B. Meek, a Democrat; and Marco Rubio, a Republican; will joust in the Florida Senate race. And the Illinois Senate candidates, Alexi Giannoulias, a Democrat, and Representative Mark Steven Kirk, a Republican, meet for the final time on Wednesday. ON THE TRAIL Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. makes a big final push with events every day. He starts off Monday in Florida (helping Representative Alan Grayson), ends the day in New Hampshire with Ann McLane Kuster, the Democratic Congressional candidate (in what will be Mr. Biden's 100th event for 2010 candidates), and finishes the week in Ohio on Sunday at a rally with President Obama.

MARCUS--Babs, on October 23, 2010. Beloved wife of David and mother of Matthew and Erica. She is also survived by her brother Alan Haber, sister-in-law Lena and her mother Lillian Haber. For all of us who knew her, the world has lost one of the nicest, kindest, generous and loving people that ever lived. She will forever be in our hearts. She taught pre-school for over 30 years with an eight year break to raise her own pre-schoolers. She was universally loved and will be missed by all of her students and those students that were not fortunate enough to have her as their teacher. Funeral services will be held Monday 11:45 at "The Riverside" 76th and Amsterdam. In lieu of flowers, she has asked that donations be made to the Babs Marcus Library Fund at Chelsea Day School 319 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

It was the first handwritten letter I'd received in 5 years. Or maybe 10. Signed by John Wilcock, a man I'd never heard of, and postmarked Ojai, Calif., it was waiting for me when I returned from my São Paulo-to-New York summer trip. Mr. Wilcock wrote that he had been an assistant editor at The Times Travel section back in the 1950s, and had written the first editions of "Mexico on $5 a Day," "Greece on $5 a Day" and "Japan on $5 a Day" for Arthur Frommer in the 1960s.

Money is being raised through outright donations and the sale of prints by Mr. Silva. "We have little doubt he will continue photographing but he will certainly not be able to go to war zones," the Marinoviches said. "We estimate he will not be able to work for about two years." Mr. Silva is at Walter Reed Army Medical Center. The New York Times has told the Pentagon that it will be responsible for his treatment and care, and is assisting his family in other ways. Should the fund collect more money than is needed, the Marinoviches said, what is left will be donated to a charity chosen by Mr. Silva.

Perhaps the biggest perk of being a fashion designer is the ability to design not for yourself but for your kids. Just ask Stella McCartney. Not only is she about to bring her fourth child into the world, she's also about to introduce a new collection specifically for the 12-and-under set. Pieces like cashmere blend pea jackets and floral dresses are designed to be both affordable and timeless, so you don't have to choose between dressing your child well and sending her to college. And the line even features shrunken versions of pieces from her main collection. Still, McCartney knows that as fashion consumers go, kids are as fickle as anyone.

A very long time ago, when I was tall and dashing in my one cheap suit from the Salvation Army, the editor of my first newspaper, the weekly NYPress, sent me north to the wilds of Midtown Manhattan in order to become a regular at the restaurant 44, in the Royalton Hotel, where Geoffrey Zakarian was the chef and the lions of Condé Nast ate antelopes and warthogs. I walked up from downtown, where the newspaper had its offices, and had lunch at 44 every day for a week. I ate the cheapest items on the menu and tipped well, and always made sure to say goodbye to the host on my way out the door. "See you tomorrow," I'd say and then give a little wave, just as if I was an editor at Vanity Fair.

A record 19 giant pandas have been bred in captivity in China this year, bringing the country's captive population to around 300, authorities say. The birth of twin female cubs at the Wolong Panda Reserve in Sichuan province last week broke the record of 18 births set in 2006. The giant panda is highly endangered, with only 1,600 thought to remain in the wild. So far, there have been no successful reintroductions of captive-bred pandas to their native habitat. [Sky News]

As a devout skeptic of both Michael Bloomberg's presidential ambitions and Sarah Palin's putative "front-runner" status in the 2012 Republican campaign, I'm naturally completely unconvinced by John Heilemann's entertainingly bizarre scenario in which Bloomberg runs as an independent in 2012, peels off enough votes and states from Obama to hang the electoral college, and ultimately delivers the White House to Palin. But I'll confine myself to just one objection. To make his scenario work, Heilemann envisions Bloomberg winning states like New Jersey, New York and Connecticut, behind a combination of moderate Republicans, centrist Democrats and "progressives disappointed with Obama." In a vacuum, these might be plausible constituencies for Hizzoner - but not in an election where Sarah Palin is the Republican nominee! How many northeastern progressives (or Lincoln Chafee Republicans, for that matter) would contemplate casting a vote for a third-party candidate knowing that it might deliver the White House to the woman they fear and loathe above all others? Not many, I'd say. Nothing would be guaranteed to rally the Obama coalition quite like the specter of a Palin presidency: For months before the election, the drumbeat that "a vote for Bloomberg is a vote for Palin" would be well-nigh deafening, and I'm pretty sure that even a weakened Obama wouldn't have that much trouble holding serve in that scenario, relegating Bloomberg to exactly the kind of John Anderson-esque performance that would be his most likely fate in any case.

One of the tenets of sabermetric dogma is that there are no clutch players, only clutch events. Or if there are, the effect is so small as to be meaningless. Over the course of many seasons, you'll see that almost all of the players perform as well in clutch situations as in normal situations. A particularly rough stretch for a player is probably just a random bad stretch rather than an innate inability to perform under pressure. After all, could you really make it to the major leagues if you couldn't handle pressure?

Cynics, or perhaps graphic designers, might argue that your average perfume is 99 percent packaging. Maybe more. ''A perfume is an image that you cannot see with your eyes,'' says Mathias Augustyniak, who, as one half of the design firm M/M (Paris), has worked on scent identities for Balenciaga and Narciso Rodriguez. When he and his partner, Michaël Amzalag, approached Ben Gorham of Byredo Parfums with an idea for a fragrance, they were not following their noses. They gave Gorham three inspirations: a block of solid ink they bought in Korea, a photograph of a Japanese friend who is a calligraphy master and an ''oversized absurd formula'' that Augustyniak drew with ink on a piece of handmade Korean paper. ''We spoke about ink with Ben, who is properly inked since he's covered with tattoos, which added a layer of resonance,'' Amzalag says. The result, M/MINK Eau de Parfum, is represented by a sort of smear campaign - artworks made from existing images, by the photographers Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin, that Amzalag and Augustyniak obscured with slicks of thick black ink. What the fragrance smells like is even more ambiguous. The artist Wolfgang Tillmans, a friend of the designers, described it to them as ''very manly,'' while a female friend declared that it reminded her of her grandmother, a comment that left Amzalag wondering if the friend had a manly grandmother. ''To me it feels like a roller coaster ride,'' he says, ''because it keeps changing once it is on your skin.''

''Hella Jongerius - Misfit,'' the title of the Dutch designer's retrospective that opens Nov. 13 at the Museum Boijmans Van Beuningen in Rotterdam, refers not so much to her status in the design world but to the imperfect objects she has long championed. As the exhibition demonstrates, Jongerius has never had trouble finding sympathy for her ideas in the design industry, where companies like Vitra, Ikea and Maharam hired her to introduce beautiful inconsistencies into their sofas, vases and upholstery fabrics. As it turns out, the only people who ever took convincing were the craftspeople themselves. Royal Tichelaar Makkum's artisans cringed when they were told to fire her 1997 B-Set pottery (above) at too high a temperature, while Nymphenburg's worried that her 2004 Sketches plates looked half-finished. ''Craft has a tradition of trying to make perfect things,'' says Louise Schouwenberg, the show's curator. ''Hella told them to stop trying, because industry can do that better, whereas their appeal is more humane.'' Jongerius persisted, and these days, evidence of the hand of the maker seems completely natural. The misfits have become the mainstream.

The Brooklyn-based pianist and bandleader Arturo O'Farrill announced over the weekend that he would appear at the 26th annual Havana International Plaza Jazz festival, Dec. 16-19. Mr. O'Farrill is the son of Chico O'Farrill, the Cuban-born composer and arranger, who died in 2001. The elder O'Farrill, one of the architects of Afro-Cuban jazz, who collaborated with Charlie Parker, Dizzy Gillespie and others in landmark works of the 1950s like "The Afro-Cuban Jazz Suite" and "The Manteca Suite," never managed to returned to his homeland after leaving it in 1960. His son, as leader of his father's old band, the Chico O'Farrill Afro-Cuban Jazz Orchestra, will be playing his father's music, and more, at the Mella Theater in Havana and in the province of Matanzas. He will also lecture at the Amadeo Roldán conservatory and perform at a children's class alongside his sons, Zachary and Adam.

I haven't written at all about HAMP -- the administration's disastrously failed home mortgage modification program, which was supposed to be the modern version of FDR's Home Owners Loan Corporation. My excuse, such as it is, is that I don't presume to know the legal ins and outs well enough to devise an alternative.

Think - but not for too long - about the unusual place that Lea Thompson occupies in the iconography of American cinema, all because of the "Back to the Future" movies. As Lorraine (Baines) McFly (Tannen), she is a symbol of 1950s American wholesomeness and the mother-to-be of the time-traveling Marty McFly (played by Michael J. Fox). She is also the hot-to-trot teenager who spurns lovable George McFly (Crispin Glover) for the boy she doesn't realize is her own offspring. And that's not even counting the four different future incarnations of the role she plays in "Back to the Future"s I and II, as well as her Old West ancestor, Maggie McFly in Part III.

Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly has enjoyed an unusual benefit while entertaining guests at the Harvard Club in Midtown Manhattan, an upscale establishment only open to those who, like Mr. Kelly, hold Harvard degrees. Over the past eight years, some or all of Mr. Kelly's expenses at the club, including dues, drinks and meals, have been paid by the New York City Police Foundation, according to Paul J. Browne, a spokesman for Mr. Kelly. Mr. Browne insisted that the practice was lawful and intended for city business, but that Mr. Kelly may have erred by failing to report the foundation's payments on his financial disclosure forms by the city's Conflict of Interest Board. (Also see The Daily News.)

The St. Regis Hotel is surrounded by high-end retail, set as it is on the corner of Fifth Avenue and 55th Street. Yet in the century since the property opened its doors, it's never had a proper shop. That changed last week with the opening of the Thornwillow at St. Regis, an "invisible store" set up in collaboration with the stationer Thornwillow Press, based in Newburgh, N.Y. Founded 25 years ago by Luke Ives Pontifell (at the tender age of 16), the company uses traditional printing techniques to produce a variety of high-end paper goods, including stationery and invitations.

We won't bury our news: The Rail is back for a limited engagement. It has returned because of Zenyatta, a once-in-a-generation mare -- no, horse -- for anyone who follows thoroughbred racing. She is a perfect 19-0 and is perfect in many other ways that we will examine and argue about over the next couple of weeks.

Either this is hilarious, or we're already jonesing for new episodes of "Mad Men" or possibly both. The clever devils at thepoke.co.uk - the satirical British Web site that previously gave us the "Wire"-inspired Monopoly board - have turned their attention to another popular cable series. They've designed a series of children's books that mashes up "Mr. Men," the adorable, bodyless characters designed by Roger Hargreaves, with "Mad Men," an AMC period drama you may have read a thing or two about. At their site (which we were pointed to by the good people at The Guardian's Media Monkey blog), you'll find covers for books like "Mr. Draper" and "Little Miss Peggy," and a complete story called "Mr. Sterling Gets Angry." Enjoy them now before your mom finds out you have an interior life and moves you to a new city.

When the season starts in August, it just doesn't feel like football. I know it's hard to explain, but I think we all know that football feeling in the air. The first few weeks of the season, it still feels like summer. But now that we're seven weeks in, the air is cooler, the leaves have turned colors, and it just smells and feels like football. Tuesday, Nov. 16, 6:45 p.m. | UpdatedA fund and a Web site, Support Joao Silva Photojournalist, have been set up by Greg and Leonie Marinovich, friends of Mr. Silva, to help him and his family as he goes through rehabilitation. Money is being raised through outright donations and the sale of prints by Mr. Silva. "We have little doubt he will continue photographing but he will certainly not be able to go to war zones," the Marinoviches said. "We estimate he will not be able to work for about two years." Mr. Silva is at Walter Reed Army Medical Center. The New York Times has told the Pentagon that it will be responsible for his treatment and care, and is assisting his family in other ways. Should the fund collect more money than is needed, the Marinoviches said, what is left will be donated to a charity chosen by Mr. Silva.

An obituary on Monday about the lexicographer Sol Steinmetz misidentified the publisher of one of the many books he edited and omitted part of its title. Random House, not McGraw-Hill, published the Random House Webster's College Dictionary, not the Random House Webster's Dictionary. The obituary also misstated the length of Mr. Steinmetz's tenure as executive editor of the dictionary division at Random House. He held that position for about five years, not a decade and a half.

Are Republican candidates in Iowa suddenly in trouble? One week before Election Day, a parade of national Republican figures is descending on the state, appearing alongside former Gov. Terry Branstad as he campaigns to return to his old job.

Veterinarians around the country are reporting a strange phenomenon: spayed dogs and cats, even some puppies and kittens, are suddenly becoming hormonal. In female pets, the symptoms resemble heat: swollen genitals, bloody discharge and behavioral problems. Male animals are showing up with swollen breast tissue and hair loss. Standard treatments and even repeated operations have had no effect.

An art review on Friday about an exhibition of work by Jay Heikes that was at the Marianne Boesky Gallery in Chelsea referred incorrectly to the show. It was Mr. Heikes's second solo gallery show in New York, not his first.

DUANE--Carolyn. It is with great sadness that we announce the death of Carolyn Philbin Duane on October 25, 2010. An extraordinary wife, mother, sister, and friend, Carolyn lived a full life and will be missed by all who knew her. She was the wife of the late Dr. Richard B. Duane, Jr. and is survived by her children; Kitty, Richard, Holly, and Bill, eight grandchildren and her brother, Ewing Philbin. Carolyn's indomitable spirit, grace and humor were with her to the end. Birding, gardening, tennis, travel, and opera, were just a few of her lifelong passions. A memorial service will be held on Friday, October 29, at 11am at The All Saints Memorial Church in Navesink, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to The All Saints Memorial Church or the The Monmouth Conservation Foundation.

CAPILLA PEAK OBSERVATORY, N.M. -- Mandy Weston stood on a ridge in the Manzano mountains, 9,000 feet above the Rio Grande Valley, grasping the talons of a juvenile northern harrier in her right hand. ''These are the supermodels of the raptor world,'' she said admiringly. ''Tall and thin.'' She playfully rotated the bird's body to reveal that its head remained in a fixed position, like that of an owl.

The bad news for Beastie Boys fans: it looks as though there will be no ''Hot Sauce Committee Part 1,'' the album that this hip-hop trio planned to release in 2009 -- its first since ''The Mix-Up,'' an all-instrumental record from 2007, and the first with any lyrical content since ''To the Five Boroughs'' in 2004. The good news: the group said on Monday that it now planned to release an album called ''Hot Sauce Committee Part 2,'' in the spring of next year.

PATRICOLA--Joanne Rose, died suddenly on Thursday, October 21, 2010 in Hudson, FL. She was 68 years old. Born January 4, 1942 she was the beloved daughter of the late Lawrence and Erminia Piscani Patricola and the dear sister of Salvatore. She was also the loving aunt of Larry, Anthony, Carmela and Sal and the beloved friend of Dr. Marion T. DiFiglia. She graduated from St. Nicholas Tolentine High School, Bronx, NY in 1959, receiving a nursing degree from Nassau Community College and completed her post graduate work at Iona College. Her nursing career included the fields of ob-gyn, surgery, medicine and psychiatric nursing. From 1978 to 1981 she served as head of the dialysis program at Our Lady of Mercy Hospital, Bronx, NY. She ended her career as a nurse and manager in private practice with her retirement in 2008. A Funeral Mass will be offered Thursday, 10:30am at St. John the Baptist Church, Yonkers, NY. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. The family will receive visitors on Wednesday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm at F. (Fox) GLEE Not even devious Sue (Jane Lynch) can prevent the choristers (above, Jenna Ushkowitz and Chris Colfer) from performing their own version of ''The Rocky Horror Picture Show'' after Mr. Schuester (Matthew Morrison) learns that Emma (Jayma Mays) is a big fan. Barry Bostwick and Meat Loaf, who appeared in that 1975 cult classic, guest star. In ''Raising Hope,'' at 9, Jimmy (Lucas Neff) gets to act out his superhero fantasies when Sabrina (Shannon Woodward) asks him to stand in for her boyfriend at a Halloween party, and Maw Maw (Cloris Leachman) reveals her inner sex kitten when she goes trick-or-treating with Virginia (Martha Plimpton). Elsewhere, Jimmy ponders whether to unleash some demons and show his daughter the videos he received from the prison where her mother (Bijou Phillips) was executed. 8 P.M. (13, 49) EMERGENCY MINE RESCUE ''Nova'' travels to the San José Mine in Chile to chronicle the 69-day ordeal of the 33 miners as they struggled to survive 95-degree heat, almost total darkness and -- in the first 17 days of their entrapment, before they knew they were being searched for -- growing despair. The report features interviews with the families of some of the miners and footage at Camp Hope, the tent city where they kept vigil. Computer-generated imagery and additional interviews with mining engineers and rescue teams illustrate the race against time to reach the miners' chamber a half-mile below the surface.

PARIS -- The French strikes and demonstrations over a proposed increase in the retirement age have lasted for weeks and attracted wide sympathy in a society whose work force is less than 10 percent unionized. But the proposal will soon become law, setting the stage for confrontations with France's unions, which continue to starve the country of gasoline, diesel and other petroleum products, and are pressing for demonstrations afterward. It will be a treacherous moment for most of the players in French politics, not least of all the unions themselves. The outcome is likely to set the tone for the many similar conflicts that are sure to arise in future years as the government seeks to deal with a budget deficit by scaling back generous social welfare provisions the state can no longer afford.

LUXEMBOURG -- Serbia took a significant step toward membership in the European Union on Monday, despite the union's suspicions that the country could do more to bring Europe's most-wanted war crimes suspect to justice. At a meeting here on Monday, foreign ministers from the 27-nation bloc decided to open Serbia's path to membership, overriding objections from those who want to keep pressure on the government in Belgrade to help arrest Ratko Mladic, a former Bosnian Serb general accused of genocide.

An operation commonly performed to remove brain tumors from the pituitary glands of humans is now available to dogs, thanks to a collaboration between a neurosurgeon and some veterinarians in Los Angeles. And that is turning out to be good for humans. So far, nine dogs and one cat that otherwise would have died have been treated successfully. All had Cushing's disease, a condition in which a tumor in the pituitary gland produces excess amounts of the steroidcortisol, leading to weight gain, muscle atrophy and high blood pressure.

An article on Monday about organizations that are spending money to influence the November elections misidentified one liberal group that recently began an advertising campaign in Colorado against Ken Buck, a Republican seeking to defeat Senator Michael Bennet. It is ''Women's Voices. Women Vote Action Fund,'' not ''Women's Voices Women Vote.'' (The action fund is set up as a legally distinct organization from the group called ''Women's Voices. Women Vote.'' Under tax and campaign finance rules, only the action fund may engage in certain political activities.)

It took Charles E. Phillips Jr., the former co-president of Oracle, all of about six weeks to find a new job. On Monday, Mr. Phillips, who stepped down from his Oracle post last month, will show up as the new chief executive of Infor, a business software maker based in Atlanta. The company's claim to fame, if you can call it that, is owning the largest business software franchise no one has ever heard of. Infor sells about $2 billion worth of software per year, mostly to midsized companies.

The cholera epidemic in Haiti is likely to grow and persist, and will probably reach the Dominican Republic, health officials said on Monday, as they rushed to distribute medical supplies in hopes of keeping ahead of the disease's spread. ''Now that cholera has established itself with a strong foothold in Haiti, it is clear to us that it will not go away for several years,'' said Dr. John Andrus of the Pan American Health Organization at a news briefing Monday in Washington.

WASHINGTON -- A midterm campaign that has turned heavily on the issue of the mounting federal debt is likely to yield a government even more split over what to do about it, people in both parties say, with diminished Democrats and reinforced Republicans confronting internal divisions even as they dig in against the other side. In the weeks after next Tuesday's elections, the White House and a lame-duck Congress will face immediate decisions testing the balance of power -- on extending the Bush-era tax rates, approving overdue spending bills to keep the government operating and, possibly, debating the recommendations that President Obama has directed a bipartisan debt-reduction commission to offer by December.

The still unresolved case of Marc Hauser, the researcher accused by Harvard of scientific misconduct, points to the painful slowness of the government-university procedure for resolving such charges. It also underscores the difficulty of defining error in a field like animal cognition where inconsistent results are common. The case is unusual because Dr. Hauser is such a prominent researcher in his field, and is known to a wider audience through his writings on morality. There seemed little doubt of the seriousness of the case when Harvard announced on Aug. 20 that he had been found solely responsible for eight counts of scientific misconduct.

Newspapers across the country broadly reported falling circulation from April through September, though the rate of decline slowed from the alarming pace in the same period last year, according to figures released on Monday by the Audit Bureau of Circulations. As for the question of which paper can rightfully lay claim to the title of the nation's biggest, The Wall Street Journal and USA Today continued to split hairs over what the numbers say.

Joseph Stein, the Tony Award-winning author of ''Fiddler on the Roof'' and more than a dozen other Broadway musicals, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 98. He died after fracturing his skull in a fall, his son Harry said, adding that his father, an inveterate jokester, had suffered numerous ailments in recent years, including prostate cancer, and used all of them as fodder for humor.

Willie Nelson: Click to ListenHeadCount.org is reaching out to Deadheads and other music fans to make sure they don't forget to visit the polls on Nov. 2. The organization, a nonpartisan group that mixes electoral participation with musical stimulation, has been traveling around the country, rounding up potential voters at more than 600 concerts (played by the Dave Matthews Band, Tom Petty, and The National, to name a few) and asking them to sign a ''Pledge to Vote'' in this year's midterms.

An article on Friday about ''Breaking New Ground: Presenting the George W. Bush Presidential Center,'' an exhibit that opened on Saturday on the campus of Southern Methodist University, referred incorrectly to Mr. Bush's attendance at Texas Rangers baseball games since he left office. He has attended several Rangers games, including opening day last year when he threw out the ceremonial first pitch; he did not wait until the Rangers began their current baseball playoff run to attend games.

There's a moment in a classic Warner Brothers cartoon when Bugs Bunny asks, ''What's all the hubbub, bub?'' Now along comes a campaign that might encourage the wascally wabbit to inquire, ''Where's all the HobNob, Bob?'' The campaign, now under way, is for a line of wines named HobNob. (''Natch,'' as Bugs would say.) The campaign, with a thrifty budget estimated at $200,000, carries the theme ''At the center of it all.''

In a chaotic universe where all empirical stimuli is subjectively interpreted by imperfect observers, who is to say what does or does not happen? Jean-Luc Godard, for one: Mr. Godard, 79, the irascible filmmaker and a pioneer of the French New Wave movement, will definitely not be attending a special Oscars ceremony on Nov. 13 to pick up an honorary Academy Award, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Monday. The question about Mr. Godard's attendance at the Governors Awards has been an open one since the summer, when the academy said it would present honorary Oscars to Mr. Godard, the actor Eli Wallach, the film preservationist Kevin Brownlow and the director Francis Ford Coppola, who is receiving the Irving G. Thalberg Memorial Award.

COLUMBIA--Patricia (Pat), died at her home late Wednesday, 20 October, in Madison, WI while surrounded by her children. Pat had led an active life in New York, Boston and Madison before passing away after a short illness. Born in NYC and raised in the Bronx, she graduated from St. Nicholas of Tolentine High School and secretarial school before beginning her professional career at Catholic Charities of NYC. In 1954 she met Peter L. Columbia, who pre-deceased her in 1983, on a blind date; they married that same year and began their family of ten children. A loving wife and devoted Mother, Pat raised her children while working for nearly thirty years at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, NY as the Executive Secretary to the Department of Anesthesiology. Upon her retirement in 1999, Pat moved to Boston, MA joining eldest son, Stephen, and his family; helping to raise her grandson, Edward. In 2007, following a serve stroke, from which she fully recovered, Pat moved to her home in Madison to join her eldest daughter, Alyce Columbia, and granddaughter, Alix. On 17 July Pat, was surrounded by her entire family of children, their spouses, sixteen grandchildren and two great-grandchildren to celebrate her 85th birthday. In 1986 she was pre-deceased by her loving son, Edward, who died of complications having contracted AIDS. Pat was devoted to her entire family to include the children of her late cousin and soul mate, Joan (Chambers) Maier. She is survived by her aforementioned children as well as Regine Sivan (Avi Sivan), Peter (Monique), Andrew, Brian, Donald (Celia), Patti, David (Linda) and all of their children and grandchildren. Pat was adamant that no flowers memorialize her; rather for those inclined to do so donations could be made in her name to local AIDS education, care and support organizations. Visitation at McGrath Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY 914-337-6770, this Wednesday (6-9:00pm) and Thursday (2-4:00 and 7-9:00pm). Pat's 9:30am funeral mass will be held at St. Nicholas of Tolentine, University Ave., at Fordham Rd., Bronx on this Friday, 29 October. Her burial will be at Ascension Cemetery, Monsey, NY, following a luncheon to celebrate her wonderful life.

Whether you realize it or not, you may be relating to your computer as if it were human. On this week's New York Times Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein chats with Clifford Nass, a Stanford University professor who studies the interaction of people and technology. He has found that the connections we have with computers and other electronic devices are fundamentally social. Professor  Nass's new book, with Corina Yen, is called "The Man Who Lied to His Laptop: What Machines Teach Us About Human Relationships."

Another day, another pop-up store. Fortunately, the latest shopkeepers to hang out a temporary shingle are Elizabeth Beer and Brian Janusiak, the married duo behind the eclectic boutique Project No. 8. Says Beer of the company's latest venture, a 100-square-foot former gallery in TriBeCa: "We heard about this space on Duane Street, which has always been one of our favorite blocks in the city, and thought it would allow us to do a series of mini-shows featuring several designers at a time." In addition to Kostas Murkudis, the Berlin-trained designer who hosted an intimate presentation at the unopened store during New York Fashion Week, the location will feature a constantly rotating selection from labels like Natalia Brilli, Boudicca and Christian Wijnants, as well as pieces from the house label, Various Projects. The TriBeCa space will be open through Valentine's Day 2011, and Beer and Janusiak are opening another pop-up store in Paris next month.

In yet another East-meets-West mash-up, the California-based K-Swiss has created a capsule collection with Brendon Babenzien, the creative director of the downtown skate shop Supreme. The first output from the collaboration, California Tennis, a limited-edition line of T-shirts, polos and perfectly worn-in collegiate sweatshirts, pays homage to 1970s courtside style. Inspired by "Tennis Girl," the saucy Martin Elliott poster image, the tops in the collection have a bicoastal ease to them and are as appropriate with a pair of swim trunks as they are with skinny black jeans. The pieces are available starting Nov. 1 on beams.co.jp, with prices ranging from about $75 for a T-shirt screen-printed with the Elliott image to about $270 for a windbreaker. It is no secret that I possess a deep love for deep-fried food. The carrot and zucchini fritter recipe that I wrote about will work beautifully for any kind of vegetable: onions, sweet potatoes, shredded winter squash and pretty much anything so long as it's cut up into little pieces for uniform frying. In fact, fritters are a great way to use up the bounty of seasonal vegetables you may be getting in your C.S.A. box (broccoli, broccoli, broccoli; turnips, turnips, turnips). Fritters demand to be dipped, says I, but you can also use them as a base for a thick spread of hummus, baba ganoush or chutney. And, when the temperature starts dropping, I love them on a plate with beef stew ladled on top.

The 1980s were a time of general excess, especially in fashion. But the emergence of a band of Belgian designers dedicated to a radically deconstructed vision of dress signaled a mucking out its Augean stables. Out with pouf skirts, in with sweaters made of old socks! Abetting this brave new look were the makeup artist Inge Grognard and her photographer husband, Ronald Stoops. Working on magazine shoots and runway shows for Dries Van Noten, Dirk Bikkembergs, Walter Van Beirendonck, Dirk Van Saene and perhaps most famously, Martin Margiela, the couple created some of the most arresting images of the '90s. The couple's long-awaited first book, "Inge Grognard Ronald Stoops (Ludion)," out at the end of the month, gathers their favorite images in one coffee-table-ready volume. The Moment recently caught up with Grognard via phone from her home in Antwerp - Stoops and the designer An Vandervorst could be heard chatting in the background - to talk about how fashion has changed since the '80s, her definition of beauty and the problem with red lipstick.

As a set designer, Gary Card is used to pouring his creativity into a wildly elaborate mise-en-scène, only to see the whole thing dismantled or destroyed once the project is finished. So when the creative director John Skelton and his partner, Dan Mitchell, approached him to design the interiors of LN-CC, a new concept store (think meticulously curated avant-garde fashion, rare books and vintage vinyl) in the scrappy east London neighborhood of Dalston, Card jumped at the chance to create something permanent. He used his surrealist sensibility to transform the space, a former boxing gym, into a hipster fun house. To enter the store, visitors navigate Card's ''deconstructed forest,'' only to find themselves in the belly of a beast - a wooden tunnel that resembles a crudely assembled whale skeleton. The rest of the 6,000-square foot-space is divided into individual rooms, like a gallery hung with mannequins (above) and a library lined with asymmetrical shelving. ''Every room needed a distinct atmosphere, tone and temperature,'' Card says. ''The idea was to move from organic to industrial, from warm to cold. And always keep it open to change.'' The main attraction is the private club space, with its sound system by the legendary sound guru Mickey Boyle. For Card's sake, we hope the parties don't get too out of hand.

LOS ANGELES - It's official: James Cameron is going back to Pandora not just for his next film, but also for his next two. Mr. Cameron, the filmmaker behind the 3-D blockbuster "Avatar," joined 20th Century Fox in announcing that he would make "Avatar 2" and "Avatar 3" as his next two movies, with the first of the sequels scheduled for release in December 2014, and the second for December of the following year. That assures a lot of fantasy-filled Decembers, as Peter Jackson has already scheduled a pair of "Hobbit" films for Warner Brothers and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in that month in the years 2012 and 2013. "Avatar" was released on Dec. 18 of last year and became the highest-grossing film in history, with almost $2.8 billion in worldwide ticket sales. Mr. Cameron and the top Fox film executives, Jim Gianopulos and Tom Rothman, jointly said they aimed to begin production next year on the first sequel. The film is not yet officially titled, they said.

My discussion of the newsroom "tyrannies" that impede effective media coverage of human-driven climate change elicited a provocative response from Randy Olson, the marine biologist turned filmmaker and communication coach for scientists. I've long described what I call tyrannies in talks to journalists and students -- including the tyrannies of (limited) time and space, balance, the lure of the "front-page thought" and conflict, the need need for a "news peg" (a reason for a story to run today, not next month, next year or never).

From VentureBeat:

One of the keys to making money is to keep your costs down. Sometimes, in the effort to save money, a company can be the victim of unintended consequences. You "save" some money by putting off machine maintenance, and a machine breaks down and stops production. You "save" some money by changing insurance companies, and you find out after you make a claim why the new company is cheaper. You "save" money by not doing safety training in your factory, and someone gets hurt doing something the wrong way.

In the late 1940s, the steroid cortisone, an anti-inflammatory drug, was first synthesized and hailed as a landmark. It soon became a safe, reliable means to treat the pain and inflammation associated with sports injuries (as well as other conditions). Cortisone shots became one of the preferred treatments for overuse injuries of tendons, like tennis elbow or an aching Achilles, which had been notoriously resistant to treatment. The shots were quite effective, providing rapid relief of pain.

GRAU--George H. of Manhattan died October 24, 2010 at the age of 87 of complications related to Parkinson's Disease. Mr. Grau had a passion for classical music, which he learned to play on an upright piano in the living room of his family's Toledo, OH home. He briefly attended the Curtis Institute and assisted in the orchestration of classical compositions. When he first arrived in New York he was a popular pianist, providing entertainment at private parties. Later he worked for RCA Red Seal Records, where he was in charge of relations with recording artists in genres from classical to hard rock. He married Mme. Jacqueline Schweitzer, a concert pianist, in Paris in 1971. They lived in New York. Preceding him in death were his parents, Fred and Genetta Grau and a younger brother, Fred Jr., all of Toledo. He is survived by his wife, Jacqueline, his twin brother Charles, also of New York, and brothers John and James of California. A funeral Mass will be said at 10am on Friday, October 29, at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, 152 West 71st St., with interment to follow at Trinity Church Cemetery. Services were made by Redden's Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in Mr. Grau's memory to: onestopseniorservices.org or the Church of the Blessed Sacrament.

Desmond Tutu, the former Anglican archbishop of Cape Town, has urged an opera company there not to perform in Israel, invoking South Africa's long struggle against apartheid in criticizing Israel's policy toward Palestinians, The Associated Press reported. The Cape Town Opera is scheduled to perform ''Porgy and Bess'' at the Tel Aviv Opera House beginning on Nov. 12. But Archbishop Tutu, a winner of the Nobel Peace Prize who retired from his official duties earlier this month, said in a statement that the tour should be postponed ''until both Israeli and Palestinian opera lovers of the region have equal opportunity and unfettered access to attend performances.'' ''Just as we said during apartheid that it was inappropriate for international artists to perform in South Africa in a society founded on discriminatory laws and racial exclusivity, so it would be wrong for Cape Town Opera to perform in Israel,'' Archbishop Tutu said in his statement. He added that it would be ''unconscionable'' for the opera company to perform ''Porgy and Bess,'' which he said has a ''universal message of nondiscrimination.''
