Tennessee's attorney general has proposed that Fisk University consider new alternatives to selling an ownership stake in its Stieglitz Art Collection to the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Ark. The artist Georgia O'Keeffe established a no-sale restriction when she donated the collection to the university about 50 years ago. In two briefs filed Friday, the attorney general, Robert E. Cooper Jr., told the Nashville chancery court of ''a new development'' in which a Fisk alumna, Carol Creswell Betsch, has established a fund within the Community Foundation of Middle Tennessee. The fund would pay the annual costs of displaying and maintaining the collection on Fisk's campus, he said. Mr. Cooper also suggested the Tennessee State Museum as a potential site to display the collection. The collection includes 101 pieces amassed by O'Keeffe's husband, the photographer Alfred Stieglitz, including works by the couple and pieces by Picasso, Cezanne and Renoir.

O'LEARY--Denis J.,M.D., 86 in Rye, NY, formerly of Rancho Bernardo, CA and Scarsdale, NY. Beloved husband of Audrey (Ryan), father of Michael, Brian, Denis and Kevin and grandfather to ten. Born Cork, Ireland and medical graduate of University College, Cork. He was an influential and recognized authority in occupational and preventive medicine. Captain in the US Army, Korean War. Retired 1987, Senior Vice President, New York Life Insurance Co. in charge of employees health. Senior attending physician, Chest Service, Bellevue Hospital. Assistant clinical professor at NYU. Past president: American Lung Association; Alcoholism Council of New York; Occupational Medical Association New York. Fellow American College Chest Physicians, American Public Health Association, and Occupational Medical Association. An eternally optimistic golfer and enthusiastic Irish bass, his voice, love and intellect will be sorely missed. A private family service will be held.

An article on Tuesday about a program to monitor migrating birds of prey misstated the elevation of the Capilla Peak Observatory in the Manzano Mountains of New Mexico. It is about 9,000 feet above sea level -- not 9,000 feet above the Rio Grande Valley.

An unusually strong jet stream from the Pacific Northwest propelled a stormthrough the nation's midsection Tuesday, downing power lines in five states andforcing the cancellation of hundreds of flights at Chicago airports. Sustainedwinds of 35 to 40 miles an hour swept from the Dakotas to the eastern GreatLakes, and tornadoes were spotted in Racine County, Wis., and Peotone, Ill.Above, the storm moved through Manteno, Ill., six miles south of Peotone.

When Warren E. Buffett announced on Monday that Todd Combs had been chosen as the heir apparent to manage the investments at his company, Berkshire Hathaway, the reaction was: Todd who? Mr. Shields was hardly alone.

An obituary on Tuesday about Constance Reid, the author of several biographies of major mathematicians, referred incorrectly to her first published book and to an article she wrote for Scientific American. The book, ''Slacks and Calluses: Our Summer in a Bomber Factory,'' was illustrated, not co-written, by Clara Marie Allen. The article was about work done by Mrs. Reid's brother-in-law, the mathematician Raphael Robinson, not by Mr. Robinson and his wife, Julia, and it was written after Mrs. Reid had left her job at San Diego High School, not while she was teaching there.

An answer in the Q&A column on Oct. 19 about the hazards of hail misstated the year that a hailstorm in India caused 246 deaths. It was 1888, not 1988.

Two weeks ago, reams of the Dalton School's student newspaper, The Daltonian, were delivered in bulk to the private school's doors on the Upper East Side. But few, if any, of those copies ever made it into homerooms or many students' hands. School officials decided to confiscate the shipment, concerned with what they said was a misrepresentation of facts in a poll splashed across the cover that revealed the student body's level of alcohol consumption. Last November, after Justice Anthony M. Kennedy of the Supreme Court, who is a venerated defender of free speech, lectured at the school, his offices required that they vet an article about his visit before it was published in The Daltonian. In an article in The New York Times, Ellen Stein, who is the head of school, supported what school officials said was the wish of the justice's office to make sure he was quoted correctly.

A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about the scientific-misconduct case against the Harvard researcher Marc Hauser misidentified a species of primates in his lab. They are cotton-top tamarins, not rhesus monkeys.

Paging Hugh Jackman! One year after an abundance of big-name stars led to an unusually profitable fall season, Broadway has returned to Earth with a more even mix of shows stocked with celebrities and those stocked with theater-trained actors who are less reliable box-office draws. Among these, several were struggling financially last week, with the new musical ''Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson'' and the revival of the play ''La Bete'' trying to build audiences after mixed reviews from the critics.

LIMOGES, France -- While the French may be renowned for their refined culinary tastes, they have another side. It was on full display last week in this city in central France known for its expensive porcelain but with another side of its own. Limoges is also a city of butchers, and their annual festival, La Frairie des Petits Ventres, or The Brotherhood of Small Bellies, is a celebration of what Christine Travers delicately terms ''products that we could never find in supermarkets.''

Joe Miller, the Republican Senate candidate from Alaska, was disciplined for using three co-workers' computers for political purposes and initially lying about it when he worked as a part-time lawyer for the Fairbanks North Star Borough in 2008, personnel records released on Tuesday under a court order showed. ''He maintained the whole time that he did not violate the computer use policy and that actually all of us did for not securing our computers,'' Jill Dolan, a lawyer for the borough and one of the colleagues whose computers was used, said in a written statement on March 13, 2008, the day after the incidents.

DORMER--Robert Thomas, 91, of Palm Harbor, Florida died on October 25, 2010 after a short illness. Before moving to Florida in 1994, he was a resident of Bayside, NY for more than 40 years. He was raised in Manhattan where he was born November 20, 1918, the son of Nicholas and Agnes Dormer. He was President of the New State Job Development Authority from 1979 until his retirement in 1991. Prior to that he served as Executive Vice President of the New York State Urban Corporation. In 1991 the New York State Economic Development Council renamed its Economic Developer of the Year Award as the Robert T. Dormer Economic Developer of the Year Award. In 1994 he was named an Honorary Life Member of the American Economic Development Council "in recognition of long and distinguished service in furthering the profession of economic development and the aims of the Council." Survivors include four children, sons Robert (Bonnie), Ronald (Nancy Nason), Daniel (Janet), a daughter, Diane, and six grandchildren. He was predeceased by his spouses, Mary Catherine McLaughlin Dormer and Gunnel Jerrebo Dormer and his brother, Nicholas. He was a graduate of New York University. During World War II he served in the US Navy with the 114th Construction Battalion (Seabees) in France from July to December 1944 and later in the South Pacific and finally in Japan in September 1945. Burial will be at the Long Island National Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island, on November 2, 2010 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to Disabled American Veterans, P.O. Box 145477, Cincinnati, OH 45250-5447

Neal Boenzi was the Fred Astaire of photojournalism, a classy master of his craft who always made it look easy. An extraordinarily patient photographer, he also had an uncanny gift for anticipating possibilities. On July 18, 1962, while at lunch at his favorite Times Square chophouse, Mr. Boenzi was interrupted by a call to head to a warehouse fire in the Bronx on East 137th Street. He was on a nearby rooftop when the warehouse wall began collapsing. Everyone ran, including his competition. Mr. Boenzi stayed and captured the moment. I asked him about that, and thinking back to his lunch, he said, ''It must have been the martini.'' Mitchel Houses, in the background of this photo, was later built on the site. Earlier photographs in the series are at nytimes.com/lens.

A music review on Tuesday about the Cuban pianist Chucho Valdés, who was performing in New York for the first time since 2003, and his quartet referred incompletely to his visits to the United States. While they require permission from the Cuban government, United States policies and visa regulations are also factors. A picture caption with the review misidentified the location of the site of the concert, the Allen Room. It is part of the Jazz at Lincoln Center complex in the Time Warner Center; it is not at Lincoln Center itself. And schedule information with the review misstated the format of Mr. Valdés's appearance at the Village Vanguard scheduled for Monday night. He will lead a trio, not perform a solo piano concert.

Because of an editing error, the Memo From Paris article on Tuesday, about the political risks faced by French labor unions in organizing the strikes against a proposed increase in the retirement age, misstated the estimated economic cost of the protests. French officials have said it is as high as $560 million in lost production for each of the eight days of national strikes so far, totaling nearly $4.5 billion -- not ''$557 million to date.''

5:59 p.m. | Updated With tensions running high in the Kentucky Senate race, a volunteer for Rand Paul, the Republican candidate, assaulted a liberal activist in Lexington Monday night, stomping his foot on her neck and shoulder. The incident was captured by numerous video cameras and quickly went viral on the Internet. Lexington police received numerous calls reporting the volunteer's identity and by midday Tuesday had delivered a criminal summons to Tim Profitt, a Bourbon County volunteer for Mr. Paul. He was ordered to appear before a Fayette County District Court judge and police said he would be charged with assault. The campaign dismissed Mr. Profitt and barred him from ''any further association with our campaign.'' The episode occurred just before Mr. Paul was to debate his Democratic rival, Jack Conway. A liberal activist, Lauren Valle, 23, a volunteer for MoveOn.org, approached Mr. Paul -- some say she ''lunged'' at him -- to give him a mock award. At that point, some men wrestled her to the ground and one appeared to grind his foot into her shoulder and neck. Another admonished him, saying, ''No, no, no. Come on,'' at which point the man stopped.

COLUMBIA--Patricia (Pat), died at her home late Wednesday, 20 October, in Madison, WI while surrounded by her children. Pat had led an active life in New York, Boston and Madison before passing away after a short illness. Born in NYC and raised in the Bronx, she graduated from St. Nicholas of Tolentine High School and secretarial school before beginning her professional career at Catholic Charities of NYC. In 1954 she met Peter L. Columbia, who pre-deceased her in 1983, on a blind date; they married that same year and began their family of ten children. A loving wife and devoted Mother, Pat raised her children while working for nearly thirty years at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, NY as the Executive Secretary to the Department of Anesthesiology. Upon her retirement in 1999, Pat moved to Boston, MA joining eldest son, Stephen, and his family; helping to raise her grandson, Edward. In 2007, following a serve stroke, from which she fully recovered, Pat moved to her home in Madison to join her eldest daughter, Alyce Columbia, and granddaughter, Alix. On 17 July Pat, was surrounded by her entire family of children, their spouses, sixteen grandchildren and two great-grandchildren to celebrate her 85th birthday. In 1986 she was pre-deceased by her loving son, Edward, who died of complications having contracted AIDS. Pat was devoted to her entire family to include the children of her late cousin and soul mate, Joan (Chambers) Maier. She is survived by her aforementioned children as well as Regine Sivan (Avi Sivan), Peter (Monique), Andrew, Brian, Donald (Celia), Patti, David (Linda) and all of their children and grandchildren. Pat was adamant that no flowers memorialize her; rather for those inclined to do so donations could be made in her name to local AIDS education, care and support organizations. Visitation at McGrath Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY 914-337-6770, this Wednesday (6-9:00pm) and Thursday (2-4:00 and 7-9:00pm). Pat's 9:30am funeral mass will be held at St. Nicholas of Tolentine, University Ave., at Fordham Rd., Bronx on this Friday, 29 October. Her burial will be at Ascension Cemetery, Monsey, NY, following a luncheon to celebrate her wonderful life.

To most people, the word "war" is likely to conjure dramatic images of combat. Soldiers ducking for cover. Helicopters swooping low. Medics treating the critically wounded. But for deployed troops, life at war is also filled with many quieter moments. Mundane, perhaps; but those moments may carry powerful memories, bitter and fond. They may evoke a vivid sense of place. They may even define a deployment in some intensely personal way.

A tipping-point state was one that might potentially put Barack Obama (or John McCain) over the top to his 270th electoral vote, thereby winning him the presidency. Undeterred by travel warnings and frightening headlines about safety in Mexico, an increasing number of international tourists are flying to the country, according to the Mexico Tourism Board. The number of international tourists who flew to Mexico from January to August increased 19 percent over the same period last year, according to the board, and most were from the United States. More than four million American citizens flew to Mexico, an increase of 15 percent over the same period last year, and about 61 percent of international tourists to Mexico are Americans.

With "Balenciaga: Spanish Master" opening in mid-November at the Queen Sofia Spanish Institute in Manhattan, a new edition of Diana Vreeland's "Allure" seems strangely well-timed. The first edition appeared in 1980, when Vreeland was special consultant to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where she organized costume shows of Balenciaga and Yves Saint Laurent, among other legends. She worked on "Allure" with Christopher Hemphill, a process that took three years as Vreeland sought the elusive quality of personality in images of celebrities and models, in their gestures and sometimes violent expressions - a special condition for pictures of Maria Callas - and Mr. Hemphill did his best to oblige her. He recorded their conversations as they went along.

The fledgling men's-wear label Tuesday Night Band Practice was born out of harmonic convergence. The founding foursome - Robin Graves and Mark Murder, who are from Britain, and Ben Bones and Dan Danger, who hail from Australia - first met up in Bali over weekly jam sessions and started turning out illustration-heavy, verse-inflected T-shirts. (Graves is an illustrator by trade with a penchant for songwriting.) But as they soon discovered, making music is one thing and making clothes is another entirely. Bones and Danger splintered off. "It's a similar situation with bands," Graves said. "People have certain directions and visions, and mine and Mark's are both coming from U.K. We're very art-directioned, and when you've got your ideas, you can work quite rapidly and leave other people behind."

Tonight, at Other Music, the ever-brooding Stephin Merritt will be manning the turntables for the opening of "All Our Friends Are In New York," a photo exhibit of which he and his band, the Magnetic Fields, are the principal subjects. About the night's musical program, Merritt told The Moment, "I suppose I'll be playing the bubblegum and psychedelic music that I generally play. Maybe with an Octoberish slant - if I show up and there are skeletons hanging over the place." The exhibit itself, which is on view through Nov. 14, is tied to the release of "Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt and the Magnetic Fields," a documentary, 10 years in the making, which Mike Hale reviewed this week in the New York Times. The exhibit features candid photos of the band, including one of Merritt taking a smoke break on the fire escape at Spin Magazine, where he once moonlighted as a proofreader. Asked what he thinks of music journalists today - he's a critical darling who in 2006 was the butt of some very bad press - Merritt said: "I think that working for a magazine is the highest possible calling and that all rock journalists are saints that are governing the country." Yes, Merritt can be sharply sarcastic, and also blunt, as in his appraisal of the documentary itself: "It's boring - it's just me and my friends, talking about me."

Hermès is more synonymous with horse riding than with motorcycling. He wrapped a piece of white lace around the colossal head of Gran Brigitte, a Haitian voodoo spirit of the dead. When she is complete, the papier-mâché Brigitte will stand 18 feet tall. The sign on the marquee at the Stephen Sondheim Theater may read "The Pee-wee Herman Show," but the man at the center of it, and behind more than 30 years of fascination with that antic, perpetually adolescent character, is the actor and comedian Paul Reubens. The popularity of Pee-wee Herman, at the Groundlings and in his original stage show, led Mr. Reubens to portray him in hit movies like "Pee-wee's Big Adventure," and on a Saturday morning television series, "Pee-wee's Playhouse." Two sex scandals could have cost Mr. Reubens his career, or made it unthinkable that he could plausibly portray the childlike Pee-wee -- instead, he successfully revived "The Pee-wee Herman Show" earlier this year in Los Angeles and is now about to open it on Broadway.

The Yankees acted quickly to retain Manager Joe Girardi, rewarding him with a three-year, $9 million contract. The framework of the deal is in place, but because the Yankees did not want to make the announcement on the day of a World Series game, the new deal will not be announced until Friday. Girardi's three-year, $7.8 million contract is set to expire on Sunday, but there was little doubt that he would return. General Manager Brian Cashman, minutes after the Yankees' season ended last Friday night in Texas, said he absolutely expected Girardi to come back, a sentiment echoed Monday at their post-mortem news conferences at Yankee Stadium.

Broadway or death. The reigning wisdom of theater producers these days is that if a play is ever going to grow up - that is, be taken seriously, receive lots of attention and, above all, make money - it can do so only on Broadway. I know that there are incontrovertible economic reasons for this theory. (Off-Broadway shows are highly unlikely ever to turn a profit.) And I suppose that as a New York theater lover, I should be grateful that the neon imprimatur of Broadway still holds a hypnotic glamor for people around the world.

When I tell stories about Iraq, the ones people react to are always the stories of violence. This is strange for me. As a public affairs officer in 2007 and 2008, I never saw combat, only its aftermath. I saw women and children wounded or dying in trauma centers. Ruins left by explosives in towns and cities across Anbar province. I saw surgeons who could do no more because the body they were trying to repair was too badly destroyed. I stood in formations as the bodies were taken away.

This morning I made coffee with an AeroPress, a device that reminds me of a horse syringe without the needle. At its most basic, it works like a French press crossed with a Melitta filter: you put coffee grounds and hot water in one plastic cylinder, then plunge it into a cup or kettle with the other. It's inexpensive (about $30), easy to use and even if it has no mechanical charisma - it looks like it was pieced together with parts from a Habitrail set - it's actually a carefully engineered tool that addresses some of the more obsessive issues concerning extraction, grind and temperature.

Even hipsters have to grow up - or, in this case, move farther downtown. A fixture on Ludlow Street since 1992, TG170, Terri Gillis's quirky-cool clothing store, has moved down the street into more streamlined digs designed by the architect Philip Otto. More Chelsea gallery than boho hangout, the store remains true to its curatorial spirit, with artwork by Rich Jacobs and Mike Mills interspersed with Gillis's collection of concrete garden animals, and signage by the graphic designer Chris Rubino. On the racks: indie labels like Corell & Corell, Hazel Brown, Mociun and Hengst.TG170, at 77 Ludlow Street; (212) 995-8660, or tg170.com.

The artist Anna Sew Hoy most often works with fabric and clay, materials usually associated with craft and handiwork, and yet the sculptures she makes are more tough than homespun. Sew Hoy began working with clay in a figure sculpting class in high school, long before she knew she wanted to be an artist, and she is interested in exploring, and playing with, its material properties. She builds her pieces from solid blocks of clay that she takes great pleasure in slapping and smacking to create the off-kilter shapes she prefers. Faceted orbs, large looped pieces that she calls buckles and textured ceramic pieces with holes that recall a hair-covered face with only the eyes showing (think Cousin Itt from the Addams Family) are some of the forms she's been working with recently.

British Columbia's Fraser River has seen a record run of sockeye salmon as an estimated 34 million fish have returned to the river this year, far above last year's total of 1.5 million. One hypothesis is that the increase may be linked to the eruption of Alaska's Kasatochi volcano in 2008; ash from the volcano may have created a massive algae bloom in Pacific waters where adolescent salmon reside, creating a veritable fish food buffet. If the connection is valid, this year's record spawn may only be a one-off event, however, scientists said. [The Globe and Mail]

One of the grand things about beets and some other root vegetables is that they lend themselves to a meatless version of everything-but-the-oink eating. It frustrates me to see people asking the market vendor to hack off the greens when they buy a bunch of beets: now, in the latter part of the season, the substantial leafy tops can provide as much to eat as a bunch of, say, Swiss chard, which is a form of beet.

Two top asset managers, Bill Gross, the co-founder of Pacific Investment Management Company, and Jeremy Grantham, the chief investment strategist at Grantham Mayo Van Otterloo & Company, have lambasted the Federal Reserve, with Mr. Grantham calling its loose monetary policy "ruinous," and Mr. Gross labeling its renewed asset purchases "somewhat of a Ponzi scheme," Reuters reported.

Friday night was crowded. Chef Joe was dismayed. Guests were opting for the comfort food. Not that his clam chowder or chicken with salsa verde or pasta with clams are anything like comfort food -- one woman complained that the salad, with goat's milk blue cheese dressing, was so fresh that the crunching sound in her head gave her a headache -- it's just that Chef Joe was considering the possibility that the naysayers and doubters had been correct: Southfork Kitchen might have to stick to the basics and let the big city boys play with esoteric embellishments and international condiments.

The more immediate question posed by President Obama's appearance on "The Daily Show With Jon Stewart" on Wednesday is whether a political satirist loses credibility when hobnobbing with a sitting president.

Not long after Sam Zell, the real estate mogul, took over the Tribune Company, he installed a sculpture in the headquarters  lobby titled "Bureaucratic Shuffle," a six-legged man going in circles and nowhere fast. But what was intended as a commentary on the existing culture at Tribune Towers came to be seen as a metaphor for the new management after the company tipped over into bankruptcy and a new, non-linear approach to management failed to gain traction.

The average cost of tuition and fees for four-year, public universities, many of them grappling with budget cuts, rose almost 8 percent this year, to $7,605, according to my colleague Tamar Lewin's reading of the College Board's annual Trends in College Pricing report. When room and board are factored in, Ms. Lewin writes of the just-released report, the average in-state student at a public university will pay $16,140 this year.

STURZ--Elizabeth Lyttleton. The Board of Directors and staff of Argus Community, Inc. mourn the loss of Elizabeth Lyttleton Sturz, the Founder of Argus, its President and its inspiration. Elizabeth was an artist and poet. She created Argus, a multiservice agency in the South Bronx, in 1968 and left an indelible mark. She changed lives, through her creativity, tenacity and concern, and her contributions continue to be felt, every day, as those she taught and inspired carry on her work. We share the grief of her beloved husband Herbert J. Sturz and entire family. Contributions to honor Elizabeth and to further her work can be made to Argus Community, Inc., 760 E. 160th Street, Bronx NY 10456.

It has been a big fall for country music with new releases by Toby Keith, Kenny Chesney and Zac Brown Band topping the Billboard album chart. That trend continues this week, with Sugarland beating Kings of Leon for No. 1. Sugarland, the country-pop duo whose lead singer, Jennifer Nettles, has recorded with Bon Jovi, is No. 1 with 203,000 sales of ''The Incredible Machine'' (Mercury Nashville), according to Nielsen SoundScan. Kings of Leon was close behind with 184,000 sales of its latest, ''Come Around Sundown'' (RCA). In a week busy with high-charting new releases ''The Union'' (Decca), Elton John's collaboration with his hero Leon Russell, opened at No. 3 with 80,000 sales; ''Fly Me to the Moon'' (J), the fifth installment in Rod Stewart's ''Great American Songbook'' series, landed in fourth place with 79,000; the latest ''Glee'' soundtrack, ''The Rocky Horror Glee Show'' (Columbia), opened at No. 6 with 48,000; and Shakira 's new Spanish-language album, ''Sale el Sol'' (Epic), bowed at No. 7 with 46,000.
BARON--Howard, MD. To our courageous brother-in-law and special Uncle Howie to our kids. We'll miss you. Our love and thoughts are with Joan and all the family. Arlene and Bob Fischer

An article on Tuesday about the spread of cholera in Haiti misspelled the given name of a Pan American Health Organization official who described the epidemic at a press briefing in Washington. He is Dr. Jon Andrus, not John.

An article on Oct. 14 about New York Comic Con, a convention for fans of comic books, film animation and video games, referred incorrectly to the character portrayed by Melanie Farnsworth. She was dressed as England, from the comic, anime series and video game ''Hetalia: Axis Powers'' -- not as Hetalia, which is the title, not a character.

At last week's ''Back to the Mac'' presentation, Steve Jobs touted the ''green'' aspects of Apple's latest iteration of the MacBook Air. I have no doubt that the company is seriously committed to the environment; as Apple notes on its Web site, every one of its products meets or exceeds Energy Star standards. But one of its products needs some work in the green department: MobileMe. The software that keeps the contacts and calendars stored on your computers, iPad, and iPhone in sync comes in a cute cardboard box. Actually, the software doesn't come in the box; you download that directly from the Apple Web site. What actually comes in the box is...virtually nothing.

LOS ANGELES - It's official: James Cameron is going back to Pandora not just for his next film, but also for his next two. Mr. Cameron, the filmmaker behind the 3-D blockbuster ''Avatar,'' joined 20th Century Fox in announcing that he would make ''Avatar 2'' and ''Avatar 3'' as his next two movies, with the first of the sequels scheduled for release in December 2014, and the second for December of the following year. That assures a lot of fantasy-filled Decembers, as Peter Jackson has already scheduled a pair of ''Hobbit'' films for Warner Brothers and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in that month in the years 2012 and 2013. ''Avatar'' was released on Dec. 18 of last year and became the highest-grossing film in history, with almost $2.8 billion in worldwide ticket sales. Mr. Cameron and the top Fox film executives, Jim Gianopulos and Tom Rothman, jointly said they aimed to begin production next year on the first sequel. The film is not yet officially titled, they said. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

BERGSTEIN--Max, 91, died October 27, 2010, at his home of natural causes. A service will be at 10am, Thursday, October 28th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York. Mr. Bergstein was born October 25, 1919, in Poland, to Chana and Yeduda Bergstein. He is a Holocaust survivor, having lost his parents, three sisters, their husbands and children in Auschwitz concentration camp. He and his beloved wife Suzanne immigrated to the United States in 1949 where he was in the diamond business for 45 years in New York City. He was a self educated, highly intellectual man who spoke eight languages fluently. He was admired, loved and respected by his family, friends and all who knew him for his intellect, wit, charm and warmth. Mr. Bergstein is survived by his sons Daniel, Joel and his wife Bonnie, and Michael and his wife Lindy, as well as by his grandchildren Liz and her husband Rob, Jordan and his wife Paula, Lance, Samara, Jacob, Suzannah and Olivia, and by his great-grandchildren Jenna, Jason, Sam and Bari. He will be missed.

After a Broadway run of more than two and a half years that included four Tony Awards and a Grammy, the hit musical ''In the Heights'' will close on Jan. 9. ''It's the right time,'' one of the producers, Kevin McCollum, said Wednesday, citing the implacable economics of Broadway. ''If we ran into another year, it wouldn't make sense.'' The ''American Idol'' winner Jordin Sparks, who joined the cast in August, will be leaving as planned in mid-November, but Lin-Manuel Miranda, who created the musical and originally starred in it, will be returning to the lead role of Usnavi for the final 19 performances. A movie version is also in the works, scheduled to begin shooting next year.
An article on Wednesday about Will Barnet, a 99-year-old artist in New York City, misspelled the given name of his daughter. She is Ona Barnet, not Oona.

Tuesday is a very big day for Jimmy McMillan. Not only will Mr. McMillan, the candidate on the Rent Is Too Damn High ticket, learn whether he is the next governor of the state of New York, but it is also the release date of his newest album. If you asked, ''Why Tuesday?'' Mr. McMillan would in all likelihood respond: ''Why not? The rent is always too damn high.'' The album, provisionally entitled ''The Rent Is Too Damn High,'' will be available for download on iTunes and other sites.The New York Times, continuing its coverage of Mr. McMillan's musical forays, has obtained an exclusive first single - maybe. It's definitely a single on the new album, but whether it has been previously available on Mr. McMillan's sprawling Web site could not be confirmed Wednesday afternoon.

DORMER--Robert Thomas, 91, of Palm Harbor, Florida died on October 25, 2010 after a short illness. Before moving to Florida in 1994, he was a resident of Bayside, NY for more than 40 years. He was raised in Manhattan where he was born November 20, 1918, the son of Nicholas and Agnes Dormer. He was President of the New State Job Development Authority from 1979 until his retirement in 1991. Prior to that he served as Executive Vice President of the New York State Urban Corporation. In 1991 the New York State Economic Development Council renamed its Economic Developer of the Year Award as the Robert T. Dormer Economic Developer of the Year Award. In 1994 he was named an Honorary Life Member of the American Economic Development Council "in recognition of long and distinguished service in furthering the profession of economic development and the aims of the Council." Survivors include four children, sons Robert (Bonnie), Ronald (Nancy Nason), Daniel (Janet), a daughter, Diane, and six grandchildren. He was predeceased by his spouses, Mary Catherine McLaughlin Dormer and Gunnel Jerrebo Dormer and his brother, Nicholas. He was a graduate of New York University. During World War II he served in the US Navy with the 114th Construction Battalion (Seabees) in France from July to December 1944 and later in the South Pacific and finally in Japan in September 1945. Burial will be at the Long Island National Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island, on November 2, 2010 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to Disabled American Veterans, P.O. Box 145477, Cincinnati, OH 45250-5447

8 P.M. (NBC) SCARED SHREKLESSMike Myers, Cameron Diaz and Antonio Banderas lend their voices to this half-hour Halloween special, made in collaboration with DreamWorks Animation. Shrek (Mr. Myers), above, challenges Fiona (Ms. Diaz), Donkey (Dean Edwards, in the role Eddie Murphy originated), Puss in Boots (Mr. Banderas) and his other fairy-tale friends to a scary storytelling contest. They must spend the night in Lord Farquaad's haunted castle, with the last one standing courageous crowned the winner. 3 P.M. (Fox) THE DR. OZ SHOW Everything you ever wanted to know about the penis, and then some.

An opera company in South Africa says it plans to take its production of ''Porgy and Bess'' to Israel, despite the urging of the retired Archbishop Desmond Tutu not to tour there, BBC News reported. Michael Williams, the managing director of Cape Town Opera, whose company is scheduled to perform at the Tel Aviv Opera House next month, said in a statement that his group was ''reluctant to adopt the essentially political position of disengagement from cultural ties'' with Israelis or with Palestinians.

With opening night (and performances for the critics) fast approaching, the creators of the new Broadway musical ''Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown'' added several changes for Tuesday night's audience, most noticeably a new number at the top of the show that had been the Act II opener. The song, ''Madrid,'' is much more upbeat than the original first song, ''My Crazy Heart,'' which had the women of the title describing their feelings about love before they had been established as characters for the audience. ''Madrid,'' a jubilant serenade to the setting of the show, is still sung by the character of the taxi driver (played by Danny Burstein), who functions as a kind of narrator. Act II now opens with a new entr'acte followed by the character Candela (Laura Benanti) calling out to her best friend and the show's central character, Pepa (Sherie Rene Scott).

An article on Wednesday about lobbyists' courting lawmakers who might lead Congressional committees if the Republicans win control of the House of Representatives misidentified a position once held by Jennifer Bell, a health care lobbyist. She was on the staff of the Senate Finance Committee; she was not an aide to Representative Dave Camp, Republican of Michigan.
London Oh what a tangled web we weave when soccer and money and governance intertwine.

GROSSMAN--Bill, 62, in Roslyn on October 16. MIT graduate and highly regarded musician, Broadway conductor (Sugar Babies and Cats), and music copyist for composers Harvey Schmidt (The Fantasticks) and Galt MacDermot (Hair). He is survived by father Irwin; brothers Edward (Bethesda, MD) and Richard; nephew David (Washington, DC); cousins Laurie Gioia, John and Robert Grossman and Vicki Wyman (Miami). Donations in his memory may be made to your favorite charity.

Last week Sony confirmed that it has ceased making tape-based Walkman players in Japan, where the first one debuted in 1979. In the United States, the cassette began to fall out of favor more than a quarter-century ago, following the demise of the eight-track tape player. When compact disc players became the sound source of choice for portable use and in automobiles, it was apparent that the cassette, despite its ability to easily record, was doomed.

The Alaska Supreme Court ruled late Wednesday that state election workers at polling places could provide lists of write-in candidates to voters who request them. The ruling, which could benefit Senator Lisa Murkowski, who is running a write-in campaign for re-election, reversed a decision by lower court judge earlier Wednesday.

BARON--Howard, age 87, on October 26, 2010. Beloved husband of Joan. Loving father of Abby, Lizzy, Mike and the late Jimmy. Cherished grandfather of Ben, Becki, Joseph, Matthew, Maggie, Emma, Jeffrey, Megan and Lily. Devoted brother of Irene Moskowitz and the late Gail Kaplan. He will be deeply missed. Memorial service Thursday, October 28, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St.

Because of an editing error, the Limoges Journal article on Wednesday, about an annual food festival in the city of Limoges in central France, misstated the date of the festival. It was on Friday, Oct. 15, not ''last week.'' (The festival is always held on the third Friday of October.)

COOPER--Anne. It is with profound sadness that we note the passing of our colleague and long-time friend, Anne Cooper. The example Anne set of kindness, commitment, loyalty and generosity of heart will stay with us for years to come. We extend our deepest condolences and love to the entire Cooper family. Robinson Lerer & Montgomery

An article on Monday about the prominence of the iPad in Hollywood misstated the timing of an episode of the ABC sitcom ''Modern Family,'' relative to the release of the iPad. The episode, in which one of the characters desperately wanted an iPad for his birthday, was shown on March 31, three days before the iPad's April 3 release -- not ''days after it was put on sale.''
7:52 p.m. | Updated By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED
International HANDLING OF ABUSE CHARGES

The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee thinks that John Raese, the Republican candidate for Senate in West Virginia, might actually make a decent senator - for Florida. In a television ad released Wednesday, the committee ties Mr. Raese to Florida, where he and his wife own a home, and asks, ''Would John Raese represent Florida or West Virginia?''

FULD--Eleanore, died peacefully on Tuesday, October 26, 2010 at the age of 102. Born in Duesseldorf, Germany on July 15, 1908 to Johanna and Louis Elkan, she emigrated to the United States in 1934 with her beloved husband Fred, and adored daughter, Ann Lee, both of whom pre-deceased her, as did her sister, Ilse. She is survived by her nephew George Reinemund, of Cary, NC, and her niece, Mary Friedman, of Santa Barbara, CA, and their families. A lady of indomitable spirit, who was an inspiration to all who knew her, she will be greatly missed and fondly remembered by her family and many friends. A Memorial Service will be held on November 28th at 11:00am at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, c/o Elise Cooke, 633 Third Avenue (28th Floor), NY, NY 10017.
An obituary on Oct. 1 about the actor Joe Mantell, using information from a family member, misstated the country from which his parents emigrated. They were from Austria, not Poland.
An article on Oct. 14 about the designer Roberta Freymann misspelled the surname of one of her customers. She is Priscilla Rattazzi, not Ratazzi.

Rahm Emanuel's showdown with the sheriff has been averted. The Cook County sheriff, Tom Dart, who posed the strongest potential competition to Mr. Emanuel's bid for Chicago mayor, announced he would not seek the office on Wednesday. When Mr. Emanuel stepped down as White House chief of staff to run for mayor on Oct. 1, his victory seemed far from certain. But potent rivals have failed to materialize - Representative Luis Gutierrez said two weeks ago that he would rather work on immigration overhaul in Congress, and Mr. Dart cited his family in his decision not to run.

GRAU--George H. of Manhattan died October 24, 2010 at the age of 87 of complications related to Parkinson's Disease. Mr. Grau had a passion for classical music, which he learned to play on an upright piano in the living room of his family's Toledo, OH home. He briefly attended the Curtis Institute and assisted in the orchestration of classical compositions. When he first arrived in New York he was a popular pianist, providing entertainment at private parties. Later he worked for RCA Red Seal Records, where he was in charge of relations with recording artists in genres from classical to hard rock. He married Mme. Jacqueline Schweitzer, a concert pianist, in Paris in 1971. They lived in New York. Preceding him in death were his parents, Fred and Genetta Grau and a younger brother, Fred Jr., all of Toledo. He is survived by his wife, Jacqueline, his twin brother Charles, also of New York, and brothers John and James of California. A funeral Mass will be said at 10am on Friday, October 29, at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, 152 West 71st St., with interment to follow at Trinity Church Cemetery. Services were made by Redden's Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in Mr. Grau's memory to: onestopseniorservices.org or the Church of the Blessed Sacrament.

McGOVERN--Coleman B.,Jr., "Terry", passed away on Friday, October 25th in his home, after struggling for many years with Parkinson's. Born on June 25th, 1923, Terry was a life-long New Yorker. He attended the Buckley School, St. Paul's School, and Yale. Terry was a renowned world traveler. He enjoyed the company of many close friends as he traipsed about the world fishing, exploring, studying at Cambridge, and visiting family in Europe. A member of the Yale class of 1945W, Terry saw combat in the Pacific as an army lieutenant. He spent the majority of his career working for Citibank. He is survived by many dear friends; his brother David; and nieces Alexandra and Justine, and their families, Paul, George and Daniel Edison, and Ivy and Nate Johnson. The family would like to extend a special thanks to Verona Campbell Wright who took such good care of Coleman for 11 years. A memorial reception will be held at the Union Club, 101 East 69th Street, on Tuesday, November 2nd, at 11am. In lieu of flowers please donate to Yale University and the Parkinson's Foundation.
SLIDE SHOW In Senator Harry Reid's hometown of Searchlight, Nev., the mere mention of the senator's name can set off arguments. nytimes.com/politics

Zenyatta is a perfect 19-0. The mare might even be invincible. She beat the boys in this race last year. There is a long line of accomplished contenders, however, intent on making her earn her immortality in the $5 million Breeders' Cup Classic. They are salty bunch, seven Grade I winners, that include a colt named Blame, who has lost only once this year; Gio Ponti, last year's reigning champion older male horse; and Espoir City, one of Japan's most highly regarded runners. Most of the rival trainers and owners concede they will be conflicted when the field loads into the gate at Churchill Downs on Nov. 6 between wanting to win what is truly a world championship race and hoping that Zenyatta, a terrific race mare, can end her career undefeated.

Carly Fiorina, the Republican candidate for Senate in California, was released from the hospital on Wednesday, a day after she was admitted for an infection related to breast cancer treatment. Ms. Fiorina will spend the night at her home in Los Altos Hills and is expected to resume a full campaign schedule by Thursday.

A chart on Tuesday with the continuation of an article about alternative approaches to the nation's fiscal policies misstated the political affiliation of Maya MacGuineas, an author of one of three federal budget plans that were compared. She is an independent, not a Republican. The headline for the chart also misstated the goals of two of the plans. While they all call for reducing the budget deficit, only one plan -- not all three -- would balance the federal budget by the year 2020. (That is the plan offered by former Senators Bill Bradley, John C. Danforth, Gary Hart and Bob Packwood.)

A report in the Media Decoder column on Monday about NuCaptcha Engage, a new video version of the online security feature known as captcha, erroneously included one company on a list of clients for the product, using information from NuCaptcha. Electronic Arts, Activision and Coastal Contacts have signed up for the product; Wrigley, a subsidiary of Mars, has not.

Phone cases with built-in batteries are certainly a great way to keep your handset running during marathon phone sessions, if you don't mind carrying around a brick-sized device. Exogear has created a battery pack for the iPhone for that, at 2 ounces and roughly half the thickness of the phone, claims to be the thinnest, lightest battery case for an iPhone 4.
I will be working for the bank for the rest of my life. I will never own anything -- not even a car. MANOLO MARBÁN, of Toledo, Spain, who will owe $140,000 to a bank after foreclosure. [A1]

BROWN--Francis C. (Retired New York Fire Department Chief) on October 26, 2010. Beloved father of Joseph, Peter, Robert, Timothy, Alice Beekman and Patrick. Dearest brother of Dorothy Sasson, Thomas and Lucille. Also survived by nine grandchildren. Reposing at the Krauss Funeral Home, Inc., 1097 Hempstead Tpke., Franklin Square, Thursday and Friday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial 10:30am Saturday at Our Lady of Perpetual Help RC Church, Brooklyn. Cremation Private.

VITANZA--Rose-Marie. Died October 25, 2010. Born March 27, 1925 in Brooklyn, NY the daughter of the late Canzio and Theresa-Levy Vitanza. She was predeceased by her sister Florence Winters and brothers Cologa, Theodore and Louis. Adored aunt of 14, great-aunt of 22, great-great-aunt of 10, honorary aunt and devoted friend to countless throughout her wonderful life. Ms. Vitanza worked as an Advertising Executive, retiring from the J.C. Penney Co. in 1984. Funeral services Saturday, October 30, 2010 at 11:00am, The Grace Episcopal Church, 85 E. Main St., Port Jervis, NY 12771 with Rev. David Lee Carlson officiating. Burial in Montoza Cemetery, Barryville, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to: Fed by Grace C/O Grace Episcopal Church, PO Box 60, Port Jervis NY 12771 or Trees for Israel, JNF.org Services by Gray-Parker Funeral Home, 845-856-5191 grayparkerfuneralhome.com

COOPER--Anne, beloved wife of Thomas, devoted mother to Lauren, daughter of Darl Fyfe and sister to Jim and Jean, passed away on Saturday, October 23rd. Anne lived life to its fullest, and touched everyone around her with her energy, compassion and love. An adoring mother and wife, a dedicated friend, a strong example of optimism and kindness and a truly generous soul, she will be missed and remain in our hearts forever. Anne is predeceased by her father, John Fyfe. A memorial service will be held at 3:00pm on Tuesday, November 2nd at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York City.
TICK--Jerome H. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Jerome H. Tick, and send condolences to his family.

LERNER--Allan Stuart Allan Stuart, a former president (1980-1996) of Ack-Tie Lining Inc., a division of Collins and Aikman Inc. in New York City, as well as a former President (1965-1975) of Superba Inc. died on October 25th in Boynton Beach, Florida. He had respiratory IPF. Born in Rochester, NY August 15, 1929, he grew up in Buffalo, NY and was a graduate of the Nichols School (1947) as well as Amherst College (1951). He also attended The Harvard Law School and has been a member of The Harvard Club of New York City for over 30 years. From 1996 to 2006, Lerner founded and successfully operated ASL Consulting/21 working with and for key organizations, as well as serving on the Robert Talbott Inc. Board of Directors for nine years in Carmel, CA. He adored both the now deceased Audrey and Robert Talbott and was deeply honored by his election. Long active in the Men's Wear Industry, Lerner was a past president and director of both the Men's Neckwear Association and the Fathers Day/Mothers Day Council, both organizations with strong retail mission statements and raising substantial funds for important charitable causes. Lerner is survived by two daughters and one son: Caryn Lerner of New York, Dana Hoffman of Clarence, NY and Eric Lerner of Woodinville, WA; as well as five grandchildren: Kyle Allan and Jenna Evelyn Bergman of New York, Dylan Lerner Hoffman of Clarence, NY, and Kyra Bikki and Ari Sage Lerner of Woodinville, WA. In addition, two sisters survive him: Mrs. Gloria Tenner of Princeton, NJ and Mrs. Joan Hayman of Boca Raton, FL. Lerner's former wife (1956-1974) Evelyn Bikki Swados pre-deceased him. Hilary Bergman, Amy Sage Lerner and Jeffrey Tenner are also dear family, as was the late Robert Hayman. At Amherst, Lerner was a member of Psi Upsilon, Sphinx, Scarab, Student Council, The Amherst Student, Class President and Agent and as Chairman of the Alumni Fund was honored by both The Distinguished Service Award and The Amherst College Medal for Eminent Service in 1966. He was also President of both the Managerial and Automotive Associations. In addition to Men's Industry organizations and activities, Lerner served as a trustee at the Nichols School in Buffalo, NY. He was also a past President of the City Club of Rochester, NY, Trustee of TV Channel WXXI Public Broadcasting, Monroe County Boy Scout Council, Trustee of Temple Broth Kodesh, and an active member of the Rochester Tennis Club. As a Florida resident since 1996 living at Quail Ridge Country Club in Boynton Beach, FL, he maintained his 60 years of tennis competition and world travels, but liked to say, "My family means the most to me, children extraordinary; BUT grandchildren, as they say in New York City, forgetaboutit!!! They are the icing and chocolate at THE VERY TOP OF THE CAKE." Donations to Amherst College and/or the Nichols School are welcome. A celebration of Lerner's life will take place at the Riverside Memorial Chapel in New York City on November 11th at 2 pm.

The Advertising column on Tuesday, about experiments with campaigns using bar codes that can be scanned by smartphones, misstated the location of the Rensselaer rail station near Albany, where the technology is being tested. The station in is Rensselaer, a municipality and county on the east side of the Hudson, adjacent to but not in Albany, which is on the west side.

KOLTON--Paul, of Stamford, CT, died peacefully on Wednesday, October 27, 2010, at age 87. He is survived by his beloved wife of 66 years, Edith Kolton, as well as son Robert Kolton, daughter Shelley Kolton, MD, and daughter-in-law Susan Shaffer. He will be deeply missed by cherished grandchildren Jordan (Melissa), Joanna (Andrew), Flannery, Ruthie and Lili, as well as great-grandson, Rio. Born on June 1, 1923 in New York City, he began his career as a prolific writer and thinker, eventually being named President of the American Stock Exchange. He served on numerous Boards, including the Financial Accounting Standards Board, among other corporate and philanthropic organizations. We will all miss his enormous heart, curious mind and brilliant sense of humor. We will not miss his sliced forehand. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name may be made to www.savethechildren.org. Family and friends will gather on Thursday from 4:00-8:00pm and Friday from 2:00-8:00 pm at the Kolton residence in Stamford.

STEIN--Joseph. The Dramatists Guild Council mourns the passing of our dear friend Joe Stein, a legendary writer and one of our most respected and beloved members. As his colleagues, we will miss not only the wit and depth of his work, but even more his unfailing good humor, warmth, and humanity. We extend our deepest sympathies to his loved ones at this difficult time. Stephen Schwartz, President The Dramatists Guild of America
Paul A. Volcker is looking to steer the rule that bears his name.

I noted on Thursday that our forecasting model -- even though it had shown an increase in Republican Paul LePage's chances to be the next governor of Maine -- still seemed to be underestimating him, given that the Democrat Elizabeth Mitchell was rapidly losing support to independent Eliot Cutler and that neither she nor Mr. Cutler were good bets to achieve the roughly 40 percent of the vote that Mr. LePage seems bound to achieve.

ARLINGTON, Tex. -The former presidents George H.W. Bush and George W. Bush will throw out the ceremonial first pitches before Game 4 of the World Series on Sunday. The Hall of Fame pitcher Nolan Ryan, the Rangers president, will do it before Game 3 on Friday.

A new poll from Field Research, highest-rated polling firm in our database, gives Barbara Boxer an 8-point lead, 49 to 41, over her Republican challenger, Carly Fiorina. While Ms. Fiorina's chances had already been on the decline -- California has been very widely polled, and most of the surveys have shown Ms. Boxer holding a lead in the mid-single digits - the new poll on Friday harms her odds somewhat further. Given the robustness of the polling (and how close we now are to Election Day), our model gives Ms. Fiorina just a 4 percent chance of making a comeback, down from 7 percent on Thursday.

ARLINGTON, Tex. - C.J. Wilson loves to cook, read and surf. He plays guitar, practices martial arts and races cars. Wilson is also an expert in finger care, thanks to the occupational hazards of his day job, pitching for the Rangers. Over the last year, Wilson has developed a comprehensive routine to manage a blister on his left middle finger, which opened and started bleeding during the seventh inning of Game 2, knocking him out with the Rangers trailing San Francisco, 1-0.

Five minutes after the home clubhouse opened Friday, before a workout at Rangers Ballpark, Holland was back at his locker, ready for more.

Bedbugs are as likely to settle in luxury hotels as youth hostels. So, travelers may wonder, is there a way to figure out whether a hotel (or theater or restaurant) is infested? Well, now there's an app for that.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. - Representative Tom Perriello squeaked his way into Congress two years ago with a 727-vote victory over his Republican opponent - after a recount. Friday night, with his political future hanging by a thread, President Obama tried to come to his rescue. It was payback, in part, for the Democratic congressman's support of the president's landmark health bill.

Bondholders of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer have approved a long-awaited restructuring plan, clearing the way for a bankruptcy filing that would eliminate some $4 billion in debt and put the studio under the management of the Hollywood executives Gary Barber and Roger Birnbaum, The New York Times reports.

Almost 20 years ago, when I was reporting on the then-emerging field of microfinance (now a $25 billion industry), I discovered that different people would often look at the same set of facts and come to opposite conclusions about whether they revealed something positive or negative. At the time, most of the funding for microloans came from foreign aid and philanthropy, and no lenders had yet turned profits. For some business-minded people, this was awful. It demonstrated that microfinance was an illegitimate kind of banking, worse ─ a form of charity. For those who were socially concerned, it was a saving grace. If microfinance ever became highly profitable, they feared, it would attract the wrong kind of people ─ profit-seekers ─ who would ultimately abandon the poor.

Writing corrections is seldom a proud chore, but it is often eye-opening and, dare I say, educational. In an Oct. 3 review of Eric Foner's book "The Fiery Trial: Abraham Lincoln and American Slavery," we incorrectly described an enigmatic portrait of Lincoln and Sojourner Truth examining a Bible. (By the way, our reviewers are not responsible for captions, and the reviewer in this case, David S. Reynolds, a distinguished professor at the CUNY Graduate Center, kindly helped steer us to the truth.) The portrait, a painting by Franklin C. Courter (1854-1947), is a wonderful piece of Americana and well deserves more generous treatment.

Let's say this right now: It's hard to go undefeated in college football. After about the third or fourth week of the season, we all start to worry about what happens if all these teams go undefeated. Then teams start losing. That's the way it works. Suddenly, every week is like a playoff. Missouri and Michigan State are essentially playing playoff games on Saturday. Oregon as well. All those teams are on the road against ranked conference opponents with a lot to prove. A loss would knock any of them out of the national title conversation (some further out than others).  This is why I am not in favor of a playoff system. (Soapbox alert.) Not that I like the B.C.S., but I do not like the idea of a playoff.

Athletes have been seeking an edge through the use of performance-enhancing substances for decades. But a sustained, systematic and widespread effort to combat cheating in sports has been around only since the International Olympic Committee created the World Anti-Doping Agency in 1999. Since then, a number of sports, including some that are not under the purview of WADA, have taken meaningful steps to tighten their testing procedures and have imposed stern punishment.

The creative streak coursing through many a Tel Aviv kitchen has spilled over to Jaffa, its ancient and often aesthetically unruly sister. Fittingly for a place that has served as a port since the Bronze Age, one of the new entrants sits in a retrofitted relic by the water: Container (Warehouse 2, Jaffa Port; 011-972-3-683-6321; entrees about $20 to $27) makes its home inside a hangar that dates from the 1920s, when Jaffa was part of the British Mandate of Palestine. The space fuses Red Hook grit with Levantine glam, incorporating a sweeping, 45-seat horseshoe-shaped bar under a warehouse-high ceiling that affords nice views of both the oversize wood oven in the open kitchen and the rotating exhibits on the walls. Adding to the mix is a three-times-a-week D.J. set.

It's perhaps the biggest thing to hit New Jersey since the Situation. At least as far as the art world is concerned. On Oct. 24, the New Jersey Museum of Contemporary Art opened with an exhibition curated by two wunderkinder of the downtown scene: Alex Gartenfeld, 23, the online editor of Interview and Art in America, as well as the curator of the West Street Gallery; and Haley Mellin, a 30-year-old artist whose curatorial work has included shows at Palais de Tokyo in Paris and Rental Gallery in New York. The theme? Made in America. Gartenfeld and Mellin bring more than a fresh perspective; their deep connections in the art community brought out a glittering roster to the kickoff, including Aurel Schmidt, Ryan McGinley and Rita Ackermann. T caught up with the dynamic duo via e-mail to find out how they are keeping all of the balls in the air and what they learned about the Garden State.

LOS ANGELES-There's been some moving and shaking among the movers and shakers at Columbia Pictures. Matt Tolmach, who had been jointly overseeing Columbia Pictures in a co-presidency with his fellow executive Doug Belgrad, is leaving the executive team for a choice assignment as one of the producers of the next "Spider-Man" film. Mr. Belgrad becomes Columbia's sole president, while Hannah Minghella was named production president of Columbia. Ms. Minghella was previously the production president of Sony Pictures Animation. Michael Lynton remains the chairman and chief executive of Sony Pictures Entertainment, which includes Columbia, and Amy Pascal remains the co-chairwoman of Sony Pictures. "I couldn't be happier for or prouder of Matt, Doug and Hannah," Ms. Pascal said in a statement on Friday.

An exuberant, colorful exhortation on a drab stretch of the Bowery in downtown Manhattan will not greet pedestrians strolling by the New Museum of Contemporary Art for much longer. On Friday the museum said that this weekend it will take down "Hell, Yes!," a sculpture by the Swiss artist Ugo Rondinone that spells those words in rainbow-colored letters on its second-floor ledge, and begin preparations to replace it with a new work by Isa Genzken called "Rose II." "Hell, Yes!" was unveiled on the museum's facade when its new building at 235 Bowery was opened in December 2007, and the sculpture became so closely associated with the institution that it was acquired by trustees and donated to the museum. Though nothing could replace it in our hearts, we'll try to keep an open mind about "Rose II," a 28-foot-tall depiction of a flower that is expected to be fully installed by the end of November. The museum said it would put "Hell, Yes!" in a new location, but did not yet know where or when this would take place.

KAMIN--Sherwin. We mourn the firm's co-founder Sherwin Kamin, who practiced law with us from 1968 until 2000. As a brilliant young tax partner, Sherwin joined with Lou Lowenstein and a group of other lawyers from Hays, Sklar & Herzberg, to combine with Kramer, Nessen & Hochman in forming Kramer Lowenstein Nessen & Kamin in 1968. The new firm's vision was a first class group of lawyers that would compete with the major firms of the day. Forty-two years after its founding, the firm is one of the country's largest top-tier firms. Sherwin, who had proven himself an intellectual powerhouse at City College and Harvard Law School, crafted a career remarkable in both depth and variety. He established, built and led the firm's tax and individual client groups, and mentored generations of younger lawyers. Sherwin was a keen intellect, eager to analyze and debate contentious and complex issues. He published numerous papers, and was an active contributor to the tax, and trust and estates sections of the American Bar Association and the New York State Bar Association. A steadfast friend, loyal partner, and all-around bon vivant, Sherwin's legacy and spirit continue to guide our firm. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his children, grandchildren and extended family. The partners, attorneys and staff of Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel LLP

BONANNO--Diane C.,(nee Mary Diane Cassetta) passed away on the 27th October 2010, at the age of 74. She bravely fought cancer over a number of years, and finally succumbed in peace and comfort, in the company of her family, at her home in Chappaqua, New York. Diane was born on 29th August 1936 in Elmira, New York to parents Elizabeth (nee LeMark) and Paul Cassetta She was an only child who enjoyed her friends, music, reading and the cinema. As a young adult she moved to Albany, where she worked as a medical secretary. There she met Philip Bonanno at the time a student at Albany Medical College. Diane and Philip married in 1963, lived in Brooklyn and Westbury before relocating to Chappaqua in 1970. Diane dedicated much of her adult life to raising their three children and giving generously of her time and her heart to her community and numerous charitable organizations, including the American Cancer Society. Diane also dutifully served as a member of the New York State Board for Professional Medical Conduct. Among her many endearing qualities, Diane will be remembered for her caring and compassion, her grace and elegance, her positive outlook and selfless approach to life. In modern parlance, Diane was a "giver", someone who routinely put others before herself; in that way she remains an inspiration to all who had the privilege to know her. All her tender qualities were complemented by a lust for a life, a keen wit, sharp sense of humor and a well-honed pragmatic view of the world. Diane lived a remarkable life and is survived by a grateful family, including her devoted husband Philip, her three children and their spouses, Dominique and Mark (Mannix) of Pleasantville, Peter and Jennifer of Pleasantville and Philip Jr and Louise Georgeson of Melbourne, Australia and her five glorious grandchildren who were the pride of her life, Sarah, Caroline, Matthew, Philip III and Max. The family will receive friends at the Beecher Funeral Home, in Pleasantville, today, Friday from 5-8pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Saturday at 10am at Holy Innocents Roman Catholic Church in Pleasantville. Diane's immediate family wishes to thank her doctors, hospice for all of their care and all their friends and family who provided her and the entire family with great support throughout. Diane left this life the way she lived it; surrounded by love and family, and full of grace and dignity. In lieu of flowers kindly make donations in Diane's name to Northern Westchester Breast Institute, 400 East Main Street, Mount Kisco, NY 10549.

The family will receive friends at the Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main St., New Canaan, CT, on Friday, October 29, 2010, from 5-8pm.

KAMIN--Sherwin, on October 27, 2010. Dear father of Lawrence, Samuel, Janet, David and Julia. Grandfather and good friend. Founding partner of Kramer, Levin, Naftalis & Frankel. Service Sunday, 12:45pm at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

HEALY--Robert E.,M.D. age 88. Born June 23, 1922 Brooklyn, NY. Died October 16, 2010 Dover, NH. Survived by Audrey his wife of 62 years, sister Helen McLaughlin of Akin, SC, his children Audrey (Cortlandt Manor, NY), Tracy (Amesbury, MA) and Jeff (Los Angeles, CA), and five grandchildren. He was the patriarch of a large and adoring extended family. Dr. Healy lived in Northern Westchester for nearly 40 years, in Mt. Kisco and in Waccabuc. In their retirement, Dr. and Mrs. Healy lived in Beaufort, SC and Amesbury, MA. A native of Brooklyn, NY, Dr. Healy was the son of Tracy K. and Florence C. Healy. Dr. Healy attended Xavier High School in Greenwich Village, Columbia College, where he was a member of Beta Theta Pi, and Cornell Medical School. He was a veteran of both WWII and the Korean War. He witnessed the Japanese surrender at Truk and was a medical officer in the occupying force. The bulk of his career was spent as an internist with the Mt. Kisco (New York) Medical Group. He also served as Senior Vice President of the Northern Westchester Hospital Center. In his later career, he worked for General Foods and for the Joint Commission. He is a past president of the Westchester County Medical Society, the Westchester Division of the American Heart Association and of the Waccabuc Country Club. His community involvements include helping establish the Greenburgh Health Center in White Plains, NY, serving on the vestry of St. Mark's Church and working as a reading coach for Literacy Volunteers of the Low Country, in South Carolina. He was also a trustee of the Stepping Stones Foundation. His life passions included golf, the New York Giants, Indian cooking, and bread making. A service to celebrate his life will be held on Friday, November 5 at 11:00am at St. Mark's Episcopal Church 85 E Main St., Mt. Kisco, NY. Gifts in his memory may be made to The Northern Westchester Hospital Center (http://www.nwhc.net/ Northern Westchester Hospital Foundation, 400 East Main Street, Mount Kisco, New York 10549).

An article on Wednesday about the acquisition of Maya Angelou's papers by the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, a unit of the New York Public Library, referred imprecisely to the funds used to buy the papers. While the money came from a private source, it was first donated to the library, so New York Public Library funds were in fact used for the papers. The article also misstated the surname of an 18th-century poet Ms. Angelou mentioned in citing the influence of some early black writers. He was Jupiter Hammon, not Harmon.

In one of the weightiest decisions facing a big-budget Broadway musical this season, the producers of ''The Addams Family'' announced Thursday that their leading man and biggest box-office draw, Nathan Lane, would be succeeded in the role of Gomez in March by Roger Rees, the Tony Award-winning theater and television actor. His contract up, Mr. Lane will give his final performance on March 6. The producers also disclosed Thursday that their other marquee name, Bebe Neuwirth, would extend in the role of Morticia Addams, Gomez's wife, into Broadway's lucrative summer months. Ms. Neuwirth and Mr. Lane have been performing in the show since November 2009, starting with a Chicago try-out and then opening on Broadway on April 9.

KOLTON--Paul, of Stamford, CT, died peacefully on Wednesday, October 27, 2010, at age 87. He is survived by his beloved wife of 66 years, Edith Kolton, as well as son Robert Kolton, daughter Shelley Kolton, MD, and daughter-in-law Susan Shaffer. He will be deeply missed by cherished grandchildren Jordan (Melissa), Joanna (Andrew), Flannery, Ruthie and Lili, as well as great-grandson, Rio. Born on June 1, 1923 in New York City, he began his career as a prolific writer and thinker, eventually being named President of the American Stock Exchange. He served on numerous Boards, including the Financial Accounting Standards Board, among other corporate and philanthropic organizations. We will all miss his enormous heart, curious mind and brilliant sense of humor. We will not miss his sliced forehand. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name may be made to www.savethechildren.org. Family and friends will gather on Thursday from 4:00-8:00pm and Friday from 2:00-8:00 pm at the Kolton residence in Stamford.

ANTHONY--Stephen H. The president, trustees, faculty, staff and students of Hamilton College extend their deepest sympathies to the family of Stephen H. Anthony, a member of the Class of 1959 and a kind and humble man who served his alma mater for more than two decades as trustee. We will miss Steve's wisdom and generous spirit, and we were deeply moved and honored by his presence on campus just two weeks before his death.

Contributions may be sent to Norwalk Hospital Foundation, 34 Maple St., Norwalk, CT 06856.

The Mets and the new agent for Hisanori Takahashi have received permission from Major League Baseball and the Players Association to push back the deadline for signing him, probably for about another week, although the exact date has not been determined. According to his contract, Takahashi has the right to become a free agent on Oct. 31 if the Mets don't re-sign him before then. But according to Rule 8 (i) (2) of the Major League Rules, if that date passes without his agreeing to a deal with the Mets, he cannot sign a major league contract with them until at least May 15, ensuring he would sign with another team.

The Yankees acted quickly to retain Manager Joe Girardi, rewarding him with a three-year, $9 million contract. The framework of the deal is in place, but because the Yankees did not want to make the announcement on the day of a World Series game, the new deal will not be announced until Friday. Girardi's three-year, $7.8 million contract is set to expire on Sunday, but there was little doubt that he would return. General Manager Brian Cashman, minutes after the Yankees' season ended last Friday night in Texas, said he absolutely expected Girardi to come back, a sentiment echoed Monday at their post-mortem news conferences at Yankee Stadium. In three seasons as Yankees manager, Girardi is 287-199, and he presided over the championship team of 2009.

STARKMAN--Rachel, 97, died peacefully October 26th, surrounded by family. She arrived alone from Poland at age 16, and subsequently married and built a family with her husband, Yiddish/ Hebrew essayist and journalist Moshe Starkman. She set down roots in New York, living her life with gusto, intelligence, warmth, and boundless love for all her family. She spent many years of her life compiling, editing, and publishing three books of writings of her late first husband, and re-married Arthur Lermer, also now deceased. She is lovingly remembered by her two children and their spouses (Monica/ Eduardo Schteingart and Reeva/ Ezra Mager), step-children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. She will be missed dearly. Memorial service: October 31, 9:30am, Plaza Chapel, Amsterdam and 91st, NYC.

The Advertising column on Thursday about DDB Remedy, a new unit of DDB Worldwide and Tribal DDB Worldwide that will focus on health care marketing, misstated part of the name of an agency where one of DDB Remedy's new executives was formerly employed. The executive, Larry Lannino, was managing partner at Sudler & Hennessey, not Sudley & Hennessey.

For years, Bill Henrickson and his three wives on the HBO drama ''Big Love'' have skated on some precarious ice -- at least until they changed what was a perfectly good opening-credit sequence for that series -- but they won't be able to keep it up for much longer. On Thursday, HBO said the coming season of ''Big Love,'' which stars Bill Paxton as a Utah polygamist, and Jeanne Tripplehorn, Chloe Sevigny and Ginnifer Goodwin as his wives, will be the show's last. Mark V. Olsen and Will Scheffer, the creators and executive producers of ''Big Love,'' said in a statement that when they started the series, ''we had a strong conception of the journey the Henrickson family would make over the course of the series, of the story we had to tell.'' They continued: ''While we were in the writers' room this year shaping our fifth season, we discovered that we were approaching the culmination of that story.''

In sobering news for incumbents in Congress, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows that a majority of voters say their own representatives do not deserve to return to office. With less than a week before the midterm elections, about 6 in 10 voters say it is time to give someone new a chance to represent their district in Congress, the poll found. That figure is higher than it was in 1994, when Democrats last lost control of the House of Representatives.

9 P.M. (TLC) WHAT NOT TO WEAR Stacy London and Clinton Kelly dispense an eighth season of tough sartorial love to fashion flunkies in 26 new episodes. Victim No. 1: Mindy Cohn, the former child actress who played Natalie Green in the 1980s television series ''The Facts of Life.'' Ms. Cohn, 44, above center, with Ms. London and Mr. Kelly, has long struggled to find a happy medium between her private and public lives, a conflict perhaps reflected in her frumpy wardrobe of shapeless, oversize dresses. But with her career back on the rise, she needs attire for the red carpet and paparazzi assaults -- and to stay off the worst-dressed lists. 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE! POLLIN--Alice M.,of Bronxville, NY, died October 27, 2010. She was 92. Professor Pollin was born in Brooklyn, NY, on March 4, 1918. She was graduated from Hunter College in 1939 and received her M.A. from Columbia University and her Ph.D. from Rutgers University. Professor Pollin had a long career in education and was Professor Emerita of Spanish, New York University, where she joined the faculty in 1959. She taught at both of NYU's campuses in New York and in its Madrid program, and she served as the director of the program for one term. Her scholarship focused on, among others, authors of the Spanish Baroque and Lorca. She was a pioneer in the use of computers in Hispanic studies and humanities in general and was one of the founders of the Institute for Computer Research in the Humanities. Professor Pollin and her husband of 65 years, Professor Burton R. Pollin, moved to Bronxville from Manhattan in 1978 and were co-founders of the Bronxville Beautification Committee, and they participated in many other civic activities. She had a wide range of interests in the arts beyond her Hispanic literary studies. She is survived by a daughter, Diana C. Pollin, of Marseilles, France, a son, Myles C. Pollin, of Manhattan, five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Her husband died in 2009.

A report in the Observatory column on Tuesday about surgery to remove pituitary tumors in dogs described incorrectly Cushing's disease, a condition that occurs in humans and dogs and is caused by such a tumor. I don't write all that often about American politics, because plenty of other people do that already. And I think I can often be most useful shining my spotlight on things that aren't being illuminated, and thus help project them onto the agenda. But I've been struck by the degree to which almost everybody across the political spectrum seems to think that President Obama is a disappointment -- and it strikes me as way too early to reach that conclusion. All in all, as I write in my Sunday column, I think the infatuation with Obama in 2008 was a bit overdone, as is the rejection of him today. As in the financial markets, the political markets regularly overshoot in both directions.
