Alaa Al Aswany, the best-selling Arabic-language novelist, has objected to the translation of one of his novels into Hebrew as protest of normalized relations between Israel and Arab nations, Agence France-Presse reported. A group called the Israel/Palestine Center for Research and Information said in an e-mail to supporters that it was offering a Hebrew translation of ''The Yacoubian Building,'' a novel by Dr. Al Aswany set in an apartment complex in his native Cairo.

As visually sumptuous as it is dramatically inert, ''Persephone,'' a multimedia production from the Ridge Theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, at least presents a lush feast of imagery for the eye to savor. At its bewitching best the production evokes a French neo-Classical painting that has magically bloomed into three dimensions. Long-tressed nymphs in Grecian drapery are decoratively arrayed around a circular band of stage trimmed with scallop-shell footlights. Films of maidens swimming and jellyfish making their inscrutable way through the ocean flash before us on a giant scrim. Later a riot of flowers dances past, followed by astrological imagery and a time-lapse film depicting a seascape as the seasons wax and wane.

An article on Friday about the race for the 23rd Congressional District in Texas referred incorrectly to the district's geography. The district encompasses all or part of 20 counties in southern and western Texas, including some along the Rio Grande River; it does not lie in the Rio Grande Valley, which refers to the lowland region near the mouth of the river. The article also misstated the location of Republican-dominated suburbs of San Antonio. They are on the northwestern side of San Antonio, not northeastern.

An exuberant, colorful exhortation on a drab stretch of the Bowery in downtown Manhattan will not greet pedestrians strolling by the New Museum of Contemporary Art for much longer. On Friday the museum said that this weekend it will take down ''Hell, Yes!,'' a sculpture by the Swiss artist Ugo Rondinone that spells those words in rainbow-colored letters on its second-floor ledge, and begin preparations to replace it with a new work by Isa Genzken called ''Rose II.'' ''Hell, Yes!'' was unveiled on the museum's facade when its new building at 235 Bowery was opened in December 2007, and the sculpture became so closely associated with the institution that it was acquired by trustees and donated to the museum. Though nothing could replace it in our hearts, we'll try to keep an open mind about ''Rose II,'' a 28-foot-tall depiction of a flower that is expected to be fully installed by the end of November. The museum said it would put ''Hell, Yes!'' in a new location, but did not yet know where or when this would take place. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

8 P.M. (HBO) AMELIA (2009) Hilary Swank, above, dons coveralls, leather jackets and an enormous smile to play Amelia Earhart, the American aviator who disappeared over the Pacific in 1937 while trying to become the first woman to circle the globe. Richard Gere is George Palmer Putnam, her quietly suffering husband to whom she wrote before their marriage: ''I shall not hold you to any medieval code of faithfulness to me nor shall I consider myself bound to you similarly. Please let us not interfere with the other's work or play.'' Manohla Dargis, reviewing this film by Mira Nair in The New York Times, wrote: ''An argument can be made that her death was a catastrophe -- a husband lost a wife and the world a feminist inspiration -- but 'Amelia' won't or can't rise to the tragic occasion. The filmmakers spend so much time turning her into a dopey romantic figure that they never give her the animating, vital will or even much of a personality that might explain how a Kansas tomboy turned Boston social worker took to the skies and then, through her deeds and words, encouraged other women to chart their own courses.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Kim Lawton looks at the interaction between the Democratic party and faith-based voters. Fred de Sam Lazaro reports on the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of St. Paul and Minneapolis's mailing last month of more than 400,000 copies of a DVD opposing same-sex marriage, prompting claims that the church is endorsing a candidate for Minnesota governor with the same beliefs and thus is violating its tax-exempt status.

To help parents and their advisers better choose a 529 plan, Morningstar recently released new ratings of the plans. The investment research firm looked at 53 of the largest and most innovative plans available and then rated them either ''top,'' ''above average,'' ''average,'' ''below average'' or ''bottom.'' The ratings assigned to the plans were based on factors like the quality of the underlying investment, investment performance, who is managing the program, the organization's track record for good stewardship of capital over time and whether the plan is reasonably priced.

BARRYTOWN, N.Y. - Didier Civil stood in the center of the dilapidated barn, surrounded by skeletons, horse heads and other costumes that will form part of Sunday's Halloween parade through Greenwich Village. He wrapped a piece of white lace around the colossal head of Gran Brigitte, a Haitian voodoo spirit of the dead. When she is complete, the papier-mache Brigitte will stand 18 feet tall. Swathed in a purple robe and headscarf, she will join her husband, Baron Samedi, at the front of the parade. While the earthquake in Haiti caused the country to cancel its annual Carnival celebration this year, the festival has a chance to resurrect itself this weekend. In Greenwich Village. ''There was a chance that the artistic voice of Haiti could merge with us,'' said Alex Kahn, who builds puppets for the parade. ''It's like we speak the same language.''

There is something about goalie masks that stirs the soul, sometimes in a dark way, apt for Halloween season. And sometimes in a nostalgic way. Perhaps the most famous mask was the lion's-head design worn in 1976-77 by the Rangers' Gilles Gratton, a renowned flake who was nicknamed Grattooney the Looney.

The elevator doors opened to a phalanx of black-clad waiters offering champagne flutes, white wine, and water with lime. The Hudson River stretched out before the full-story windows. The Empire State building loomed close enough to touch from the 14th floor balcony. And in every corner -- by the raw salmon bar, the grand staircase and the willowy model looking past her hefty suitor -- the conversation was in Russian. This was the launch party for the United States edition of Snob magazine, the new Russian-language luxury magazine launched by Mikhail Prokhorov, the Russian oligarch who recently bought the New Jersey Nets and seems set on creating a splash in New York. At the party Thursday night, Russian artists, journalists, executives and models toasted Mr. Prokhorov, the magazine and one another.

Paying for a home inspection isn't just for potential home buyers. There are good reasons that those going through a divorce would also want to hire a home inspector. Traditionally, divorcing spouses have tended to rely on appraisals to determine the value of their home, if they try to revalue it. But, according to divorce lawyers, appraisals tend to focus on how a home's features and square footage compare with comparable properties.

A Field Poll out Thursday on the California governor's race shows Jerry Brown, the Democrat, with a 10-point lead among likely voters over Meg Whitman, the Republican and former eBay executive. That marks a significant change from the last Field Poll, in September, which found the two candidates tied. Mr. Brown is helped in the latest poll by support among independents, women and Latinos. The poll was conducted Oct. 14 to 26 among 1,092 likely voters, and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. The Florida governor's race looks like a tossup heading into Election Day. A Quinnipiac University poll released Thursday shows the Democrat Alex Sink and the Republican Rick Scott locked in a tight race, with Ms. Sink supported by 45 percent of likely voters and Mr. Scott by 41 percent. The poll was conducted Oct. 18 to 24 among 784 likely voters and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.

SMITH--Reginald. The Board and staff of God's Love We Deliver are deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved Board member, Reggie. The kindest and gentlest soul, Reggie had a heart of pure gold. He touched people's lives in a most special way by giving selflessly of his time and talents. Reggie was full of life and love, and was a role model for all of us in living well while serving our community. Reggie was dedicated to God's Love for over 20 years, delivering more than 70,000 meals to our clients. Everyone at God's Love and in our community mourns Reggie's passing. We send our heartfelt condolences to his partner and our dear friend, Robert Herbert, as well as his niece, Jamillah Malik and his nephew, Richard Alsberry. All of us will miss Reggie deeply and will remember him forever.

By his own account, Salvatore Vitale took part in 11 murders during his 30 years with the Bonanno crime family. But Mr. Vitale, a former underboss who became perhaps the most significant Mafia defector in nearly two decades, will not have to serve any more than the seven years he has already spent in prison. A judge on Friday sentenced him to time served. He had faced the possibility of life in prison.

ALLISON--Mary Emma. The US Fund for UNICEF mourns the passing of Mary Emma Allison, co-founder of "Trick-or-Treat for UNICEF," who died on October 27th, at age 93. In 1947, after a busy Halloween night, Mrs. Allison told her husband, the Reverend Clyde Allison: "It's too bad we can't turn this into something good." This notion grew into the nation's longest-running youth service program, which has raised nearly $160 million and helped save millions of young lives. Our debt is enormous, and we remember Mrs. Allison with abiding gratitude and love. Undoubtedly, the children we serve would say the same, if given the opportunity. To post a condolence, please visit unicefusa.org/allisontribute.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. - Representative Tom Perriello squeaked his way into Congress two years ago with a 727-vote victory over his Republican opponent - after a recount. Friday night, with his political future hanging by a thread, President Obama tried to come to his rescue. It was payback, in part, for the Democratic congressman's support of the president's landmark health bill. ''Tom went to Washington to do what's hard, he went to do what's right, and now the lobbyists and the special interests are going after him,'' Mr. Obama told a cheering throng of 10,000 who gathered in an outdoor pavilion and pedestrian mall downtown, a few miles from the grounds of the University of Virginia. ''And the question I have for you is, 'When somebody like this has your back, do you have his back?'''

STARKMAN--Rachel, 97, died peacefully October 26th, surrounded by family. She arrived alone from Poland at age 16, and subsequently married and built a family with her husband, Yiddish/ Hebrew essayist and journalist Moshe Starkman. She set down roots in New York, living her life with gusto, intelligence, warmth, and boundless love for all her family. She spent many years of her life compiling, editing, and publishing three books of writings of her late first husband, and re-married Arthur Lermer, also now deceased. She is lovingly remembered by her two children and their spouses (Monica/ Eduardo Schteingart and Reeva/ Ezra Mager), step-children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. She will be missed dearly. Memorial service: October 31, 9:30am, Plaza Chapel, Amsterdam and 91st, NYC.

If his bid to be Florida's next governor is successful, Rick Scott could find himself in the awkward position of choosing his own inquisitor. New documents show that complaints into a chain of clinics he ran have been referred to the state health department, whose head is appointed by the governor. Throughout the close race against Alex Sink, his Democratic opponent, Mr. Scott has stressed that he was never charged with wrongdoing when the health care conglomerate he built, Columbia/HCA, was fined with $1.7 billion for defrauding government health programs in 1997.

An actor in the coming Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' was injured last week during a demonstration of one of the many flying and acrobatic effects in the $60 million show, whose creators have promised an unprecedented aerial spectacle while also going to lengths to ensure safety. A spokesman for the show on Friday confirmed the accident in which Kevin Aubin, a dancer and one of several performers who doubles as Spider-Man in the show, broke both his wrists when he was catapulted into the air - in a kind of sling-shot effect - from the back of the stage to its lip, where he landed with notable force.

Though it doesn't take particularly large obstacles to impede a hobbit, a film adaptation of that J. R. R. Tolkien novel cleared a crucial hurdle on Friday as New Zealand's government passed a new labor bill promised to the ''Hobbit'' filmmakers, despite the objections of some legislators, Reuters reported. The bill, which states that people who work on film productions are independent contractors (who are not allowed to bargain collectively under New Zealand law), was promised to Peter Jackson and the film studios behind two planned ''Hobbit'' movies, who recently agreed to keep the production in New Zealand. Mr. Jackson, the producer and director of ''The Hobbit,'' had clashed with actors' guilds in New Zealand and Australia, which had called on its members to boycott the project.

An article on Friday about vaccinating boys and young men against human papillomavirus, or HPV, misstated the availability of the vaccine Cervarix, made by GlaxoSmithKline. It has been approved for use in female patients, but not for male patients. (Another vaccine, Gardasil, made by Merck, is available to both.)

An article in some editions on Friday about a lawsuit that claims an elderly woman was severely injured by two 4-year-olds racing their bicycles on a Manhattan sidewalk misstated the timing of the woman's death. The woman, Claire Menagh, died of unrelated causes three months after she was struck, not three weeks.

An obituary on Oct. 21 about the oncologist Georges Mathé referred incorrectly to an experiment he conducted. He treated four physicists who had become ill from radiation exposure as a result of a nuclear reactor accident; he did not give them ''life-threatening doses of radiation.'' The obituary also referred incorrectly to the concentration camp to which Dr. Mathé was sent during World War II. While it was run by the German occupiers of Poland, it was not ''a Polish'' concentration camp.

A Flemish culture minister's plan to put the Royal Flanders Ballet and Flemish Opera under the same management has prompted the dance troupe's artistic director, Kathryn Bennetts, to submit her resignation, citing the loss of independence. She said she would leave when her contract ends in two years. Under the minister's plan, beginning in 2013 an artistic director for the ballet and a music director for the opera would report to an administrator who would be responsible for programs and budgets.

POLLIN--Alice M.,of Bronxville, NY, died October 27, 2010. She was 92. Professor Pollin was born in Brooklyn, NY, on March 4, 1918. She was graduated from Hunter College in 1939 and received her M.A. from Columbia University and her Ph.D. from Rutgers University. Professor Pollin had a long career in education and was Professor Emerita of Spanish, New York University, where she joined the faculty in 1959. She taught at both of NYU's campuses in New York and in its Madrid program, and she served as the director of the program for one term. Her scholarship focused on, among others, authors of the Spanish Baroque and Lorca. She was a pioneer in the use of computers in Hispanic studies and humanities in general and was one of the founders of the Institute for Computer Research in the Humanities. Professor Pollin and her husband of 65 years, Professor Burton R. Pollin, moved to Bronxville from Manhattan in 1978 and were co-founders of the Bronxville Beautification Committee, and they participated in many other civic activities. She had a wide range of interests in the arts beyond her Hispanic literary studies. She is survived by a daughter, Diana C. Pollin, of Marseilles, France, a son, Myles C. Pollin, of Manhattan, five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Her husband died in 2009.

ARLINGTON, Tex. - The only other time Pat Burrell played in the World Series, in 2008 with Philadelphia, he went hitless in his first 13 at-bats. Burrell is not quite in that dire territory, but his quest for his first hit against Texas will have to wait at least another day. Burrell was pulled out of the Giants' lineup for Sunday's Game 4 after striking out in all four plate appearances Saturday night. Through three games, he is 0 for 9 with eight strikeouts.

CLEVELAND - At his final campaign rally before Election Day, President Obama compared the economy with a car that had been driven into a ditch. The Republicans, he said, hadn't helped push it out but instead had watched from the side while "sipping Slurpees." It's one of his favorite lines and, according to Mark Knoller of CBS News, the president has used it 35 times so far this election cycle but Sunday could have been the last. Indeed, voters will soon decide whether to give Congressional Republicans the keys to the car back.

I have spent almost a quarter century photographing philosophers. For the most part, philosophers exist, and have always existed, outside the public spotlight. Yet when we reflect upon those eras of humankind that burn especially bright, it is largely the philosophers that we remember. Despite being unknown at a time, the philosophers of an era survive longer in collective memory than wealthy nobleman and politicians, or the popular figures of stage, song and stadium. Because of this disconnect between living fame and later recognition, we have less of a record of these thinkers than we should. Our museums are filled with busts and paintings of long-forgotten wealth and beauty instead of the philosophers who have so influenced contemporary politics and society. My aim in this project has been the modest one of making sure that, for this era at least, there is some record of the philosophers.

An article on Oct. 17 about visiting the small family vineyards and restaurants of the Wachau Valley of Austria by bike described the Domäne Wachau cooperative incorrectly. It is a governing body that regulates its own members, not all the valley's vintners. And it is the biggest exporter in the Wachau; it is not the sole exporter there.

Bedbugs are as likely to settle in luxury hotels as youth hostels. So, travelers may wonder, is there a way to figure out whether a hotel (or theater or restaurant) is infested? Well, now there's an app for that. The new Bed Bug Alert ($1.99 at iTunes.apple.com) app for the Apple iPhone and iPod Touch shows users a GPS-enabled Google map that indicates nearby bedbug-infested sites as red push pins. The locations are based on addresses of bedbug outbreaks reported by the media, by governmental agencies and by users across the country.

TOWNIES All holidays are measured by their varying degrees of stress but New Year's takes that stress and whittles it down to a single second. Thus we throw money, confetti, booze, anything we can think of at the problem. When that fails, we drop a 1,000-pound ball on it. And Halloween in the city -- that otherwise harmless children's holiday with its adorably occult roots -- was weaned on New Year's. These sister holidays mark the beginning and the end of the holiday season in New York, with the former increasingly taking its cue from the latter. Streets are shut down for Halloween, costumes are purchased, it's impossible to get a cab and people seem legitimately concerned about their whereabouts weeks in advance.

Last fall I came across a copy of ''Native Trees of Canada, Bulletin No. 61, Fifth Edition,'' originally published in 1917 by the Department of Northern Affairs and National Resources, Forestry Branch. In its flat, monochrome survey photographs I saw a simplified version of the Canadian landscape, like the one I understood as a child. Seeing the pictures reminded me of our capacity to colorize memories, some not even our own. I made a series of paintings from the book, and afterward, whenever I read a story, any mention of a tree stood out like an old friend. It's hard to find stories about Canada that do not include references to its trees. Here, from my bookshelf, are passages from some of my favorite Canadian authors on their leafy heritage. After passing the rapids, the river widened into another small lake, perfectly round in form, and having in its center a tiny green island, in the midst of which stood, like a shattered monument of bygone storms, one blasted, black ash tree. -- Susanna Moodie , ''Roughing It in the Bush ''

Over the past few days, thousands of Democratic-leaning voters nationwide -- including the young people, minorities and unmarried women who were a crucial part of Barack Obama's 2008 coalition and whom the party is desperate to rouse again on Tuesday -- received a message in their mailboxes that effectively said: we're keeping an eye on you. The mailers are the handiwork of Hal Malchow, a political consultant who is acting on a theory that first intrigued him four years ago. Before the 2006 Michigan gubernatorial primary, three political scientists isolated a group of voters and mailed them copies of their voting histories, listing the elections in which they participated and those they missed. Included were their neighbors' voting histories, too, along with a warning: after the polls closed, everyone would get an updated set. After the primary, the academics examined the voter rolls and were startled by the potency of peer pressure as a motivational tool. The mailer was 10 times better at turning nonvoters into voters than the typical piece of pre-election mail whose effectiveness has ever been measured. Malchow, a 58-year-old former Mississippi securities lawyer who managed Al Gore's first Senate campaign and went on to start a direct-mail firm, read the academics' study and wanted to put the device to work. But he had trouble persuading his firm's clients -- which over the years have included the Democratic National Committee and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. -- to incorporate such a tactic into their get-out-the-vote programs. All feared a backlash from citizens who might regard the mailer as a threat from someone seeking their vote.

It's Halloween. The pumpkins are being carved and the cobwebs spread. Fanciful get-ups are everywhere. Earlier this month, the Anime Festival and Comic Con combined forces to fill every inch of the Javits Center, and many of the thousands of visitors were elaborately costumed as their favorite comic-book subjects. The showstopper was a woman with green hair spread out like wings, held in place with egg white. With BoltBus, Megabus, and an array of Chinatown-to-Chinatown companies already operating, it might seem the market for discount New York-to-D.C. bus lines has reached capacity. But one upstart is betting there's room for a new angle. The Know It Express, which debuts Friday, bypasses Manhattan and downtown Washington altogether, instead offering direct service from Washington's trendy U Street to Brooklyn's Atlantic Terminal, at the nexus of Fort Greene, Park Slope and Prospect Heights. The bus line, which one blog has already bestowed with the moniker ''hipster highway,''was founded by Shalonda Hunter, the founder of the Washington-based culture and travel Web site TheKnowIt, who hopes to tap into a market of young travelers looking to eschew Times Square and the National Mall for Brooklyn Flea and U Street's indie music venues.

REICHNER--Oscar. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of Oscar Reichner, a highly respected leader in the Brooklyn, NY, Jewish Community, the beloved husband of Mrs. Magda Reichner. He was the cherished father of Mrs. Chani (and Yisroel) Braunstein of NY and Renee (and Robert Eli) Rubinstein, of Toronto, Ontario, who is a member of the Stern College for Women Board of Overseers, and together with her husband is a YU Benefactor. Heartfelt condolences are extended to all of them, and his seven grandchildren and seventeen great-grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Shira Yoshor, Chair, Stern College Board Samuel Z. Eltes, Chair, National Board, Canadian Friends of Yeshiva University

RAGUS--Dale Smolen, of Weston, MA and Naples, FL, died Sunday, October 24, 2010, at Brigham & Women's Hospital after a long battle with lymphoma. She was 59. The daughter of Muriel and Henry Smolen, she was born on May 22, 1951, in Brooklyn, NY, and was raised in East Meadow, Long Island. She graduated Vassar College in 1972 and Cornell Law School in 1975. She practiced law as a trusts and estates and matrimonial attorney at the firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy in New York. Mrs. Ragus found that being a "divorce" lawyer was a daunting profession psychologically speaking. She had to deal with families where there was child abuse and those where a child was suffering from a fatal childhood illness. Getting calls from private detectives in the middle of the night when they had finally been able to track down a fleeing husband was not uncommon. She was part of the legal team that represented such famous people as Joan Kennedy and Pete Peterson. She was even involved in a case involving the disappearance of the wife, a case that was never solved. Her skills as a client advocate earned her the nick-name of the "Little Barracuda" of the matrimonial bar. She and her husband were actually married by legal contract. She eventually had her own private matrimonial practice until retiring to raise her daughter full time. She found that the most discouraging aspect of her profession was the persistent misrepresenting of facts by both attorneys and clients in court. She and her family moved to Weston, MA in 1990. Mrs. Ragus is survived by her mother Muriel Smolen, her brother David Smolen, her husband Jeremy Ragus and her daughter Jennifer Ragus. While fluent in four languages as a child, her early goal in life was to become a veterinarian out of her love for animals, a goal she abandoned due to innate fears of medical procedures - a cruel irony in light of her eventually having to endure years of painful cancer treatments. Described by her husband as "The smartest women I ever met", she was known for her lightening quick mind and her determination to live a life based on her terms. Just for the intellectual fun of it, she appeared on both of the television shows Jeopardy, where she was a two-time winner, and Wheel of Fortune, where she also won. She loved family, animals, cooking and old movies. She was a gourmet cook who approached any dinner with the goal of "never cooking the same thing twice." Above all, however, she valued intellectual honesty. The greatest joys in her life came from being with her family and having had the chance to raise her daughter, Jennifer at home on a full time basis. We will love and miss her always.

HICKEY FREEMAN has been synonymous with clean tailored suiting for the last 100 years, so it's no surprise that Opening Ceremony turned to the august brand for its latest men's wear collaboration aimed at neo-traditionalists. Combining the Hickey Freeman heritage with Opening Ceremony's youthful aesthetic, the retweaked classics include slim-line pants ($300) and suit jackets ($1,395) available in houndstooth, herringbone, pinstripes and tweeds. SARA MOONVES

An answer in the Social Q's column last Sunday about how to deal with an employer's request that employees' Facebook pages be used for business as well as personal matters misspelled the surname of the actress who starred in ''Norma Rae,'' a film about efforts to unionize the workplace. She is Sally Field, not Fields.

SMITH--Reginald. The Board and staff of God's Love We Deliver are deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved Board member, Reggie. The kindest and gentlest soul, Reggie had a heart of pure gold. He touched people's lives in a most special way by giving selflessly of his time and talents. Reggie was full of life and love, and was a role model for all of us in living well while serving our community. Reggie was dedicated to God's Love for over 20 years, delivering more than 70,000 meals to our clients. Everyone at God's Love and in our community mourns Reggie's passing. We send our heartfelt condolences to his partner and our dear friend, Robert Herbert, as well as his niece, Jamillah Malik and his nephew, Richard Alsberry. All of us will miss Reggie deeply and will remember him forever.

I had barely finished signing in at the Expectant Mother Care counseling center in Downtown Brooklyn when a staff member ushered me into a darkened room for a sonogram. As we both watched the flickering image of what looked more or less like a tadpole, she called my attention to every anatomical detail, from eyes and nose to hands and toes. Staring at the little bugger wriggling around inside me, a tear slid out of my eye. Did that tear trigger some alarm? Suddenly, two more people crowded into that tiny, darkened room. One asked if I was considering abortion.

THIS is the kind of place that no one wants to leave. And those who do often find themselves angling to come back. The Alexo family provides a good example. Ken Alexo Jr. grew up in Cranford but left after getting married: he and his wife, Alexandra, bought a house they could afford in Clark. Last October, eight years and three children later, they moved back to Cranford. Ms. Alexo said they had considered 30 or 40 houses, but only in Cranford. They ''never looked anywhere else,'' she said.

LANDAU-WEINSTEIN--Florence. Beloved wife of Sidney Weinstein, treasured mother of Madeline Kuflik and Vivian Malta, devoted grandmother of Joanna and Elana Kuflik, adored mother-in-law to Sidney Kuflik and Paul Malta, cherished sister to Carrie Dube, and caring aunt to Michael and Philip Dube and Richard Mintzes, passed away at her home in Manhattan on October 29. She was predeceased by her loving husband Jack Cohen and her cherished sister Shirley Mintzes. Florence's indomitable spirit and sense of justice were a tower of strength to all who were fortunate enough to know her. She cared deeply about her family, friends and community, and could always be counted upon in times of need. She will be profoundly missed by all. Donations in her memory can be made to the National Lung Cancer Partnership.

With its opulent movie palaces and nightclubs, the Grand Circus Park district, north of Detroit's riverfront, has always been a Motor City hot spot. Like much of the city, the area lost some of its luster during the auto industry decline, and there are still some empty storefronts and vacant lots. But its namesake park has been spruced up, and when Detroit's pro sports teams are in town, the area fills with fans. Topping everything off is a selection of theaters and concert venues, and a thriving restaurant scene. MICHELINE MAYNARD ROAST 1128 Washington Boulevard (313) 961-2500 roastdetroit.com Roast, Detroit's most talked about restaurant, is the first foray outside Cleveland by Michael Symon of ''Iron Chef'' fame. Dinner only; weekend reservations must be booked two to three weeks ahead. The meat-dominated menu features a variety of steaks and a ''beast of the day'' (market price), like a suckling pig that revolves in a kitchen window.

WITH ''Balenciaga: Spanish Master'' opening in mid-November at the Queen Sofia Spanish Institute in Manhattan, a new edition of Diana Vreeland's ''Allure'' seems strangely well timed. The first edition appeared in 1980, when Mrs. Vreeland was a special consultant to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where she organized costume shows of Balenciaga and Yves Saint Laurent, among other legends. She worked on ''Allure'' with Christopher Hemphill, a process that took three years as she sought the elusive quality of personality in images of celebrities and models, in their gestures and sometimes violent expressions -- a special condition for pictures of Maria Callas -- and Mr. Hemphill did his best to oblige her. He recorded their conversations as they went along. In the original foreword, Mr. Hemphill wrote: ''I went through archives going back to the beginnings of the century. Mrs. Vreeland often emphasized that we were only re-editing other people's editing, but in our working and reworking of the material, it became our own.''

Jane Smiley's most recent young-adult novel, ''A Good Horse,'' was published this month. It may be that great racemares are less common than great racehorses, but it may also be that the greatest racemares are slightly more common.
DANOVITCH--Stuart, MD. On the death of our beloved courageous brother-in-law and uncle, we send our love to Sylvia and family. Gil, Rona, Eric & Mark Eisner

THE conventional wisdom is that the minivan is on life support, a victim of drive-by shootings by marauding gangs of part-truck, part-car crossover wagons. But some automakers just won't pull the plug. While General Motors and Ford abandoned the sliding-door minivan in recent years, Toyota has doubled down with a new version of its Sienna that went on sale in February. Chrysler, which created the modern minivan, is bringing out redesigned Chrysler Town & Country and Dodge Grand Caravan minivans around Christmas. Kia has freshened its Sedona with a smaller but more powerful and efficient engine. Nissan has temporarily dropped its Quest while it prepares to introduce a new version early next year.

10 P.M. (AMC) THE WALKING DEAD Robert Kirkman's zombie comic-book series comes to life in this new drama about a Southern sheriff's deputy (Andrew Lincoln) who wakes up from a coma after a shootout to find his town overrun by the undead -- and his wife (Sarah Wayne Callies) and son (Chandler Riggs) missing. Now he's a man looking for his family, and anyone who gets in his way is going to lose. Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley said, ''The television adaptation is surprisingly scary and remarkably good, a show that visually echoes the stylized comic-book aesthetic of the original and combines elegant suspense with gratifyingly crude and gruesome slasher-film gore.'' She added that the series is ''not for everyone, obviously, but it is well made: a hard-core zombie story that even vampire lovers can watch.'' 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY The topic this morning is the midterm elections, discussed here by Michael Steele, chairman of the Republican National Committee, and Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois. DAVISON--Mary, of Bayside, NY, died on October 28 at age 95. Loving wife to the late Dr. Selvan Davison. Mother to Ann and David. A beautiful strong woman. A Mt. Sinai trained nurse who practiced in the 1930s-40s. Her grandchildren Kate, Andrew, Rebecca and Eliza will miss their adored and adoring Grandma Mary. Her son-in-law Leonard Rubin and daughter-in-law Emily Davison loved her and she loved them. She had relatives and friends from many generations who exchanged love and affection with her for years. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Mary's Hospital for Children in Bayside, NY, or Visiting Nurse Service of New York.

LONDON -- The Ohio collector Harry Yeaggy brought home the top prize from Thursday's RM Auctions Automobiles of London sale, a 1964 Aston Martin DB5 James Bond film car from ''Goldfinger'' and ''Thunderball.'' The car sold for 2,600,000. With the addition of auction fees, the final figure is expected to be over $4,600,00.

A picture caption on Oct. 3 with a review about ''The Fiery Trial: Abraham Lincoln and American Slavery,'' by Eric Foner, included an erroneous date and description of a portrait of Lincoln and Sojourner Truth. The portrait was a painting, by Franklin C. Courter, made circa 1893, not an 1862 print, and it was not specifically intended to celebrate the Emancipation Proclamation. More information about the painting can be found at nytimes.com/papercuts.

Flights from the United States to Azerbaijan generally require at least one stopover, usually in Moscow or Istanbul. A recent online search found round-trip flights from Kennedy Airport to Baku on Aeroflot in late November starting at $763. Americans traveling to Azerbaijan must obtain an entry visa before their arrival in the country. WHERE TO STAY

KAMIN--Sherwin. We mourn the firm's co-founder Sherwin Kamin, who practiced law with us from 1968 until 2000. As a brilliant young tax partner, Sherwin joined with Lou Lowenstein and a group of other lawyers from Hays, Sklar & Herzberg, to combine with Kramer, Nessen & Hochman in forming Kramer Lowenstein Nessen & Kamin in 1968. The new firm's vision was a first class group of lawyers that would compete with the major firms of the day. Forty-two years after its founding, the firm is one of the country's largest top-tier firms. Sherwin, who had proven himself an intellectual powerhouse at City College and Harvard Law School, crafted a career remarkable in both depth and variety. He established, built and led the firm's tax and individual client groups, and mentored generations of younger lawyers. Sherwin was a keen intellect, eager to analyze and debate contentious and complex issues. He published numerous papers, and was an active contributor to the tax, and trust and estates sections of the American Bar Association and the New York State Bar Association. A steadfast friend, loyal partner, and all-around bon vivant, Sherwin's legacy and spirit continue to guide our firm. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his children, grandchildren and extended family. The partners, attorneys and staff of Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel LLP

CARRERE--Mary Ellis Tack, active in civic, charitable and social organizations, died quietly in her 93rd year at her home in Buenos Aires, Argentina. She grew up in New York City and later lived there during the war, and in Tulsa, Oklahoma and New Orleans where she lived for more than 65 years. Mrs. Carrere served as the First Lady of the Navy League of the United States in the 1970s travelling worldwide with her husband Ernest A. Carrere, who served as national president, and was a senior partner in the law firm Jones, Walker, Waechter, Poitevent, Carrere & Denegre and member of the Metropolitan Club of New York. Survived by six children: Theodore T. Carrere, Elizabeth L. Carrere, Robert A. Carrere, Sallie A. Miller, Mary Ellis Hasseltine and Ernest A. Carrere IV and was preceded in death by a son, Edward Donelson Carrere. Sister of Sue Tillman of Gulfport, Mississippi, the Reverend Theodore Tack, OSA of Tulsa, Oklahoma and the late Katherine Donelson Smith of New Orleans. In lieu of flowers, donations to Memorial Hall Museum at Historic Deerfield, Box 428, Deerfield MA 01342 or via deerfield-ma.org would be appreciated. Please contact pvmaoffice@deerfield.history.museum for additional information. Burial will be private and take place at Lake Lawn Metairie Cemetery in New Orleans.
LUSTIG--Irving M. 89, of Myrtle Beach, SC, died peacefully October 21, 2010. Survived by his beloved wife of 48 years, Adrienne M. Lustig. Rest In Peace My Love.

GETZLER--A.E. Loving husband of Doris Feder Getzler, beloved father of Renee (Joe) Septimus, Marian Getzler-(Jonathan) Kramer, Joel (Rachel Rand) Getzler, adored brother of Shelly (Lawrence) Horowitz, most caring grandfather of ten and great-grandfather of five.

KRASS--Alfred C.,born in Brooklyn, NY, lived in Levittown, died at St. Mary Medical Center on October 26, from complications from pneumonia. He was 74. Alfred was born into a Jewish family and converted to Christianity while at Amherst College. He attended Yale Divinity School, and was ordained a minister of the United Church of Christ in 1961. He spent his life in service to God and the people with and among whom he lived. A man of prayer, he had a strong passion for justice and peace, a great compassion for others, and an ever-growing understanding of all people as children of God. As he has said of himself, he began with evangelism and ended with peacemaking. He served as a missionary in Ghana, working in church planting, community development, and literacy. Then in New York City he was the evangelism consultant for the United Church Board for World Ministries. He studied at the New School for Social Research and received an MA in sociology. In Philadelphia, he participated in Jubilee Fellowship, an ecumenical house church, was an editor of The Other Side magazine, and did community organizing with the Southwest Germantown Association and Germantown Residents Acting to Conserve Energy. He was called as full time pastor to United Christian Church in 1987. He was the founder and first president of the Interfaith Housing Development Corporation. He also founded the Lower Bucks Center for Church and Community, and was active in peace projects with the Metropolitan Christian Council and The Pennsylvania Conference of the UCC. Alfred is survived by his wife of 48 years, Susan, his sons Thomas and Michael and his partner Anna Luten and their son Bruno. He is also survived by his older brother William Krasilovsky, and many nieces and nephews whom he loved. Services will be held on Tuesday, November 2, at 2pm at the Bucks County Presbyterian Church, 1550 Woodbourne Road, Levittown. Scattering of ashes and a reception follows at United Christian Church, 8525 New Falls Road, Levittown. Clergy of all faiths are invited to robe. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to United Christian Church, 8525 New Falls Road, Levittown, or Peaceful Living, an organization which provides loving services for people with mental retardation, 2210 Shelly Road, Suite 2, Harleysville, PA 19438.
Problems at All Levels To the Sports Editor:

THE Pied Piper was nowhere to be heard, and Santa Claus wouldn't be coming to town for a few more weeks, but something irresistible had drawn a small crowd to the West Fourth Street basketball courts in Greenwich Village on a recent Thursday morning. Huddled in groups of two and three, a few dozen men and women in their 20s and 30s glanced at one another and at their smartphones, rereading the Twitter and Foursquare messages that directed them here, waiting for something to happen. Without fanfare a white van sailed up to the curb, and from it emerged a thin, 58-year-old man -- wearing a gray suit, a tiny red bow tie and white loafers -- who seemed as uncertain to meet his fans as they were excited to receive him. The gathering parted as he stepped onto the blacktop, picked up a basketball and made a few graceless attempts at hurling it at a hoop. ''Yeah, match that,'' he said snidely, to laughter.

DUANE--Carolyn. It is with great sadness that we announce the death of Carolyn Philbin Duane on October 25, 2010. An extraordinary wife, mother, sister, and friend, Carolyn lived a full life and will be missed by all who knew her. She was the wife of the late Dr. Richard B. Duane, Jr. and is survived by her children; Kitty, Richard, Holly, and Bill, eight grandchildren and her brother, Ewing Philbin. Carolyn's indomitable spirit, grace and humor were with her to the end. Birding, gardening, tennis, travel, and opera, were just a few of her lifelong passions. A memorial service will be held on Friday, October 29, at 11am at The All Saints Memorial Church in Navesink, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to The All Saints Memorial Church or the The Monmouth Conservation Foundation.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''N.F.L. Crackdown Tests Limits of Mayhem,'' Oct. 24: I do not watch football for the hard hits, and I find it hard to believe that much of America does either. Every team is capable of bone-crushing tackles, but fans tend to watch for the hope of a win. Thus, strengthening the punishment for helmet-to-helmet contact will have no influence on the N.F.L.'s popularity in America.

DAVID BLAINE, who has shivered inside ice blocks in Times Square and floated in a water-filled sphere on Oprah Winfrey's talk show, put the handcuffs on my wrists, talking about Harry Houdini the whole time. ''For him,'' he said as we stood inside the Jewish Museum, at 1109 Fifth Avenue (92nd Street), where an exhibition on Houdini opened on Friday, ''sometimes the difficult thing was keeping the handcuffs on.''

She was a woman of extraordinary taste with a great appetite for life. A memorial service will be held in late December in her beloved New York City.

IN a bit of magic sure to be included on the DVD of the new film version of ''The Tempest,'' Russell Brand, the British comedian and actor, offers his take on the jester Trinculo. Sitting at a rehearsal across a plastic table from Alfred Molina, who plays his comic partner, Stefano, Mr. Brand is asked by an off-camera Julie Taymor, the film's director, simply to introduce himself as Trinculo. It's as if she had lighted a bottle rocket. Mr. Brand takes off, fully in character, long legs folding and unfolding under him as he unpacks a Shakespearean origins myth, riffing through a magpie's love of shiny things, the glow of a king's approbations, the jester's high-low perch and, of course, God and nature's destructive habits.

Broncos (2-5) at 49ers (1-6) in LondonSunday, 1 p.m.Line: 49ers by 1 1/2 The British gave us awkward comedy, so it's only fair that we send them awkward football. Ricky Gervais for Josh McDaniels: an equitable tit-for-tat. We could wow the English with the Saints and Steelers or export superstars like Tom Brady and gimpy Brett Favre, but no one can top the Broncos and 49ers when it comes to squirmy laughs.

Loving grandfather of Justin, Christopher, Benjamin and Danielle. Lawrence was a senior partner at Smith & Smith PC, Attorneys in New York City. Funeral Service will be held 10am on Monday, November 1st at Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. Should friends desire, contributions may be made in his memory to the Huntington Foundation of America.

THE 1980s were a time of general excess. But the emergence of a band of Belgian designers dedicated to a radically deconstructed vision of dress signaled a mucking out of fashion's Augean stables. Out with pouf skirts, in with sweaters made of old socks. Abetting this brave new look were the makeup artist Inge Grognard and her husband, the photographer Ronald Stoops. Working on magazine shoots and runway shows for Dries Van Noten, Walter Van Beirendonck, Dirk Van Saene and, perhaps most famously, Martin Margiela, the couple created some of the most arresting images of the '90s. Ms. Grognard said, ''It's the little mistakes or defaults that really make someone beautiful.'' The couple's long-awaited first book, ''Inge Grognard/Ronald Stoops,'' published by Ludion, comes out this month. NANCY MacDONELL

HAMER--Joseph M.,78, Retired Actor, died on October 15, 2010. Beloved father of Christopher Hamer of Seattle, Michael Hamer of New York City and Vanessa Hamer of East Hampton. Loving grandfather of Aiden. He is predeceased by his wife, Susan Lynn Martin and survived by his former wife, Patricia M. Draper of Sun Valley, ID. Mr. Hamer was born in Dayton, Ohio. He got involved in acting as an Undergraduate at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio. Joe received a Master's Degree in Theatre from UCLA and did Doctoral Thesis work at Ohio State. He appeared on Broadway in "The Great White Hope" and acted in over 300 TV and Radio commercials and several soap operas and TV movies. Joseph was an active member of the Player's Club in Gramercy Park until his retirement in 1993. Graveside services will be held at Calvary Cemetery, Dayton, Ohio on Thursday, November 4th at 1pm.

ATLANTA -- Federal vaccine advisers on Thursday began the delicate task of deciding whether two vaccines against sexually transmitted infections that can result in genital warts and cancers should be used more widely in boys and young men. Concerns about whether to vaccinate against a sexually transmitted disease are made even more charged because much of the serious disease results from homosexual sex. The advisers must also decide whether vaccinating boys would divert scarce resources from a vaccination campaign for girls that has had poor results.

PHILADELPHIA -- The battle for control of Congress rolled into a frenetic final weekend as Democrats fought to preserve the Senate as their power center on Capitol Hill, trying to hold off a Republican surge that could reshape the political order in Washington. With Republicans in a strong position to capture the House, President Obama on Saturday opened a four-state weekend swing here to rally support for Senate candidates in Connecticut, Illinois, Ohio and Pennsylvania, hoping to build a critical firewall to protect the party's Senate majority from Republican gains across the country.

An article in some copies last Sunday about Horseman's Hollow, a new Halloween attraction in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y., that features historical characters like Major John André, the British spy, misidentified the nearby town where he was hanged. It was Tappan -- not Tarrytown, where he was captured.

San Francisco AT the annual South by Southwest gathering of techies in Austin, Tex., in March, conference organizers had chosen a hangar-size room to accommodate their star speaker: Evan Williams, the co-founder of Twitter, the messaging and social networking site that had become a digital phenomenon.

TRABERMAN--Ellen Ellen Traberman, 47, died peacefully at home in Hoboken, NJ, surrounded by her family, on September 21, 2010. The cause of death was metastatic breast cancer. A wonderful wife, sweet sister, loving daughter, cherished aunt and loyal friend to many, Ellen left an indelible mark on all who knew her during her too short life. Ellen enjoyed traveling the world in style. She was a caring and intuitive person who had the gift of instantly connecting with people. Many sought Ellen's advice and guidance, as she cared deeply about those around her, and they trusted her wisdom, insight, and skill in helping them find solutions to life's challenges. Ellen eagerly passed along her "life lessons" to those special young people in her life. Ellen earned a BBA in Finance from Emory University in 1984, and an MBA from Rider University in 1991. Ellen had a notable career, primarily as a senior sales and marketing executive at a number of large corporations where she led many award winning sales teams. Ellen was cremated and her remains were scattered in the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Old Saybrook, CT on October 8, 2010. Survived by her loving husband Ralph Pignatelli, mother Tama, father Meyer, brother Peter, sister Sara, brother-in-law Elliot, niece Stephanie, and nephew Garrett, all of whom, along with extended family and many friends, mourn her loss. She brightened our lives - a woman whose goodness, generosity and sweetness will stay with all of us in our hearts and minds forever.

ALLISON--Mary Emma. The US Fund for UNICEF mourns the passing of Mary Emma Allison, co-founder of "Trick-or-Treat for UNICEF," who died on October 27th, at age 93. In 1947, after a busy Halloween night, Mrs. Allison told her husband, the Reverend Clyde Allison: "It's too bad we can't turn this into something good." This notion grew into the nation's longest-running youth service program, which has raised nearly $160 million and helped save millions of young lives. Our debt is enormous, and we remember Mrs. Allison with abiding gratitude and love. Undoubtedly, the children we serve would say the same, if given the opportunity. To post a condolence, please visit unicefusa.org/allisontribute.

RAVEN--Barbara, October 18 at age 75. Barbara was Minister of the Chaplain Program and Director Of Pastoral Care at Unity of New York, a beloved member of the Unity family. She is survived by her niece, nephews and cousins, and by many dearly beloved lifelong friends. All who knew Barbara will miss her love, friendship, humor, and spirit of determination, a living example of courage and strength. A celebration of Barbara's life will be held on December 19 at 2:30pm at Symphony Space, 95th Street and Broadway.

EVERITT--Sylvia, 89, formerly of Great Neck, NY, died peacefully on October 28, 2010. She was predeceased by her devoted and adoring husband, Edgar Everitt, her son David Everitt and her first husband, Sam Kramer, who was killed during the last days of World War II. She is survived by her loving daughter, Judith Everitt, son-in-law John Abrams, daughter-in-law Laurie Everitt and grandsons: Ethan and Seth Abrams and Anthony and Gregory Everitt. Sylvia was one of the first women welders to work in the Brooklyn Navy Yard during WWII and later she served as a social worker assisting blinded veterans. We already miss her love laughter and strudel. Please visit TheKimbleFuneralHome.com to extend condolences to her family.

EISENBERG--Joyce Diane, 70, died peacefully surrounded by family on Friday October 29, 2010. Joyce is survived by a grateful family, including her devoted husband Arnold married for 50 years, her three children and their spouses, David and Cindy Eisenberg of Bal Harbour, Karyn and Mark (Pappas) of New York City, and Julie and Michael (Pitman) of New York City, and her five glorious adoring grandchildren Sophia, Theodora, Zoe, Bella and Lola. Joyce lived a remarkable and fulfilling life and will be remembered for her caring and compassion, her grace and elegance, her positive outlook and selfless approach to life. Joyce was a "giver", someone who routinely put others before herself; in that way she remains an inspiration to all who had the privilege to know her. All her tender qualities were complimented by a lust for life and a well-honed pragmatic view of the world. She will be deeply missed by all. Service Monday, November 1st 11:30am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St, New York City.

But there's an undercard as well -- there typically is -- and even if it's received scant attention by comparison, don't think it doesn't matter. His beard, it was said, was longer than God's but not as long as Charles Darwin's. Thousands of books teetered perilously in his office, and a motion-sensitive door startled visitors with cricket chirps. He took notes on his own thoughts while conversing with others. The evolutionary biologist Leigh Van Valen's eccentricities were legend far beyond the University of Chicago, where brilliant and idiosyncratic professors rule. He named 20 fossil mammals he had discovered after characters in J. R. R. Tolkien's fiction, and his most famous hypothesis -- among the most cited in the literature of evolution -- was named for the Red Queen in Lewis Carroll's ''Through the Looking Glass.''

DAUB--Harold, age 93, formerly of Roslyn, New York, passed away on October 21, 2010 in Boca Raton, Florida. He is survived by his widow, Ruth Daub, to whom he was married for 67 years; and his children, Madeline (Stanley) Kanter of Barrington, Rhode Island; JoAnn Daub of Great Neck, New York; and Peter Daub of Washington, D.C.; together with his grandchildren, David Kanter (Peggy Wu) and Joshua Kanter (Francine Silverman) and his great-grandchildren, Gabriel Kanter and Natalie Kanter. Dubby, an avid gin and pinochle player, will be missed by all. Donations can be made in his memory to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407.

THE phone calls roll into Andrew M. Cuomo's campaign headquarters all day long, each one a tinder box: Why do no African-Americans live in Westchester? How dare Mr. Cuomo take his daughters to a gay pride parade? Does Mr. Cuomo know that hydrofracking will destroy upstate New York, and what is his position? Now someone on the line -- he is 81 and persistent -- wants to talk to the attorney general, whom he calls Andy. He is a case for Marilyn Thornton, the doyenne of the volunteer corps by dint of maturity, experience and temperament. She can sweet-talk a daisy into bloom on a snowy day -- a phone conversation that begins with a duel often ends in a truce, or better.

KATE MOSS'S slinky dresses, cigarette pants, downtown tees and furry jackets have become even cooler -- and more accessible -- since Topshop globalized her high-low, devil-may-care style. So when it was announced that the Kate Moss for Topshop winter collection, which is being released on Tuesday, would be her last, it was the High Street shot heard around the world. The swan song collaboration features nine of Ms. Moss's favorite pieces, including boho capes, vintage-inspired floral dresses and chiffon maxi-skirts. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

ENDERTON--Herbert B.,Professor Emeritus of Mathematics at UCLA and reviews editor for the Journal of Symbolic Logic, died October 20 at age 74. Author of the popular texts "A Mathematical Introduction to Logic," "Elements of Set Theory," and the recently completed "Computability Theory," Enderton lived in Santa Monica. He is survived by sons Eric and Bert, a granddaughter, and his loving wife of 49 years, Cathy.

SUYDAM--Lispenard, died peacefully in Exeter, NH at the age of 92 on October 26th. He was born on September 11, 1918 in Blue Point, NY. He was predeceased by his father, Walter Lispenard Suydam II, his mother, Elizabeth Suydam, his brother, Joseph Suydam, and his sister Elizabeth Von Briesen. Liz or Lizard, as he was affectionately known, graduated from the Stonybrook School, in Stonybrook, NY and Colgate University, Class of 1942. During World War II, he served with distinction in the Coast Guard. While on a troop ship off Singapore, his ship was torpedoed but he endured. Lispenard worked at the Brookaven National Laboratory as an administrator from 1950 until his retirement in 1977. For the next 20 plus years he happily resided in the coastal communities of South Bristol and New Harbor, ME with his wife of 67 years, Peggy. Lispenard, who described people he truly admired as "solid citizens" was truly one himself. He served on the Blue Point School Committee, was commodore of the Bellport Yacht Club as well as the Pattersquash Gunner's Club and the Great South Bay Scooter Club. Additionally, he was a lifelong member of the Holland, St. Nicholas and Bellport Historical Societies and the Suffolk County Marine Museum. Lastly, he was one of the last remaining "bay men" of the Great South Bay whether winning the Queen of the Bay Regatta in his Senta or duck hunting or scootering over a frozen bay. Lispenard was a gifted craftsman who could fix almost anything even though his meticulous approach often took longer than projected. But the finished product was done "just right." Probably, one of the happiest days of his life took place on July 4, 1962 when his three sons won each of their divisions in the Babylon Yacht Club Regatta. He simply levitated with joy! Lispenard is survived by his wife, Peggy Suydam, and his sons: Walter Lispenard Suydam III and his partner Elizabeth Parker, Bryce Card Suydam and his wife, Maryann and Peter Van Cortlandt Suydam and his partner, Sally Vittum. Additionally, he is survived by four grandchildren and six nieces and nephews. He will be missed for his outstanding sense of humor, integrity and loyalty. And, in the end, he truly felt blessed to have lived a wonderful life.

THE NEWS Two packages containing explosive devices shipped from Yemen and bound for synagogues in Chicago were intercepted in Britain and Dubai, setting off a global terror alert Friday that included searching other planes. BEHIND THE NEWS The explosives were packed in toner cartridges for computer printers. Speaking at the White House late Friday afternoon, President Obama called the packages a ''credible terrorist threat against our country.'' Both contained PETN, according to Representative Jane Harman, a California Democrat; the same explosive was sewn into the underwear of a Nigerian man who tried to blow up a commercial airliner over Detroit on Christmas Day. American officials said they were tipped off to the explosives by the intelligence service in Saudi Arabia and emphasized that they were looking for additional explosives. The attempted terror attack emerged just four days before the 2010 midterm elections. For months, issues of national security and terrorism have taken a back seat to concerns about the sluggish economy. ''The events of the past 24 hours underscores the necessity of remaining vigilant against terrorism,'' Mr. Obama said.

Nissan is recalling about 747,000 vehicles in the United States for a possible stalling problem, the automaker said on Thursday in a news release. The recall covers about 2.2 million vehicles worldwide.

LAST Sunday, we showcased several reimaginations of the iconic New York City subway map by prominent artists and designers. At the same time, we invited readers to make their own maps, using a special interactive tool on our Web site. There were maps that analyzed the subway by race and maps that looked at its geography. Maps of the city's nightlife and maps focused on tourism. There were maps that were primarily about color and others primarily about shapes. Maps by lifelong New Yorkers and a few by people living far away. And there were maps with a message (not one but two about the much-loved but oft-ignored G train between Brooklyn and Queens).

My wife and I are planning to travel to Portugal for a three-week trip that will include Christmas and New Year's. We would appreciate suggestions as to how we might best enjoy these holidays while we are there. We also wonder if any regions of the country have particularly distinctive celebrations. George Helmkamp, Kansas City, Mo. A.To help answer your question, I turned to Mario Fernandes, a writer for GoLisbon.com, a guide to the city of Lisbon and other parts of Portugal. In an e-mail, he wrote that holiday decorations are put up in Lisbon in late October or early November, with lights covering most of the downtown area. Visit the city's main Christmas tree, which usually sits at the top of Parque Eduardo VII, Lisbon's ''Central Park,'' with views of the historical center (the location has not yet been confirmed for this year). He added that the trees that have gone up the last couple of years (above) were said to be Europe's largest. (The trees are artificial, and the design changes every year.)

WHEN it comes to superhero movies, today's audiences come loaded with certain expectations: an emotional origin story, a menacing villain and the dynamic triumph of good over evil. The filmmakers behind the 3-D animated comedy ''Megamind,'' who have feasted on a steady diet of these movies over the years, embrace the genre's staples in their creation but still manage to find an original twist: Their film is not based on a prior comic strip and it puts a superhero's archenemy front and center. Will Ferrell provides the voice of Megamind, an odd character who, as a baby, is sent away in a pod from his home planet just before it is destroyed. His nemesis, Metro Man (Brad Pitt), is dispatched at the same time, but while his pod lands into a home of privilege, Megamind's lands in a prison. Because of his intelligence, awkwardness, outcast status and the ability to be very good at being bad, he takes on the role of supervillain and begins a regular battle with Metro Man to take over Metro City.

PERHAPS the biggest perk of being a fashion designer is not the ability to design for yourself but for your children. Just ask Stella McCartney. The designer is about to bring her fourth child into the world, and introduce a collection on Wednesday specifically for the 12-and-under set. Pieces like cashmere-blend pea jackets and floral dresses are designed to be affordable (the line is priced from $20 for T-shirts to $155 for jackets) and timeless so that you don't have to choose between dressing your children well and sending them to college. Still, Ms. McCartney knows that as fashion consumers go, children are as fickle as anyone. ''My daughter is 3 and deep in the pink thing,'' she said, ''and I have to remind myself she will probably hate it in six months.'' ALIX BROWNE

Even hipsters have to grow up - or, in this case, move farther downtown. A fixture on Ludlow Street since 1992, TG170, Terri Gillis's quirky-cool clothing store, has moved down the street into more streamlined digs designed by the architect Philip Otto. More Chelsea gallery than boho hangout, the store remains true to its curatorial spirit, with artwork by Rich Jacobs and Mike Mills interspersed with Gillis's collection of concrete garden animals, and signage by the graphic designer Chris Rubino. On the racks: indie labels like Corell & Corell, Hazel Brown, Mociun and Hengst. TG170, at 77 Ludlow Street; (212) 995-8660, or tg170.com. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A COUPLE of weeks ago, an old man living near the airport called Carl P. Paladino's campaign headquarters in downtown Buffalo. He wanted to offer his services -- actually, his roof. Every plane arriving at or departing from Buffalo Niagara International passed directly over his house, in Cheektowaga. While normally a bother, the situation was -- in an election year, he sensed -- a golden opportunity. Any chance, he asked, that he could get a giant Paladino sign? And a young guy with a ladder?

IN a bit of magic sure to be included on the DVD of the new film version of ''The Tempest,'' Russell Brand, the British comedian and actor, offers his take on the jester Trinculo. Sitting at a rehearsal across a plastic table from Alfred Molina, who plays his comic partner, Stefano, Mr. Brand is asked by an off-camera Julie Taymor, the film's director, simply to introduce himself as Trinculo. It's as if she had lighted a bottle rocket. Mr. Brand takes off, fully in character, long legs folding and unfolding under him as he unpacks a Shakespearean origins myth, riffing through a magpie's love of shiny things, the glow of a king's approbations, the jester's high-low perch and, of course, God and nature's destructive habits.

Hilton Hotels and Resorts is introducing a new, separate spa brand, the eforea: spa at Hilton. The first of 80 planned outposts opens today, at the Hilton Short Hills, in New Jersey, and several others will follow in the coming month, in hotels in Pattaya, Thailand, and Melbourne, Australia, among others. Many of Hilton's 123 current spas -- and most of its new ones -- will adopt eforea's concept. Its look is sleek, simple and modern. Rectangular pods dot the spa's transitional and thermal lounges, including dry and wet change pods, and sauna and steam pods. There is also a Vichy Shower Room, and private treatment rooms with showers and comfortable seating.

ARLINGTON, Tex. - The Giants' pitching coach, Dave Righetti, said he was concerned about the drop in starter Jonathan Sanchez's velocity recently, and thinks it could be attributable to fatigue at the end of a long season. Sanchez struggled early in Game 3 of the World Series on Saturday, allowing four runs on six hits, including Mitch Moreland's three-run homer in the second inning of the Rangers' 4-2 victory. He also could not get out of the third inning of his previous start, in Game 6 of the National League Championship Series. ''I'm definitely concerned about it,'' Righetti said. ''He's a young guy, and he's been through a lot. He carried us here, and you know what? He's going to say he's fine, but yeah, it's something. It's definitely a concern.

Americans don't save enough. In 2005, Americans' personal savings rate was negative for the first time since the Great Depression ─ instead of piling up savings, we are piling up debt. According to Financial Engines, an investment advisory firm that has surveyed the 401(k) retirement savings plans of 2.8 million people, only 28 percent of savers are on track to retire on 70 percent of our final salaries ─ and 70 percent may not be adequate to pay for health costs or travel. Several readers have objected to my assertion, in today's column, that Social Security was passed "amid strong economic growth, rather than at the bottom of a recession." After all, wasn't the program created during the Great Depression? So it was - but not, crucially, during F.D.R.'s first year in office, 1933, when the unemployment rate crested at 25 percent and economic growth was nowhere to be seen. Instead, the program was signed into law in August 1935, by which point the jobless rate was down to 20 percent and falling and the economy was growing at a brisk 8.9 percent clip, after growing by over 10 percent in 1934. By way of contrast, Barack Obama signed the health care bill in March of 2010, when unemployment had barely ticked down from its Great Recession high and G.D.P. growth was still anemic - as, indeed, it remains to this day. Of course it goes without saying that the overall economic situation was worse in the Depression. But Roosevelt could legitimately claim that the country had turned the corner (and, just as importantly, that the 1934 midterms had confirmed his political mandate) by the time he turned from economic policy to old-age entitlements. Obama, on the other hand, got his entitlement passed in the first 15 months of his administration - but one of the (many) reasons it's been a harder sell than Social Security, I suspect, is that the country is still waiting for real growth to return.

We're about to discuss zombies, so you can see the cannibalism joke coming a mile away: viewers ate up the premiere of "The Walking Dead," the new AMC series, adapted from the comic books written by Robert Kirkman, about humans struggling to survive in a world overrun by flesh-eating ghouls. The first episode of the show, which had the good fortune to make its debut on Halloween night at 10 P.M., was watched by 5.3 million people, AMC said, making it the largest audience for any original series on the channel. (By comparison, the season finale of the AMC drama "Mad Men," on which the dead do not reawaken and are simply made fodder for black comedy, drew 2.44 million viewers.) Not surprisingly, "The Walking Dead" performed particularly strongly with audience members aged 18 to 49, drawing 3.6 million viewers in that demographic. In a statement, AMC president Charlie Collier said, "It's a good day to be dead," and we'll just leave it at that.

Battle lines have been hardening over the proposed Keystone XL pipeline over the last couple of weeks. The pipeline, which will stretch from Alberta in Canada to refineries on the Gulf Coast, would nearly double the United States' capacity to import oil made from Canadian oil sands. Canadian oil sands are a plentiful and secure source of oil, but the extraction process is high in carbon dioxide emissions and takes a toll on pristine Canadian forest ecosystems.

As long as I'm writing about where the Democrats went astray, I should say something about the liberal enthusiasm for political science models "proving" that structural factors and only structural factors - unemployment, changes in personal income, the number of seats in play - explain the Democratic Party's looming midterm rout. The Democrats would need to lose more than 45 seats in the House of Representatives, Jonathan Chait recently argued, citing one such academic model, for this election to count as a real referendum on Obama's leadership. Invoking a different political scientist, Kevin Drum suggested that "about 70 percent of the seat changes" this Tuesday are the result of forces beyond the Democrats' control, leaving just 30 percent of any conservative swing to be pinned on day-to-day politics and policy choices.

Women's Wear Daily, the quippy and quirky trade paper of the garment industry, marked its centennial with a commemorative magazine out Monday that traces the evolution of fashion and also of its own coverage of fashion. For the cover, its editors came up with a pretty novel approach to illustrating 100 years of putting out a paper: a montage of notable designers, celebrities and socialites assembled as if they were the audience of a runway show. Yves Saint Laurent, Coco Chanel, Karl Lagerfeld, Ralph Lauren and Jackie Kennedy are in the front row; Andy Warhol, Claude Montana and Cindy Crawford are all the way in the back, so you can't imagine that anyone will be complaining too much about their placement (as long as they were included).

We are midway through the current season of "Dexter'', and we can certainly see a glimpse of what is to come: Lumen and Dexter are soulmates, two people whose psychologies have been shaped almost entirely by extreme violence. The final scene with them in Rita's old bathroom perfectly evoked their like-mindedness and their potential for the kind of real connection that Dexter has never experienced. Yet it also revealed his totalizing fear of actually having that kind of bond.Michael C. Hall's performance here was really powerful: his face seemed to quiver and his body to recoil without actually doing so, as Lumen outlined her biography -- her fear of marriage and of stifling convention, her need to breathe and experience thrills in life beyond having the right kind of china. Of course, this terror of dull, suburban normalcy is exactly what keeps Dexter so restive. He saw himself with frightening clarity in Lumen and is clearly afraid of what it might mean that the fates have delivered to him a woman who would not only accept his proclivities but also share them.

The prime restaurant location for visitors to BAM has changed hands but remains in a Germanic mode like its predecessor, Thomas Beisl. Ursula and Jonas Hegewisch, she from Chicago, he from Hamburg, Germany, both once living and working in Berlin, have found room to display their collection of vintage pewter bric-a-brac, including a few gnomes. "We wanted to recreate the real Berlin atmosphere, Ms. Hegewisch said. The chef, Steven Linares, is "learning to prepare German food," she said. Among the dishes are a type of corned beef mixed like a hash with beets and pickles, spatezle with cheese, some sausages, and maultaschen, a kind of big ravioli with a vegetable filling served in mushroom broth. Rote grutze, a red berry dessert, will be on the dessert menu, and German and Austrian selections will dominate the wine list. The tent on the west side of the restaurant is winterized and will open in a couple of weeks to expand the seating; 25 Lafayette Avenue (Ashland Place), (718) 222-5800.

In 1924, the French designer Jean-Michel Frank collaborated with Hermès on a collection of furniture, including the Confortable armchair and sofa, the elegant, cubic forms of which made it one of the most admired - and widely copied - designs of the 20th century. This month in Paris, for the inauguration of its new home division, Maison, Hermès is reintroducing these and other Frank pieces, including a straw-marquetry screen, a shagreen-covered vanity and the designer's X-base dining table. Robert Chavez, the president and C.E.O. of Hermès USA, sees ''a very exciting potential in the U.S.'' for the Jean-Michel Frank by Hermès collection, given the customer demand for furniture with the Hermès label. Previously, the company's furniture was limited to Pippa, a small collection by the architect Rena Dumas, who designed Hermès stores and who was married to Jean-Louis Dumas, the chairman of Hermès from 1978 to 2006. (Rena died in 2009, and Jean-Louis in May.) Their son, Pierre-Alexis Dumas, the company's artistic director and a sixth-generation member of the founding Hermès family, said starting Maison with historic designs was a deliberate strategy: ''We had to go backward to understand our roots and to go forward into the future.'' And in that future - April 2011, to be exact - the company will unveil further Maison collections, this time by a roster of (yet to be revealed) contemporary designers.

Extensive testing of Gulf of Mexico seafood by federal scientists has found only minute traces of the dispersant Corexit, which was used to break up oil from the BP spill, officials say. Apparently not even Mr. Springsteen himself can resist the temptation: in Thom Zimny's new video for the song "Save My Love," from Mr. Springsteen's coming album "The Promise," the Boss gets to revisit the glory days of 1977 as he and his bandmates were gearing up to record "Darkness on the Edge of Town." Don't be put off by the inclusion of requisite scenes and familiar nuggets of dialogue from "Citizen Kane," "Sunset Boulevard" and "Jaws" in Turner Classic Movies' seven-part documentary series "Moguls and Movie Stars: A History of Hollywood," which premieres Monday night. The program is far less interested in myth-telling than in breaking down the gears of Tinseltown's myth machine. "Unlike a lot of histories that have been made, we're not a series of clips of the highlights of the great movies," says Jon Wilkman, the series' director, writer and producer. Instead, he tells The Moment, it's about "how Hollywood functioned. It's a history of Hollywood power - who had it, how'd they get it, what they did with it and how'd they lose it."
