BERGMAN--Ruth, nee Adell, a beautiful person, passed away exactly as she wanted to: peacefully, quickly, painlessly. Supportive, loving mother to Penny Bergman Schenkel and Jody Gottlieb, and to grandchildren Michelle, Jenna, William and Skylar. Devoted to dear brother Leonard Adell, sister-in-law Bernice Adell, sister Lillian and brother-in-law Sam Robbins (both deceased). Cherished aunt of nieces Sheri Robbins and Sheila Charton. Born to Sam and Minnie Adell. Raised in Brooklyn. Graduated James Madison High School and attended F.I.T. Ruth was a successful independent business woman. She believed in Hadassah, intellectual curiosity, women's rights and liberal causes. Cancer survivor. The extended families of the Adells, Bergmans, Gottliebs, Robbins, Chartons, Rubinsteins and Bauers, along with her many wonderful friends, will miss her kindness to everyone.

The Texans rushed for 257 yards in a 34-24 win over the Colts in the season opener, but those numbers don't convey how crazy the game was. The teams combined for 48 first downs, Peyton Manning threw 57 passes, and each team scored two fourth-quarter touchdowns. Indianapolis must overcome injuries to avoid a first-ever sweep by Houston. The Colts listed 12 players on their injury report, but the report does not include Dallas Clark and Bob Sanders (out for the season) or the suspended punter Pat McAfee. The surprising young stars who helped them through last year's injury crisis, like Pierre Garcon and Austin Collie, are banged up, so the Colts are counting on another batch of surprising young stars like Blair White to step in. Pick: Texans. MIKE TANIER

While this college football season has not provided the relentless spate of high-caliber upsets like the 2007 season, when Louisiana State won the national title with two losses, it certainly has delivered on surprises. Consider that with five full weeks remaining in the regular season, three of the top five teams in the Bowl Championship Series standings - No. 3 Texas Christian, No. 4 Boise State and No. 5 Utah - come from outside of college football's six power conferences. And consider some of the axis-shifting data that has defined this wacky season. Nevada is ranked higher in the B.C.S. than Florida. Mississippi State is ranked higher than Virginia Tech. Baylor is ranked higher than Michigan. Syracuse is ranked higher than Miami. All of those teams are ranked higher than Texas, which has fallen so far and so fast that no one really raised an eyebrow when the Longhorns lost to Baylor on Saturday night.

The Federal Trade Commission announced Wednesday that it would cease its inquiry into Google's collection of consumer data transmitted over wireless networks by its Street View cars. In a letter issued Wednesday morning, David C. Vladek, the director of the bureau of consumer protection, cited the steps the company had taken in response to concerns that it had collected unencrypted ''payload data,'' including the appointment of a director of privacy for engineering and product management, additional staff training on privacy issues and the incorporation of a new privacy review process for new initiatives.

MADRID -- Twenty-one years ago, Antonio Meño Ortega, a keen mountaineer and law student in Madrid, slipped into a coma after being accidentally deprived of oxygen while undergoing cosmetic surgery on his nose. Since then, his parents have fought a desperate public legal battle to demonstrate that medical negligence led to their son's plight, in the process losing their fruit store and their house, and still owing nearly $555,000 in legal bills.

With Election Day a day away, political ads filling prime-time TV, and dozens of Congressional seats up for grabs, a look at the Senate candidate Web sites shows two Tea Party-backed candidates drawing the most traffic. Rand Paul, above, who is running against Jack Conway in Kentucky, had the largest share in the week ending Oct. 23. Joe Miller, who is running against Scott McAdams in Alaska, was No. 3. That race also features a write-in campaign by Senator Lisa Murkowski, who was defeated by Mr. Miller in the Republican primary.

(ABC) DANCING WITH THE STARS Helio Castroneves, Kelly Osbourne, Mel B., Drew Lachey, Gilles Marini and Emmitt Smith take turns at the judges' table as the six remaining couples trot and twirl across the ballroom floor in this 200th episode. WOLGEL--Harold H.,on October 29, 2010 at age 90. Loving husband of Betty Wolgel. Devoted father of Susan, Barbara (Henry), and Amy. Adored grandfather of Alissa, David, Rachel, Joshua, and Daniel. Cherished brother of Marjorie and the late Milton. A graduate of City College and Columbia Law School, he served in the U.S. Army, he was a partner in the law firm of Gottesman, Wolgel, Malamy, Flynn & Weinberg, a past-president of Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, a member of the Nassau County Human Rights Commission and active in B'nai B'rith, the Great Neck PTAs, and the Great Neck Democratic Club. A man of great intelligence and valor. He will be missed by many. Services were held Sunday, October 31, 2010, at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY.

Barnes & Noble on Tuesday introduced a new color version of its digital e-reader called the Nook Color, which comes with a new Google Android operating system. The announcement took place at an elaborate press conference in New York, with dancers, actors and a storyline about a modern-day reader who enjoys consuming digital books.

VAN LEEUWEN--Leon B. "Butje", 87, died October 29, 2010. Born in Rotterdam he immigrated to New York during WW II. He was quick with a smile and a joke, and is remembered by family and friends for his warm heart, generosity and twinkling eyes.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about Microsoft's results for the first quarter of its current fiscal year misstated the company's revenue for the first quarter of last year. It was $12.9 billion, not $15.8 billion.

Two old media outlets, ABC and CBS, have new media partners for Tuesday's midterm elections. ABC is live-streaming its election night special reports on Facebook; CBS is collaborating with Google to mine search results and YouTube video viewing trends.

REIF--Dr. Irving Lester, 99, died October 30 of cancer. Beloved husband to Natalie Wilder Reif, beloved father to Karla Reif-Teitler of Brooklyn; Robin Reif of Manhattan; Henry Reif of London, England; Jessica Reif Cohen of Manhattan and Nancy Reif of Roseland, N.J., beloved father-in-law to Jay Teitler and Bob Cohen; adored grandfather to Amanda, Joshua, Kara, Marisa, Sophia, AJ and Vanessa. He was a family doctor in Brooklyn for 60 years, making house calls to the very end. In WWII, he was Regimental Surgeon of the Rainbow Division's 232nd, one of three U.S. units to liberate Dachau on April 29, 1945. He was decorated for organizing field hospitals in the Bad Gastein Valley for concentration camp survivors. Prior to the war, he was a physician in the Civilian Conservation Corps. His great passions in life were his family, medicine, social justice and the Brooklyn Dodgers. He never forgave them for moving to L.A. He also loved the New York Times Obituary section which he read every day, with a sense of triumph at outliving nearly everyone. Always his own man--irreverent, blunt, bowing to no one--there was no one like him, nor will there ever be. He will be greatly mourned and missed. The family will hold a private service.

KAVALER--Lucy Estrin, 87, died on October 30. Beloved wife of Arthur for 62 years, mother of Roger and Andrea, sister of Anne Maurer. Warm and charming, Lucy had grace and beauty, loved by her many friends. Graduate of Oberlin College and became an accomplished author of 17 books, including "The Astors," "Mushrooms, Molds & Miracles," and "Heroes & Lovers." Had highly successful career as magazine editor, including The Female Patient and Skin Cancer Journal. Services: Tuesday November 2 12:45pm, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76th St, New York City.

Theodore C. Sorensen, one of the last links to John F. Kennedy's administration, a writer and counselor who did much to shape the president's narrative, image and legacy, died Sunday in Manhattan. He was 82. His death, at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, was from complications of a stroke he suffered a week ago, his wife, Gillian Sorensen, said.

Talk about a mismatch. Time magazine's election preview issue contains four separate inside covers, each one featuring a Republican or Tea Party candidate prominent in politics this year: Rand Paul, Meg Whitman, Marco Rubio and Christine O'Donnell.

An article on Thursday about Searchlight, Nev., hometown of the Senate majority leader, referred incorrectly to a thoroughfare named for him in a forlorn part of town. As a photograph with the article showed, it is Harry Reid Road, not Street.

A film review on Friday about ''Last Play at Shea,'' a documentary about Billy Joel's two Shea Stadium concerts in July 2008, misstated the number of times Mr. Joel was divorced. It is three times, not two.

FUCHS--Stanley. Beloved and most treasured love of Caryl for nearly 59 years. Dearest and proud father of his children Robin, Steven, Debbie, Charlie, and Joanna. Delightful and endearing grandpa of Alex, Randi, Jared, Michael, Daniel, and Hailey. He lived life to the fullest and was an avid tennis player, sailor, golfer, and fabulous dancer. He made everything possible for his family and for others as well. He always gave with a full heart and will be remembered in our hearts forever. Services: Monday 10:15am at Beth El Synagogue, Northfield Road, New Rochelle, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in his name to your favorite charity or to Beth El Synagogue.

ELECTION DAY COUNTDOWN Tuesday is the big day, when voters finally head to the polls. But Monday kicks off a stream of last-minute campaigning, with many of the big names out in full force. Michelle Obama is going to Pennsylvania for an event with Representative Joe Sestak, the Democratic candidate for Senate. Then she is off to Nevada to help Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader.

ROSENBERGER--Carl M.,63, of Bonita Springs, FL passed away October 28, 2010 after a brief illness. He was a Captain in the U.S. Army and distinguished veteran of the Vietnam War. Carl was an Executive at the Bank of New York (New York City) before retiring and moving to Bonita Springs. Son of the late Carl A. and Lorraine P. Rosenberger, beloved husband of Barbara, loving brother to Bill, Anne and Michael. Caring uncle to Caitlin and Meghan Flynn, Claire and Jackson Rosenberger, Laurie Altman and Marc Eidelkind. A military ceremony will precede his interment at South Florida National Cemetery. For online condolences please visit www.fullerfuneralhome.com

SCHWARTZ--Melvin, 88, of Palm Beach Gardens FL, passed away on Saturday, October 30, 2010. Beloved husband of Phyllis (nee Steinbaum). Loving father of Linda, predeceased by son Stephen. Dear brother of Norma Silfen and Harvey (deceased), brother-in-law Larry Steinbaum, sister-in-law Vonnie Steinbaum, and sister-in-law Gail Schwartz. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, November 3, 2010 at 2:30pm, at Star of David Chapel 9321 Memorial Park Road, West Palm Beach FL. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County.

In his new role as a political leader, which is what you call somebody if he hosts a rally on the Washington Mall for over 200,000 people, Jon Stewart was a little hemmed at the Rally to Restore Sanity on Saturday. Because sanity should know no party, partisan rhetoric was not on the teleprompter. So instead the host of ''The Daily Show'' took steady aim on the one American institution that everyone can agree to hate: The Media. Within the first minute of his deft, very articulate stump speech at the end of the rally, Mr. Stewart turned his gun sights on the, um, fake news, which he called, ''the country's 24-hour political pundit perpetual panic conflictinator,'' which, he added, ''did not cause our problems, but its existence makes solving them that much harder.''

SARASOHN--Roy, of Boca Raton, FL formally of South Orange, NJ died October 29th. Fabulous husband and best friend of Helen Sarasohn and dear father of January Gold and Lane Sarasohn. He will be missed by his many dear and wonderful friends.

Everyone sends text messages they later regret - just ask Brett Favre. But sometimes the everyday texts that contain clever witticisms, pithy observations and inside jokes are also worth sharing, says Lauren Leto.

DRAZEN--Margaret P.,90, formerly of Armonk, NY, passed away after a long illness in Jupiter, FL on October 31, 2010. Marge was married to the love of her life, the late Martin Drazen, for 61 years before his death in 2004. Everyone who knew Marge loved her dearly as she was truly a special woman. She was a Founder of the Life Long Learning Society at Florida Atlantic University in Jupiter, and actively loved learning there until she was no longer able to attend classes. A wonderful and devoted matriarch, she deeply cherished her family and friends. All will sorely miss her wise, inquisitive and gentle nature. She is survived by her devoted daughters and son-in-law, Karen and Martin Berger and Laurel Drazen, and by her adoring granddaughters and their spouses, step-grandchildren, and eight great-grandchildren. Memorial service on November 2 at 3:00pm at Temple Judea, 4311 Hood Road, Palm Beach Gardens, FL. In lieu of flowers, her family would be grateful for contributions in her memory to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407.

An article last Monday about the recent troubles of the Parents Television Council gave outdated information about the income of L. Brent Bozell III, the conservative activist who founded the council in 1995. He is paid by the Media Research Center, another nonprofit group he founded, but is no longer paid by the Parents Television Council. (Last year, the most recent year for which the organizations made payment information public, Mr. Bozell was paid $24,500 by the council and $218,319 by the center.)

Instead of putting candles on a cake to celebrate its 10-year anniversary, Lucky magazine is lighting up its December issue with more than 100 online videos connected to each editorial page in the magazine. Lucky, a Conde Nast fashion magazine, is working with Talk Market, a company that helps retailers produce Web videos using a proprietary technology that automates the video editing process. The December issue represents the first major media partnership for Talk Market and the first time Lucky has had so many videos attached to an issue.

The standard TV remote control, lost so many times beneath sofa cushions, may soon be lost to history. Good riddance, says Chris Lavoie, a radio producer living in Los Angeles. Taking advantage of advances in smartphones, Mr. Lavoie uses an app on his iPhone to control his Apple TV set-top box and search for things to watch.

The great waves of plague that twice devastated Europe and changed the course of history had their origins in China, as did a third outbreak that struck less harmfully in the 19th century, a team of medical geneticists reported Sunday. And in separate research, a team of biologists says it has established that the agent that caused the most deadly plague, the Black Death, was the bacterium known as Yersinia pestis. It has been the favored cause, but a minority of biologists and historians have vigorously argued that the Black Death differed from modern cases of plague studied in India and therefore must have had a different cause.
International BLACK DEATH'S ORIGINS

Playing for the first time since Week 1, when he separated his right shoulder, the Lions' Matthew Stafford, left, went 26 of 45 for 212 yards with 4 touchdowns in a victory against the Redskins. For the second week in a row, Dan Carpenter kicked five field goals, including a career-best 54-yarder, as the Dolphins beat the Bengals. The five field goals were the second most by a Dolphins kicker.

For birders, the great prothonotary show has apparently ended. It played outside the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue for seven days after Matthew Rymkiewicz, the manager of development information at the library and a bird watcher, went out at lunchtime on Oct. 21. Along the wall past Patience, the lion at the south edge of the steps leading to the main entrance, he saw ''two sparrows scratching about and right next to them, this brilliant blue and gold bird.''
SUNDAY Josh Freeman's 53-yard pass to Arrelious Benn set up LaGarrette Blount's 1-yard winning run with 5:13 left. The Bucs beat Arizona, 38-35.

SEIDEMAN--Ruth, 93, after a long journey into peacefulness. Beloved wife of the late Emanuel, loving mother of Ellen and Larry, Peter and Barbara, Charles and Lisa. Revered sister of Harold and Helene and the late Zelda Hirsch. Adored grandmother to Michael and Nancy, Bonnie and John, Wendy and Stewart, Abby, Zachary and Todd. Doting great-grandmother of Jake, Marli, Cecelia, Mory, Mia and Jason. She was loved and devoted by and too all. Graveside services Shiva at Ellen Appel Monday thru Wednesday.

Since then, his parents have fought a desperate, public legal battle to demonstrate that medical negligence led to their son's coma, in the process losing their fruit store, as well as their house, and still owing 400,000, now nearly $555,000, in legal costs.

We don't know the final extent of the Democratic losses yet. But we do know the questions that liberals and Democrats will be asking themselves tomorrow morning. Was it all worthwhile? Was the 111th Congress's flurry of legislative activity worth the backlash it helped create? Were the health care bill and the stimulus worth handing John Boehner the gavel in the House of the Representatives? Did it make sense to push and push and then keep on pushing, even after the polls and town halls and special-election outcomes made it clear the voters were going to push back?
The Times's Megan Liberman and Michael D. Shear discuss the salient points of this election.

If you have your low-budget heart set on high-end islands like St. Bart's or St. Martin or Turks and Caicos this winter, with enough research and flexibility you may be able to pull it off. A cool (and stunning) 5 foot 11, Yara Flinn is readily mistaken for a runway clothes hanger. But if the Brooklynite designer appears on the catwalk, it's to take a bow at the end of her show. Not that she isn't her own best model. Now only in her second season and with her first runway show under her belt, Flinn is clearly looking at her own downtown style for inspiration. "I'm always thinking of comfort - physical or psychological - it's about the great fabrics like stretch silk," she says. Translation: no-brainer, well-made pieces like slouchy jumpsuits, cropped crepe tees and ombre chiffon sash dresses. And, at prices ranging from $150 to $500 a girl could easily go all out. "I never usually wear a complete Nomia look," the 27-year-old designer insists. "I'll incorporate an American Apparel or Salvation Army T-shirt to my wool and mesh leggings and biker jacket with a pair of vintage roper boots from Capezio." Her "do try this at home" advice: just add some pieces from Uniqlo ("their jeans have a great fit and don't stretch out"), Metropolis Apparel (43 Third Avenue) and Beacon's Closet (88 North 11th Street, Brooklyn).

A little-known amendment to the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act could reshape the way small businesses bank. The amendment, added in the House of Representatives with no debate, repeals a law that prohibited financial institutions from paying interest on business checking accounts, which are known as demand deposit accounts. The prohibition had been part of the Glass-Steagall Act and was in force for nearly 70 years.

Proxy access is a hotly debated topic. Advocates contend that loosening the limits on proxy access will empower shareholders, heighten board accountability, restore shareholder confidence and result in more economically run public corporations. Detractors refute these propositions and assert that proxy access is a Potemkin village that will pre-empt state law, enable special-interest shareholders to hold up companies and otherwise provide corporations with few of the benefits that its proponents argue, other than increased costs to comply with new regulations.

Demi Lovato, the 18-year-old pop singer and Disney star, has withdrawn from a concert tour to check into a rehabilitation facility, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lovato, a star of the Disney Channel series "Sonny With a Chance" and its popular "Camp Rock" television movies, and whose albums include "Don't Forget" and "Here We Go Again," had been performing with the Jonas Brothers, another Disney act. But her representatives said in a statement she left the tour over the weekend to address "emotional and physical issues." The statement added: "Demi has decided to take personal responsibility for her actions and seek help. She is doing just that. Demi and her family ask that the media respect her privacy during this difficult time." The statement did not specify what treatment she was receiving or the location of the facility. In a 2009 interview with The New York Times, Ms. Lovato talked about her rapid ascent to fame, saying, "Some days I get really excited, and some days I get scared because I feel like I have to live up to certain pressures."

SIMON--Gisela. After a long illness, died in the Tippet Home Hospice Center on October 31, 2010. Loving wife of the late Joseph Simon, she is survived by sons Mark and Larry, daughter-in-laws Magdalena and Katherine, and grandchildren Lukas and Aimara. She was born in Abterode, a small farming town, in Hessen, Germany. After surviving Theresienstadt (Terezin) concentration camp, she emigrated to New York City in 1946. A lover of family, friends, travel, conversation, jewelry, and coffee, Gisela was blessed with a joie de vivre that touched all that knew her. Funeral services will be held on at 11:30am on Tuesday, November 2, at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. Larry will sit Shiva at Gisela's address from 7-9pm on Wednesday, November 3 and from 2-4pm and 7-9pm on Thursday, November 4. Mark keep the same schedule at his home in Philadelphia, PA 315 S. 46th St. 19143. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Jimmy Fund, 44 Binney St.

Now here's a bit of news we presume Whoopi Goldberg won't walk out on. The coming Broadway production of ''Sister Act,'' the musical adapted from her hit 1992 comedy, has found its lead, and to those of you who were hoping the New York transfer would retain the star of its original West End production, your faith has been rewarded. Patina Miller, who was nominated for an Olivier Award for her performance as Deloris Van Cartier, the undercover nun who's secretly an aspiring disco star, when ''Sister Act'' was presented at the London Palladium, will reprise that role on Broadway, press representatives for the show said on Monday. This latest production of the musical will begin previews at the Broadway Theater on March 24 and open on April 20. It features a score composed by Alan Menken with lyrics by Glenn Slater and a book by Cheri and Bill Steinkellner, and will be directed by Jerry Zaks.

PROUDFIT--John, died on October 30 at the age of 78. He was the adored husband of Sally, and much loved by his brothers Michael and Graeme, sister Fenella and sisters-in-law Jose, Jacqueline and Jane, honorary brother Edmund and his many nieces and nephews in America, England and New Zealand. He was an Assistant Attorney General for the State of New York for many years and was in charge of the Environmental Protection Bureau. John was brave, unselfish, loving and will be sorely missed by all his family and friends. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, November 10 at 3pm at St. Bart's Church, 325 Park Avenue at 51st St., New York City. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be given in his name to Oxfam America or Feed the Children.

Tuesday, Oct. 26 There are six botanists on this expedition, but two of them are a continent away. Robin Foster and Corine Vriesendorp of the Field Museum, who have done dozens of these rapid inventories and who are taking a well-deserved break this time around, are going to join us at the end of the trip in Iquitos, where they'll help identify the photos and specimens we've collected.

The American Library Association has added an award for gay and lesbian literature to its annual prizes for children's books. The prizes, which include the prestigious John Newbery and Randolph Caldecott medals, will be announced on Jan. 10. The new award, called the Stonewall Children's and Young Adult Literature Award, is for an English-language book ''of exceptional merit relating to the gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgendered experience,'' the association said on Monday. Stonewall Awards for adult books have been handed out since 1971.

The chief executive of Exco Resources has teamed up with the billionaire oilman T. Boone Pickens and two private investment firms to make a $4.36 billion takeover bid for the natural gas producer, whose stock has slumped 30 percent this year. The offer, announced Monday, is for $20.50 a share, a 38 percent premium to the company's closing price on Friday.

SORENSEN--Theodore C. The Council on Foreign Relations (CFR) mourns the passing of Theodore C. Sorensen, whose powerful rhetoric and sage prescriptions guided numerous world leaders. Known for his work as President Kennedy's adviser and speechwriter, Mr. Sorensen led a long and distinguished career as both a public servant and prominent lawyer. A dedicated member of and active presence at CFR for close to 45 years, Mr. Sorensen served on the Board of Directors from 1993 to 2004. Ted spoke at CFR dozens of times and could always be counted on to ask the most provocative questions. CFR has been honored to have been associated with him. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Gillian, his four children, and other members of his family. Carla A. Hills, Co-Chair Robert E. Rubin, Co-Chair Richard N. Haass, President

SACRAMENTO -- In the three years since her son Diego was given a diagnosis of autism at age 2, Carmen Aguilar has made countless contributions to research on this perplexing disorder. She has donated all manner of biological samples and agreed to keep journals of everything she's eaten, inhaled or rubbed on her skin. Researchers attended the birth of her second son, Emilio, looking on as she pushed, leaving with Tupperware containers full of tissue samples, the placenta and the baby's first stool.

SCHWARTZ--Melvin, 88, of Palm Beach Gardens FL, passed away on Saturday, October 30, 2010. Beloved husband of Phyllis (nee Steinbaum). Loving father of Linda, predeceased by son Stephen. Dear brother of Norma Silfen and Harvey (deceased), brother-in-law Larry Steinbaum, sister-in-law Vonnie Steinbaum, and sister-in-law Gail Schwartz. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, November 3, 2010 at 2:30pm, at Star of David Chapel 9321 Memorial Park Road, West Palm Beach FL. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County.

An Alfred Hitchcock thriller may wrap up its loose ends in under two hours, but a longstanding legal dispute over whether the 2007 movie ''Disturbia'' infringes on the copyright of Hitchcock's ''Rear Window'' and its source material is far from over. On Thursday the Sheldon Abend Revocable Trust, which owns the rights to the 1942 Cornell Woolrich short story ''It Had to Be Murder,'' from which ''Rear Window'' was adapted, filed a new suit against Universal Pictures over ''Disturbia,'' The Hollywood Reporter said.

Rodents, the traditional scourge of New York City, are having a rough year. The rise of the bedbug seems to have rendered rats a has-been pest, a mere nuisance to be ignored rather than read about in countless alarmist news articles. The bedbug is a breakout media star; the rat is, well, still a rat. But there is one realm where the rodent still rules, where rats play the stars of an underground theater with a captive audience in the millions. Where else but the subway?

MURPHY--C. Gordon. Beloved husband of Elva passed away October 26, 2010 of natural causes. He is survived by five children; Gregg Murphy, Lance Murphy and Eric Murphy of California, Janann Kaufman of Anchorage, AK and Gwendolyn Murphy of North Carolina, and six grandchildren. A private ceremony is planned.

PROUDFIT--John. The board and staff of Citizens Union mourn the passing of our long-time board member John Proudfit and offer heartfelt condolences to his wife Sally. John was a deeply committed champion of government reform. His tireless participation in CU's work educated and informed countless New Yorkers. Passionate about reasoned political dialogue, John advanced civic discourse to create a better New York. Peter Sherwin, Chair Dick Dadey, Exec. Dir. Citizens Union

The Ambac Financial Group, the bond insurer waylaid by the financial crisis, moved closer to a bankruptcy filing on Monday, announcing that it plans to skip an interest payment on some of its bonds.

After living in an underground chamber for 69 days, completing a marathon probably doesn't seem like that big a deal. And so Edison Pena, the Chilean miner who ran three to six miles a day during his confinement, will be standing on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge Sunday morning with the other 43,000 runners in the New York City Marathon. ''He might be running some, and walking some,'' a New York Road Runners spokesman said after the group heard from a Chilean consular official. Read about Mr. Pena's marathon plans in On the Run, the Times's marathon blog. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

No matter how it turns out, at least one message from the midterm election is clear: this is not a moment of harmonic convergence. The campaign has been all about irreconcilable differences -- on health care, on spending and climate, on who's a lunatic and who's a tyrant. Political handicappers expect at best a divided government, and at worst a paralyzed, feuding one: ''Survivor: Washington, D.C.,'' with gavels and filibusters in place of bonfires and tribal headbands.

Lee Fisher is up with one of the most unusual - and honest - closing ads this election season. Sitting on a front stoop and wearing jeans and a green shirt, Mr. Fisher, the Democratic candidate for Senate in Ohio, faces the camera and says: ''I'm Lee Fisher. Pay very close attention to this ad 'cause you're not going to see it too many times.''

A picture caption on Saturday with an article about the making of the new album ''AfroCubism'' misidentified a singer shown performing with two other musicians who worked on the album. The musician in the center is Kasse Mady Diabaté -- not Toumani Diabaté, another member of the group.

WEIGL--Henry. Age 98, a resident of North Palm Beach, Florida, passed away on October 30, 2010 in Greenwich, Connecticut (said his wife, Marie). He died of natural causes. Born in Springfield Gardens, New York, July 6, 1912, son of Otto Weigl and Lottie Schultz. He attended a one room school house and then Jamaica High School. He received a BA from NYU in 1933 and, on a scholastic scholarship, went to Harvard Law School. He graduated in 1936, Cum Laude. He was with Wherry, Condon & Forsyth until 1941 and Defense Plant Corporation until 1943. He joined Standard Brands Incorporated in 1943 in the Legal Department. He became General Counsel in 1948 and thereafter held executive positions until he became Chairman and CEO in 1964. He was responsible for the Acquisition of many important products including Clinton Corn Processing and Planters Peanut Company. He led the company through 20 Years of consecutive increases in sales and earnings. He retired in 1977. He served as a Trustee of The Nutrition Foundation, Greenwich Hospital Association and President of the Board of Trustees of Elmira College. He was a Director Of Grocery Manufacturers of America, State National Bank of Connecticut, First National Supermarkets Corporation. His club memberships include Lost Tree Club, Everglades Club, Greenwich Country Club, Indian Harbor Yacht Club and University Club, New York City. He is survived by his beloved wife Of 41 years, the former Marie Babington. He was previously married to Gladys Hines, deceased 1967. He is also survived by two daughters from his first marriage, Pamela Coulter and Judith Buttinger, three grandchildren Rebecca Bell, Leslie Coyne, Christine Coulter, and four Great-grand children. He was Predeceased by two brothers. Memorial service will be held on Tuesday, November 2, 2010 at 11:00am at the Second Congregational Church, 139 E. Putnam Ave., Greenwich, CT. A private funeral service will be held at Queen of Peace Cemetery, Royal Palm Beach, Fl. and a memorial service in Florida at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Harvard Law School Scholarship Fund, 125 Mount Auburn St., Cambridge, MA. 02138.

''A little bit of soap,'' the old song goes, ''will never wash away my tears.'' But what might a whole lot of soap do? Not to mention detergent, paper towels, sponges, disinfecting wipes and more than 25,000 other health, beauty and household products. The answer is of keen interest to Quidsi, the e-commerce company that operates Diapers.com. Quidsi is promoting its newest Web site, Soap.com, with a cheeky campaign that plays up convenience along with value.

Wednesday, Oct. 27 Life is tough for tropical mammalogists. They work on a group with a limited number of species, maybe 150 at places like the ones we are in, and most of those species are bats and rats. Other than monkeys, most of the large mammals in the Amazon are rare. To detect them, mammalogists look for signs - scat, tracks, scratch marks, anything to let them know that a species is here. Worse, they have yahoo ornithologists reporting weird bats, and clueless botanists seeing rare deer. But they have to follow up on these reports. They also have to work night and day. Some mammals (monkeys, for example) are out in daylight hours, but for most, nighttime is when they are active.

Babies born during the brief but intense Biafra famine in Nigeria 40 years ago have grown up to be more susceptible to obesity and its attendant maladies than those born on either side of it, scientists have found. The researchers, from the Karolinska Institute in Sweden and the University of Nigeria Teaching Hospital in Enugu, said the finding added evidence to the argument that malnutrition in the womb causes greater susceptibility to such problems in later life.

How much food does your family waste? A lot, if you are typical. By most estimates, a quarter to half of all food produced in the United States goes uneaten - left in fields, spoiled in transport, thrown out at the grocery store, scraped into the garbage or forgotten until it spoils.

A woman in her mid-30s wearing a hijab, the traditional Muslim head covering, comes to an urgent care center complaining of leg pain. The first thing she asks: ''Are there any woman doctors around?'' She declines to be alone in an exam room with a male doctor. She does not want to be touched by a man who is not a family member, even as part of a medical examination.

8 P.M. (ESPN) MARION JONES: PRESS PAUSE After starring in basketball at the University of North Carolina, winning at the 1997 and '99 world track and field championships, and capturing three gold and two bronze medals at the 2000 Sydney Olympics, Marion Jones, above, finally admitted in 2007 what many had long suspected: she had used steroids. Ms. Jones was sentenced to six months in prison for lying to federal investigators and was stripped of her Olympic medals. In this ''30 for 30'' documentary, John Singleton, the Oscar-nominated director (''Boyz N the Hood''), who ran track in high school, looks at the moment and its repercussions in Ms. Jones's life when she had the opportunity to tell the truth but chose not to. ''The best sports stories are always those that start in athletics and then transcend it and are almost a commentary on the human condition,'' Mr. Singleton said in an interview for ESPN. ''And that's what I think that this story is.'' 3 P.M. (Fox) THE DR. OZ SHOW Kitchen safety measures for preventing food-borne illnesses, especially at Thanksgiving.

An article on Monday about efforts by nonprofit organizations to solicit donations by text message misstated the name of a nonprofit network co-founded by Katrin Verclas, who commented on the trend. It is MobileAction.org, not MobileAccess.

The On Baseball column on Oct. 23, about the National League Championship Series between the Philadelphia Phillies and the San Francisco Giants and the history between those teams, misstated the number of players on base in a 1908 game when Fred Merkle failed to touch second, leading to the Giants' loss of the pennant. There were men on first (Merkle) and third (Moose McCormick) when Al Bridwell hit a line-drive single to center; the bases were not loaded for the play that would become known as Merkle's blunder.

From our standpoint the closest thing approaching a dramatic moment on ''Three's Company'' was the tension of whether audiences would accept Jenilee Harrison as a replacement for Suzanne Somers. But James Franco, as is his wont, sees more in that retro two-girls-and-a-guy comedy than just double entendres and the loveless marriage of the Ropers, and has made it the subject of a new work to be presented at the New Frontier program of the Sundance Film Festival in January. On Monday the Sundance Institute announced the artists and works that will be featured in its 2011 New Frontier lineup, which is intended ''for festival audiences to explore the latest in cinematic innovation and transmedia storytelling,'' according to a news release. On the bill is ''Three's Company: The Drama,'' by Mr. Franco, the multitasking star of ''Howl'' and ''127 Hours,'' which is described as ''a multi-media examination of the classic 70s sitcom.'' The description provided by festival organizers continues: ''Television has undoubtedly shaped our world: our increased exposure to dramatic entertainment, the shapes of our houses, the shape of the time in our day. In this piece James Franco hopes to pull television from the box and view it from 'a slightly oblique perspective.'''

ARLINGTON, Tex. - With the Cliff Lee free-agency sweepstakes set to begin, one of the Texas Rangers' new owners launched a preemptive strike on Monday by criticizing Yankees fans for their ''violent'' and ''apathetic'' behavior during the American League Championship Series. Chuck Greenberg's comments during an interview with a Dallas radio station echoed remarks made by Lee's wife, Kristen, who said she was treated rudely by the Yankee Stadium crowd, and seemed to be a calculated attempt to keep that incident from being forgotten as Texas tries to convince Lee that it would be a better fit in 2011.

MOSCOW -- President Dmitri A. Medvedev flew on Monday into the south Kuril Islands, which the Soviet Union seized from Japan at the end of World War II, making it clear that Russia had no plans to cede the mineral-rich territory despite Japanese protests. Mr. Medvedev is the first Russian president to visit one of the disputed Kuril islands. The four islands lie between the Japanese island of Hokkaido and the rest of the Kuril archipelago, which is Russian territory.

SOLOMON--John David. Beloved father of Sara and Rebecca, husband of Abby, son of Ann and Richard, brother of Jimmy, cherished friend to so many, passed away on November 1, 2010 at the age of 47. He died of complications from a stem cell transplant for treatment of leukemia. An accomplished journalist, John was a regular contributor to publications, including The Washington Post, The New York Times and USA Today, as well as to National Public Radio, on homeland security and other public policy topics. He was working on a book about emergency preparedness, to be published in 2011, called, "In Case Of Emergency, Read Book: Simple Steps To Prepare You and Your Family For Terrorism, Natural Disasters and Other 21st Century Crises." John wanted it "to serve as a guide and encouragement for citizens to begin the preparedness process." He created the blog, "In Case of Emergency, Read Blog A Citizen's Eye View of Public Preparedness", whose readers included the head of the Federal Emergency Management Agency according to The Washington Post. Many days (and nights) John would be in his home office or hospital room preparing his next "Feed Blitz". Born June 7, 1963 in Boston, MA, John was raised in New York City where he attended Collegiate School. Selected "Head Boy" by his classmates and faculty, he maintained a lifelong association with the school, from being a member of its Board of Trustees to leading the East Side against the West in 30 annual Thanksgiving Friday football games. John graduated from Harvard College, with a "major" in The Harvard Crimson, and relished being at his 25th Reunion this past spring with his adored girls. His avid interest in politics and, in particular, the role of government developed early, including working the floor of 1980 Democratic National Convention. John began his career as the Press Secretary for U.S. Congressman Philip Sharp before joining New York City's homeless housing development unit. After working in India, John attended Harvard Business School, graduating in 1991. He returned to New York City to manage Lifetime Television's news and public service campaigns, where he met and fell in love with Abby. They were married on May 9, 1998 and were blessed in 2000 with Sara and in 2002 with Rebecca. John covered so much ground while calling so little attention to himself, it is impossible to know all of his civic contributions big and small. He was a founding board member of the Metropolitan Waterfront Alliance, an Adjunct Instructor in Emergency Medicine at the State University of New York College of Medicine, an active member of New York City's Citizen Emergency Response Team Program, and a Vice Chair of the Trauma and Family Violence Division of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services. An All-City basketball player and gifted leader, John was always up for a pickup game even while on his honeymoon. Through his incomparable kindness, humility, wit, intelligence, integrity, grace, enthusiasm, determination, empathy and love he elevated all of us, individually and collectively. Friends may call Tuesday evening 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Services will be Wednesday, November 3, 10am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations in John's memory may be sent to The New York Community Trust for the John D. Solomon Memorial Fund (at 909 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10022) to be disbursed for the charitable purposes that John held dear.

SORENSEN--Theodore Chaikin. The partners, associates, counsel, and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death of our former partner, current Of Counsel, friend and colleague, Theodore C. Sorensen. Ted Sorensen was a national treasure who served our nation and our law firm with great distinction for nearly 60 years. Ted was a remarkable man of acute judgment who lived a life marked by grace, wit, wisdom, brilliance, integrity, devotion to the public good, always a servant of peace and justice. Ted's impact on our nation was enormous and has been well chronicled, especially his service to President Kennedy in times of grave crisis. Since joining our firm in 1966, Ted provided equally wise counsel to his clients and his partners at Paul, Weiss from sovereign nations and world leaders struggling to create sustainable democracies, to Fortune 100 companies seeking franchise-protecting advice, to Paul, Weiss lawyers seeking counsel about matters large and small, professional and personal, and to the poorest members of our society. At our firm, Ted was a cherished friend, teacher, and mentor. Ted's annual State of the Firm remarks are legendary, delivered in Ted's unique style, with his galloping prose, impeccable timing, alliterative charms and inimitable wit. Our firm, and our lives, are greatly diminished by his passing. He was truly one of a kind. We express our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife Gillian, daughter Juliet, sons Eric, Steve and Phil, seven grandchildren and to all other members of the Sorensen family.

If you've ever stumbled your way through a newly darkened movie theater, unable to distinguish an armrest from a splayed leg or a draped coat from a child's head, you may well question some of the design features of the human visual system. Sure, we can see lots of colors during the day, but turn down the lights and, well, did you know that a large bucket of popcorn can accommodate an entire woman's shoe without tipping over? Yet for all these apparent flaws, the basic building blocks of human eyesight turn out to be practically perfect. Scientists have learned that the fundamental units of vision, the photoreceptor cells that carpet the retinal tissue of the eye and respond to light, are not just good or great or phabulous at their job. They are not merely exceptionally impressive by the standards of biology, with whatever slop and wiggle room the animate category implies. Photoreceptors operate at the outermost boundary allowed by the laws of physics, which means they are as good as they can be, period. Each one is designed to detect and respond to single photons of light -- the smallest possible packages in which light comes wrapped.

Football trounced baseball in the ratings on Sunday as NBC's ''Sunday Night Football'' match-up between the New Orleans Saints and the Pittsburgh Steelers easily outperformed Game 4 of the World Series on Fox. Although final audience figures were not available on Monday, Nielsen's preliminary overnight estimates for the games show them leading the night over all. ''Sunday Night Football'' drew the highest ratings, although the audience for the broadcast was nowhere near last week's record-breaking game, which drew 25.6 million viewers. Fox's ratings for the San Francisco Giants' Game 4 victory over the Texas Rangers were up slightly, compared with Thursday's Game 2, which drew 14.1 million viewers when final ratings were released. Game 3 on Saturday attracted the lowest ratings for the series by a significant margin. The two networks led the night over all, with Fox's also getting a boost from an overrun of its afternoon football coverage well into the 7 o'clock hour. CBS placed third, garnering its most viewers at 7 with ''60 Minutes'' (10.7 million) followed by the reality shows ''The Amazing Race'' (9.2 million) and ''Undercover Boss'' (10.4 million) at 8 and 9. ABC was fourth. AMC said that the premiere of its new series ''The Walking Dead'' had been watched by 5.3 million, the largest audience for an original series on the channel. (By comparison, the season finale of the AMC drama ''Mad Men'' drew 2.44 million viewers.)
International OFFICIALS STEP UP SEARCH

Peyton Manning got Indianapolis' makeshift offense chugging like its old self Monday night. Manning, the four-time league most valuable player, threw two touchdown passes, then watched Mike Hart run for a career-high 84 yards and Jacob Tamme score his first career touch-down to help Indianapolis get past the visiting Houston Texans, 30-17.The victory allowed the Colts (5-2) to get even in the head-to-head series with Houston (4-3), and it gave the de-fending A.F.C. champion Colts sole possession of the South Division lead for the first time this season. And even though the Colts were missing the All-Pro tight end Dallas Clark, receiver Austin Collie and running back Joseph Addai with injuries, Manning and his teammates did not miss a beat. ''Whoever's in there has to find away to do the job,'' Manning said. ''It' snot always going to be pretty, but we've just got to keep grinding and making some plays.'' Manning was 26 of 45 for 268 yards. Hart ran with the same determination he used to become Michigan's career rushing leader and provided the Colts with a rare ground game. Tamme, Clark's replacement, caught six passes for 64 yards. But it was not just the new guys making plays -- or only the offense. Reggae Wayne caught a touchdown pass, Manning ran for a first down for the first time in nearly two years, and even became the lead blocker on a first-down catch-and-run by Pierre Garçon in the third quarter. The Colts' defense put consistent pressure on Houston quarterback Matt Schaub, too. Schaub struggled horribly in the first half and could not rally the Texan sin the second as defensive ends Dwight Freeney and Robert Mathis applied pressure. The Colts had three sacks.

Although the Federal Trade Commission last week dropped its investigation of personal data inadvertently collected by Google's StreetView cars, state authorities and officials in European and other countries are still looking into privacy issues related to the service. In my column this week I divulge the fact that I no longer soak dried beans before cooking them. If you're like me, and don't know that you want to make bean stew until, well, the moment you want to make bean stew, then that eight-hour prep just isn't in the cards.  That said, soaking beans overnight to soften them is really a great choice if you're the kind of person who knows what you will want for dinner tomorrow. The eight hours or so spent in the water drastically reduces the cooking time. This saves energy and gets your dinner on the table faster once you bring everything to a boil. So feel free to soak the beans for this recipe if you're so inclined. Just watch them carefully to see when they are done - probably in half the time it took me with unsoaked beans. Another issue that I briefly bring up in the column is refrigerating the beans while they soak. Years ago, I was taught that soaking beans might start to ferment if left in a very warm room overnight. Soaking in the fridge eliminates this concern. However, several readers have written to me saying that they never refrigerate their soaking beans and haven't had any problems. One friend, from the Caribbean, said she always soaks her beans outside on the porch overnight in 80-degree weather, and that those beans seem to cook up perfectly well. I'm curious to hear how you do it - do you soak at room temperature or in the fridge? What about quick soaking? Many readers use pressure cookers, so I'm asking, do you soak if you use a pressure cooker? Leave a comment to share your leguminous adventures.

Bottega Veneta, best known for its high level of artisanal craftsmanship and logo-free take on luxury living, has partnered with the Swiss watch giant Girard Perregaux to produce its first watch, the BVX. As elegantly subtle as the house's signature woven leather accessories, the unisex watch features a dark, brushed-titanium curved case with a brown face and a cigar-colored crocodile strap. But don't let the sexy simplicity fool you: inside this chic exterior lies an 18-karat rose gold automatic movement made expressly by Girard Perregaux for Bottega Veneta. And this watch has a face that even Dorian Gray could love, with nary a name or initial marring its smooth, lacquered surface, adhering strictly to the company's famous motto: "When your own initials are enough." The BVX is $14,600 and will be available starting in December.

I grew up without a fireplace because my neurotic (but fabulous) parents were afraid of fire. So I've always been obsessed with them. In the house we built on Shelter Island, I put a bright orange vintage Preway in the bedroom. I had to search far and wide, and finally found the right one on Craigslist. The Preway is no longer in production, but you can still get free-standing fireplaces from Malm, a company out in Santa Rosa, Calif., that has been making them with great proportions and clean lines since the 1960s. (The one above is available from Design Within Reach.) When I am making a piece of pottery, I know that it's finished - and that it's good - if it looks like it's supposed to be that way, like it's been uncovered rather than created. To me, that's a Malm fireplace. And I like that it's democratic, not precious. At its height of popularity, you were as likely to see one in a mobile home as you were in a groovy modernist manse. Those who dismiss these beauties as a bit of '70s nostalgia need to look again. I'm never happier than when I lie in bed and stare at my Preway, a glowing beacon of orange optimism in the corner of the room.

Australia and India raised interest rates on Tuesday, in separate moves that highlighted the growing contrast between the Asia-Pacific region’s rapid growth and the still-fragile recovery in other parts of the world.

Republicans captured the House Tuesday by ousting powerful Democratic committee chairmen as well as newcomers who faced a voter backlash after supporting an aggressive Democratic legislative agenda for the past two years. The dozens of Democrats who lost in the economically struggling Midwest include Representative Ike Skelton of Missouri, who heads the Armed Services Committee. Mr. Skelton was joined in defeat by Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the chairman of the Budget Committee.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Feeling pessimistic, but bucking the national trend, California voters decided against a pair of untested Republicans in favor of old-school Democrats on Tuesday. In the governor's race, the state's attorney general, Jerry Brown, 72, was elected California's oldest chief executive and will return to the office he held from 1975 to 1983. Mr. Brown's victory came despite the record $140 million spent by his Republican challenger, Meg Whitman, a former chief executive of eBay who was trying to become the first woman to be elected governor in the nation's most populous state.

President George W. Bush considered dumping Vice President Dick Cheney from his 2004 reelection ticket to dispel the myths about Mr. Cheney's power in the White House and ''demonstrate that I was in charge,'' the former president says in a new memoir. The idea came from Mr. Cheney, who offered to drop out of the race one day during a private lunch between the two men in mid-2003. ''I did consider the offer,'' Mr. Bush writes, and spent several weeks exploring the possibility of replacing Mr. Cheney with Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, the majority leader, before opting against the switch.

SMALLMAN--Honey (Steinhauer). Sons David and Scott, their spouses Mary Lisa and Julie, and granddaughters Katherine, Miriam and Abigail, all other family members and dear friends mourn her passing on Sunday, October 31, 2010 after a courageous six-week battle with cancer.

DAVIS--Fred Bunker, 79 died in Omaha, NE. Fred (aka Fritz) was a graduate of Oberlin College and Harvard Law School. In the 1960s and 70s he was associated with the New York law firms Mudge, Stern, Baldwin and Todd, and Cahill Gordon and Reindel. He also served two years as an Assistant Attorney General of New York. He moved to Omaha to accept a partnership in the Kutak Rock law firm, where he continued a successful practice in states securities regulation ("blue sky") law. Survived by his wife of 50 years, Janet; daughter, Susannah; daughter, Rachel Sonnenblick; son-in-law, Richard Sonnenblick; granddaughter, Lily. Funeral in Omaha on November 3. Donations suggested to the Hawk Migration Association of North America (www.hmana.org), for which he was an enthusiastic and hardworking volunteer.
Coverage of the election results on the Caucus blog and Nate Silver's FiveThirtyEight blog, which will examine trends in the voting. nytimes.com/politics

Richard Blumenthal, the longtime attorney general of Connecticut, withstood a $50 million spending assault, his own major missteps and a brutal climate for Democrats on Tuesday, defeating the professional wrestling tycoon Linda E. McMahon to capture a Senate seat being vacated by Christopher J. Dodd. In choosing Mr. Blumenthal, voters in Connecticut defied the national electoral trend, standing by the ultimate insider -- a career politician who had become the face of the state's Democratic establishment -- over a plain-speaking, conservative Republican, a first-time candidate who had built a business into an empire and created hundreds of jobs.

Claude Lanzmann's epic Holocaust documentary, ''Shoah,'' will receive a new release to mark its 25th anniversary, using two 35 mm prints of the film that will be shown at Lincoln Plaza Cinemas and the IFC Center in December, IFC Films said on Tuesday. Mr. Lanzmann, a French Jewish filmmaker, spent 11 years making the nine-and-a-half-hour ''Shoah,'' which does not use historical footage and instead consists primarily of first-person interviews conducted in 14 countries with survivors, witnesses and accomplices: a barber who sheared the hair of women before they were killed in the gas chambers of Treblinka, a locomotive engineer who drove Jews to their deaths.

SOLOMON--John. Just a few years ago, John joined the Board of Trustees at JBFCS. We knew right away how lucky we got, and we never stopped appreciating his quiet fortitude, his grace under pressure and most of all, his caring heart. Losing John means we have lost something very precious, as have all those vulnerable New Yorkers he tried to help. May John's memory, and his spirit, be for a blessing. Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services Anthony E. Mann, President Paul Levine, Exec. V.P. and CEO

Republicans captured six Congressional seats in New York and New Jersey on Tuesday night, riding a wave of voter dissatisfaction that swept Democrats across the country out of power. The outcomes capped a season in which Republican candidates, the national Republican Party and conservative nonprofit organizations poured millions of dollars into both states to defeat incumbent Democrats representing swing districts.
CHIMENTO--Frank. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Frank Chimento, associated with The New York Times from December 1, 1956 until retiring on January 1, 1991.
BROKKEN--Jim. November 3, 2005 Half a decade of less fun- the other Jim.

''Follow the thumping'' is not what library employees usually say to patrons lost amid the stacks. But on Monday night, as the 2010 Library Lions dinner at the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue wound up to a throbbing after-party - in hushed halls more used to whispers - guests clinked glasses and shouted above the bass. Attendees in feathered and furred couture passed between the library's marble lions, Patience and Fortitude, at 7 p.m., satin trains fluttering up the stairs along a path lined with tall white Santeria-like candles. They were there to celebrate this year's winners of the Library Lion award for distinguished work in the literary field. Upstairs in the Edna Barnes Salomon Room, partygoers drank cocktails under the watchful eyes of Astors whose portraits ringed the room. Melvil Dewey and the demise of his decimal system were as hotly discussed as if he were front-page news.

SOLOMON--John. The Board and Staff of 480 Park Ave Corporation mourn the passing of John Solomon, son of Board Member, Richard Solomon and Mrs. Solomon and offer our heartfelt condolences. John was a frequent visitor and we will miss him.

FURER--Andrew Jonathan. On October 31, 2010. Born perfect, truly perfect, son of Manuel and Vivian, brother of Rachel, and Jessica Furer. Memorial service on Friday 2pm at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave., at 81st Street.

SOLOMON--John. The Collegiate School Class of '81 mourns the loss of John "Solly" Solomon. John was voted "Head Boy" of our class and over the years he made it not just a title, but a description. It wasn't that Solly was a great guy--though he was--it was that he made us all feel like better men just for being close to him. He was our leader, our captain, our Willis Reed. Without him we are more than a little lost. Without him we are much less than we were, and we will miss him forever.

SORENSEN--Theodore Chaikin. The partners, associates, counsel, and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death of our former partner, current Of Counsel, friend and colleague, Theodore C. Sorensen. Ted Sorensen was a national treasure who served our nation and our law firm with great distinction for nearly 60 years. Ted was a remarkable man of acute judgment who lived a life marked by grace, wit, wisdom, brilliance, integrity, devotion to the public good, always a servant of peace and justice. Ted's impact on our nation was enormous and has been well chronicled, especially his service to President Kennedy in times of grave crisis. Since joining our firm in 1966, Ted provided equally wise counsel to his clients and his partners at Paul, Weiss from sovereign nations and world leaders struggling to create sustainable democracies, to Fortune 100 companies seeking franchise-protecting advice, to Paul, Weiss lawyers seeking counsel about matters large and small, professional and personal, and to the poorest members of our society. At our firm, Ted was a cherished friend, teacher, and mentor. Ted's annual State of the Firm remarks are legendary, delivered in Ted's unique style, with his galloping prose, impeccable timing, alliterative charms and inimitable wit. Our firm, and our lives, are greatly diminished by his passing. He was truly one of a kind. We express our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife Gillian, daughter Juliet, sons Eric, Steve and Phil, seven grandchildren and to all other members of the Sorensen family.

KRAAR--Martin S. The leadership, staff, and entire community of the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science deeply mourn the passing of Martin S. Kraar, former Executive Vice President. For 10 years, Marty led the American Committee and cultivated a devoted circle of loyal friends and supporters of the Weizmann Institute. Under his sound management, the organization reached record-breaking achievements in financial resource development. Marty came to the American Committee after an outstanding career in Jewish communal affairs. His genuine passion for the Weizmann Institute, for science, and for Israel greatly inspired the professional staff and ardent major supporters throughout the United States. Marty established enduring personal friendships with scientists at the Institute and with much of the leadership of the American Committee. When he left Weizmann in 2008 to establish Kraar Associates, a private consultancy, Marty's friends in the United States and around the world honored him by contributing to the establishment of the Kraar Observatory Project, an educational astronomy program at the Institute. Marty's vision, compassion, and insight will be missed enormously by the entire Weizmann Institute family. We extend heartfelt condolences to Marty's wife, Lynda; to daughters Shanna, Anita, Miriam, and Yona; and to the entire family. May Marty's memory be for a blessing. Lawrence S. Blumberg, Chairman, American Committee Pennie Abramson, President American Committee Marshall S. Levin, Executive V.P. & C.E.O., American Committee Mandy Moross, Chair Weizmann Institute Prof. Daniel Zajfman, President, Weizmann Institute

Malcolm MacKenzie threw a fist at Brandon Jovanovich's face and quickly apologized: ''Oh, we're doing gut -- I'm sorry!'' Mr. Jovanovich shrugged off the misdirected punch scripted for his torso. He was too busy grabbing Elina Garanca around the neck so he could drag her off. ''You all right?'' he asked.

PROUDFIT--John, died on October 30 at the age of 78. He was the adored husband of Sally, and much loved by his brothers Michael and Graeme, sister Fenella and sisters-in-law Jose, Jacqueline and Jane, honorary brother Edmund and his many nieces and nephews in America, England and New Zealand. He was an Assistant Attorney General for the State of New York for many years and was in charge of the Environmental Protection Bureau. John was brave, unselfish, loving and will be sorely missed by all his family and friends. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, November 10 at 3pm at St. Bart's Church, 325 Park Avenue at 51st St., New York City. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be given in his name to Oxfam America or Feed the Children.

TANGER--Stanley, Greensboro, NC, age 87, died peacefully of natural causes on October 23, 2010 surrounded by his family. Beloved husband of Doris Tanger for 63 years. Son of the late Harriette and Moe Tanger of Wallingford, CT and brother of Lois Magid and the late Renee Lowenberg. He is lovingly survived by his wife, his sister, his children Steven Tanger, Jane Black, and Susan and Joseph Nehmen, his grandchildren Marcie and Jordan Pantzer, Laurie Nehmen, Jason and Amy Black, Stacy Black, Schuster Tanger and Andrew Tanger and his great-grandchildren Annabelle and Charles Pantzer. Mr. Tanger will be remembered for founding Tanger Factory Outlet Centers in 1981. He is widely credited with creating the first factory outlet strip shopping center in Burlington, N.C. Under his leadership as the President and CEO, the company became a publicly traded REIT on the NYSE in 1993 and he received the Inc. Magazine Entrepreneur of the Year Award for Real Estate in 1994. He was a member of the Young Presidents' Organization and the World Presidents' Organization. Mr. Tanger will also be remembered for his lifelong commitment to philanthropy. Along with his wife, Mr. Tanger donated to many charities including the American Cancer Society, receiving their highest honor, the Excalibur Award seven times from 1994 to 2004. He also generously donated to Duke University, supporting the Duke Comprehensive Cancer Center, Duke Eye Center and the Iron Dukes and was a major donor to the Moses Cone Cancer Care Center expansion. Mr. Tanger donated the Tanger Family Bicentennial Garden and numerous sculptures in the garden to the City of Greensboro. In 2010, Mr. Tanger received the McIver Medal from the University of North Carolina at Greensboro and the Ben Cone Award from the Greensboro Jewish Federation. Mr. Tanger was an Eagle Scout and awarded the Silver Beaver Award on February 11, 2004. In 2000, he donated Lake Tanger to the Old North State Council for the North Carolina Boy Scout Camp. Mr. Tanger served as a pilot in WWII. He adored flying planes, cars and chocolate chip cookies. Funeral services were held on Monday, October 25 at Temple Emanuel, 1129 Jefferson Road, Greensboro. Burial followed in the Hebrew Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Temple Emanuel. Online condolences may be made at www.haneslineberryfuneral-homes.com

In leading his party to midterm triumph, Representative John A. Boehner, the next speaker of the House, is not at the endgame. He is at the beginning of the next and harder fight. Relying on his decades of experience with the inner workings of the House, Mr. Boehner, of Ohio, now has less than two years to show that the Republican Party is the antidote to what ails Washington, with a discordant caucus, a stagnant economy, a hostile White House with veto power and the long shadow of 1994 all looming before him.

In a case that has had its share of odd turns, the battle between the British financier Guy Hands and Citigroup over the buyout of the EMI Group took a cinematic twist on Tuesday morning. In the end, a juror was left on the cutting room floor. The scene was set after Theodore V. Wells Jr., the lead lawyer for Citigroup, marched into the federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan and made an application to remove a juror from the trial, which is in its third week.

Six weeks ago, Oracle's chief executive, Larry Ellison, said that his deal-happy company planned to set its sights on software makers that cater to specific industries. It found one on Tuesday. Oracle's impending $1 billion acquisition of the e-commerce software provider Art Technology Group, which was announced Tuesday, fits Mr. Ellison's description perfectly: Art Technology makes software for retailers to peddle their wares online. Its customers include Best Buy, CVS, Macy's and OfficeMax, among others.

SORENSEN--Theodore C. The directors, officers and national chapters of the United Nations Association of the United States of America are deeply saddened at the passing of Theodore C. Sorensen, a great servant of democracy and a brilliant champion of human rights in America and throughout the world. We extend our sincere sympathy to our friend and colleague Gillian and to the entire family. William J. McDonough, Co-Chair Thomas Pickering, Co-Chair A. Edward Elmendorf, President and CEO

The Tea Party movement set the agenda in its first midterms, its energy propelling the Republican sweep in the House and capturing the mood of a significant chunk of the electorate, with a remarkable 4 in 10 voters in exit polls expressing support for the movement. But in the Senate, the effect was exactly what establishment Republicans had feared: While Tea Party energy powered some victories, concerns about Tea Party extremism also cost them what could have been easy gains -- most notably in Nevada, where the Senate Democratic leader, Harry Reid, survived a challenge from Sharron Angle, a Tea Party favorite.

The actors Kiefer Sutherland and Jason Patric will play the brothers James and Tom Daley this spring in the first Broadway revival of ''That Championship Season,'' the 1973 Pulitzer Prize-winning play about friendship, regrets, and basketball, the producers announced on Tuesday. Brian Cox, Jim Gaffigan, and Chris Noth will round out the ensemble cast, under the direction of Gregory Mosher (last season's ''A View from the Bridge''). The production has some notable bloodlines. Mr. Patric, perhaps best known for the films ''Sleepers'' and ''The Lost Boys,'' is a son of the play's author, the late Jason Miller. Mr. Patric and Mr. Sutherland were in ''The Lost Boys'' together and are good friends, though they were not always so; when Julia Roberts broke off her engagement to Mr. Sutherland in 1991, she soon began dating Mr. Patric.

SORENSEN--Ted. The International Center for Transitional Justice community mourns the passing of Ted Sorensen. From the time he joined our board as a founding member, Ted always asked the tough and insightful questions, making sure we stayed focused on achieving tangible results that would improve people's lives in the countries we serve. He did so with charm and wit and with a canny instinct for always ferreting out what was important. He loved to spend time exchanging ideas with young people at ICTJ and he was unfailingly courteous to everyone in our organization. We shall miss this great and gentle man who was a true humanist and an inspiration to us all. We pass our condolences to Ted's beloved Gillian and the entire Sorensen family. Kofi Appenteng, Chairman David Tolbert, President Vincent Mai, Board Member Harvey P. Dale, Board Member Ken Miller, Board Member Minna Schrag, Board Member Alex Boraine, Founding President Juan Mendez, President Emeritus

Republicans improved their lot in the Senate on Tuesday but were foiled by Democrats in a few key states with a high number of independent voters in their bid to capture both houses of Congress. By adding seats in Pennsylvania, Indiana, Arkansas, Illinois, Wisconsin and North Dakota, Republicans narrowed the gap with Democrats. They maintained control in states like Florida, Kentucky and New Hampshire.

Inspectors from the New York State Department of Labor will visit Broadway's Foxwoods Theater on Wednesday to examine the flying and safety devices and watch some of the aerial stunts for the upcoming musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,'' which is expected to feature acrobatic flying that is unprecedented for Broadway. The inspection has been in the offing for months, but it also comes two weeks after a flying technique in the show went awry, resulting in two broken wrists for actor Kevin Aubin. During the stunt, Mr. Aubin was launched from the back of the stage like a slingshot, landing again with serious force at the lip of the stage.

Demi Lovato, the 18-year-old pop singer and Disney star, has withdrawn from a concert tour to check into a rehabilitation facility, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lovato, a star of the Disney Channel series ''Sonny With a Chance'' and its popular ''Camp Rock'' television movies, and whose albums include ''Don't Forget'' and ''Here We Go Again,'' had been performing with the Jonas Brothers, another Disney act. But her representatives said in a statement she left the tour over the weekend to address ''emotional and physical issues.'' The statement added: ''Demi has decided to take personal responsibility for her actions and seek help. She is doing just that. Demi and her family ask that the media respect her privacy during this difficult time.'' The statement did not specify what treatment she was receiving or the location of the facility. In a 2009 interview with The New York Times, Ms. Lovato talked about her rapid ascent to fame, saying, ''Some days I get really excited, and some days I get scared because I feel like I have to live up to certain pressures.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Last month's one-night-only reading of Larry Kramer's play ''The Normal Heart'' on Broadway is poised to return as a full production in the spring, Mr. Kramer and the theater producer Daryl Roth said in interviews on Monday, with Joe Mantello on track to reprise his performance at the reading as Ned Weeks. Ms. Roth said that she was well into laying the groundwork for a multiweek Broadway run of ''The Normal Heart,'' probably starting in March or April. ''We are now working on putting all the elements together, working on budgets, inquiring if the appropriate theater would be available, cast availability, schedules, etc.,'' she said.

Republicans captured control of the House of Representatives on Tuesday and expanded their voice in the Senate, riding a wave of voter discontent as they dealt a setback to President Obama just two years after his triumphal victory. A Republican resurgence, propelled by deep economic worries and a forceful opposition to the Democratic agenda of health care and government spending, delivered defeats to House Democrats from the Northeast to the South and across the Midwest. The tide swept aside dozens of lawmakers, regardless of their seniority or their voting records, upending the balance of power for the second half of Mr. Obama's term.

An Associated Press report on Monday about Sunday's N.F.L. games misstated, in some editions, the Dallas Cowboys' record after a 35-17 loss to the Jacksonville Jaguars. That loss made them 1-6, not 1-5. The error was repeated in a picture caption.

Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, completing a painstakingly plotted comeback from political ruin nearly a decade ago, won a resounding victory on Tuesday in the race for governor of New York, easily beating his Republican rival, Carl P. Paladino. Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat, triumphed with the help of independent voters, suburbanites and city dwellers from all corners of the state, a broad sweep that stood out as his party suffered setbacks in Congress and other statehouse races around the country.

The Books of The Times review on Friday, about ''Must You Go?: My Life With Harold Pinter,'' by Antonia Fraser, referred incorrectly to a Pinter play that Ms. Fraser told Pinter, at a party in 1975, that she liked. The play, ''The Birthday Party,'' had its premiere in 1958. It was not ''new'' in 1975. (Ms. Fraser had seen a revival.)

A theater review on Monday about ''The Scottsboro Boys,'' at the Lyceum Theater, with music and lyrics by John Kander and Fred Ebb, erroneously attributed a distinction to another Kander and Ebb musical, ''Chicago.'' The longest-running revival in Broadway history was ''Oh! Calcutta,'' with 5,959 performances from 1976 to 1989 -- not the current revival of ''Chicago,'' which has had about 160 fewer performances. (The error also appeared in articles on Jan. 3, March 11 and May 1 of this year, and on Jan. 23, 2008.)

When I was 21 and a military photographer in West Germany, I sought the advice of Red Grandy, chief photographer for Stars and Stripes in Europe. He was already famous for taking this shot near Koblenz, Germany, in 1951, at the moment when Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, then commanding NATO, learned that President Harry S. Truman had dismissed Gen. Douglas MacArthur as the Korean War commander. Mr. Grandy knew that General Eisenhower had not heard the news, and positioned himself accordingly. The lesson: anticipation is as critical as luck. Earlier photographs in the series are at nytimes.com/lens.

Solomon

In five months, the Texas Rangers went from bankruptcy to playing in the World Series. They went from borrowing $40 million from Major League Baseball to stay afloat to vowing to aggressively pursue their free-agent pitcher, Cliff Lee, against certain competition from the Yankees.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the dismantling of the art installation ''Big Bambú: You Can't, You Don't, and You Won't Stop,'' on the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misstated the length of cord used to make the work. It was 70 miles -- not 7. The article also misstated the number of marriage proposals made in the bamboo thicket when the installation, which closed Sunday, was open. It was six, not three. Using information from the artists who created the work, Doug and Mike Starn, the article also referred incorrectly to its status when they ran out of cord. The rock climbers who were building it, and the artists, had to stop work but the installation was not closed for a week.

The undrafted rookie runningback LeGARRETTE BLOUNT of theBuccaneers is turning heads, butthis year it is for the right rea-sons. Last year, he drew atten-tion for punching a Boise State player after Oregon's opener and for the suspension that followed.
