SOLOMON--John David. Beloved father of Sara and Rebecca, husband of Abby, son of Ann and Richard, brother of Jimmy, cherished friend to so many, passed away on November 1, 2010 at the age of 47. He died of complications from a stem cell transplant for treatment of leukemia. An accomplished journalist, John was a regular contributor to publications, including The Washington Post, The New York Times and USA Today, as well as to National Public Radio, on homeland security and other public policy topics. He was working on a book about emergency preparedness, to be published in 2011, called, "In Case Of Emergency, Read Book: Simple Steps To Prepare You and Your Family For Terrorism, Natural Disasters and Other 21st Century Crises." John wanted it "to serve as a guide and encouragement for citizens to begin the preparedness process." He created the blog, "In Case of Emergency, Read Blog A Citizen's Eye View of Public Preparedness", whose readers included the head of the Federal Emergency Management Agency according to The Washington Post. Many days (and nights) John would be in his home office or hospital room preparing his next "Feed Blitz". Born June 7, 1963 in Boston, MA, John was raised in New York City where he attended Collegiate School. Selected "Head Boy" by his classmates and faculty, he maintained a lifelong association with the school, from being a member of its Board of Trustees to leading the East Side against the West in 30 annual Thanksgiving Friday football games. John graduated from Harvard College, with a "major" in The Harvard Crimson, and relished being at his 25th Reunion this past spring with his adored girls. His avid interest in politics and, in particular, the role of government developed early, including working the floor of the 1980 Democratic National Convention. John began his career as the Press Secretary for U.S. Congressman Philip Sharp before joining New York City's homeless housing development unit. After working in India, John attended Harvard Business School, graduating in 1991. He returned to New York City to manage Lifetime Television's news and public service campaigns, where he met and fell in love with Abby. They were married on May 9, 1998 and were blessed in 2000 with Sara and in 2002 with Rebecca. John covered so much ground while calling so little attention to himself, it is impossible to know all of his civic contributions big and small. He was a founding board member of the Metropolitan Waterfront Alliance, an Adjunct Instructor in Emergency Medicine at the State University of New York College of Medicine, an active member of New York City's Citizen Emergency Response Team Program, and a Vice Chair of the Trauma and Family Violence Division of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services. An All-City basketball player and gifted leader, John was always up for a pickup game even while on his honeymoon. Through his incomparable kindness, humility, wit, intelligence, integrity, grace, enthusiasm, determination, empathy and love he elevated all of us, individually and collectively. Friends may call Tuesday evening 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Services will be Wednesday, November 3, 10am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations in John's memory may be sent to The New York Community Trust for the John D. Solomon Memorial Fund (at 909 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10022) to be disbursed for the charitable purposes that John held dear.

WHITE--Bernadette (Iskyan), October 28, 2010 in Stuart, FL. Formerly of Forest Hills and Manhasset. Devoted mother to Bonnie and the late Bradley. Predeceased by beloved husband Jack. Services at a later date.

SOLOMON--John David. John, loving husband of Abby, devoted father of Sara and Rebecca, son of Richard and Ann, brother of James, brother-in-law of Vanita, passed away on November 1st. John was idolized as the perfect big brother by his five first cousins. No one ever heard a negative word or thought from John; he was relentlessly upbeat and encouraging, quick to laugh (and clap) enthusiastically at any joke and advise on any problem. He was dedicated to his family and friends and was a tireless supporter of each of us. He was a passionate athlete, playing football and basketball at full speed without once losing his good nature; it always a joy to be a part of any type of game with John. His focus and attention to all our interests and accomplishments meant that every minute we spent with him was full of love, curiosity, enthusiasm for life, and dedication to family closeness. As with everyone who knew John, we will miss him forever. Remembered with love by his first cousins, Stephanie, Sasha, Joshua, Abigail, and Kate.

SOLOMON--John. To the entire Solomon family. John will forever be our talented, thoughtful, exuberant and kindest of friends, who lit up our college years and thereafter. Deeply intelligent, he never took himself too seriously -- willing to don a costume on many nights unrelated to Halloween to the delight of his equally immature friends (us), his daughters and fun loving Abby. Always more interested in others than himself and the most engaging conversationalist, John elevated those around him. We will miss him terribly and will treasure the legacy of the family he left behind. Elena and Tory Kiam, Judy Greenstein

(13, 49) THE SILVER PHARAOH ''Secrets of the Dead'' opens a new season by venturing inside the royal tomb of Pharaoh Psusennes I, a final resting place even more spectacular than Tutankhamen's, filled with lavish jewels and treasures. It was discovered almost by accident in 1939 by the French archaeologist Pierre Montet. The most startling find was the silver sarcophagus, inlaid with gold, above, now recognized as one of the most exquisite artifacts to have resurfaced from ancient Egypt. HULKA--John P.,66, died on Thursday, October 28, 2010, in Phoenix, AZ. He was born December 2, 1943, in New York, NY, to the late John P. Hulka, Sr., and Mary (DaSilva) Hulka. His military career began with service in the Honor Guard at Arlington National Cemetery and included two tours of duty in Vietnam as a U.S. Army Airborne Infantry Officer with frontline combat units. Among his military honors are the Purple Heart, two Bronze Stars, and two Silver Stars. After graduating from UNC-Chapel Hill and leaving the Army with the rank of Captain, he spent more than 30 years in the finance industry in San Francisco, New York, and Sydney, Australia, reaching senior management positions at Morgan Stanley and Merrill Lynch. His survivors include his son, Evan Hulka, of San Francisco, CA; his brother, Charles Hulka, of Phoenix; his sister, Kathryn Hulka, of Cave Creek, AZ; two nieces, Greta Truett and Sara Hulka, both of Phoenix; his wife for 36 years, Judith Hulka, of San Francisco; and his companion at the end of his life, Kim Hendricks, of Cave Creek. Messinger Pinnacle Peak Mortuary, 8555 E. Pinnacle Peak Road, Scottsdale, AZ, 85255, will host a viewing from 6pm to 8pm on November 5, 2010, and a memorial service to celebrate John's life, beginning at 11am on November 6, 2010. Interment with full military honors will take place on a future date at Arlington National Cemetery. Memorial donations may be sent to the Hydrocephalus Association, 870 Market St., Suite 705, San Francisco, CA, 94102, or the Hospice of the Valley, 1510 E. Flower St., Phoenix, AZ, 85014.

The words of a president can convey - or conceal - a great deal of meaning. As the United States approached the central crisis in its history, there was no reason to expect great eloquence from the man whose election had precipitated that conflict. Abraham Lincoln was often described as an uncouth barbarian, and had received the least education of any presidential nominee in American history, save Andrew Jackson. Yet there he was in the fall of 1860, standing before the American people, the embodiment of their hopes and fears. In this politically charged atmosphere, the words that flowed from his pen, and his equally expressive silences, did a great deal to define the conflict coming into view. This occasional feature in the Disunion series will probe Lincoln's language, looking at his speeches and public pronouncements during the long transition between his election eve on Nov. 5, 1860, and his First Inaugural Address on March 4, 1861.

In reading the nearly 700 reader responses to my Oct. 17 essay for The Stone, ("Morals Without God?") I notice how many readers are relieved to see that there are shades of gray when it comes to the question whether morality requires God. I believe that such a discussion needs to revolve around both the distant past, in which religion likely played little or no role if we go back far enough, and modern times, in which it is hard to disentangle morality and religion. The latter point seemed obvious to me, yet proved controversial. Even though 90 percent of my text questions the religious origins of human morality, and wonders if we need a God to be good, it is the other 10 percent - in which I tentatively assign a role to religion - that drew most ire. Atheists, it seems (at least those who responded here) don't like any less than 100 percent agreement with their position.To have a productive debate, religion needs to recognize the power of the scientific method and the truths it has revealed, but its opponents need to recognize that one cannot simply dismiss a social phenomenon found in every major society. If humans are inherently religious, or at least show rituals related to the supernatural, there is a big question to be answered. The issue is not whether or not God exists - which I find to be a monumentally uninteresting question defined, as it is, by the narrow parameters of monotheism - but why humans universally feel the need for supernatural entities. Is this just to stay socially connected or does it also underpin morality? And if so, what will happen to morality in its absence?

The British designer Linda Farrow was one of the first to see the vision thing as a fashion thing - she started her namesake eyewear line back in 1970. Over the years, Farrow's glasses have provided chic cover for everyone from Yoko Ono to Kanye West. Now, Linda Farrow Luxe is introducing a special collection of 50 frames that includes both updated styles from the archives and new designs curated by Simon Jablon, Farrow's son and the managing director of the brand. "Every year we push the collection in design and technicalities but still have the same essence," Jablon says. Take, for example, the large Jackie O. cat-eye frames covered in cream, taupe, gray, aubergine or black snake. The retro style is modeled above by the actress Nathalie Love, who appears - alongside her best friend, the artist Louis Eisner - in a campaign by the photographer Tim Barber that is, well, worthy of framing.

The annual Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show in Las Vegas is an opportunity for companies selling aftermarket automotive accessories to let their imaginations run wild. After directing the indie Joy Division biopic "Control" and the George Clooney thriller "The American," as well as scores of music videos for groups like Nirvana, U2 and Depeche Mode, Anton Corbijn is back to where it all began for him: portraiture. No matter the strata of their celebrity, Corbijn manages to draw out something as yet undiscovered from his subjects. "Inwards and Onwards," on view at Stellan Holm Gallery until Dec. 15, is a small selection of Corbijn's black-and-white portraits of the creative people whose orbits have intersected his own. Rockers like Tom Waits and Anthony Kiedis mingle with painters such as Richard Prince and Lucian Freud. Corbijn holds them all in equal regard.

The artist Tauba Auerbach deals with perception and illusion, finding moments of ambiguity between two dimensions and three. (Think of her trompe l'oeil ''folded'' canvases, at this year's Whitney Biennial.) Which is why, presumably, she fell so hard for pop-up books. ''When a page closes, you see an object kind of smush, and in that moment, it's in a liminal state not unlike the Fold paintings,'' she says. Auerbach began collecting classic pop-ups like ''Alphabeta Concertina'' and ''Andy Warhol's Index (Book)'' last year, and also began the process of making her own. To create ''[2,3]'' - which is being introduced this weekend by Printed Matter at the NY Art Book Fair - she spent months teaching herself how to construct complex geometric shapes from strips of paper, then several more creating templates and instructional videos so that the printer could reproduce them. Among the pieces are ''Cubearc'' (above), a delicate Möbius-like curl and ''Ziggurat'': 10 nested tiers that telescope out to 18 inches high. ''I tried things that someone who had experience probably would have shied away from,'' says Auerbach, who insists that her goal ''wasn't to make the most complicated thing possible. It was just to make something beautiful and uncanny happen.''

It has now been almost three years since the economy entered the Great Recession and two years since it took the nosedive in the fall of 2008. Though the economists say the recession was over months ago, the small-business owners I talk to have not seen sales rebound to where they were. Some businesses haven't rebounded at all. I have been in business for more than 30 years, and I have never seen anything like this. It's like a normal recession but with an extra year or two thrown in. Yes, things have stabilized, and in some cases they have gotten better. On the human side, things are precarious.

ASHFORTH--Elsie L.,of Rye, NY and Palm Beach, FL died October 30, 2010 of a sudden heart attack in Greenwich, CT. She was 96 and the widow of James H. Madden and H. Adams Ashforth, Sr., both of Greenwich. Prior to his death, Mr. Ashforth had been Chairman of the Board of The Ashforth Company, a real estate concern with properties on the east and west coasts. Mrs. Ashforth is survived by her daughter Christina L. Madden (Mrs. Charles S. Whitman III) of New York, her son Peter Madden of Glenville, CT, and her granddaughter Elizabeth Whitman of New York. Another son, Michael Madden, predeceased her. Mrs. Ashforth is also survived by three step- children: Mrs. Eldon Harvey, Jr. of Mystic, CT, Alden Ashforth of New Orleans, and Marna A. Geoffroy of Los Angeles, as well as 14 step- grandchildren, 30 stepgreat-grandchildren and two stepgreat-great-grandchildren. She was predeceased by a stepson, Henry A. Ashforth, Jr. Born April 8, 1914 to Raymond D. and Beatrice Kobbe Little, Elsie Ashforth grew up in Europe and was privately educated there. (Mr. Little had served on a number of Davis Cup tennis teams for the United States in the 1900-1920 era.) She was a Powers model in the 1930s, and lent her first name to the female cow, wife to the bull Elmer, in a famous series of Borden Milk cartoon print commercials. A talented artist, particularly in watercolor, she exhibited her work in New York and Connecticut, and only ceased painting in her eighties, when she published her memoirs. She was active to the end and made many younger friends in her later years in Rye and Palm Beach. Beautiful inside and outside, she was always a perfect lady. Greatly beloved by all, she will be deeply missed and lovingly remembered. Services will be held Friday, November 5, 2010. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, Greenwich, CT 06831.

MITTY--Msgr. Edward John J.,PA, passed away peacefully at St. Patrick's Home on Tuesday, November 2nd, 2010. He was born October 10, 1924 to William F. and Margaret Mitty. Msgr. Mitty was predeceased by his brothers, John Mitty and Dr. William F. Mitty and his sister, Mary C. Mitty. He is survived by his devoted sister, Margaret M. Conroy. He is also survived by his nephew Francis Conroy, wife Gail and their children Christine, Kevin, and Meghan. Msgr. Mitty was ordained April 26, 1950 by his uncle, The Most Reverend John J. Mitty, D.D., the former Archbishop of San Francisco at St. Joseph's Seminary. Throughout his sixty years of service to the Archdiocese, he served at: St. Mary's in Katonah, and St. Joseph's in Yorkville, Chaplain of The Harlem Valley State Hospital, Director of Calvary and Allied Cemeteries, and Pastor of Our Lady of Victory in lower Manhattan. He was made Domestic Prelate and Assistant Chancellor in 1965 and Prothonotary Apostolic in 1966. Msgr. Mitty was an active member of The New York Athletic Club and The Friendly Sons of St. Patrick. The Wall Street community and Our Lady of Victory Parish played a major role in Msgr.'s later life. He was indeed a spiritual presence after the tragedy of September 11th. Wall Street honored Msgr. Mitty at his retirement by asking him to ring the closing bell at the New York Stock Exchange. Msgr. was an avid traveler and led many religious pilgrimages. Visiting hours will be Thursday and Friday from 2-4 and 7-9 at the Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home in Bronxville, NY and Friday from 11-12:30pm at Our Lady of Victory Church, 60 William St, New York, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Margaret's of Cortona, Riverdale, NY on Saturday, November 6th at 10am. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

The Mets, acknowledging that their fans are dismayed with the team and the cost of attending home games, said on Wednesday that ticket prices would be cut by an average of 14 percent for next season. Nearly 600,000 fewer fans attended Mets games in 2010, a 19 percent decline, an embarrassing and worrying development for a team that spent $800 million to build Citi Field, which opened in 2009.

One of the positive byproducts of this recession may be that it has forced many of us to consider different ways to operate our enterprises. Business as usual has been replaced with ingenuity, fresh thinking and alternative solutions. That's also true when it comes to selling those businesses. Many sellers have had to put their exit plans on hold, which is why this might be the time to take a closer look at an unfamiliar and misunderstood exit tool: selling your business to employees through a worker-owned cooperative.

LOEB--Elizabeth. The Loeb family marks with profound sadness the passing of Elizabeth "Peggy" Loeb, 84 wife, mother, grandmother, teacher, Pan American Stewardess, gourmet cook, animal lover, and jewelry designer extraordinaire. Born in Bad Kissingen, Germany as trouble was mounting in that country, Peggy spent much of her school years in Vevey, Switzerland, and later studied at Charles University in Prague. Towards the end of WWII, she nursed German soldiers, then fled Czechoslovakia to avoid the advancing Russian army. Walking for three months at night and often hiding in foxholes to avoid rapacious soldiers, she made her way to the Bavarian town of Freising, where an uncle was a city elder. When the US Army arrived, Peggy--who spoke perfect English--was persuaded by her uncle to surrender the town. After the war, Peggy's command of English also landed her a secretarial position with the British Counsel General in Frankfurt, and later a position with Pan American Airlines. Falling in with a lively international crowd in post-war Frankfurt, she met Marshall Loeb, an American correspondent with the United Press. Their unlikely romance startled both families, and they were married in August, 1954 in the Frankfurt City Hall. A planned year-long honeymoon around the world was cut a bit short by the arrival of Michael Rolf, who was later joined by a sister, Margaret Karen. Peggy devoted herself to her family and to guiding the flourishing journalistic career of her husband, who became the Managing Editor of Money and Fortune Magazines, a radio and television commentator, and the author of more than a dozen books. The family traveled widely in support of Marshall's work, and settled in Scarsdale, New York, where Peggy held court in her spacious kitchen and at the Scarsdale pool, impressing friends with her incisive take on events of the day, her candid appraisal of people, her sage advice, puckish humor, and cultivated tastes. A memorial service will be held Sunday, November 14, at 5 pm at The Core Club, 66 East 55th Street, in New York City. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in her memory to the Humane Society of New York (212) 752-4842.

KESSLER--Esther Ziegelman died Wednesday, at the age of 104. To all her family she represented the triumphs of life and love. Widowed at the age of 28, she journeyed to America in late 1938 with her two children, Luba (Lillian) and Aaron, after the death of her husband Abraham Ziegelman. The joyful reunion with her brothers in America was soon overshadowed by the Nazi invasion of Poland. Esther lost her mother, her sister, numerous nieces and nephews, cousins, friends and neighbors in the Holocaust. The unbearable pain stayed with her all her life. In spite of the many hardships and tragedies she had in her life she showed no bitterness or self-pity. She remarried happily to Frank Kessler. She is survived by her daughter, Luba Chanales and her husband, Irwin. Her son Aaron and his wife Marjorie; step-children, Helen and Arnold; grandchildren, Alan, Sheldon, Jane and Amy; great-grandchildren, Yehuda, Shoshana, Aliza, Avi, Rebecca, Emily, Etai, Emma, Henry and Edward; and great-great-grandchildren, Ashi, Nava and Tova.

And with good reason: ITA's own site has been the secret weapon of road warriors because of its ability to sort through lots of flight options and deliver the results in an easy-to-read chart.

Tea Party candidates may have cost Republicans potential gains in the Senate, but they won a large number of seats in the House. In many cases, they won despite accusations of extremism, eccentric comments or the taint of scandal. And they won in races where Democrats had believed that a Tea Party candidate would improve Democratic chances. Some were first-time candidates who had entered politics through the Tea Party movement, others had run for office before but embraced the language and agenda of the Tea Party and were helped by an aggressive get-out-the-vote operation.

NEW YORK An article in some editions on Friday about a lawsuit that claims an elderly woman was severely injured by a girl and a boy riding their bicycles on a Manhattan sidewalk misstated the age of one of them at the time of the accident. The boy was 5 -- not 4, which was the age of the girl. A correction in this space on Saturday also misstated the boy's age.

A little-known amendment to the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act could reshape the way small businesses bank. The amendment, added in the House of Representatives with no debate, repeals a law that prohibited financial institutions from paying interest on business checking accounts, which are known as demand deposit accounts. The prohibition had been part of the Glass-Steagall Act and was in force for nearly 70 years. The amendment was sponsored by Representative Scott Murphy, a Democrat from New York who is facing a tough battle to save his seat in today's election.* ''I started my first business when I was 24,'' said Mr. Murphy in a phone interview between campaign appearances on Friday. ''And I went around to different banks and talked to them about getting set up, and I was amazed that I was paying them to have an account, and they weren't paying me any interest. It's just one of those antiquated rules that's left on the books but is hurting our small businesses, so we got rid of it.''

Donald Garner Jr. was at his auto-salvage lot shooting the breeze last year when a customer mentioned that her nine-year-old twin sons had just gotten back from computer camp. Great skill to have, said Mr. Garner, who went on to complain about how much he was going to have to pay a pro to build a decent Web site. Why not ask her boys to do it? the customer asked. He could pay them whatever he thought the results were worth. He thought about it. Why not? he replied. Mr. Garner had to suppress a laugh when the boys showed up the next day with clipboards and serious looks. But he dutifully gave them a rough idea of what he had in mind, and then waved goodbye without particularly high expectations. A month later, he was stunned and delighted when they delivered exactly the sort of site he had had in mind. He dashed off a check for $2,000, but the boys would accept only $700. ''They did a beautiful job -- just superb,'' Mr. Garner said. (Take a look.)

WASHINGTON -- For all the towering ambitions of this city's residents, its buildings are generally short and boxy. Its low-slung architecture is no accident. In 1910, Congress passed an act limiting the heights of buildings in the capital. The first residential skyscraper, the Cairo, had been built, and at 12 stories, it was higher than fire ladders could reach and scandalously out of sync with its smaller neighbors.

The global taste for modern masters helped the market for Impressionist and modern art continue its upward climb at Christie's on Wednesday night, where record prices were reached for artists like Matisse and Gris. The evening's auction, the second of the week, illustrated how -- with supplies dwindling and the number of new collectors growing -- many buyers are finding the marketplace particularly competitive, even for works that are not considered top flight.

While the landscape for private equity firms is improving, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is still encountering a bit of a slowdown in its profit-making. The private equity giant said that its third-quarter profit fell 61 percent from the comparable period last year, to $317.3 million. K.K.R. attributed the drop in profitability to smaller gains in the value of its private equity portfolio. By comparison, one of the firm's biggest rivals, the Blackstone Group, reported a 23 percent jump in its third-quarter profits as the value of its holdings rose.

HENRY--Reverend Kenneth Earl, Sr.,77, of Decatur, Georgia, died Thursday, October 28, 2010, following a four month battle with cancer. He was surrounded by his family and loved ones at the time of his passing. He was born in Palestine, Texas, to Ophelia G. and Reverend Enoch W. Henry, Sr., on December 27, 1932. Rev. Kenneth Henry graduated from Lincoln High School, Palestine, Texas, and received degrees from Jarvis Christian College, Hawkins, Texas (BA); and Yale University, School of Divinity, New Haven, Connecticut (B. Div. and S.T.M.). He was married to Dr. Pearl L. Henry (nee Smith). Rev. Henry was Associate Professor of Church History at the Interdenominational Theological Center (ITC), Atlanta, Georgia, where he taught for more than 30 years, retiring in 2003 (awarded Professor Emeritus 2010). He co-authored (along with Mark Ellingsen), a history of the ITC, in a recent publication titled, Making Black Ecumenism Happen: The History of the Interdenominational Theological Center as a Paradigm for Christian Unity. Atlanta, Georgia: ITC Press, 2008. He was a founding member of the Ray of Hope Christian Church (Disciples of Christ), Decatur, Georgia. Reverend Henry was a guest lecturer and speaker at colleges, universities, churches and church conferences nationally and internationally. Reverend Henry's accomplishments and honors include: ordained as a minister in the Christian Church, Disciples of Christ (1956), first African American to serve as First Vice Moderator of the Christian Church; active board member for several national-level church organizations (Council on Christian Unity, Division of Overseas Ministries, Campbell-Stone), inclusion in the Encyclopedia of African American Culture and History. Vol. 2, ed. Jack Salzman, David Lionel Smith, and Cornel West. 769-770. New York: Simon and Schuster Macmillan, 1996; and induction into the Jarvis Christian College Hall of Fame (1996). He is survived by Pearl Lean Henry (wife), Decatur, Georgia; Valarie Henry (daughter), Atlanta, Georgia; Kenneth E. Henry, Jr. (son), Minneapolis, Minnesota, and his sisters, Annie L. Fain (Palestine, TX); Mattie Henry Ester (San Francisco, CA); Ruthye M. Jackson (Palestine, TX), and Bettye J. Cannon (Atlanta, GA) and his brother, Dr. Charles E. Henry (Janice), Lubbock, TX. Memorial Services will be held at 2:00pm, Saturday, November 6, 2010, at Ray of Hope Christian Church, Rev. Dr. Cynthia L. Hale, Senior Pastor, officiating, located at 2778 Snapfinger Road, Decatur, Georgia 30034. Dr. Claude Walker, Kansas City, MO, will give the eulogy. Flowers may be sent to the church on the day of the service.

To the Editor: Having tried to dissuade a few friends from undertaking a ''cleansing diet'' in the past, I read Judith Newman's account (''The Juice Cleanse,'' Oct. 28) of such an experience with great interest. I was pleased to see that Ms. Newman solicited the opinion of a physician, who readers can reasonably assume is more of an authority on the health benefits of this fad than Sarah Jessica Parker. I hope Dr. David Colbert's point, that the bowel self-cleans, is well taken by readers.

The battle for the living room? Oh, it's on, all right. On Wednesday, Roku, the Internet-TV set-top box manufacturer, announced that it would be licensing its technology to other manufacturers. The first company to sign on was Netgear, the home router company, which has relabeled the Roku XD box and is now selling it at Best Buy and other stores.

The pundits were wrong. They suggested the results were a foregone conclusion. Plenty of people didn't bother to vote. And at least one contender, who claimed to be ''exhausted'' by the grueling process, seemed almost to welcome defeat. And yet Tuesday's election did contain some drama and suspense: Bristol Palin made it through another round of elimination on the ABC reality show ''Dancing With the Stars.'' Her mother, the former Alaska governor Sarah Palin, was quick to fete that victory along with those of the Tea Party candidates Rand Paul and Marco Rubio. ''Bristol Palin is safe, so now I can concentrate on all these other votes,'' she said.

Music-minded Mac users have GarageBand, which is bundled on all new Macs, to create and edit music. Windows computers, by comparison, don't include music-creation software, and that has left some users singing the blues. Unaccompanied. And that is why I was interested in taking a look at new consumer hardware and software bundles from Avid, the company that owns Pro Tools and Sibelius, the music recording and notation software used by composers and professional musicians.

The Chinese conceptual artist Ai Weiwei seemed to take in stride an announcement by China's government that it would tear down his new studio in Shanghai after saying he doesn't have a proper permit for it. Mr. Ai, writing on his Twitter account, said that he would ''celebrate'' the occasion by holding a banquet for his supporters, Agence France-Presse reported. Though Mr. Ai was previously invited to build his studio in a part of Shanghai that is being turned into an arts district, the government has since declared it illegal and plans to demolish it. In his posts on Twitter, Mr. Ai wrote that on Sunday he would hold a ''River Crab Fest'' at the studio - ''river crab'' being a bit of Chinese slang for censorship on the Internet or elsewhere.

General Motors confirmed on Wednesday that the government would sell enough shares in the automaker's initial public offering to become a minority investor, a crucial step toward refashioning itself as a smaller, more profitable company.

MILLER--Lee (Shirley) D. passed away November 2, 2010 after a courageous battle with cancer. Beloved wife of Charles for 22 years, adored mother of Monique Thorngren (Eric), Lisa Rubin (Jeff), devoted grandmother of Ryan Thorngren, Sydney and Sasha Rubin. Lee lived her life to the fullest as a professional dancer, RN, fashion retailer, and real estate agent. She was creative at every turn and generous to all. Born in Connecticut, raised in Mineola, LI, she resided in New York City until moving to Westhampton Beach 15 years ago. Lee was equally balanced by her love and devotion to her friends and family. She is missed terribly already. Family will receive friends Friday, November 5th, 3-5pm with a memorial service 4:30pm at The Follett and Werner Funeral Home, 60 Mill road Westhampton Beach. Shiva will be observed, Saturday November 6, 7-9pm and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9pm at 64 Brittany Lane, Westhampton Beach. Expressions of sympathy may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering c/o Dr. John Fiore and Fight Chance (34 Bay Street, Sag Harbor, NY).

As a Republican wave swept across the United States on Tuesday, the Fox News Channel drew the biggest midterm election audience in its history. Fox News, a favorite of Republicans with its stable of conservative hosts like Glenn Beck, had an average of 6.96 million viewers in prime time on Tuesday, according to the Nielsen Company. That was more than double the audience for CNN, which drew an average of 2.42 million viewers Tuesday night, and more than triple that for MSNBC, at 1.94 million viewers.

WASHINGTON -- President Obama may find a rare opening for possible bipartisan cooperation, with a Republican House helping to re-energize American efforts to reduce trade barriers. The president wants American exports to double by 2015, but to do that he will have to make progress on a trade agenda. At the top of the list are the completion of free-trade agreements with South Korea, Colombia and Panama that have languished since 2007; jump-starting the Doha round of world trade negotiations, which have been stalled for two years; and expansion of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, that could open the way for more trade between the Americas and the Asia-Pacific region.

Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 19 about people who have reached or are nearing their 100th birthday misstated the number of presidencies they have lived through. It is 18 (Taft through Obama), not 19.

Escalating a war of words between his government and Yale University, President Alan Garcia of Peru has made a formal request for President Obama's intervention in a long-running dispute over the ownership of a large group of artifacts excavated in 1912 at Machu Picchu by a Yale explorer. Peru has argued that the items were only lent to the university and should have been returned long ago. Yale has contended that it returned all borrowed objects in the 1920s, retaining only those to which it had full title. In 2007 the sides reached a tentative agreement that would have set up a long-term collaboration and granted title of the disputed antiquities to Peru while allowing a certain number, including the piece above, to remain at Yale for study and display. But that deal fell apart in 2008, and Peru filed a civil suit in federal court in Connecticut.

Morphoses, the dance company co-founded by the choreographer Christopher Wheeldon, has figured out its plans after Mr. Wheeldon abruptly announced his departure as artistic director in February. His co-founder and the company's director, Lourdes Lopez, said on Wednesday that a different artistic director will be put in place each season. First on the list is Luca Veggetti, the Italian stage director and choreographer. He will produce an ''original, full-length, multidisciplinary staging'' of Euripides' ''Bacchae'' next season, collaborating with the Italian composer Paolo Aralla, the performance artist and playwright Luca Scarlini and the flutist Erin Lesser, the company said. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

SOLOMON--John. The Dalton School mourns the loss of parent, John Solomon, father of Sara '18 and Rebecca '21 and husband to Abby. A regular visitor to his daughter's classrooms and a valued participant in the Dalton community, we will miss his ready smile and warm sense of humor. We extend our deepest condolences to the Solomon family. Ellen C. Stein The Dalton School

SORENSEN--Ted. The International Center for Transitional Justice community mourns the passing of Ted Sorensen. From the time he joined our board as a founding member, Ted always asked the tough and insightful questions, making sure we stayed focused on achieving tangible results that would improve people's lives in the countries we serve. He did so with charm and wit and with a canny instinct for always ferreting out what was important. He loved to spend time exchanging ideas with young people at ICTJ and he was unfailingly courteous to everyone in our organization. We shall miss this great and gentle man who was a true humanist and an inspiration to us all. We pass our condolences to Ted's beloved Gillian and the entire Sorensen family. Kofi Appenteng, Chairman David Tolbert, President Vincent Mai, Board Member Harvey P. Dale, Board Member Ken Miller, Board Member Minna Schrag, Board Member Alex Boraine, Founding President Juan Mendez, President Emeritus

TOMMY, a new collection being introduced by Tommy Hilfiger, takes the company's traditional preppy look and pitches it toward a younger downtown crowd. Pictured are a green military jacket ($129), skirt ($69), scarf ($34), boot ($119) and suede belt ($29). The men's tote is $59. The line is available at a new store that features a chandelier made of bicycle parts. 375 Bleecker Street (Perry Street); (646) 638-4812.

RIZZO--Thomas Dignan, died on November 2, 2010 after a long and fulfilling life. He is survived by his devoted wife of 52 years, Jean Kathryn Foley. Preceded in death by his parents, Rose and Peter-Cyrus Rizzo, MD, his twin brother Peter-Cyrus Rizzo, III, MD, and son, Robert Gerard. He is survived by his six children Thomas, Jr. (Margaret), Peter Foley (Charlotte) James (Patty), Kathryn English (J.L.), William (Elisa) and Francis (Meeghan), 20 grandchildren: Thomas, III, Katie, Elizabeth, Carolyn, Meredith, Hilary, Matthew, Alex, Madeleine, Abigail, Peter, Luke, Timothy, Grace, Claire, Lucy, John, Billy, Sara, Jean Kathryn; and dozens of nieces and nephews. "Big Daddy," as he was affectionately known by to his grandchildren, graduated in 1949 from Fordham Preparatory School. He was a cum laude graduate from Georgetown University and Georgetown Medical School in 1958 and 1956, respectively. The discrepancy occurred when he was accepted to medical school early prior to completing his undergraduate studies. He trained in surgery at St. Vincent's Hospital (NY) and in orthopedic surgery at The Hospital for Special Surgery (Hospital for the Ruptured and Crippled). He also was a Fellow of the American College of Surgeons. Following his service as captain in the USAF from 1959-1961, he completed a fellowship at Newington Hospital for Crippled Children. In 1963, he entered private practice and was a member of the surgical staff at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, NY until his retirement in 2009. Over his career he had appointments at St. John's Riverside Hospital, Dobbs Ferry Hospital, Doctors Hospital, and The Hospital for Special Surgery. He was a member of a number of medical and academic organizations including the American Medical Association, Georgia Orthopaedic Society, Past President of the Westchester County (NY) Medical Society, Alpha Omega Alpha Honor Medical Society, Eastern Orthopedic Association, Veteran Member of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, Georgetown University School of Medicine Board of Visitors, and the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons. In addition to being a member of the Knights of Malta, he was an honorary usher at the Cathedral of Saint Patrick, where he was privileged to serve during the Papal visits of John Paul II and Benedict XVI. After "retiring" to Georgia, he became involved with the Coastal Medical Access Program (CMAP) for Southeastern Georgia and was a member of the Board of Trustees for the International Seafarers' Center. His advice to his children and grandchildren was that "your inheritance is your education" and he afforded them a great one. It was with great pride he helped endow the Peter-Cyrus Rizzo and Rose Dignan Rizzo Chair in Orthopedic Surgery at Georgetown University School of Medicine in honor of his parents, and establish the Rizzo Family Science Lab at St. Joseph School in Bronxville, NY, a nationally recognized blue ribbon grammar school, where his children were educated. A Mass of Christian Burial will take place at St. William Catholic Church, St. Simons Island, Georgia on November 5, 2010. A memorial service at Saint Joseph's Church, Bronxville will be determined at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. William Catholic Church or the Hospice of the Golden Isles in Brunswick, GA.

To the editor: I enjoyed Gillian Reagan's piece on the trend in dyeing hair red (''Carriers of the Torch, in a Chorus of Red,'' Oct. 28). Since 1999 I've been working on a book about cultural representations of redheads, and it's hardly new for singers to make a statement about a fresh direction for their careers by going red. For her ''Ray of Light'' album (1998), Madonna dyed her hair strawberry blond; David Bowie's most outrageous incarnation, Ziggy Stardust (1972), was topped with a bright copper shag; and Johnny Rotten's spiked red hair has survived his return to John Lydon. Anne Margaret Daniel
ALASKA

EMMETT--Karen. The Principals and staff of BWD Group LLC are stunned by the devastating loss of our friend and colleague, Karen. As executive assistant to Marc Blumencranz for 17 years, she was both his friend and indispensible teammate. Karen's untimely and sudden death at the age of 49 is heart wrenching and inconceivable to us all. Her professionalism and dedication to BWD were unsurpassed. Karen will also be missed for her fun loving nature as she was often the life of the party. We would like to extend our deepest heartfelt condolences to her loving husband Kevin, to Junior, her parents and all of her family. Roger, Stuart, Marc and Eric

SAN FRANCISCO -- The mayor quoted Jerry Garcia, and one player pulled underwear out of his pants and held it up before 100,000 people. Another player referred to a ballot proposition to legalize marijuana as spectators with orange wigs and provocative signs cheered, snapped photos and blew kisses at their heroes. A city known for its alternative flair hosted a gigantic party Wednesday to celebrate that most American of championships, a World Series title, in a bash befitting the long wait so many of the city's residents had endured to participate in this event.
THE ARTS A video game review on Saturday about Rock Band 3, which can be connected to computer music software like Pro Tools, misidentified the maker of Pro Tools. It is Avid, not Apple.

EVENTS Armed with thread, custom-made fabric and a sewing machine, the designer Karelle Levy makes custom clothes on the spot, a process she has christened ''Quickie Couture.'' Ms. Levy is setting up shop from 4 to 9 p.m. tonight at the EVA NEW YORK boutique on the Bowery. Ms. Levy cuts and pins the garment on the customer's body: a sweater takes about 20 minutes; a gown an hour. ''I don't do zippers, I don't do buttons, I keep it simple,'' says Ms. Levy, who has a knitwear line, Krelwear. Clients are encouraged to take part in the creative process, by dictating anything from a lower V-neck to one-arm dresses. A tank top is approximately $50; a dress starts at $100. Nothing exceeds $350. Ms. Levy has taken Polaroids of the nearly 850 pieces completed in the last two years, some of which may be found at krel2go.blogspot.com. 355A Bowery (4th Street); (212) 925-3890. evanewyork.net.

WOMEN who fondly remember wearing their chunky ''Doc Martens'' with baby doll dresses will want to make a pilgrimage to the new Dr. Martens flagship store in SoHo, which is based on its Northhamptonshire factory yet has the reverential feel of a fine arts gallery. The boots are displayed on glass shelves surrounded by gold frames, illuminated by a lighting scheme, and shoppers can lounge in leather club chairs when trying on shoes. The store, opened in conjunction with the brand's 50th anniversary, will feature boots in the exclusive-to-New-York colors Big Apple Red and Statue of Liberty Green (above, $139.95). Dr. Martens, 148 Spring Street (Wooster Street); (212) 226-8500; drmartens.com.

DES MOINES -- An unprecedented vote to remove three Iowa Supreme Court justices who were part of the unanimous decision that legalized same-sex marriage in the state was celebrated by conservatives as a popular rebuke of judicial overreach, even as it alarmed proponents of an independent judiciary. The outcome of the election was heralded both as a statewide repudiation of same-sex marriage and as a national demonstration that conservatives who have long complained about ''legislators in robes'' are able to effectively target and remove judges who issue unpopular decisions.

Thomas C. Foley, a wealthy Republican businessman, and Dannel P. Malloy, a former Democratic mayor of Stamford, remained locked in a tight race to become Connecticut's next governor, according to incomplete returns. By 9:30 a.m. on Wednesday, partial returns showed that Mr. Foley led by 11,000 votes, or one percentage point, out of one million ballots cast. But 10 percent of the state's precincts had not yet reported, and most of those were in the Democratic strongholds of Bridgeport and New Haven, prompting Democrats to express guarded optimism that Mr. Malloy would eke out a victory.

Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson picked up shortstop Jose Reyes's $11 million option for 2011 and continues to negotiate with Arn Tellem, the agent for reliever Hisanori Takahashi. The Mets have offered Takahashi a one-year deal, but he wants a multiyear contract. If no deal is reached by midnight Saturday, Takahashi will become a free agent and will not return to the Mets because by rule he could not re-sign until May 15.

A report in the Browsing column last Thursday about Club Monaco's collaboration with the online retailer Shopbop misstated Club Monaco's history of selling items online. The company had a brief e-commerce operation in the late 1990s; this is not its first one.

If Kanye West really wanted to astound us maybe he would have spent Election Night at home watching returns and waiting to see if the Republicans retook the House of Representatives. Instead, hip-hop's answer to Zelig took a slightly less surprising route: on Tuesday night Mr. West spent several hours on New York's Hot 97 radio station (97.1 FM), fielding questions from the host Funkmaster Flex in a rollicking and candid interview. Needless to say, it did not take long for Funkmaster Flex to bring up Mr. West's appearance at the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards, when he interrupted an acceptance speech by Taylor Swift to complain that her award for best video by a female artist should have gone to Beyonce. And instead of adopting the apologetic stance he had previously taken when addressing the subject, Mr. West gave a more complicated and revealing response.

ROSENBERG--Shelly Kane, 54, died quietly on November 3, 2010 after a short illness. He is survived by his wife Rachel, daughter Chloe, mother Muriel and sisters Lisa and Susan. Shelly was a long- standing member of the furniture industry and most recently owned SRA Home, a furniture and fabric distributor and sales company. Shelly was very proud of his standing as an Eagle Scout and loved his softball league and skiing with his daughter. He was much beloved by his many close friends and family members and he loved them equally. Funeral services 10am Friday, November 5th, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spent much of the run-up to Tuesday's election as campaigner-in-chief, traveling the country to endorse or hold fund-raisers for some 30 candidates. So how did the mayor's picks fare on Election Day? For the most part, those who received the Bloomberg treatment prevailed, including four of six candidates for governor and seven of eight candidates for the House of Representatives.

RUMSEY--Mary Maloney. Born April 21,1911, the daughter of Edward and Hilda Maloney, in East Norwich, NY. She later attended Rutgers University. On October 5, 1934 she married Charles Rumsey and remained happily married to him until his death in 2007. She resided in Sands Point, New York and New York City. She is survived by her son Charles C. Rumsey Jr. and her daughter Celia D. Rumsey, two granddaughters of her deceased son Peter; Celia C. Rumsey and Alita Rumsey Kavalauskas, and four great-grandchildren; Ian, Nicole, Kevin and Dean. She began her career as a social worker. During the course of her life she became an active philanthropist, a patron of the arts, and an avid gardener. She will be deeply missed. A memorial service will be held Friday, November 5, 2010 at 11am at the United Methodist Church, 35 Middle Neck Road, Port Washington, NY 11050. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in memory of Mary M. Rumsey, to the Nassau County Museum of Art, 1 Museum Drive, Roslyn Harbor, NY, 11576. Attention: Constance Schwarz.

BUSINESS DAY An article on Monday about Steven Spielberg's efforts to re-energize DreamWorks Studios misstated the worldwide ticket sales of ''The Peacemaker,'' the first movie released by the original DreamWorks SKG. The worldwide total was about $110 million -- not $69 million, which was its foreign sales. (United States sales added another $41 million.)

In a case study we've just published, Adriana Gardella writes about Fikes Products, a 30-employee company that sells janitorial supplies and services to restaurants, retailers, and other businesses. Mark Sims, the owner, wanted to hire a strong No. 2 person and also fill four additional slots. But he didn't trust his own hiring abilities and he was reluctant to spend the money for a recruiter. Ultimately, he did decide to use a recruiter. Below, you can read what several business owners with relevant experience think of Mr. Sims's decisions, and you can leave your own comments below. We'll follow up next week with a blog post that will explain how the decisions worked for Fikes.

LUSSIER--Lillian S.,105, resident of Sayville, Long Island and Northridge, California died on October 29. She is deeply missed by her daughter, Virginia, her family, and friends. She gave generously of her time to others. She never had an unkind word to say about anyone. She enhanced everything she touched. Her sterling character traits made her a true pleasure to be around. We will miss you, Lillian.

It's the players that have been in the league who will have to adjust to him. Already regarded as one of the fastest players with the ball in his hand, John Wall was a blur Tuesday night in the Wizards' home opener against the Philadelphia 76ers.

On Saturday, all eyes will be on the Mountain West. At least all the eyes that can be. Texas Christian will travel to play Utah in one of the more intriguing matchups between undefeated teams this season. Both teams have established themselves as top-notch programs in the past decade, but they find themselves lagging behind Boise State this season when it comes to non-B.C.S. teams cracking the B.C.S. This game provides a chance for each to showcase why they should be considered among the country's elite. Another team that is hoping for some national recognition is Baylor, which beat Texas last week and is hoping to go into Oklahoma State and upend the Cowboys. Nick Saban is sure to get a, ahem, loud reception when Alabama takes the field against Louisiana State. Perhaps Les Miles can draw on some of his magic and help the Tigers beat back the Tide. Arkansas and South Carolina face off in another marquee SEC matchup, while Arizona will look to slow down Stanford's offense in a key Pac-10 game.

Twenty years ago I witnessed what seemed to be a medical miracle in a village deep in Bolivia: a nearly lifeless child dehydrated by severe diarrhea was given sips of a sugar and salt solution and recovered in a couple of hours. Curious about this simple yet lifesaving mixture called oral rehydration solution, I learned that United States-funded scientists had discovered it in 1968 in then-East Pakistan as a simple, cheap alternative to intravenous treatment. Defying all expectations, the researchers learned that at the right proportions, oral rehydration could resurrect even severely dehydrated adults suffering from cholera.

Stuffed cabbage need not be difficult, nor do you have to serve it in a ketchupy, sickly sweet sauce. Made with a well-spiced tomato sauce, it can be really good. I made stuffed cabbage with lamb and rice for this week's Minimalist.

"I just wanted to capture the momentum of the day," says Frank Muytjens, the head designer of men's wear at J. Crew. Equipped with a Canon EOS 7D camera, Muytjens drew out the ease and effortlessness of J. Crew's spring 2011 collection on his models leading up to the presentation yesterday at Milk Studios. "It can get crazy backstage, but it's always a calm and organized chaos," Muytjens says. This mentality complements the Americana feel derived from Cy Twombly, Irving Penn, naval uniforms and Prouts Neck: "It's a clean, fresh look but with a lot of texture - disheveled dressy. Fabrics with metal yarns woven in - nubby rustic yarns for sweaters, but in a fitted silhouette." Highlights include a reworked gray hoodie elevated through toggle and button closures, paired with vintage patchwork detailed shorts. The collection hits stores on Feb. 11.

Except when visualizing alligators in the sewers and lost fishbowl pets, New Yorkers rarely think about what happens to the stuff that drains from sinks and toilet bowls. The first week of November is a melancholy time in college football. The season is in full swing, but the end is in sight. A good or bad start can be erased with wins or losses in November. This week the Mountain West takes center stage as a pair of top-five teams battles for a conference crown as well as maybe a spot in a Bowl Championship Series game (or even a shot at a national title). In the South, Alabama travels to Baton Rouge with the SEC West in the balance. At the same time, Texas Christian plays Utah. It would be a good Saturday to be in front of several televisions. Oklahoma State hosts Baylor (yes, Baylor) with each team in control of its destiny in the Big 12 South. There is a logjam at the top of the Big 10. How will that shake out? There are only a few Saturdays left.

A Zaha Hadid-designed wine tasting pavilion (above) or stemless Riedel wineglass may seem commonplace now. But they are manifestations of a cultural shift that happened after the so-called Judgment of Paris in 1976, in which a number of California wines were deemed superior to their French counterparts. On Nov. 20, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art will open ''How Wine Became Modern: Design and Wine 1976 to Now.'' Organized by Henry Urbach, the museum's curator of architecture and design, the exhibition - which is designed by the architects Diller Scofidio and Renfro - explores the evolution of wine's visual and material culture. It includes a gallery devoted to the subject of terroir, a commissioned wall work by Peter Wegner that charts more than 200 paint colors with names like Cabernet and Crush, and a look at, among other issues, the effect of architecture on wine tourism. The museum knows the subject well, having organized the first architectural competition for the design of a winery, in 1985. The winner was the architect-artist team of Michael Graves and Edward Schmidt, resulting in Clos Pegase, the prototype of the modern designer winery.

For the last three decades, the Italian home products manufacturer Alessi has been at the forefront of design, producing instant icons like Michael Graves's bird-whistle teakettle (above), Philippe Starck's infamous Juicy Salif juicer and Richard Sapper's elegant espresso pot - a fixture on many a yuppie's high-end cooktop. The Philadelphia Museum of Art is celebrating the 90-year-old company with an exhibition, ''Alessi: Ethical and Radical,'' which opens Nov. 21. Central to Alessi's success is its creative mastermind, Alberto Alessi, a grandson of the founder, who has run the company since the 1970s. ''He's absolutely unique in the amount of time and money that he has spent on design,'' said Kathryn Hiesinger, the exhibition's curator. Included in the show are planned reissues of designs from the 1920s, '30s and '40s, a time that Alberto Alessi describes as ''predesign,'' before the rise of glossy ''designer'' products - which is ironic coming from the man who helped invent the category. But, as Heisinger explained, ''Alberto is now in his minimalist, simplicity mode; he's against overdesign.'' Well, he's been right before.

The age at which Europeans and Americans first have sex is the same -- 17, on average, on both sides of the Atlantic. The percentage who use birth control from the start? In Holland it's 64 percent and in the United States it's 26 percent. The percentage who have regrets about their first time, wishing they had waited: 63 percent of boys and 69 percent of girls in the United States, and only 5 percent of boys and 12 percent of girls in the Netherlands. Teen pregnancy rates: three to six times higher here than in Western Europe. S.T.D. rates: 20 to 30 times higher here than Holland. H.I.V. rate? Theirs is six times lower.

Now, the day that couldn't get here soon enough, is taking too long to go away.

The New York Philharmonic's Cuba strategy worked. The United States Treasury Department has issued a license for the orchestra to visit Havana sometime next year, a Philharmonic spokesman said in an e-mail late on Thursday. (The orchestra was in Luxembourg, wrapping up a European tour.) The Philharmonic last year canceled the trip because the Treasury Department had denied permission for its patrons - who were paying for the visit - to go along, viewing them as tourists and thus not allowed under United States sanctions. The orchestra tried to get around the problem by adding an educational concert and listing the patrons as docents. The spokesman, Eric Latzky, said approval came late Wednesday. The dates still have to be worked out.

When Frederic Malle, the master French perfumer, proclaims that his latest fragrance is one of his best ever, it's nothing to sniff at. He knows from perfume. To celebrate his company's 10-year anniversary, Mr. Malle teamed up with one of his favorite noses - Dominique Ropion- to create Portrait of a Lady, a heady mixture of ingredients such as Turkish rose essence, raspberry, cassis, cinnamon, patchouli heart, ambroxan and musk. The resulting scent- lushly feminine, with a sensually earthy dry-down courtesy of the patchouli- is fragrant proof that this lady has some serious sex appeal. Available next month for $280 (100 ml) at Barneys New York, or join the waiting list at Malle's Editions de Parfum, 898 Madison Avenue; (212) 249-7941.

The New York City Marathon is this Sunday, which means thousands of runners making their way through every borough, innumerable fans, and many flavors of blaring music. Many regard the marathon as a joyous occasion, but others see it as a serious disruption in their lives, Trymaine Lee reports in The Times. And nowhere is the conflict between excited supporter and annoyed city dweller more apparent than at mile 21, or 138th Street in Harlem, when the marathon turns down Fifth Avenue for the final stretch. As some runners hit the wall and others push themselves for the finish, the race cuts a swath through the daily lives of the neighborhood's residents, for good or ill.

There's something for everyone at F.D, the philanthropist and collector Fiona Druckenmiller's new Midtown boutique. That is, if the everyone in question is seeking exquisite new and vintage jewels (the shop boasts an impressive cache of period Cartier and Van Cleef & Arpels), watches, sculptures, Art Deco furniture, photography, first-edition manuscripts and swanky barware. The interior, designed in collaboration with the décor firm Pamela Banker Associates, is best described as cozy chic. "We wanted it to be homey and welcoming, not intimidating," Druckenmiller says. "People will hopefully feel comfortable enough to linger, have a coffee or glass of wine, and spend time learning about the objects that interest them."

The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation has given the Smithsonian Institution $30 million to create an endowment for online education programs aimed at students in underserved communities. The donation was reported on Wednesday by the Puget Sound Business Journal. In a press release, the Smithsonian said it would use the donation to build on existing programs that use interactive Web sites, online conferences, distance learning and games to reach new audiences. The donation follows two $10 million grants by the foundation to the Smithsonian since 2009, one of them to support the construction of the new National Museum of African American History and Culture. The chairwoman of the Smithsonian's board of regents, Patricia Q. Stonesifer, is a former chief executive of the Gates Foundation. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

MINTZ--Seymour S. On Wednesday, November 3, 2010, Seymour S. Mintz of Bethesda, MD. Beloved husband of Bettie Mintz; devoted father of Alex Stein, Sallie Findlay, John Mintz and James Mintz; grandfather of six and great-grandfather of four. A Memorial Service will be held at Joseph Gawler's Sons Chapel, 5130 Wisconsin Ave. NW, Washington, DC 20016 on Sunday, November 7 at 2pm. Interment private.

LEHRER--Jacob (Jack), of Santa Rosa, California died at age 81 on October 31, 2010. He is survived by his wife Sonja of 53 years, his six children (and spouses), Erik (Elizabeth), Ingrid (Chris), Heidi, Jake (Melissa), Pieter (Christy) and Kristen, his fabulous 10 grandchildren, and his brother, Sander Lehrer of New York City; his brother Joseph and sister Hannah predeceased him. Jack was a builder of homes and commercial properties for 50 years in Long Island, New York, Antigua, West Indies and Northern California. He was a high school and college running back, a licensed aircraft pilot and an accomplished sailor. He welcomed challenges, seeing them always as opportunities. He loved his work and being with his family and friends. He was dearly loved and will be sorely missed and lovingly remembered always.

Like Jerry Moss, Sting is no stranger to success, achieving stardom as the front man of The Police on Moss's A&M Records label. So it seems fitting that the most decorated racehorse that Moss has ever owned is named after the band's third album, ''Zenyattà Mondatta.'' It is a formula that Moss has cashed in on before, when Giacomo, named after Sting's son, won the Kentucky Derby in 2005. But if Giacomo achieved gold status, Zenyatta, at 19-0, is well on her way to platinum.

9 P.M. (NBC) DATELINE NBC In March 2006 Matthew Winkler, whose Church of Christ congregation knew him as a pious preacher and a loving father and husband, was found shot dead in the bedroom of his home in Selmer, Tenn. Police searched for his wife, Mary (above), and the couple's three daughters, finally locating them in Alabama. Ms. Winkler confessed to killing her husband, alleging that he inflicted severe mental and physical abuse on her, and that she was worried for the safety of their children. In 2007 she was convicted of voluntary manslaughter, confined to a mental health center for treatment and freed after 67 days. In this two-hour report she speaks with Keith Morrison about what drove her to kill. 8 P.M. (National Geographic) DOG WHISPERER Rhona Mitra, who bares her fangs as a picture-perfect housewife with vampire tendencies on ''The Gates'' on ABC, worked at a dog rescue center as a teenager. But it's Ms. Mitra who needs rescuing from the aggression of her own French bulldog, Oscar, whose sweet temperament turned sour after he was attacked by a pit bull while on location with his actress owner in South Africa. Now Ms. Mitra is worried that he'll escape from the yard of their home in Venice, Calif., which is in a neighborhood she calls ''pit central.''

An article on Aug. 6 about the finances of the Denver Public Schools referred imprecisely to a 2008 debt issue that contained an interest-rate swap. While the 2008 deal differed from a security sold by the school system in 2005 and carried more risk than the earlier version, both deals used an interest-rate swap; the 2008 version was not the first time that type of swap was used.

The Chilean miners have been rescued, so let the book deals begin. A reporter for the British newspaper The Guardian has sold ''33 Men,'' an account of the miners' ordeal, to G. P. Putnam's Sons, the publisher announced on Thursday.

Though it may appear in the pictured photograph that the artist Louis Wiltshire is working on a shapeless mass of clay, or possibly some outrageous outfit that Lady Gaga will wear to her next public appearance, we are assured by the people at Madame Tussauds that he is in fact transforming it into a likeness of that pop star's head, which will sit atop one of eight figures of Lady Gaga that the wax museum franchise is preparing. On Thursday, Madame Tussauds said it would simultaneously reveal all eight Lady Gaga sculptures at its worldwide locations on Dec. 9, depicting the ''Poker Face'' and ''Bad Romance'' singer in styles described as Lady in Lace (the outfit worn by Lady Gaga at the 2010 Brit Awards); Telephone (worn on the BBC talk show ''Friday Night With Jonathan Ross'' in March); Harlequin (worn at the Grand Intercontinental Hotel Seoul); Kinky Boots (worn at the Hakkasan restaurant in London); Mini Mouse (worn at the BBC Radio studios); Hair Hat (worn at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas); Wired Wing Dress (worn on the German show ''Wetten, Dass ..?''); and Big Hair (worn outside the Phoenix Hotel in Copenhagen).

9:46 p.m. | Updated Charlie Samuels, the Mets' longtime clubhouse manager, has been suspended after the team learned he was tied to a law-enforcement investigation into illegal gambling, according to a lawyer briefed on the matter and a law-enforcement official. The gambling is believed to be tied to football, the lawyer said Thursday.

Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet, the company formed in 2003 by the Wal-Mart heiress Nancy Laurie and led by its artistic director, Benoit-Swan Pouffer, possesses spacious Chelsea headquarters, the money to commission works by out-of-town choreographers and an online store. Yet the most attractive part of the Cedar Lake package is its 15 dancers -- even in less-than-stellar pieces and wearing socks. (They love to dance in socks.) On Tuesday night the group returned to the Joyce Theater to present its second program of the season, featuring the New York premiere of Hofesh Shechter's ''Fools,'' originally created for Bern Ballet but expanded for Cedar Lake, as well as Didy Veldman's ''Frame of View,'' choreographed for the troupe in 2009. The evening also included a reprise of ''Sunday, Again,'' a fairly dire work by Jo Stromgren performed on last week's program.

An article on Thursday about a decision by Iowa voters on Tuesday to remove three of the state's Supreme Court justices referred incorrectly to the composition of the State Judicial Nominating Commission, which will nominate replacements. The group includes seven nonlawyer commissioners appointed by the governor; it is not composed entirely of lawyers.

During trick-or-treat time last Sunday, intrepid Times staffers visited the homes of the candidates for governor, where they were handed fistfuls of Junior Mints and Laffy Taffy, sniffed by Carl P. Paladino's dog and greeted by Andrew M. Cuomo himself. But it turns out that the best Halloween story was unfolding at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's town house on Manhattan's Upper East Side. Halloween insiders in that neighborhood know that the mayor - who has declared war on junk food - gives out the biggest and most caloric treats: full-size candy bars. This year Mr. Bloomberg did not disappoint: Our source reports that the mayor - actually, it may not have been the mayor; it was a person dressed up as Mickey Mouse - answered the door at the five-story Beaux Arts town house and dispensed big Snickers and Twix bars out of a plastic pumpkin as Mr. Bloomberg's security team looked on. The source, who admits actually visiting Mr. Bloomberg's home twice Sunday, once about 5 p.m., then again at 7:30, said that on his second visit, it was dark, and the candy had all run out. But the Mickey character, in a high-pitched voice, instructed the trick-or-treaters to wait, and then another mysterious figure appeared, with more rich goodies. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The Seattle Symphony, suffering from a momentary leadership vacuum, has settled on a British orchestra official, Simon Woods, as its next executive director. Mr. Woods, a former president and chief executive of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra who is now chief executive of the Royal Scottish National Orchestra, will take over in Seattle in May, the orchestra said on Wednesday. Meanwhile, Mr. Woods will spend one week a month in Seattle starting in January, a spokeswoman said, and the chairwoman of the orchestra's board, Leslie Jackson Chihuly, ''is taking an active role'' until he arrives. The orchestra's previous top administrator left in February, and a temporary replacement departed last month. Mr. Woods's arrival will coincide with that of the new music director, Ludovic Morlot, who takes over next season from Gerard Schwarz. Mr. Schwarz is in his 26th season with the orchestra. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

ASHFORTH--Elsie L.,of Rye, NY and Palm Beach, FL died October 30, 2010 of a sudden heart attack in Greenwich, CT. She was 96 and the widow of James H. Madden and H. Adams Ashforth, Sr., both of Greenwich. Prior to his death, Mr. Ashforth had been Chairman of the Board of The Ashforth Company, a real estate concern with properties on the east and west coasts. Mrs. Ashforth is survived by her daughter Christina L. Madden (Mrs. Charles S. Whitman III) of New York, her son Peter Madden of Glenville, CT, and her granddaughter Elizabeth Whitman of New York. Another son, Michael Madden, predeceased her. Mrs. Ashforth is also survived by three step- children: Mrs. Eldon Harvey, Jr. of Mystic, CT, Alden Ashforth of New Orleans, and Marna A. Geoffroy of Los Angeles, as well as 14 step- grandchildren, 30 stepgreat-grandchildren and two stepgreat-great-grandchildren. She was predeceased by a stepson, Henry A. Ashforth, Jr. Born April 8, 1914 to Raymond D. and Beatrice Kobbe Little, Elsie Ashforth grew up in Europe and was privately educated there. (Mr. Little had served on a number of Davis Cup tennis teams for the United States in the 1900-1920 era.) She was a Powers model in the 1930s, and lent her first name to the female cow, wife to the bull Elmer, in a famous series of Borden Milk cartoon print commercials. A talented artist, particularly in watercolor, she exhibited her work in New York and Connecticut, and only ceased painting in her eighties, when she published her memoirs. She was active to the end and made many younger friends in her later years in Rye and Palm Beach. Beautiful inside and outside, she was always a perfect lady. Greatly beloved by all, she will be deeply missed and lovingly remembered. Services will be held Friday, November 5, 2010. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, Greenwich, CT 06831.

KRAMER--Alexander D.,94, of Cliffside Park, NJ formerly of Woodmere, NY, on November 3. Beloved husband and best friend for 60 years of Muriel (Rosenberg), adored father of Lisa Kramer and Laurie and Jerry Rockoff, and adoring grandfather of Zachary and Max. You will be in our hearts forever.

Edison Peña blinked in the glare of camera flashes and shook his head as if in disbelief that he was in New York to run the marathon. Humble in his crisp black suit and brown shoes, he may be a miner by trade, but he is a runner at his core. Nothing daunts him now, not even singing an Elvis solo. ''I gave a letter to the postman, he put it in his sack, bright and early next morning, he brought my letter back,'' Peña crooned in near-perfect pitch. ''She wrote upon it: Return to sender, address unknown.''

The Yankees hope to ring in the Christmas season with their fans this year. For the first time, the team is hosting a ''Breakfast With Santa'' on the mornings of Dec. 4 and 5 at the Hard Rock Cafe at Yankee Stadium. Fans will dine at a hot breakfast buffet, get a personal photo with Santa Claus and take a tour of the Stadium (which normally costs $15 for adults and $8 for others). Children will receive a gift bag with goodies ''directly from the North Pole.''

BOCK--Jerrold Lewis. The Dramatists Guild Council mourns the passing of Guild member Jerry Bock, one of the most accomplished composers in the history of Broadway. As his colleagues, we will miss not only the charm and lyricism of his music, but even more the grace of his company. We extend our deepest sympathies to his loved ones at this difficult time. Stephen Schwartz, President The Dramatists Guild of America

Once again, George Wein's jazz festivals in New York and Newport, R.I., are without title sponsors. CareFusion, the medical technology company that supported the New York series this summer and the Newport festival for the last two, will not be renewing its deal, the company said in an announcement circulated by Mr. Wein, 85, who helped found the Newport Jazz Festival in 1954.

James Harrison has said he still doesn't know what he could have done differently on his hit to a Cleveland receiver three weeks ago that drew a $75,000 fine from the N.F.L. and became one of the prime examples in the league's crackdown on hits to the head. On Thursday, the N.F.L. gave Harrison something more to think about. It fined him $20,000 for hitting Saints quarterback Drew Brees with the crown of his helmet Sunday after Brees had already thrown a pass. He has now been fined a total of $100,000 in the first half of the season. He was fined $5,000 in September for a hit on Tennessee quarterback Vince Young.

MITTY--Msgr. Edward John J.,PA, passed away peacefully at St. Patrick's Home on Tuesday, November 2nd, 2010. He was born October 10, 1924 to William F. and Margaret Mitty. Msgr. Mitty was predeceased by his brothers, John Mitty and Dr. William F. Mitty and his sister, Mary C. Mitty. He is survived by his devoted sister, Margaret M. Conroy. He is also survived by his nephew Francis Conroy, wife Gail and their children Christine, Kevin, and Meghan. Msgr. Mitty was ordained April 26, 1950 by his uncle, The Most Reverend John J. Mitty, D.D., the former Archbishop of San Francisco at St. Joseph's Seminary. Throughout his sixty years of service to the Archdiocese, he served at: St. Mary's in Katonah, and St. Joseph's in Yorkville, Chaplain of The Harlem Valley State Hospital, Director of Calvary and Allied Cemeteries, and Pastor of Our Lady of Victory in lower Manhattan. He was made Domestic Prelate and Assistant Chancellor in 1965 and Prothonotary Apostolic in 1966. Msgr. Mitty was an active member of The New York Athletic Club and The Friendly Sons of St. Patrick. The Wall Street community and Our Lady of Victory Parish played a major role in Msgr.'s later life. He was indeed a spiritual presence after the tragedy of September 11th. Wall Street honored Msgr. Mitty at his retirement by asking him to ring the closing bell at the New York Stock Exchange. Msgr. was an avid traveler and led many religious pilgrimages. Visiting hours will be Thursday and Friday from 2-4 and 7-9 at the Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home in Bronxville, NY and Friday from 11-12:30pm at Our Lady of Victory Church, 60 William St, New York, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Margaret's of Cortona, Riverdale, NY on Saturday, November 6th at 10am. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

WOULD you be willing to place a bet that you'll live past the age of 80? What about 85? A relatively new product, known as longevity insurance, allows you to put money on those odds -- and the longer you can beat them, the more money you stand to collect. But the point isn't about making a ghoulish gamble. The insurance is a way to protect you from running out of money should you live to a ripe old age, though it turns your retirement years into something of a contest with the insurance company.

An article on Tuesday about China's new focus on investing in European countries hard hit by the financial crisis misstated the job title of Carl B. Fisk University in Nashville has gained approval to sell an ownership stake in its Stieglitz Art Collection to the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Ark., the university announced. Under the agreement, approved by the Chancery Court in Davidson County, the museum will pay the financially troubled university $30 million to acquire a one-half interest in the collection, which was donated to the university about 50 years ago by the artist Georgia O'Keeffe. But Fisk may have discretionary use of only $10 million of the proceeds, the court ruled. The rest is to be placed in an endowment fund and used solely for the costs of displaying and maintaining the art.

The chances of Hisanori Takahashi remaining with the Mets are dwindling by the hour as the deadline to re-sign him approaches. With no significant progress in contract talks, it appears he will leave the Mets. The Mets are not willing to guarantee a two-year contract for Takahashi, the versatile Japanese left-hander who wants at least that to remain with the team. It is believed that Takahashi's agent, Arn Tellem, is asking the Mets for a minimum of two years in the neighborhood of $4 million, while the Mets are willing to give him one guaranteed year and an option for a second, with the total value closer to $3 million.

With the midterm election results still rolling in, this Sunday's television talk shows focus on the lame duck session of Congress that begins in just over a week, and the next session, when Republicans will control the House.

In a letter to colleagues, the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, who is seeking to remain as minority leader despite her party's steep election losses, urged House Democrats to unite behind her and even said she hopes to help ousted lawmakers return to Congress in two years.

My Sunday column wrestles with growing economic inequality in America -- and the sad reality that our income gaps look like those of a classic banana republic. I didn't have space in the column to look at why the gaps have grown larger, but this is explored at some depth in the Slate series that I mention and link to in the column. It's not fundamentally about tax policy, but my hunch is that it has a good deal to do with social mores and acceptability.

Yes, I know: YHTMAAAIYP*. But: as a followup to my shibboleths post, I'm a bit shocked at the way so many people are treating US quantitative easing as somehow equivalent to Chinese currency manipulation.

Right now everyone seems to believe that rising commodity prices are telling us to beware of inflation. I think that's dead wrong. Partly that's because the sticky prices are the ones to worry about. But it's also worth having some perspective on commodity prices themselves.
