Randall Wallace knows a thing or two about show business. He wrote the screenplay for "Braveheart," which won the Academy Award for best picture and earned him a nomination for best original screenplay in 1996. He is also a novelist, songwriter, producer and director, and even has a black belt. What he is not is a horseman, and yet one would never guess that after viewing "Secretariat," which he directed and which has grossed more than $46 million domestically.

More than a quarter of the unmarried women who gave birth in a recent year were living with a partner, according to a Census Bureau report that for the first time measured the percentage of unmarried mothers who were not living alone. ''Everybody tends to think of single mothers as being alone with their child, and we wanted to look at whether that was true,'' said Jane Dye, the demographer who wrote the report, ''Fertility of American Women: 2008.'' ''We found that 28 percent of these women were living with an unmarried partner, whether opposite sex or same sex.''

Suzan-Lori Parks, the Pulitzer-Prize winning playwright of ''Topdog/Underdog,'' and Diedre Murray, the musician and composer, are developing a new version of ''Porgy and Bess'' that features rearrangements of George Gershwin's famed score and plays down its roots as an opera. Manden n'ko Radio was abuzz on a recent Wednesday night. Despite the hiss and crackle of cellphone static, the radio program - actually a massive, New York-based conference call for Guinean expatriates - draws hundreds of listeners. ''The number of Guineans abroad doesn't compare to the number in the country,'' one caller declared in French around 10 p.m. as Omar Sano, a taxi driver and volunteer radio host, listened. ''But these Guineans can represent thousands of Guineans in the country.''

The Mets no longer have the services of the versatile left-handed pitcher Hisanori Takahashi, who provided one of the few pleasant surprises for the team in 2010, in part because they were not willing to guarantee him a two-year contract worth roughly $4 million per season. They do, however, still have Oliver Perez, the ineffective left-hander who is owed $12 million next season after going 0-5 in 17 games in 2010.

The New York Philharmonic's Cuba strategy worked. The United States Treasury Department has issued a license for the orchestra to visit Havana sometime next year, a Philharmonic spokesman said in an e-mail late on Thursday. (The orchestra was in Luxembourg, wrapping up a European tour.) The Philharmonic last year canceled the trip because the Treasury Department had denied permission for its patrons - who were paying for the visit - to go along, viewing them as tourists and thus not allowed under United States sanctions. The orchestra tried to get around the problem by adding an educational concert and listing the patrons as docents. The spokesman, Eric Latzky, said approval came late Wednesday. The dates still have to be worked out. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

When he was growing up in Middle Village, Queens, a poor child from a working-class neighborhood, Mike Repole was pretty sure he could do anything. Maybe he would play shortstop for the Mets someday or become a multimillionaire. Maybe he'd own a young racehorse that would run so fast that anything, even a Kentucky Derby win, would seem possible. Repole never did play for the Mets. Other than that, he's doing pretty well. Repole, 41, a St. John's graduate, is a founder and the former president of Glaceau, the company that introduced Vitaminwater and was sold to Coca-Cola for a reported $4.1 billion. After conquering the business world, he set his sights on doing the same in horse racing and finding the sort of special horse that would keep him awake at night with nervous energy and anticipation. He thinks he might just have done it. He will know more Saturday at Churchill Downs.

It wasn't just your imagination: there really was an uptick in political ads this year. Hey, you: Do you like Michael Jackson? Have you spent the last eight months anxiously trolling the Internet for news of his posthumously assembled album of outtakes and unfinished tracks? Are you O.K. with long, tease-filled marketing campaigns? Yes? Well, then this is a great day for you. After saying in March that such an album would be released this fall, the estate of Michael Jackson and Epic Records, a division of Sony, announced on Thursday that the album would be called ''Michael,'' and would come out on Dec. 14. And what's on this album? Well, they're not saying much for now.

PHOENIX -- There was plenty of grim news for Latinos in Tuesday's election results: three Latino congressmen were voted out, the odds of an immigration overhaul appeared to diminish and -- here in the state that gave rise to the strictest immigration measure of all -- hardliners were re-elected amid vows to continue cracking down on illegal immigrants. But 2010 also signifies a milestone of sorts for Latinos, the country's largest minority: their overwhelming support for Democrats in the midterm elections is credited with helping to keep the Senate Democratic. And Latinos won an unprecedented voice in the Republican Party with the election of more Latino Republicans than ever before -- sometimes without the support of Latino voters, who tend to put issues before ethnicity.

WINTER--Eleanor L.,of Delray Beach, Florida died on November 3, 2010 at the age of 88. Beloved wife of the late Marvin S. Winter; adored mother of Benjamin and Susan Winter, James and Susan Winter, Douglas and Bonnie Winter, Karen and Barry Miller; adoring grandmother of David (Liz), Jennifer (Matt), Alison, Stacy (Ross), Kira, Eric, Jonathan, Nathan, Matthew and Dana; loving great grandmother of Mia, Charlie and Lily; and dear companion to Julius Spencer. Eleanor was a graduate of Skidmore College where she developed a lifelong interest in the arts and was a founding donor and continuing benefactor of the Tang Museum on the Skidmore campus. She was a dedicated philanthropist and formerly a trustee of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. Eleanor was a talented artist, a world traveler, a patron of the arts and a woman of indomitable spirit. She will be deeply missed and remembered with love. The family will observe a private funeral but will receive family and friends at Eleanor's apartment this coming Monday and Tuesday from 4pm to 8pm.

By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED 7:56 p.m. | Updated The American International Group on Friday reported a $2.4 billion loss for the third quarter on charges related to its restructuring, but said that its effort to repay its taxpayer-financed bailout was on track. A.I.G. also said that it was hoping to win approval to start selling the government's stakes in the company early next year. The second consecutive quarterly loss arose from $4.5 billion in charges related to various asset sales, including the initial public offering of a big Asian life insurance subsidiary. But income from its remaining insurance businesses rose more than 6 percent from the same time last year, to $2.1 billion.

WINTER--Eleanor Linder. The Skidmore College community mourns the death of Eleanor Linder Winter, Class of 1943, a generous benefactor, friend, and patron of the arts. Her philanthropy has provided special opportunities for Skidmore students to learn through exposure to the arts, particularly through her support of the College's Frances Young Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery, which named its Winter Gallery in her honor. Eleanor and her family, including grandson Jonathan Winter, Class of 2007, established the Winter Family Exhibition Fund to support students as they collaborate with faculty and Tang curators to create shows for the Winter Gallery. Skidmore further recognized Eleanor's commitment by naming the Department of Art History offices in her honor. All of us in the Skidmore community offer our deepest condolences to Eleanor's family and friends. Janet Lucas Whitman '59, Chair, Board of Trustees Philip A. Glotzbach, President

WOSK--Miriam, passed away peacefully on November 5th. She will be dearly missed. Born in Vancouver, she bravely moved to New York to study art at nineteen and then eventually to Los Angeles. She started her career as an illustrator, designing the famed cover of the first issue of Ms. Magazine, and ended it as a world-renowned artist. Miriam was a woman with a unique vision that she manifested in the world through her art, her personal style, her home, her collections and the people she chose to surround herself with. She loved color; she loved the sun; she loved the ocean; she loved quiet and she also loved any excess of the senses. Her curiosity took her around the world and she brought the world into her home. Miriam was a wonderful hostess. She was a committed supporter of the arts, of creativity in all forms, and of spiritual pursuits. She faced illness with courage and grace. Above all, she was a deeply loving mother. She is survived by her son, Adam Gunther, and a large network of extended family and friends. A private funeral for family will be held in Hawaii. There will be a memorial service announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Inner City Arts at 720 Kohler Street, Los Angeles, CA 90021.

Women abound in plays about science. How else would writers simplify lofty concepts for the audience without some wife, sister or comely student fetchingly furrowing her brow at the brilliant fellows and saying something along the lines of, ''Wait, let me get this straight ...''? Among the many virtues of Anna Ziegler's intermittently pedantic but largely satisfying ''Photograph 51'' is a refusal to soften the woman at its center, the British scientist Rosalind Franklin (Kristen Bush), by making her anything other than formidably, even self-sabotagingly, intelligent. As Ms. Ziegler tells it, Franklin -- who got further faster than anyone else in the 1950s race to grasp the double-helical structure of DNA, only to falter because of her own rigorous standards -- is possibly the smartest and definitely the most persistent person in the room.

In place of flowers, a donation may be made in her memory to the Children's Cancer and Blood Foundation, 333 East 38th Street, Suite 830 New York, New York 10016 (212-297-4336) .

8 P.M. (HBO) AVATAR (2009) This ''trippy joy ride about the end of life -- our moviegoing life included,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, took several decades of dreaming, four years of making and a production budget of $230 million from the director James Cameron. It also snared nine Oscar nominations but failed to earn both the best director and best picture awards. (Those went to Mr. Cameron's ex-wife Kathryn Bigelow for ''The Hurt Locker.'') Sam Worthington plays a paraplegic former Marine who is transported from a wheelchair into a 10-foot, blue-skinned, part-alien and part-human body, above right, the better to infiltrate, on behalf of a greedy corporation, a distant moon that harbors a valuable substance called unobtainium. Alas, he falls in love, with both this lush, brilliantly colored dreamscape and one of its slinky inhabitants (Zoë Saldana), above left. ''Created to conquer hearts, minds, history books and box-office records, the movie -- one of the most expensive in history, the jungle drums thump -- is glorious and goofy and blissfully deranged,'' Ms. Dargis said. ''If the story of a paradise found and potentially lost feels resonant, it's because 'Avatar' is as much about our Earth as the universe that Mr. Cameron has invented. But the movie's truer meaning is in the audacity of its filmmaking.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY On Wednesday the Supreme Court heard oral arguments opposing a program that gives Arizona taxpayers a dollar-for-dollar state tax credit of up to $500 for donations to private ''student tuition organizations.'' These groups are permitted to limit the scholarships they offer to schools of a given religion, and many do. In their challenge, some Arizona taxpayers said the program, in effect, used state money to finance religious education and thus violated the First Amendment's prohibition on the official establishment of religion. Tim O'Brien reports.

But Mr. Coppola, the director whose films include ''The Godfather'' and ''The Outsiders,'' dreams of more universal terrors, and it was one such vision that inspired his coming film, ''Twixt Now and Sunrise,'' which he is currently shooting and plans to release next year. In a statement Mr. Coppola discussed the origins of the movie, which stars Val Kilmer and which he said ''seemed to have the imagery of Hawthorne or Poe.''

We don't quite have a story today but there's a little surprise near the end that, if things work out correctly, makes you revisit the theme with a new appreciation. The first three theme answers start with words that are roughly synonyms. As every public figure knows, there are certain words that can not be uttered without causing shock or offense. These words, commonly known as "slurs," target groups on the basis of race, nationality, religion, gender, sexual orientation, immigration status and sundry other demographics.  Many of us were reminded of the impact of such speech in August, when the radio host Dr. Laura Schlessinger repeatedly uttered a racial slur on a broadcast of her show. A public outcry followed, and ultimately led to her resignation. Many such incidents of abuse and offense, often with much more serious consequences, seem to appear in the news by the day.

GARN--George, age 84, New York City businessman, USAF pilot. He is survived by his beloved companion Fanny, sons Andrew and Douglas, grandsons Dylan and Graham, daughter-in-law Randi, and his first wife Meriwether. He lived graciously and peacefully and will be missed greatly.

LOCHART--Paul Matthews, architect and veteran of two foreign wars, died in his home in New York City on November 4, 2010, at the age of 85. The cause of death was pneumonia. Paul was a first lieutenant in the US Infantry in Germany and in Korea. He graduated from Yale School of Architecture in 1950. He worked as an architect for Chase Manhattan Bank before going into private practice in 1967. He is survived by his wife, Jacqueline; his sons, Andrew and James; his sister, Catherine Shipman; and two granddaughters.

HEARN--Cecelia Anne, nee Philbin of Point Lookout, New York on November 6, 2010. She is survived by her husband of 58 years, George H. Hearn and her children Annemarie J. Cook (Lynndey) of Nesconset, NY; Margaret M. Fischer (Steve); of Wellesley, MA; and George H. Hearn Jr. (Meg Medina) of Newport Beach, CA. She is also survived by six loving grandchildren, Allyson, Sarahbeth, Christian and Demmianne Cook; Katie and Michael Fischer. Beloved sister of Mary Nugent and the late Doris Thompson and Patricia Thursland of Long Beach, NY. Anne was a graduate of Long Beach High School and a Lady of the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem. Formerly a resident of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, NY; Washington, DC and Garden City, NY. Anne traveled extensively with her husband during his professional and public life. She had been a resident of Our Lady of Consolation nursing home for several years. A memorial Mass for family and friends will be held on Saturday, November 13th, 11:30 at Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal Church, Point Lookout, NY. Memorial donations can be made to Our Lady of Consolation 111 Beach Drive, West Islip, NY 11795.
HEYMAN--Samuel J. November 7, 2009. Dad, Mom and we miss you, we love you and think about you every day. Larry, Ellie, Jenny and Liz

HELLER--Diana Schubart Was a financial industry pioneer, one of the first to make her way in the largely male world of brokerage institutions. Her career as a portfolio manager began in the early 1970s, after a divorce in 1973, and continued into the 1990s. Earlier, she had had a career in modern dance. Her financial career began when she went to work for Kuhn Loeb & Co., after qualifying as a broker. When Kuhn Loeb merged with Lehman Brothers in 1977, she continued as the only female executive with the firm until, in 1981, shortly before the firm sold itself to the newly merged Shearsonmerican Express, she was recruited by Morgan Guaranty Trust Co. as a vice president. There she managed the investments of a number of high-profile accounts, among them Georgia O'Keeffe's, the wife of Mrs. Heller's great-uncle Alfred Sieglitz, the renowned photographer and art pioneer. She retired in 1991. Born in 1920 in New York City to Dorothy Obermeyer Schubart, an artist and interior decorator and close friend of O'Keeffe's, and William Howard Schubart, Diana Heller attended Greenwich Academy (Class of 1938) and Sarah Lawrence (1942) where she studied dance with Martha Graham and Merce Cunningham. After graduating, she served in the WAVES during World War II and then worked as a dance instructor at the Donald Sawyer Dance Studio in New York. She continued her own studies in ballet and tap, appearing in several Broadway shows including "The Merry Widow." "I danced so much," she said, "I'd have to walk down the stairs backward to keep my calf muscles from stiffening." Mrs. Heller's father was a world-renowned financial policy expert, first at the old Bank of Manhattan and, later, as a senior partner at Lazard Freres & Co. He was a participant in the Bretton Woods Conference in 1944. Her only sibling, William Howard Schubart Jr., died in the Pacific Theater just before the end of World War II. She is survived by two sons from her 1956 marriage to Dr. Sidney Heller, Mark Heller, an executive coach and business strategist, and Jeffrey Heller, an executive director at Cushman Wakefield, and his wife Barbra Heller, a nutritionist. She is also survived by a nephew, William Howard Schubart III of Hinesburg, Vermont, and two grand-nephews, Peter Boynton Schubart, also of Vermont and William Howard Schubart IV of New York City.

If you have your low-budget heart set on high-end islands like St. Bart's or St. Martin or Turks and Caicos this winter, with enough research and flexibility you may be able to pull it off. But the real way to keep costs down is to head to the lower-cost islands that actively compete for travelers with light wallets. The first rule is that the lower your budget, the greater the proportion that will be devoted to airfare. That's why the Bahamas is a good place to start looking this winter, when the islands' Ministry of Tourism offers airfare promotions. Under the Free Companion Airfare and Instant Air Credit, travelers who book a four-night stay at certain hotels (some under $150 a night) will get either a companion ticket free or a $300 ''instant air credit.'' Travel must be booked by Dec. 1. Even if you don't stay in a hotel covered by the deal, the Bahamas is one of the cheaper destinations to fly this winter, at least from New York. On the other hand, the relative lack of all-inclusive resorts means that it's trickier to keep costs down for meals and other activities once you're there.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Baseball Rite, Still Bubbly but Less Intoxicating,'' Oct. 31: The Texas Rangers and other sports teams will not be credible in discouraging an association with alcohol consumption in their postgame and other public rituals until they stop accepting ads for beer. Any attempt to avoid portraying sports figures as drinkers of Champagne and other alcohol, particularly for the children's sake, will be ineffective as long as these children are bombarded with beer commercials at every break.

For a studio course at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, industrial and interior design students created this prototype suite from a tired, 1960s space (top right), guided by the sustainability mantra ''reduce, reinvent, reuse.'' Students will try out the living lab next semester; based on their likes, dislikes and energy use, the design will be refined for future dorm renovations.

''My arm -- something is biting my arm!'' The 26-year-old woman struggled to sit up in bed. What's wrong? her husband asked, alarmed and suddenly wide awake. His wife didn't seem to hear him. Suddenly, her whole body began to jerk. Although he had never seen a seizure, the young man knew immediately that this was one. After a long and terrifying minute the jerking stopped and his wife lay quiet with her eyes closed, as if she were asleep. When he couldn't wake her, he picked up the phone and dialed 911. In the emergency room, the young woman was sleepy and confused. She didn't remember the seizure. All she knew was that she felt bad earlier that day. Her shoulders ached and she had these strange shooting pains that ran up her neck, into her skull. She had a wicked headache too. Although she had this headache for months, it was much worse that day. At home she took a long hot bath and went to bed. She woke up in the ambulance.

FUCHS--Patricia, of New York City. Beloved and devoted wife, mother and grandmother, passed away on October 30, 2010. Survived by husband Milton, sons Jeffrey and wife Susan, Spencer and wife Julie, grandchildren Jessica, Brittany, Justin and Arielle.

There was a party of dudes from Montana sitting at a table in Vij's in Vancouver, British Columbia, getting ready to graze. They were businessmen, in the city for a conference, and the hotel had sent them out to South Granville Street to wait for a table, for Vij's takes no reservations and never has. The men sat in the bar and had a few beers, and after a table opened they took it and looked at the menu and ordered, each of them asking for a variation on the same theme: some mutton kebabs to start, the beef tenderloin after; the mutton kebabs to start, the lamb Popsicles after.

Cynics, or perhaps graphic designers, might argue that your average perfume is 99 percent packaging. Maybe more. ''A perfume is an image that you cannot see with your eyes,'' says Mathias Augustyniak, who, as one half of the design firm M/M (Paris), has worked on scent identities for Balenciaga and Narciso Rodriguez. When he and his partner, Michaël Amzalag, approached Ben Gorham of Byredo Parfums with an idea for a fragrance, they were not following their noses. They gave Gorham three inspirations: a block of solid ink they bought in Korea, a photograph of a Japanese friend who is a calligraphy master and an ''oversized absurd formula'' that Augustyniak drew with ink on a piece of handmade Korean paper. ''We spoke about ink with Ben, who is properly inked since he's covered with tattoos, which added a layer of resonance,'' Amzalag says. The result, M/MINK Eau de Parfum, is represented by a sort of smear campaign -- artworks made from existing images, by the photographers Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin, that Amzalag and Augustyniak obscured with slicks of thick black ink. What the fragrance smells like is even more ambiguous. The artist Wolfgang Tillmans, a friend of the designers, described it to them as ''very manly,'' while a female friend declared that it reminded her of her grandmother, a comment that left Amzalag wondering if the friend had a manly grandmother. ''To me it feels like a roller coaster ride,'' he says, ''because it keeps changing once it is on your skin.'' ALIX BROWNE

George A. Hirsch is the founding publisher of New York magazine, the longtime publisher of Runner's World and the chairman of the New York Road Runners. If Fred Lebow, founder of the New York City Marathon, could see the 43,000 runners crowding together on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge on Sunday morning, he would surely allow himself a slight smile. He would not be satisfied, however. He would want to see even more. Lebow was a dreamer and a schemer who combined a deep passion for running with a genius for promotion. Without him, marathoning in New York and around the world would never have reached its current mass appeal.

The artist Tauba Auerbach deals with perception and illusion, finding moments of ambiguity between two dimensions and three. (Think of her trompe l'oeil ''folded'' canvases, at this year's Whitney Biennial.) Which is why, presumably, she fell so hard for pop-up books. ''When a page closes, you see an object kind of smush, and in that moment, it's in a liminal state not unlike the Fold paintings,'' she says. Auerbach began collecting classic pop-ups like ''Alphabeta Concertina'' and ''Andy Warhol's Index (Book)'' last year, and also began the process of making her own. To create ''[2,3]'' -- which is being introduced this weekend by Printed Matter at the NY Art Book Fair -- she spent months teaching herself how to construct complex geometric shapes from strips of paper, then several more creating templates and instructional videos so that the printer could reproduce them. Among the pieces are ''Cubearc'' (above), a delicate Möbius-like curl and ''Ziggurat'': 10 nested tiers that telescope out to 18 inches high. ''I tried things that someone who had experience probably would have shied away from,'' says Auerbach, who insists that her goal ''wasn't to make the most complicated thing possible. It was just to make something beautiful and uncanny happen.'' MONICA KHEMSUROV

Last month, City Room asked readers to reveal any financial decisions of recent years that they would like to undo. Many commenters went beyond those parameters to describe regrets of life, love and career, and we highlighted our favorites in another post. But then that post generated a whole new set of observations, which were featured this past week. Here are some of our favorites:

THE ART OF LIVING Yvonne Force Villareal, a co-founder of Art Production Fund, the nonprofit public art organization, knows firsthand the way art can fill a void. ''I didn't have a TV until third grade,'' she says, ''so I was an obsessive drawer, creating elaborate soap operas about my life, page after page, daily.'' Fast-forward to the loft she shares with her husband, the artist Leo Villareal; their young son, Cuatro; and a fluffy black Pomeranian named Puff Baby. (The couple's second child is due this month.) Their airy West Village space is populated with pieces by artists she ''knows and loves,'' like John Currin, Alex Katz, Lisa Yuskavage, Aaron Young, Nate Lowman, Rachel Feinstein and, of course, Villareal. The art shares billing with bold vintage furnishings. ''I'm a freak for sexy, sleazy, tacky, beautfiul design from the '70s,'' she says. She attributes her love of big sectionals by Pierre Cardin, blocky tables by Paul Evans and massive John Chamberlain parachute couches to her eccentric upbringing. ''I lived in a 24-foot trailer with a few flimsy built-ins, and then moved to a huge Victorian house where my mom had all uncomfortable antiques, and no couch.''
DANTO--Jules. Deepest condolences to the family of our friend and colleague of 15 years. Lovingly remembered by Sylvia, Robin, Howard, Alan, Mike and Lansco staff.
Dance Jack Anderson

When Miki Gorman ran her first marathon in 1973, she was 38 years old. She had taken up running five years earlier believing that it would stoke her appetite and help her gain weight. ''I weighed 87 pounds,'' Gorman said, laughing. ''I was like a stick.''Her simple aim to exercise led to determined training that reached 120 miles a week at its peak. In the mid-1970s, Gorman became the first and only woman to win the New York City and Boston Marathons twice.

WACHSMAN--Florence. 1926-2010. "Flauri" Wachsman was born in New York City on May 8, 1926 and grew up in Williamsburg. She attended PS16, Seward Park High School and New York University for Computer Science. She worked most notably with the Muss Dev. Co. as Executive Secretary until her retirement. Flauri was a warm, loving and beautiful person, respected by all who knew her. She passed away on September 24, 2010, leaving family and friends stunned and grieving for their loss. She brought kindness and friendship to all, and unconditional love to her family. Predeceased by parents Philip and Clara Wachsman, and brothers Abraham, Mack, Joseph and David, she is survived by her brother Arthur Wachsman, sister Lillian Schaffer, numerous nephews, nieces, and devoted friends Dorothy McDonald and Marilyn Wantman. All who knew her will never forget Flauri's presence, beauty and kindness. She will live in the hearts of her family and friends forever.

About a year ago, I submitted a lighthearted complaint to this section about my undying disdain for the stinky ginkgo trees in the Queens neighborhood in which I lived at the time. The editor expressed interest but regretfully told me that there were simply too many complaints to publish. Maybe in the future, I was told. Feh. It was enough just to be recognized, I told myself.

AFTER logging 460 training miles since June, I found myself staring at my computer screen, my thumb on the track pad hovering over the deregistration button for the 2010 New York City Marathon. I was seriously considering dropping out. I had just learned that I had been placed in the last wave of the marathon's 40,000 registered runners, which meant I'd be running on the lower deck of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge (not the upper deck, as I had dreamed of running) and at the very back of the pack (less of a surprise, but still upsetting).

In Switzerland, a sans-serif, politely modern, supersleek, always tidy, adamantly neutral country, where everything uniformly ticktocks, lock-step, you might begin to think each new building and interior were designed by the same architect. Switzerland even has a typeface -- Helvetica -- named after it (the country is also known as Confoederatio Helvetica), in which no letter steps out of line. But an eBay purchase led me to Zurich, where I found the serif, the dingbat and the curvy character, all in one: Arthur Rooks. I bought a primitive spindle-back farm chair for peanuts, which Rooks, the invisible seller at the other end of my eBay transaction, claimed was hand-carved, 150 years old and straight from the ferme in Belfort, France, about an hour and a half across the border from Zurich. I PayPal-ed it, pronto, and Rooks shipped it to me meticulously cushioned and perfectly crated, in a matter of days, as if I'd just bought slippers at Zappos. It was exactly as described, and got me wondering, Who is this guy? With that stout, German-sounding name, I pictured a hardy hiker in lederhosen, surrounded by Alpine shipping-room elves. I discovered that Rooks also runs a home furnishings Web site, quintessentia.com, where you will find a treasure trove of seriously good stuff. He sells Bauhaus, Arts & Crafts, early Swiss Modernist and much better midcentury modern than you can find in New York.

When Prince George received his mother, Queen Mary, for lunch, Constance Spry, who did his flower arrangements, deployed carnations, her bête noir, in conventional containers, which she loathed. But when the queen wasn't around, the ''flowers'' were more likely to be kale and lichen-crusted branches massed in serving pieces that Spry raided, to the amusement of her royal client, from his Meissen dinner set. No one flinches at similar combinations in unorthodox holders today, but as a practitioner of ''flower decorating,'' a term she insisted on, Spry broke new ground rescuing humble materials that usually went out with the wheelbarrow, including grasses, berries and vegetables. As the garden writer Beverley Nichols noted, Spry was ''the first floral artist who ever walked straight from the herbaceous border to the cabbage patch.'' There hasn't been anything truly new in floristry since Spry died in 1960 at age 73, a point of which readers of a new biography, ''The Surprising Life of Constance Spry'' (Macmillan), by Sue Shephard, are easily persuaded.

HARVARD, founded in 1636, enjoyed a monopoly in the colonies for more than half a century, when it was joined by the College of William & Mary. If there existed a student organization in all that time, it left no fossil evidence. Harry R. Lewis, a former dean of Harvard College who has studied its history, explains: ''The college was run by Puritans and Calvinists. Students had to turn out for chapel at a certain time. They couldn't make noise. The college was not student-friendly.'' (Indeed, its first schoolmaster, Nathaniel Eaton, was forced to step down for starving students and wielding a stick large enough, it was said, to kill a horse.) Early extracurricular activities involved huddling around books and periodicals outside the curriculum -- and out of which, according to archivists and librarians, would come respect for debate, polished argument and the American Revolution. From one end, this concrete and glass house looks as if it had burst through the rocks on which it stands. From the other, it seems to nestle into them, a civilized shelter in a wild setting. Of course, the reality involves inspired design and engineering, but the appearance is magical nonetheless. The house was designed as a weekend getaway for Merrill Wright, a Seattle resident, by Tom Kundig, of the local firm Olson Kundig Architects, who is known for houses that are both elegantly rugged and eminently livable. It occupies a 15-acre site in the San Juan Islands off Washington State. A compact, 2,200-square-foot box with a sod roof and tall steel-framed windows, the house consists of a main space, 61 feet long and 12 feet high, with a large kitchen at the back and a living and dining area overlooking the water up front. There's also a master bedroom and sitting room as well as a small guest room on the main floor, and another guest room tucked beneath the house. What looks like a wood-sided boxcar pierces the house at the kitchen end; it contains a utility shed outdoors and a pantry-laundry room and bookcases indoors. (Chris Gerrick was the project manager, and Charlie Fairchild worked with Wright on the interiors.)
1. The day before the day after tomorrow will be Saturday. The day after the day before yesterday was Thursday. What day is today?

Randall Wallace knows a thing or two about show business. He wrote the screenplay for ''Braveheart,'' which won the Academy Award for best picture and earned him a nomination for best original screenplay in 1996. He is also a novelist, songwriter, producer and director, and even has a black belt. What he is not is a horseman, and yet one would never guess that after viewing ''Secretariat,'' which he directed and which has grossed more than $46 million domestically. The realistic race scenes, the showcasing of horses as both tenacious athletes and lovable creatures, and the care given to conveying the intricacies of a cutthroat industry all contribute to the allure of this film.

METSELAAR--Jack, on November 5, 2010. Beloved father of Paul and Fran, beloved father-in-law to Lisa, adored grandfather to Allison and Lindsey Metselaar and Ben Kriegel. He was the sweetest, kindest man, and will always be in our hearts. Funeral Service on November 7th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76th St at 3pm.

AT first listen, ''We R Who We R,'' the current single from the pop singer Ke$ha, sounds like just another entry in her glitter-caked catalog of dance hits. Eccentrically spelled song title? Check. Effervescent electro-pop production courtesy of the megaproducer Dr. Luke? Check. Ample use of Auto Tune? Double check. But ''We R Who We R'' has a subtext: It is intended as a response to the recent rash of suicides by gay teenagers and young adults, several of whom were close to Ke$ha's age. (She is 23.) ''It's heartbreaking,'' said the singer, who has sold upward of 29 million tracks worldwide since her first album, ''Animal,'' made its debut at No. 1 in January, with lyrics about brushing her teeth with whiskey. She called her latest single an anthem for those ''who haven't felt accepted because of their sexuality,'' a torch song for ''people being themselves unapologetically.''

Donna Wilson has become the Tim Burton of London's knitting circle. Back when the designer was a student at the Royal College of Art, she began crafting dolls out of old ''jumpers,'' the British word for sweaters. The leggy dolls without noses or mouths were picked up by Couverture, a chic lifestyle shop. Today, Wilson's quirky menagerie includes 30-odd creatures, like the charming hybrid Cyril Squirrel-Fox and Puddle Man (essentially a pool of water with a face), all of which are made from knitted lamb's wool in Wilson's East End workshop, not to mention cushions, throws, ottomans, sofas and rugs. Many of these are commissions from and collaborations with SCP, the British home furnishings manufacturer. The daughter of farmers, Wilson grew up in Banff in Aberdeenshire, Scotland, and recalled an idyllic childhood playing in the fields. ''It was inside me but also encouraged by my grandma,'' Wilson said of her urge to make things. When she taught herself machine knitting, she discovered that she could ''replicate textures found in nature,'' and her memories filtered into her art in the form of natural landscapes and textures like moss, bark and stone. ''It still amazes me that you can create a fabric from a bit of yarn,'' she said.

The illustrations on these pages are taken from the New York Times Best Illustrated Children's Books of 2010. Annually since 1952, the Book Review has asked a panel of judges to select 10 winners from among the several thousand children's books published during the year. The judges this time around were Robert Sabuda, a co-creator of the best-selling ''Encyclopedia Prehistorica'' series and twice the recipient of a Times Best Illustrated award; Elizabeth Bird, a children's librarian with the New York Public Library, whose first picture book, ''Giant Dance Party,'' is due out next year; and David Barringer, a novelist and designer who is the author of ''There's Nothing Funny About Design.'' 1. HERE COMES THE GARBAGE BARGE! By Jonah Winter. Illustrated by Red Nose Studio. Schwartz & Wade Books.

Gretel: Abby Kellett's charming online shop draws customers from all over the country with its fresh, unpretentious mix of home accessories and lighting. The Miami-based Web retailer is drawn to objects that aren't fussy or overworked. ''I especially like objects that are nostalgic, handmade or show the influence of another culture,'' she says. Go to gretelhome.com. SANDRA BALLENTINE

Assume Vivid Astro Focus, the art collective spearheaded by the Brazilian-born, New York-based Eli Sudbrack and the Paris-based Christophe Hamaide Pierson, has gained notoriety for its happenings, videos and gallery-covering wall art created in a palette that ranges from psychedelic to incandescent. In keeping with their maximalist philosophy, the artists test our capacity for visual overload with ''AVAF,'' a new book from Rizzoli International that comes with a mask and poster no less, along with several thousand photographs, sketches and notes documenting artworks performed and installed at the Whitney and Athens biennials, Los Angeles MoCA, and Deitch Projects gallery. The Moment spoke with Sudbrack about the duo's strobe-lit visions of utopia. Q.It's often hard to translate 3-D and video art into print. How did you deal with that complication?A.We provided the designers, Kleber Mattheus and Roberta Cardoso, with all our imagery - from wallpaper files and sketches to pictures documenting our installations, performances and openings - and we gave the designers a lot of freedom. Many pages in the book are a remix of existing works, and therefore, new. I would rather say that the book itself is a new work.

SCOTT--Donald Houston, of Glen Cove, New York, passed away peacefully on November 4, 2010, surrounded by Barbara, his wife of forty-four years, and his son Donald Ryan. He is survived by sister, Charlotte (Rhett) Sutherland; sisters-in-law Deborah Spinetta and Alice (Nicholas) Salerno, mother and father-in-law Yolanda and Anthony Spinetta, and two nieces and three nephews. Donald was born and raised in Southern Virginia on a farm during World War II. He attended Emory and Henry College, University of Virginia, and the University of Tennessee earning a Master's of Science and completed advanced post-graduate work in microbiology. His first job was in Edgewood Arsenal, Maryland for the defense department in the Biological Warfare Research Laboratory where he worked on researching germs during the Cold War. After his department was closed down, he began teaching and coaching track at the high school level in Fredericksburg, VA where he won his first State Championship in outdoor track. Don moved to Manhasset, NY after marrying Barbara in 1968 where he carried on his teaching and coaching at Manhasset High School for 44 years. At Manhasset High School, he introduced the first advanced science class in conjunction with Syracuse University and is one of the most winningest coaches of the combined running sports. Don was a devoted family man, he had a tremendous passion for his work, and a great love for helping others. Visiting hours: Monday from 2-9 at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home in Manhasset, NY. Mass will be held on Tuesday at 10am at St. Mary's RC Church in Manhasset, NY. Interment will follow at the Locust Valley Cemetery. Donations in lieu of flowers, may be made to the Don Scott Memorial Fund at PO Box #

At the London Design Festival in September, I came upon so many homespun, handmade objects and installations that within hours I was feeling guilty for not having made my own shoes. The prevailing aesthetic wasn't crafty, exactly -- and it certainly wasn't decorative -- but it was definitely hand-hewn, mostly in wood, with a less-is-more, whittled-down vibe (and I use the word ''whittled'' advisedly). You could see it in the tall, spindle-back settle and three-legged stools in the Seating for Eating collection, designed by Ilse Crawford's office, Studioilse, and made by De La Espada. These pieces capture the cozy, retro-rural look that Crawford has used in interiors projects like the Olde Bell Inn and the Crown Inn, which she designed with 6a Architects. Going with the grain Studioilse's Seating for Eating furniture.; 1. Alex Hellum's Ulrik stool for SCP. 2. Great Camp Dresser by Paul Loebach for MatterMade. 3. Day Bed One from Another Country. 4. Spade Chair from Assemblage 1 by Studio Toogood. In a similar vein, the handmade products of Another Country, a British company headed by Paul de Zwart (the founding publisher of Wallpaper magazine), embody what it calls ''the spirit and functionality'' of country, Shaker, Scandinavian and Japanese archetypes. In fact, the pieces' simplicity and solidity won Another Country a spot in the shops run by Monocle magazine, the arbiter of ascetic cool.

So far Toyota has retrofitted almost 2.2 million of its older vehicles with its Smart Stop system, designed under some circumstances to override the gas pedal and cut power to the engine. The automaker announced the system as part of its effort to deal with unintended acceleration concerns. Toyota says if the gas pedal is depressed first and then the brake pedal is being pushed ''firmly for longer than one-half second at speeds greater than five miles per hour'' the system tells the engine to cut power and idle.
Classical Allan Kozinn

What a week in fashion it was, and I'm not even talking about the long drum roll up to the Lanvin sale at H & M. Rather, I refer to the exuberant displays of hair and fashion we saw in politics and baseball. First, there was Tim Lincecum on the mound for the San Francisco Giants in the World Series: the shoulder-length hair, the stringy body of a power pitcher. His style immediately interested me, and I'm not a baseball fan, not at all. I'm more likely to cringe when I see Troy Polamalu of the Pittsburgh Steelers, with his curly Samson locks flying over his pads. Doesn't it get tangled in someone's teeth? I'm more apt to watch football than baseball - for the dreads and resplendent tattoos on tree-trunk size arms. But unaffected Lincecum beats any male model, and I hope he's never tempted to act like one if GQ calls. Then there is Brian Wilson, the San Francisco closer - or rather, the Beard of Brian Wilson. I know sports writers and bloggers comment a lot on his dense black face rug. A columnist recently asked him if he enhanced it with dye.

HERR--H. Buff, born May 4, 1947, died November 2, 2010. Consummate New Yorker, photographer extraordinaire, computer guru. A lover of fine food, fine wine, and fine women. A man's man, an urban cowboy, erudite, well read and intellectually curious. He leaves behind an adoring wife and daughter, Maki B. Podell and Emma Storm. Sister Elisa, brother Laurin, mother Chloris, and friends in most time zones. Complex and flawed, he will always be with us.

The ''Living In'' article on Oct. 24, about Pound Ridge, N.Y., misidentified the municipality in which Fox Lane High School is located. It is in Bedford, not Mount Kisco.

MY midlife obsession with Stephen Sondheim began on a Friday night in April 14 years ago, when my daughter Kate persuaded me to take her to her school's spring musical. She was 12, a seventh grader dreaming of the day when she would be cast in one of the school's productions. I was 44, a lifelong jazz snob, who viewed the prospect of watching teenagers perform a musical with dread. We were going to see something called ''Sweeney Todd.'' I'd never heard of it. Music and lyrics by Mr. Sondheim. I had no clue. I can't recall the exact moment, but at some point during the first act I turned to my daughter with an astonished grin. The melodies were so rich, the harmonies so gorgeous, the lyrics so inventive and lush. I had never heard anything like it in my life. (And this was a high school production!)
Dark Side of the Moon coffee table by Piero Lissoni for Glas Italia, $7,290. At DDC Domus Design Collection. Go to ddcnyc.com.

There's something for everyone at F.D, the philanthropist and collector Fiona Druckenmiller's new Midtown boutique. That is, if the everyone in question is seeking exquisite new and vintage jewels (the shop boasts an impressive cache of period Cartier and Van Cleef & Arpels), watches, sculptures, Art Deco furniture, photography, first-edition manuscripts and swanky barware. The interior, designed in collaboration with the decor firm Pamela Banker Associates, is best described as cozy chic. ''We wanted it to be homey and welcoming, not intimidating,'' Druckenmiller says. ''People will hopefully feel comfortable enough to linger, have a coffee or glass of wine, and spend time learning about the objects that interest them.'' 21 East 65th Street; (212) 772-2440; fionasescape.com.

I grew up without a fireplace because my neurotic (but fabulous) parents were afraid of fire. So I've always been obsessed with them. In the house we built on Shelter Island, I put a bright orange vintage Preway in the bedroom. I had to search far and wide, and finally found the right one on Craigslist. The Preway is no longer in production, but you can still get free-standing fireplaces from Malm, a company out in Santa Rosa, Calif., that has been making them with great proportions and clean lines since the 1960s. (The one above is available from Design Within Reach.) When I am making a piece of pottery, I know that it's finished -- and that it's good -- if it looks like it's supposed to be that way, like it's been uncovered rather than created. To me, that's a Malm fireplace. And I like that it's democratic, not precious. At its height of popularity, you were as likely to see one in a mobile home as you were in a groovy modernist manse. Those who dismiss these beauties as a bit of '70s nostalgia need to look again. I'm never happier than when I lie in bed and stare at my Preway, a glowing beacon of orange optimism in the corner of the room.

Joseph G. Gavin Jr., who rode herd over the immensely complex design, construction and testing of the first manned vehicle to land on the moon -- a task that included anticipating 400 different landing surfaces, from ice to boulders to dust to potholes -- died on Saturday in Amherst, Mass. He was 90. The cause was acute leukemia and pneumonia, his family said.

ACKERMAN--Dr. Jerome (Jerry) Bernard, 87, practiced pediatric dentistry in Mid-town Manhattan for nearly 40 years. Featured in a book about a child's first dental visit. "I have twenty teeth. Do you?" Music major at CCNY, songwriter/musician: Went to NYU dental school to follow in his father's footsteps. Creative thinker. Held two patents. Real estate developer in Antigua in the 1960s-1970s where he also practiced dentistry. Loved to collect art and antiques, sail, windsurf, and ski well into his 70s. Survived by his wife Dena, sister June, four sons Andrew, Thomas, Mitchell, and James, ten grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

Chiefs (5-2) at Raiders (4-4)Sunday, 4:15 p.m.Line: Raiders by 2 1/2The last time the weekly previews led off with a Chiefs-Raiders capsule, Len Dawson squared off against Daryle Lamonica, and Red Smith's analysis was peppered with ''Laugh-In'' references. That's a slight exaggeration, but Oakland and Kansas City are rarely competitive at the same time. The last time both teams finished with a winning record was 1993, when Jeff Hostetler and Joe Montana were the quarterbacks. Thanks to soft schedules, the Chargers' pratfall and (yes) good play, the Chiefs and the Raiders are first and second in the A.F.C. West, giving this game honest-to-Al-Davis playoff implications.

If you're going to build your dream house in a city that revolves around cars, why not plant it right on the side of a freeway? Ronnie Self, an architect, has done just that on a plot of land in a gritty but art-filled neighborhood with unobstructed views of the downtown skyline in Houston. Self, who teaches architecture at the University of Houston, lived for more than a dozen years in Paris, where he worked for Renzo Piano on projects like the Beyeler Foundation near Basel, Switzerland, and the Brancusi Workshop at the Centre Pompidou. When he returned to his native Texas and looked for a place to build a house (which he now shares with Bernard Bonnet, the book buyer for the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston), he found the Third Ward. A central neighborhood, it was filled with ramshackle shotgun houses, wood-frame bungalows and abandoned lots; the lot he bought was marked by a sign, written on a piece of plywood and nailed onto a tree.

How bad was it for Democrats last week? By nearly every demographic measure, the party lost ground, significantly in some cases. The result was the largest reshuffling of the House of Representatives in 50 years.

BUSSEL--Lili, M.D. The child analysts at the New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute mourn the loss of Dr. Lili Bussel. Dr. Bussel played a central role in educating every child analyst at our Institute for decades through her teaching, supervision, and mentoring of students and colleagues. Dr. Bussel was reknowned and beloved for her uncanny grasp of the unconscious, her reliable wisdom, and her passionate devotion to her patients, her students, and her friends. We will cherish her bravery and integrity, her mischievous humor, and her heartfelt generosity. We will strive to keep her spirit alive through our best efforts on behalf of our patients, our students, and our colleagues. Her influence will be felt by countless patients and young analysts who will never have met her directly. We extend our deepest condolence to the Bussel and Cunningham-Rundles families. Steven J. Wein, M.D., Associate Dean for Child Analysis

Jim Squires is the breeder of the 2001 Kentucky Derby winner, Monarchos, and the author of ''Horse of a Different Color'' and ''Headless Horsemen.'' Having somehow -- miraculously, I suspect -- made a living for two decades breeding thoroughbred horses, no horse racing event has been more important to me than the Breeders' Cup, which along with the Kentucky Derby each year constitutes the sport's lone escape route from obscurity.

FLOHR--Claire, 92, died on November 4, 2010, at her Manhattan home. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel on November 9, at 11:15am. She was born on July 29, 1918, in Manhattan where she was a lifelong resident. Her passion for people and love of learning found its way to Fordham University's Lincoln Center Campus, where she worked as an administrative assistant for numerous years and was treasured by many. An elegant, charming and witty lady, she loved to tell a good joke, hear a not too bawdy joke, and be in the company of her family and friends. Her empathy for those in need, whether human or feline, were as much a part of her persona as her hearty laugh, warm smile, and generous heart. What she received in life paled in comparison to what she gave. Her daughter, Karen and son-in-law, Frank, her grandson Erik and his wife, Jennifer survive her. Condolences may be sent to Karen Niles, at 2205 Curtis Ave. #

Throughout his recent run for Senate, the Florida Republican Marco Rubio made a big deal of the sacrifices his Cuban immigrant family made ''so that I could live the American dream.'' By campaign's end, he was using the phrase so regularly that spokesmen for his Democratic opponent, Congressman Kendrick B. Meek, were reminding reporters that Rubio did not have a patent on it. The American dream mattered a lot in this election. Americans for Prosperity, a conservative activist group, laid out plans for repealing President Obama's health care reform and fighting environmental regulation at its Defending the American Dream Summit two months ago. The president, meanwhile, closed this fall's campaign with an exhortation to ''restore the American dream for not just some, but for every, every, everybody in this great land.'' If both sides agree that the dream is imperiled, and that recovering it is a top national priority, then it may be this ''dream''of ours is not a unifying idea but a vague slogan, no more to be trusted than any other piece of campaign rhetoric. When the popular historian James Truslow Adams coined the phrase ''the American dream'' in ''The Epic of America'' (1931), it was as a kind of lazy-minded leitmotif. Sometimes it meant the frontier spirit, sometimes Jeffersonian democracy and sometimes just the hope that Americans could ''grow to fullest development as men and women, unhampered by the barriers which had slowly been erected in older civilizations.'' As a chronicler of common people, Adams had a peculiarity: he was a snob. He was dazzled by the material and cultural riches of aristocratic societies and bemoaned their lack in America. The American dream, he implied, is what we got as a consolation prize. It could find its expression in plebeian anti-intellectualism and an unjustified sense of entitlement. It was never, Adams admitted, ''a logical concept of thought.''

HOCHHAUSER--Aidalina Campillo, died November 4th at age 92. Predeceased by beloved husband Herbert, she was the proud mother of Michele (Ricardo) Bertran Esq., and David (Janet) Hochhauser, MD and the even prouder "Mama" to grandchildren Nicole Aida and Danielle Bertran, and Elizabeth, Rachel, Vanessa, Michael, Kimberly, Madeleine and Kevin Hochhauser. During WWII she served in the Navy and the Red Cross. She and Herbert were graduates of NYU and the Columbia University School of Social Work. Aida was a New York City Board of Education Social Worker, Puerto Rican patriot, world traveler, theatre lover and avid biography reader. She charmed everyone with her unique humor, "pizazz," knowledge of people and view of life. Aida is also survived by siblings Filiberto and Pura Campillo. Mama: "unforgettable is what you are."

WINTER--Eleanor. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of Eleanor Winter. Earlier in 1860, when Abraham Lincoln, the Illinois lawyer, looked at the electoral map, he made a stunning discovery: if he could win 16of the 17 northern states plus the west-ern states of California and Oregon, he'd have enough votes in the Electoral College to win the presidency. Forget the tempestuous South; even if every southern state fell into line be-hind one of his rivals -- Senator Stephen Douglas of Illinois, Senator John Bell of Tennessee, Vice President John Breckenridge of Kentucky, the squab-bling standard bearers of the factions of the suicidally splintered Democratic party -- Lincoln could win with just the votes of the increasingly populated, firmly Free State North. And after the results from the state elections in October 1860 -- Pennsylvania had been suspect and Indiana iffy, but both tilted decisively toward the Republicans -- the erstwhile rail-splitter looked like he just might convert his audacious gamble.-- JAMIE MALANOWSKI, excerpt from'' Will Lincoln Prevail?'' For more, nytimes.com/opinionator

While I agree wholeheartedly with Virginia Heffernan's assessment in The Medium that the partying, out-of-control woman is a particular object of fear and revulsion, I find it unfortunate that she used my comments as grist for her argument. My comments are not reserved exclusively for celebrities -- or for women. Let me be clear that I would have offered that same comment had the subject in question been a man. Furthermore, the use of my comments to support Heffernan's thesis that we ''demonize fun-loving women'' requires a complete disregard for the context in which they originally were made. I was responding to a question about what lengths I would go to, as a father, should one of my children (I have 17-year-old triplets) develop a life-threatening addiction, all other measures having been exhausted. As a clinician, I would never want to be coercive in relation to a patient, nor do I harbor the illusion that as a physician I am capable of forcing someone to change their behavior, no matter how detrimental to their health. Finally, I am not ''scheming to frame . . . party girls,'' hoping that they ''end up behind bars.'' An individual in police custody, however, is unable to do any further harm to himself or others, and I have seen firsthand how a forced choice between remaining in jail or entering a treatment program offers a lifesaving first step for those in the throes of addiction.

In 1924, the French designer Jean-Michel Frank collaborated with Hermès on a collection of furniture, including the Confortable armchair (below) and sofa, the elegant, cubic forms of which made it one of the most admired -- and widely copied -- designs of the 20th century. This month in Paris, for the inauguration of its new home division, Maison, Hermès is reintroducing these and other Frank pieces, including a straw-marquetry screen, a shagreen-covered vanity and the designer's X-base dining table. Robert Chavez, the president and C.E.O. of Hermès USA, sees ''a very exciting potential in the U.S.'' for the Jean-Michel Frank by Hermès collection, given the customer demand for furniture with the Hermès label. Previously, the company's furniture was limited to Pippa, a small collection by the architect Rena Dumas, who designed Hermès stores and who was married to Jean-Louis Dumas, the chairman of Hermès from 1978 to 2006. (Rena died in 2009, and Jean-Louis in May.) Their son, Pierre-Alexis Dumas, the company's artistic director and a sixth-generation member of the founding Hermès family, said starting Maison with historic designs was a deliberate strategy: ''We had to go backward to understand our roots and to go forward into the future.'' And in that future -- April 2011, to be exact -- the company will unveil further Maison collections, this time by a roster of (yet to be revealed) contemporary designers. PILAR VILADAS

KRASNOW--Mildred, (Millie/Bubbie), born April 15, 1915 in Yonkers, NY. She died at the age of 95 on the morning of November 5, 2010 at her home in Riverdale, NY. Loving wife of the late Dr. George Krasnow and devoted mother to their late son musician/composer John Lee Krasnow. Millie was a generous and prolific force in New Jersey government for over 20 years. Her professional achievements include being appointed as the first Executive Director of the Bergen County Office on Aging, a position she held with distinction for 19 years. Millie was also the President of the New Jersey Executive Directors Association on Aging, the President of the Gerontological Society of New Jersey and The President of the New Jersey Association of Office on Aging Executive Directors and Administrators. In addition Millie served on the Federal Board and the Region II Federal Council Committee on Aging Task Force, The National Gerontological Society, The National Council for the Aging, The American Aging Association and was on the Board of Directors of the New York Citizens Committees on Aging. Millie's dynamic political career included being an outspoken Democratic Delegate in 1964 at The Democratic National Convention; she was the President of the Democratic Women of Bergen County and the Vice Chairman of the Democratic County Committee. Millie also ran for political office in 1955 in her hometown of Closter, NJ. Millie received many citations and awards throughout her career including Women of Achievement in 1968 from the Women's Club of Bergen County, Outstanding Public Service in 1973 from the Social Security Administration of the US Department of Health, Outstanding Leadership 1974 from the National Council of Negro Women and was featured in the publication "Who's Who in American Politics." Millie is survived by her longtime companion Dr. Charles Francomano, her daughter-in-law Sharon Krasnow, her granddaughters Highlyann and Tamar Krasnow and her great-granddaughters Nyeah and Jaelee Krasnow-Osorio. Bubbie will leave a profound, permanent and positive mark in our hearts. She is deeply loved and missed. A service in her memory will be held Monday, November 8th at 1pm at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 353 2nd Ave., NYC, (between 20th and 21st St.)

As a set designer, Gary Card is used to pouring his creativity into a wildly elaborate mise-en-scène, only to see the whole thing dismantled or destroyed once the project is finished. So when the creative director John Skelton and his partner, Dan Mitchell, approached him to design the interiors of LN-CC, a new concept store (think meticulously curated avant-garde fashion, rare books and vintage vinyl) in the scrappy east London neighborhood of Dalston, Card jumped at the chance to create something permanent. He used his surrealist sensibility to transform the space, a former boxing gym, into a hipster fun house. To enter the store, visitors navigate Card's ''deconstructed forest,'' only to find themselves in the belly of a beast -- a wooden tunnel that resembles a crudely assembled whale skeleton. The rest of the 6,000-square foot-space is divided into individual rooms, like a gallery hung with mannequins (left) and a library lined with asymmetrical shelving. ''Every room needed a distinct atmosphere, tone and temperature,'' Card says. ''The idea was to move from organic to industrial, from warm to cold. And always keep it open to change.'' The main attraction is the private club space, with its sound system by the legendary sound guru Mickey Boyle. For Card's sake, we hope the parties don't get too out of hand. ANA FINEL HONIGMAN

What started as a discussion of women's lack of parity in the workplace devolved into a discussion about parental roles and responsibilities in and outside the home. When will women's lack of equality in the workplace be viewed as a valuable issue in its own right, rather than having to be related to motherhood? Parity has not been reached by childless women either, and we face the additional discrimination that workers without families face: the expectation that we cover for colleagues who are caring for sick children, work late because we don't have to pick up kids and support financing for on-site child care. Maybe once we've made more progress for working mothers, we can focus on treating all workers equally, whether they choose to procreate or not. ALISON GROSSBLATT-WAIT Portland, Ore.

The exuberance of autumn in New York was everywhere last week. The chilly weather moved everyone into fall dressing, and the style of the decade was at its peak, the mixing of separate pieces to form a total look that has everything to do with how it is worn. Predominating were shades of gray, beige and Army olive with a dash of plaid shirt. Flaming colors were mostly left to the trees, at their zenith in the parks. Chrysanthemums filled urns all over the city.

For the last three decades, the Italian home products manufacturer Alessi has been at the forefront of design, producing instant icons like Michael Graves's bird-whistle teakettle (left), Philippe Starck's infamous Juicy Salif juicer and Richard Sapper's elegant espresso pot -- a fixture on many a yuppie's high-end cooktop. The Philadelphia Museum of Art is celebrating the 90-year-old company with an exhibition, ''Alessi: Ethical and Radical,'' which opens Nov. 21. Central to Alessi's success is its creative mastermind, Alberto Alessi, a grandson of the founder, who has run the company since the 1970s. ''He's absolutely unique in the amount of time and money that he has spent on design,'' said Kathryn Hiesinger, the exhibition's curator. Included in the show are planned reissues of designs from the 1920s, '30s and '40s, a time that Alberto Alessi describes as ''predesign,'' before the rise of glossy ''designer'' products -- which is ironic coming from the man who helped invent the category. But, as Heisinger explained, ''Alberto is now in his minimalist, simplicity mode; he's against overdesign.'' Well, he's been right before. ARLENE HIRST
1. Friday 2.

THE NEWS The Federal Reserve said it would buy $600 billion worth of Treasury bonds over eight months in hopes of pushing down long-term interest rates and speeding up an economic recovery it called ''disappointingly slow.'' BEHIND THE NEWS With no room left to use its usual stimulus tool -- cuts in short-term rates, which are already near zero -- the Fed has been trying to pump some life into the economy through ''quantitative easing'' measures, like buying debt. Some critics saw risks that the Fed's debt buying would set the stage for high inflation once the economy revives; others said the new measures did not go far enough to make much difference.

The Department of Education has just published new rules to protect students from aggressive or misleading recruiting at for-profit institutions, and to provide consumers with information about program effectiveness. Next year, the department will put forth the most controversial aspect of its ''gainful employment'' rule: enforcement. It proposes curtailing federal aid to vocational programs whose former students have a loan repayment rate of less than 35 percent or a high debt-to-income ratio.James Kvaal, deputy undersecretary of education, says loan repayment rates give a better picture of hardship than the traditional default rate. In that rate, borrowers who don't have to make a payment -- say, because of forbearance, economic-hardship deferment or an income-based repayment plan -- ''are counted as successes,'' he says, ''despite being economically unable to afford their loan.'' During hearings on the new rules, the government released exhaustive repayment data for the first time. Though the statistics are on an institutional level (rules apply to programs), they shed light on the burden of debt across the board. Below is the data (2007-8 unless indicated) on the nation's largest four-year institutions, including those owned by publicly traded companies, as compiled by BMO Capital Markets.

KENNEDY--John R.,retired president and chief executive officer of Federal Paper Board Company and former chairman of the board of directors of Georgetown University, died November 3, 2010 at his home in Vero Beach, Florida. He was 80 years old. The cause of death was leukemia. Kennedy was a prominent paper company executive who built Federal Paper Board Company of Montvale, New Jersey, into one of the nation's largest producers of paperboard. He joined Federal in 1952 after graduating from Georgetown University and spent his entire career with the company, serving as CEO from 1975 to 1996. He modernized and grew the company by making major investments in large paperboard and pulp mills in the South. Under his leadership, Federal's revenues increased from $175 million in 1974 to $1.9 billion in 1995, while earnings rose more than tenfold from $12 million to $142 million during the same period. In 1996, Kennedy negotiated the sale of the company to International Paper Company for $3.7 billion, providing a sizable return for Federal's shareholders. He was elected to the International Paper board of directors and continued to serve until he reached mandatory retirement age in 2002. He was also active in many educational and civic causes. He served on the board of directors of Georgetown University, Washington, D.C., from 1981 to 1987 and from 1993 to 2002. He was elected acting chair of the board in 1995 and served as chair from 1996 to 2002. He was a major financial contributor to the university. Kennedy Hall, which provides housing for Georgetown students, is named for him and his wife, Elizabeth. In addition, he was a former director of the Foreign Policy Association, the American Forest & Paper Association and the Duke University School of Forestry and Environmental Studies, and a former member of the board of governors of the United Nations Association of the United States of America. He was heavily involved with Pathfinder Village and a founder of the Kennedy-Willis Center on Down Syndrome. In 1997, he co-founded the nonprofit East Hampton Healthcare Foundation to provide medical care for the people of East Hampton, New York, where he had a summer home. The foundation operates a health care center and urgent-care walk-in facility. He was former vice chairman of the Indian River Medical Center Foundation, which raises funds for the Indian River Medical Center in Vero Beach, Florida, and was special adviser to the board at his death. He was a board member to the Riverside Theatre in Vero Beach, the Humane Society of Vero Beach and Vero Beach Museum of Art. Besides serving as a director of International Paper, the world's largest paper company, his corporate board memberships during his career included Chase Industries, Inc., Devlieg-Bullard Inc., First Fidelity Bancorporation, Holnam Inc., Idea Integration Corp., Magma Copper Company, MPS Group Inc., Pioneer Companies, Inc., American Mutual Insurance and Spartech Corporation. John R. "Jack" Kennedy was born in Queens, New York, on September 21, 1930. His parents, John R. Kennedy Sr. and Ethel Rose Leavy Kennedy, were both children of Irish Immigrants. Kennedy's marriage to his first wife, Joyce Willis, ended in divorce. In 1974, he married Elizabeth Spyros. Besides his wife, he is survived by three sons from his first marriage, John R. Kennedy III, Ponte Vedra, FL, James W. Kennedy, Amagansett, NY and Andrew Kennedy, Edmeston, NY; a daughter from his first marriage, Paula Kennedy Harrigan, New Canaan, CT; a stepson, Nicholas L. Spyros, Haymarket, VA; his sister, Ethel Kennedy Marran, Vero Beach, FL; his brother, Quentin Kennedy, Tenafly, NJ; and nine grandchildren. A viewing will be held on Sunday, November 7, 2010 from 47pm at Strunk Funeral Home, 916 17th Street, Vero Beach. A Mass of Christian Burial will take place on Monday, November 8 at 10:30am at Holy Cross Catholic Church, Iris Lane and A1A, Vero Beach. Burial will be private at John's Island Cemetery, Indian River Shores, Florida. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center to support the leukemia research efforts of Dr. Mark Frattini. Donations can be sent to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Attention: Dr. Mark Frattini, 1275 York Avenue, Box 432, New York, New York 10065.

McLEAN--Edward C. (Ted), of Chappaqua, NY, and Sanibel, FL, died November 3 of respiratory failure. He was born June 23, 1935, the son of the Honorable Edward C. McLean and Louise Hunter McLean. He was a member of the Town of New Castle Planning Board, and of the Conservation Advisory Council and Conservation Board. He was a passionate genealogist and shell collector, but his family was his greatest passion. He is survived by his wife of 49 years, Jennifer Prescott McLean, daughters Alison of Vienna, VA, Elizabeth of Severna Park, MD, a son Thomas (Wendy) of South Salem, NY, a brother Alan of Norwalk, CT, and four grandchildren. Gifts in his memory may be made to the Bailey-Matthews Shell Museum, PO Box 1580, Sanibel, FL 33957.

''Hella Jongerius -- Misfit,'' the title of the Dutch designer's retrospective that opens Nov. 13 at the Museum Boijmans Van Beuningen in Rotterdam, refers not so much to her status in the design world but to the imperfect objects she has long championed. As the exhibition demonstrates, Jongerius has never had trouble finding sympathy for her ideas in the design industry, where companies like Vitra, Ikea and Maharam hired her to introduce beautiful inconsistencies into their sofas, vases and upholstery fabrics. As it turns out, the only people who ever took convincing were the craftspeople themselves. Royal Tichelaar Makkum's artisans cringed when they were told to fire her 1997 B-Set pottery (right) at too high a temperature, while Nymphenburg's worried that her 2004 Sketches plates looked half-finished. ''Craft has a tradition of trying to make perfect things,'' says Louise Schouwenberg, the show's curator. ''Hella told them to stop trying, because industry can do that better, whereas their appeal is more humane.'' Jongerius persisted, and these days, evidence of the hand of the maker seems completely natural. The misfits have become the mainstream. MONICA KHEMSUROV

Styled to a T takes the trends to the streets. Few men can pull off the season's ubiquitous chunky sweaters without looking, well, chunky. One exception was always Miles Davis, the strikingly svelte, knit-happy original. Davis riffed on his signature woolly jumpers with tapered, ankle-skimming trousers - a balance of proportions that was demonstrated in fall shows from Acne to Burberry to Jil Sander.

If you have your low-budget heart set on high-end islands like St. Bart's or St. Martin or Turks and Caicos this winter, with enough research and flexibility you may be able to pull it off. But the real way to keep costs down is to head to the lower-cost islands that actively compete for travelers with light wallets. The first rule is that the lower your budget, the greater the proportion that will be devoted to airfare. That's why the Bahamas is a good place to start looking this winter, when the islands' Ministry of Tourism offers airfare promotions. Under the Free Companion Airfare and Instant Air Credit, travelers who book a four-night stay at certain hotels (some under $150 a night) will get either a companion ticket free or a $300 ''instant air credit.'' Travel must be booked by Dec. 1. Even if you don't stay in a hotel covered by the deal, the Bahamas is one of the cheaper destinations to fly this winter, at least from New York. On the other hand, the relative lack of all-inclusive resorts means that it's trickier to keep costs down for meals and other activities once you're there.

IF people at the Knitting Factory recognized Jake Silbermann's cornflower-blue eyes last month, they were too cool to let on. The word ''Nuke'' was not uttered once.

A Zaha Hadid-designed wine tasting pavilion (above) or stemless Riedel wineglass may seem commonplace now. But they are manifestations of a cultural shift that happened after the so-called Judgment of Paris in 1976, in which a number of California wines were deemed superior to their French counterparts. On Nov. 20, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art will open ''How Wine Became Modern: Design + Wine 1976 to Now.'' Organized by Henry Urbach, the museum's curator of architecture and design, the exhibition -- which is designed by the architects Diller Scofidio + Renfro -- explores the evolution of wine's visual and material culture. It includes a gallery devoted to the subject of terroir, a commissioned wall work by Peter Wegner that charts more than 200 paint colors with names like Cabernet and Crush, and a look at, among other issues, the effect of architecture on wine tourism. The museum knows the subject well, having organized the first architectural competition for the design of a winery, in 1985. The winner was the architect-artist team of Michael Graves and Edward Schmidt, resulting in Clos Pegase, the prototype of the modern designer winery. PILAR VILADAS

An obituary last Sunday about the evolutionary biologist Leigh Van Valen referred incorrectly to a line of cancer cells that he suggested had evolved into an independent species. Dr. Van Valen and a colleague, Virginia C. Maiorana, did indeed propose a name, Helacyton gartleri, for this species; he did not ''hold back from suggesting a name.''

Dozens of gray compartments, lined neatly in rows, inhabit a boxy concrete building on the edge of the impoverished border town of Presidio. The only sound, aside from occasional clanking, is the whirring of air-conditioners to keep the compartments cool. This $25 million contraption is the largest battery system in the United States -- locals have dubbed it Bob, for Big Ole Battery. It began operating earlier this year, and is the latest mark of the state's interest in a nascent but rapidly evolving industry: the storage of electricity.
