When Frederic Malle, the master French perfumer, proclaims that his latest fragrance is one of his best ever, it's nothing to sniff at. He knows from perfume. To celebrate his company's 10-year anniversary, Mr. Malle teamed up with one of his favorite noses - Dominique Ropion- to create Portrait of a Lady, a heady mixture of ingredients such as Turkish rose essence, raspberry, cassis, cinnamon, patchouli heart, ambroxan and musk. The resulting scent- lushly feminine, with a sensually earthy dry-down courtesy of the patchouli- is fragrant proof that this lady has some serious sex appeal. Available next month for $280 (100 ml) at Barneys New York, or join the waiting list at Malle's Editions de Parfum, 898 Madison Avenue; (212) 249-7941. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

MILLER--Lee (Shirley) D. passed away November 2, 2010 after fighting a courageous battle with cancer. Beloved wife of Charles for 22 years, adored mother of Monique Thorngren (Eric), Lisa Rubin (Jeff), devoted grandmother of Ryan Thorngren, Sydney and Sasha Rubin. Lee lived her life to the fullest as a professional dancer, RN, fashion retailer, and real estate agent. She was creative at every turn and generous to all. Born in Connecticut, raised in Mineola, LI, she resided in New York City until moving to Westhampton Beach 15 years ago. Lee was equally balanced by her love and devotion to her friends and family. She is missed terribly already. Family will receive friends Friday, November 5th, 3-5pm with a memorial service 4:30pm at The Follett and Werner Funeral Home, 60 Mill road Westhampton Beach. Shiva will be observed, Saturday November 6, 7-9pm and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9pm at 64 Brittany Lane, Westhampton Beach. Expressions of sympathy may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering c/o Dr. John Fiore and Fight Chance (34 Bay St., Sag Harbor, NY).

Aquarter-century ago, the term ''foodie'' denoted a small set of people who lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, lined up at the Silver Palate on weekends and occasionally roasted a chicken breast in a packet of aluminum foil with something peculiar, like raspberries. Now these people are everywhere in America, and they're cooking anything they can get their hands on, around the clock -- tutti foodie. The farmers' market in New York's Union Square, once a sleepy little happening where restaurateurs foraged for chives to tie the tops of their beggar's purses, is now a quad-weekly mob scene so dense you need a cleaver just to get out of the subway exit, let alone hack through the towering forests of purple cauliflower. Midwestern homemakers devote entire blogs to cupcakes. Your Republican father-in-law can pronounce ''quinoa.''

WILLIAM MIDDLETON For ''Roadside Attraction'' (Page 47), William Middleton dropped in on the architect Ronnie Self, who built his Houston house practically on top of a freeway. Like Self, Middleton lived in Paris (he was the bureau chief for W and Women's Wear Daily) before eventually winding up in Houston. Once there, Middleton resisted buying a car, choosing instead to bike everywhere. ''That worked for about two summers,'' he says, ''which I think is pretty heroic.'' A native of Kansas, Middleton is now at work on a biography of the French art patrons John and Dominique de Menil, whose spirits loom large over Houston. When he's not buried in the archives of the Menil Collection, he enjoys making pilgrimages to the couple's Houston house by Philip Johnson (far right).

LAS VEGAS -- Honda once owned the aftermarket tuner market, but about a decade ago, the Japanese automaker started bringing out more mild-mannered models that intentionally turned away from the high-performance crowd. Now, it appears Honda wants at least part of that market back, and a collection of radically tweaked CR-Z hybrids on display at this year's SEMA Show is meant to do just that. ''Green means go'' is a theme that is prominently espoused at the Honda stand. ''We've reached out to the import tuner community and asked them to push the CR-Z's limits,'' said Chris Martin, a Honda spokesman.

To mark the sesquicentennial year of the Civil War in 1861, The Times has prepared an interactive timeline covering events from Lincoln's election on Nov. 6, 1860, through the imposition of martial law in St. Louis on Dec. 26, 1861. The timeline contains pictures and drawings from the Times archive and the Library of Congress along with links to the original Times articles. There are also links to Topic pages on individual subjects and an overview of the war, with searchable archive articles, resource lists and essays by historians and from authoritative reference sources, along with an extensive recommended-reading list. More material will be added as the commemoration progresses. Visit the timeline »

Elections with results as dramatic as this year's are sometimes referred to as "realigning elections." The term -- although somewhat ambiguous and overused -- usually refers to an election in which one party not only gains a significant amount of power, but coalitions also shift, the signature of which is usually that the rising party performs particularly well in certain geographic regions or among certain demographic groups.

Though AMC ordered just six episodes of "The Walking Dead" for its first season, it seemed a virtual certainty that the show would rise again when its debut episode, broadcast on Halloween, broke a ratings record for that cable channel by drawing 5.3 million viewers, the largest audience it had recorded for an original series. Overview | How can we learn to pay closer attention to detail in writing? How can we put knowledge about grammar and mechanics into practice? In this lesson, students consider errors in signage and other textual displays and create lists of common errors to check as they proofread. They then practice proofreading and develop strategies, taking into consideration the possible consequences of making language mistakes.

Unless you are Stephen Hawking, there is a good chance that Brian Eno is smarter than you. But that's O.K., because rather than using his intellect for nefarious purposes or taunting you with his superior exam grades, Mr. Eno, the musician, producer and multi-hyphenate, channels his powers into artistic pursuits. To promote his new album, "Small Craft on a Milk Sea," he has started a series of videos, titled "Seven Sessions on a Milk Sea," documenting improvised performances at his London studio with the musicians Jon Hopkins and Leo Abrahams. An entry, titled "Signal Success," can be seen above, and subsequent videos will be posted at Mr. Eno's official Web site, brian-eno.net/seven-sessions. Now leave him be so he can play six simultaneous chess games and prove the existence of cold fusion.

Fratelli Rosetti's latest collaboration, with George Esquivel, the recent Council of Fashion Designers of America inductee, has us beaming with patriotism. The "America" satchel - a flexible leather bucket bag in natural leather, sea blue, white and black - promises to be as covetable as the designer's signature handmade shoes. "It's so minimal in design - in terms of shape and structure," Esquivel says. "But the true beauty of the bag is revealed when it is put to work." Indeed, the shoulder strap can be removed transforming the tote into a proper purse; a bag inside the bag can be carried on its own as an evening clutch. The America is available in mid-November, but the collaboration will continue through the fall 2011 season with more carry-alls to come. Now that's our idea of the American dream."America" satchel, $1,200. Available at Fratelli Rossetti flagship locations, call (212) 888-5107.
